webTitle: McGrath wafts woeful West Indies away

fields.headline: McGrath wafts woeful West Indies away
fields.trailText: So much for the glorious unpredictability of Test cricket. The opening day of this series saw West Indies collapse and the worst fears about a grossly uneven series confirmed all within three hours.
fields.body:
So much for the glorious unpredictability of Test cricket. The opening day of this series at the Gabba was, rather, one of inglorious predictability. Steve Waugh won the toss, West Indies collapsed and the worst fears about a grossly uneven series were confirmed within three hours.

Apart from a clinically efficient display of fast bowling that brought Glenn McGrath six for 17 off 20 overs, the Australian attack was respectable but hardly in the form to dismiss a Test team for 82.

Sadly, though the West Indies' total was their lowest in Australia for 49 years, the tourists' collapse was no surprise. These men are repeat offenders. This was their fourth total under 100 this year. They face a very long summer.

In the one grandstand that sweeps around the revamped Gabba, legendary West Indian players, including Sir Garfield Sobers, Wes Hall and Rohan Kanhai, all here to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the famous 1960-61 tied Test, must have squirmed in their seats at this poor display.

By stumps Australia had gained a first-innings lead, finishing at 107 for one, with Michael Slater on 54 and the local boy Matthew Hayden unluckily run out late in the day for 44.

Australia will now bat for a day or two before trying to secure the win that will ensure they equal the world record of 11 consecutive Test victories set by Clive Lloyd's great West Indies team of the mid-1980s.

On a newly relaid pitch of limited preparation but little venom, McGrath merely put the ball in the right place time and again. His fourth wicket took him past Craig McDermott's career tally of 291 and into third place on Australia's list.

Only the twin peaks of Shane Warne (366) and Dennis Lillee (355) loom above and it is surely only a matter of time before McGrath plants his flag on the summit.

McGrath twice missed hat-tricks yesterday and dismissed three batsmen with his first deliveries to them, including Brian Lara. McGrath also greeted the two inexperienced West Indies fast bowlers, Mervyn Dillon and Marlon Black, with rearing throat balls. The message was clear.

Before the series McGrath had said that he was confident of maintaining his dominance over Lara. After the leg-spinner Stuart MacGill took the first wicket to bring Lara to the crease, McGrath asked his captain for a second spell.

Having faced only three balls from MacGill, the West Indies' major hope seemed so keen to defend tightly against a bowler who clearly has him rattled that he went too far outside his off-stump and paid the price, edging to Adam Gilchrist and falling to the paceman for the 11th time in Tests.

The West Indies lost their last seven wickets for 23, with the captain and No5 Jimmy Adams left stranded on 16. His will be the longest summer of all.

webTitle: Pride will force Robbo out come what may

fields.headline: Pride will force Robbo out come what may
fields.trailText: Even if Middlesbrough turn things around, I would not expect to see Bryan Robson at Boro next season. There's only so much a man can take.
fields.body:
Middlesbrough's game at home to Bradford tomorrow looks like real make-or-break stuff for the club and for Bryan Robson. But whatever the outcome I don't expect Robbo to be at the Riverside at the start of next season.

If Boro lose it will be difficult for him to carry on. But even if they win and start to turn things round - which I hope and expect they will - I've got a feeling Bryan might say enough is enough in May.

It might be time for him to move on after seven seasons, and I don't think he'll forget the way the crowd turned on him during last weekend's home defeat by Leicester. Robbo is no quitter but that will rankle with him because he's got great pride - in fact I'm sure he'd love to turn it round himself and be able to walk away with his head high.

The abuse he took the one time he stepped out of the dugout into his technical area was disgraceful. We tend to knock our legends and whatever you say about Bryan Robson he is a football legend. He should not be treated like that.

If he does walk there will be no shortage of takers and I'm sure he'll want to carry on at another club. I was very surprised he went into management because I always thought he would do something in the horse-racing world, where he's got big interests. But now he's taken the plunge I think it's in his blood.

Robbo doesn't show his emotions but he'll be hurting badly at the situation his team are in. Not even the most ardent Boro supporter will be feeling it as much as he is. I know from managing him at West Brom and Manchester United that even in five-a-sides his desire to win was phenomenal.

Too many of his players have underperformed and tomorrow they have to start bursting blood vessels, being brave and earning their big money. Bryan, though, would be the first to accept a large chunk of responsibility. I admire the way he has taken the flak and not tried to deflect it on to his squad.

Of course he's made mistakes. You would have to question some of his signings, like Paul Gascoigne and Christian Karembeu, although I fail to understand why everyone keeps coming out with this huge sum of money he's spent and ignoring the money he's brought in.

I also think he would have benefited from finding a new coach to change the picture a bit, give a fresh voice and deflect some of the attention, just as Jim Smith has done with Colin Todd at Derby. But in many ways Robbo's made his own job difficult by giving the club a new expectancy.

I would remind people at Middlesbrough that they have been to three cup finals since 1997 under Bryan. The only time most of their fans ever saw Wembley before then was on the television or if they went to a Status Quo concert. But people have short memories, and that will be just as obvious if Boro get a few decent results on the bounce. If I was in Bryan's shoes I'd be reminding my players how quickly West Ham and Derby have turned things round.

Last month Derby lost 4-0 at home to Liverpool and it was all doom and gloom, with people asking whether Jim Smith should keep his job. On Saturday the fans were chanting Jim's name and I know there's a genuine feeling at Derby that they can beat Manchester United tomorrow.

Bryan experienced a similar turnaround with me at West Brom in 1979-80. We had lost five or six major players from a very good side and by Christmas we were bottom of the old First Division.

But I knew we still had the quality so I kept pegging away and encouraging, and the big turning point came in January at Crystal Palace. Terry Venables was the manager of Palace then but he was ill that night and didn't come. We recovered from 2-0 down in the last eight minutes to get a point, ended up losing about one of our last 19 games and finished 10th. I think that's the best I've managed.

The big players at Middlesbrough such as Paul Ince and Karembeu have been in enough mixers and melting pots to know what's required tomorrow. If they show their worth and have a modicum of luck Boro could be mid-table very soon. But I still wouldn't expect to find Bryan Robson at Boro for the start of the new season.

fields.headline: Pressure mounts at Arsenal
fields.trailText: Arsenal's season is in danger of collapse. Upcoming games against Leeds and Bayern Munich must be won if they are to get back on track, writes Jon Brodkin.
fields.body:
As Arsène Wenger waited by the baggage carousel at Luton airport in the small hours of yesterday morning digesting Arsenal's crushing defeat in Moscow, he must have been praying his side's form would turn up as mislaid luggage.

Only a few weeks earlier he had stood in the same spot savouring a draw at Lazio that qualified his team for the second phase of the Champions League. Holding their own against the Italian champions and neck and neck with Manchester United in the Premiership, Arsenal seemed well set. Now their season is in serious danger of collapse.

If they lose at Leeds on Sunday and United win at Derby tomorrow, Arsenal will trail the champions by eight points. Wednesday's 4-1 capitulation at Spartak left them with one point and one goal from four matches.

"We have to correct certain things quickly but we shouldn't be too catastrophic," Wenger said. Of course, the form that produced a 15-match unbeaten sequence earlier this season could return as quickly as it disappeared. But the signs are not promising.

If it were not enough that Arsenal's forwards have lost their range, drawing blanks against Shakhtar Donetsk, Derby and Everton before wasting critical early chances in Moscow, their back line fell apart in uncharacteristic fashion on Wednesday.

The defensive weakness of the full-backs was exposed and Tony Adams and Martin Keown struggled against the sort of quick, skilful forwards they always feel least comfortable with. But desperately missed were the strength and protection offered by Patrick Vieira and Gilles Grimandi.

Take Paul Scholes and Roy Keane out of Manchester United's midfield and they might struggle too. But whereas Nicky Butt and David Beckham could slot in quite comfortably, Arsenal had to deploy Ray Parlour and Nelson Vivas out of position. Hard as Parlour fought in the centre, beside him Vivas again looked what he is: a competent full-back who has struggled to settle in the Premiership.

To call Arsenal's squad lightweight would provoke howls of derision from most Premiership clubs, and rightly so. But the issue now is not whether Arsenal are stronger than, say, Coventry but whether they can cope with a high volume of games and still match Manchester United and the rest of Europe's best.

Wenger will know this defeat need not be terminal to his quarter-final hopes. But the pressure is mounting. The game at home to Bayern Munich in 11 days' time, like that at Elland Road on Sunday, must be won.

webTitle: Chelsea told they cannot call up their own player

fields.headline: Chelsea told they cannot call up their own player
fields.trailText: Chelsea at loggerheads with the FA, Tottenham's Ian Walker staying put and whole lot more.
fields.body:
Chelsea are at loggerheads with the Football Association after the Premiership side's request to have Mikail Forssell's year-long loan deal with Crystal Palace revoked following the £12m sale of Tore Andre Flo to Rangers was refused.

Chelsea's managing director Colin Hutchison said: "The football authorities are not taking our situation into account. Instead they are simply quoting the rule book which says the loan has to continue."

The Tottenham Hotspur goalkeeper Ian Walker has withdrawn his transfer request and asked to be loaned out instead. Walker requested a transfer after Neil Sullivan was signed from Wimbledon in May.

The Leeds goalkeeper Nigel Martyn will be out until Christmas after aggravating his groin injury in training.

Sunderland have released the German international defender Thomas Helmer. The 35-year-old made only one Premiership start and two appearances after joining them under the Bosman ruling from Bayern Munich last year.

Blackburn Rovers have signed the Sheffield United striker Marcus Bent for £2.1m in a deal that also sees the Rovers forward James Thomas join United for a year's loan.

John Toshack has won a £500,000 compensation pay-out from the European champions Real Madrid after being sacked as their manager last season.

webTitle: Liverpool splutter on a last-gasp leveller

fields.headline: Liverpool splutter on a last-gasp leveller
fields.standfirst:
Houllier's side see their work undone by Alexandris's late strike
Alexandris 65, 90 | Barmby 38, Gerrard 67

Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Gérard Houllier's side saw their good work undone by a late strike that preserved the Greeks' to preserve their unbeaten European record.
fields.byline: Ian Ross at the Olympic stadium
fields.body:
Liverpool conceded a last-gasp equaliser to Alexios Alexandris, who rounded off a good night for himself in this third-round first leg to enable the Greek champions to preserve their unbeaten European record here beneath Athens' polluted skies.

Logic and statistics pointed, persuasively so, towards a Liverpool defeat last night but the dream of an extended run in the Uefa Cup lives on for the Merseysiders after a splendid performance of diligence and character.

Olympiakos had made much of a 15-game unbeaten home sequence in Champions' League fixtures, but on a night when a sense of organisation always seemed likely to eclipse a sense of flair, Liverpool were superior in almost every department and will now feel justifiably confident of reaching the final 16.

Liverpool's coach Gérard Houllier is prone to the occasional flutter and last night the gambler which lurks within him was clearly evident.

The easy option would have been to have used Emile Heskey as a battering ram and lone striker. But, no, Michael Owen was also included, such is the value placed upon an away goal in European football these days. The Frenchman's sense of adventure was to be well rewarded.

In his desperation to grab possession and make a contribution, however, Owen was constantly drawn backwards to search for the ball and help his midfield, a source of some joy for Olympiakos who promptly attempted to seize a curiously disjointed game by the throat.

Having quickly identified Djimi Traore as Liverpool's weakest defensive link, the Greeks soon poured down the left flank bearing not gifts but carrying genuine menace.

Liverpool survived a decidedly uncomfortable period simply because Sami Hyppia and Markus Babbel held firm in the centre, thus protecting their goalkeeper Sander Westerveld whose confidence has been shredded in recent weeks, more often than not by his own clumsy deeds.

To Houllier's absolute delight, however, the only real danger Westerveld faced during the course of a dull opening half was the nauseous smog. The Dutchman did flap at several crosses, but he always will. Liverpool's football was always intelligently paced, though, often nicely orchestrated and usually precise enough to move them between defence and attack without too much discomfort.

Even so they did not look like scoring until they did just that, and only seven minutes before the interval. A lovely goal it was too, Heskey heading a Jamie Carragher throw into the path of Nick Barmby who swept a fine rising drive into the roof of the net. Needless to say, the cauldron fell silent.

The goal drained away much of Olympiakos' enthusiasm and confidence, and in truth Liverpool really should have inflicted further damage on a team who at best were ordinary by Premiership standards.

They certainly went close. Heskey turned a close-range header only fractionally wide just after the re-start and Barmby struck the underside of the bar after arriving unannounced at the far post.

And then, after so much shadow boxing, the evening finally caught light.

Twenty minutes after the interval, unexpectedly it must be said, Olympiakos squared the game when Alexandris's spectacular volley after a cross from the Brazilian Giovanni flew beyond Westerveld.

Fleetingly, Scouse nerves were on edge, though they were to be calmed almost immediately when Steven Gerrard rose splendidly to head home a Barmby corner.

Really, that should have been it but, ridiculously bearing in mind the late profligacy of Liverpool's substitute Vladimir Smicer who was on for Owen, Olympiakos drew level at the death, Alexandris punishing defensive hesitancy after latching on to a team-mate's header.

Olympiakos ( 4-4-2): Eleftheropoulos; Mavrogenidis (Giannakopoulos, 57), Mamanatidis, Anatolakis, Kontis; Pursanidis (Luciano, h-t), Patsatzoglou, Zetterberg (Georgatos, 71), Djordjevic; Giovanni, Alexandris.

Liverpool ( 4-4-2) Westerveld; Carragher, Hyypia, Babbel, Traore (Staunton, h-t); Barmby, Hamann, Gerrard, Murphy (McAllister, 90); Heskey, Owen (Smicer, 66).

Referee : R Temmink ( Neth)

fields.headline: Keynes' vision is still relevant
fields.standfirst: As the pursuit of economic growth without regard for people's welfare brings global instability ever closer, the enduring value of Keynes's 20th century vision becomes clearer, writes Peter Townsend
fields.trailText: Comment: As the pursuit of economic growth without regard for people's welfare brings global instability ever closer, the enduring value of Keynes's 20th century vision becomes clearer, writes Peter Townsend.
fields.body:
John Maynard Keynes, the greatest economist of the 20th century, was a visionary who wanted to combine social and economic policy to make a better world. This vision is coming back to haunt international agencies and government leaders alike. Since the early 1970s, as Robert Skidelsky's third and final part of his biography now makes clear, Keynes's influence has been on the wane. Manipulating money took priority over serving people.

Keynes's views were misrepresented in the struggles to establish monetarism. They were said to be of merely passing relevance. But after 30 years their perennial value is being recognised. Macro-economic policy decides big things, like how many people are employed, how much a country produces, and how wages and salaries or profits and rents are divided and interest rates fixed - all of which determine the distribution of living standards. Keynes believed that macro-economic policy, whatever form it takes, and the level of social welfare cannot be disentangled.

For Britain this means that planned collective provision of resources has to be the right basis today for economic growth, as well as for free choice in the market. It has to be the right basis also for social stability and freedom from poverty. Modernised welfare, not residualised welfare, has to be the order of the day. Public services have to be strengthened or re-established, not replaced. Keynes perceived the affordability as well as the collective security of national insurance. This view prevailed -- the Beveridge report, and the post-1945 welfare state, would not have happened, otherwise.

His backing had a knock-on effect around Europe. The pooling of risks through compulsory insurance ensured a minimum income for unemployed people but also brought corresponding measures for the elderly, disabled and families with children.

Internationally the strategy has to be the same. Public investment, state planning, public services and redistributive taxes and benefits have to play a big role in even the poorest countries.

The financial agencies have to set the example. The failure of monetarist or neo-liberal policies to reduce the growing indebtedness and impoverishment of most of the poor countries, provide public sector institutions to guarantee minimally decent living standards, and quickly resolve past and current conflicts across the globe and stabilise societies is manifest. Cuts, deregulation and privatisation are no longer credible features of development.

Keynes anticipated the need for the IMF and the World Bank, but not on the lines insisted upon by the Americans. "We need," he said in 1943, "a central institution, of a purely technical and non-political character, to aid and support other international institutions concerned with the planning and regulation of the world's economic life." Instead, as Skidelsky shows, the US Treasury was determined "to concentrate financial power in Washington".

Keynes backed gifts as well as low-interest loans for countries recovering from war, or otherwise impoverished. His open-mindedness and generosity, as well as professional rigour, might have resolved the problems of indebted poor countries long ago. Changes towards the direction of Keynes are now being signalled. UN agencies such as the United Nations Research Institute for Social Development are promoting a much larger role for social policy. The World Bank's policies on structural adjustment and social funds have come under sustained criticism for deepening rather than alleviating poverty, and denuding governments of already threadbare public services. The implication is the need to restore or create large-scale, if "basic", public services.

The United Nations Development Programme and the United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef), especially, have exposed the weaknesses of the strategy of economic growth, privatisation and cuts in public expenditure whatever the social cost. The Washington consensus is being challenged.

Even Joe Stiglitz, the chief economist at the World Bank, wanted to start a palace revolution and soften the bank's rigid strategy. He was forced out of office. Like global warming the message about global polarisation has become stark.

Change soon or there will be disaster. For Britain and other countries, as for the powerful financial international agencies, there has to be a revival of Keynesian planning for modernised social insurance, more jobs in the public services, more redistribution and less privatisation in the economy.

 John Maynard Keynes: Fighting for Britain 1937-1946, Robert Skidelsky, Macmillan, £25

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Steve Greaves
fields.trailText: You've chosen a good route! In Vancouver, don't fail to visit the Capiliano suspension bridge. Also, the US border is less than 100 kilometres away. You might consider a side trip into Washington State, to add another country's immigration stamp to your passport.
fields.body:
I live in Sydney, but have travelled widely in the past. One warning: when you've travelled abroad once and have enjoyed the experience, you'll find that you can't get enough of it!

You've chosen a good route! In Vancouver, don't fail to visit the Capiliano suspension bridge. Also, the US border is less than 100 kilometres away. You might consider a side trip into Washington State, just to add another country's immigration stamp to your passport.

Sydney? I may not be a good guide here. As a native Sydneyite I probably don't fully appreciate the treasures on my own doorstep, but make sure your friends at least take you on one trip to see the Blue Mountains behind the city. A day trip to Canberra might also be in order. Word of warning - when you get to one of our celebrated surfing beaches, don't fail to smear on the sun block.

After Sydney, you might find Melbourne a little disappointing. It isn't as picturesque, it lacks surfing beaches on its front doorstep and is generally regarded as more conservative than Sydney... but you must discover it for yourself. In any case, here are four places of interest you can look into: Phillip Island fairy penguin parade; the Yarra Valley wineries (some of the best in Australia); Daylesford Spa in central Victoria and the spectacular coast road between Geelong and Port Campbell (with views of the Twelve Apostles rock formations en route).

Cairns? Definitely take a glass bottomed boat out to Green Island - a real coral island on the Great Barrier Reef - and view the living coral in all its brilliant colours. Be warned though: October to April is the tropical wet season there and it gets very humid!

Uluru - lucky you! The surrounding region, with its clear desert air and splendid rock colours, is really something. I hope you find the local Aboriginal culture interesting; the indigenous Australian culture and way of life is the oldest on Earth. Europeans characteristically think of Australia as "young" and their own countries as "old", but consider it from an Aboriginal point of view and you get a totally different picture.

Good luck, Milly, and enjoy your travels. Hope this has been of help!

fields.body: Hi Sue - I'm really excited for you! Hope you have a wonderful time. How long are you staying in Malaysia? There's some great stuff to see - if you get a chance, be sure to visit Taman Negara, the national park, where there's some really fab primary rainforest where you can go and stay (nicely done - doesn't spoil the environment much). webTitle: Clerical error puts Preston third bottom in NHS cost tables

fields.headline: Clerical error puts Preston third bottom in NHS cost tables
fields.trailText: An NHS trust listed in official league tables as the third least cost-efficient in England by the Department of Health claims a statistical error was responsible for its poor ranking. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
An NHS trust listed in official league tables as the third least cost-efficient in England by the Department of Health (DoH) claims a statistical error was responsible for its poor ranking.

It says a mistake in forms that it submitted to officials earlier this year meant that it recorded as £186m the cost of providing services, when it should have been £159m.

"Our own investigations indicated that if this error had not occurred the trust would have been around the national average," said a spokesperson.

The error - which it says has been accepted by Whitehall - will embarrass both the trust and ministers, who have used the tables to exhort inefficient trusts to bring themselves up to the standards of the most efficient.

Preston Acute Hospitals trust stands out in the table because it is the only general hospital trust in list of the 10 most costly trusts - alongside more obviously expensive specialist heart and children's hospitals.

The published tables show that costs at Preston are 66% above the England NHS average. The majority of trusts - 87% - fell within 20% of the average.

Its apparently poor showing in the tables came as a shock to the trust when it was contacted by Society Guardian. The trust had compared well with its peers in last year's report and had expected to do so again.

"We have informed the Department of Health and they are correcting our figure to provide an accurate set of reference costs," a trust spokesperson said.

Was your trust inaccurately listed in the Reference costs 2000 report? Contact us at SocietyGuardian.co.uk.

webTitle: NHS league tables are only valuable when comparing like with like

fields.headline: NHS league tables are only valuable when comparing like with like
fields.standfirst: Every health trust has its own explanation for variations in the cost of care. Only by comparing similar trusts can we draw useful conclusions.
fields.trailText: Every health trust has its own explanation for variations in the cost of care. Only by comparing similar trusts can we draw useful conclusions, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
Despite the apparently bewildering columns, figures and league tables, the NHS reference costs 2000 report gives a useful - if partial - insight into the comparative efficiency of hospitals and community services in England.

The report is billed as "the most comprehensive coverage of service costs in the public domain of any health service" and covers 9m episodes of NHS care recorded in 1999-00, equivalent to 60% of NHS expenditure.

The league table "rankings" are not entirely trustworthy - they are not as transparent an index of performance as, say, a league table of football clubs, and nor do they necessarily reflect clinical quality.

Most trusts with high average costs will be able to provide plausible evidence as to why specific local conditions - such as carrying out a high proportion of complex and costly operations - justify their "low" cost efficiency.

But they do provide a useful benchmark guide to how well trusts that are of a broadly similar size and type, and carry out a broadly similar mix of operations, have succeeded in making services more cost-efficient - meaning providing more care for every pound spent.

Take the big London teaching hospitals for example. While costs at St George's Healthcare trust and King's Healthcare trust are respectively 15% and 8% above the NHS average, near neighbours Guys and St Thomas' trust costs is 10% below.

Similarly, a successful caesarian section costs £4,385 at Barts and the London NHS trust; the same procedure costs £1,956 a few miles further south at King's Healthcare trust and £1,521 a few minutes drive further west at University College London Hospitals trust.

Identification of such variations among what, on the face of it, are similar trusts allows managers to address inefficiencies where it this clinically justified - perhaps developing more efficient ways of working, or reducing the length of time patients spend in hospital.

Health minister John Denham says the tables are "essential to raise standards across the NHS and address the unacceptable variations in performance in a co-ordinated way".

Snapshots from the report include:

 Hip replacements were undertaken in 185 NHS trusts in 1999-00. The average cost of a planned primary hip operation (when a hip is replaced for the first time) was £3,899. But mean costs ranged from £6,962 per operation at the Royal Shrewsbury Hositals trust to £2,217 at Preston Acute Hospitals trust;
 The average cost of delivering a baby in England in the normal way (natural unplanned delivery) is £738, with an average length of stay of two days. The average cost of a planned caesarian birth was £1,738, with an average length of stay in hospital of five days;
 Some 31, 887 patients were admitted to hospital in England with viral pneumonia in 1999-00, a 6.5% increase on the previous year. The report says it is "possible that this has links with the levels of influenza recorded during the 1999-00 winter";
 In 1999-00, 0.3% of the 12.5m visits to accident and emergency departments ended with patient deaths. There are no comparative figures for the previous year.

webTitle: Anniesland: victors pay tribute to Dewar

fields.headline: Anniesland: victors pay tribute to Dewar
fields.trailText: Anniesland's new MP John Robertson and MSP Bill Butler paid tribute in their  victory speeches to their predecessor, Scottish first minister Donald Dewar, whose shock death on 11 October prompted the by-elections.
fields.body:
Anniesland's new MP John Robertson and MSP Bill Butler paid tribute in their victory speeches to their predecessor, Scottish first minister Donald Dewar, whose shock death on 11 October prompted the by-elections.

Mr Butler said: "No-one will be able to fill Donald's shoes but I consider it a huge honour to be given the chance to follow in his footsteps.

"The people of Anniesland voted for decency, fairness and social justice - Donald Dewar's values and New Labour's values."

And Mr Robertson said: "I cannot be another Donald Dewar. I can only be John Robertson.

"But I promise the people of Anniesland that I will represent them to the best of my ability."

Later, the SNP's Westminster seat candidate Grant Thoms said: "We've achieved a 6% swing in Labour's safest seat in a by-election that no-one wanted. Translated nationally that means 13 Labour seats would go to the Scottish National Party."

A spokesman for the Scottish Liberal Democrats said: "Our share of the vote has increased substantially in both Glasgow seats. The swing was around 6% from Labour to the Scottish National Party in both the Westminster and Holyrood polls.

"We know that the real losers tonight are the SNP and the Tories. They have failed to make any improvement. This must be extremely worrying for the SNP so close to the General Election."

webTitle: Apathy sweeps to victory in byelection test

fields.headline: Apathy sweeps to victory in byelection test
fields.standfirst: Labour held on to the four contested seats, but most people chose not to vote at all, writes Guardian columnist David McKie
fields.trailText: Labour held on to the four contested seats, but most people chose not to vote at all, writes Guardian columnist David McKie
fields.body:
There's no doubt who came best out of last night's round of byelections, in Preston, West Bromwich and the Anniesland division of Glasgow, where vacancies had to be filled both for Westminster and for the Scottish parliament. This was a very good night for the Can't Be Bothered party, and a pretty dispiriting moment for anyone else.

It is easy to tell the story in terms of Labour majorities slashed: down from 18,680 to 4,426 in Preston; down from 15,154 to 6,337 in the Westminster contest at Anniesland. (You can't make any comparison for West Bromwich, since in May 1997 Betty Boothroyd stood as the Speaker Seeking Re-election and the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats did not put up candidates against her).

But these aren't the statistics that really matter. The lower the turnouts in byelections, the less figures for majorities and for swing from one side to the other tell you about the real electoral world. And these turnouts were very low: not as abject as at some of the previous byelections in this parliament, but a mere 38% in Scotland, 30% in Lancashire and 28% in the Midlands.

In these circumstances it makes sense to look at the figures in a less conventional way, and concentrate less on each party's share of the vote than on the proportion of the electorate which bothered to turn out for each of them. Analysed in this fashion, the story at Preston was this: around 13% of those entitled to vote took the trouble to go to the polling stations and mark their crosses for Labour. Some 7% did the same for the Tories; while 70% stayed at home.

In West Bromwich, the figures were very similar: 14% of those entitled to vote gave their support to Labour, 9% turned out for the Tories, 72% stayed away.

In Glasgow Anniesland, the figures for the Westminster election show 20% turning out for Labour, 8% for the Scottish National Party and 4% for the Tories, with 62% preferring to do something else. In the election for the Scottish parliament, the SNP did rather better than in the Westminster contest and Labour a little worse, but again the stayaways were the majority tendency at 62%.

So these contests were very much a minority preoccupation. In so far as one can detect the mood of the nation it seems to be this. People are not enthusiastic about this government. Of those who voted Labour in May 1997, roughly 70% defected in Preston this time, (a figure which no doubt reflects disputes in the local party over who should be its candidate), roughly 60% in West Bromwich, and just about half in Anniesland.

But there is no great enthusiasm either for trying to turn Labour out. In the great byelections of the Thatcher years, which helped engineer her eviction from office 10 years ago this week, what struck terror in Conservative hearts was not just Tory defections but the positive surge in Labour or Lib Dem support. There was little sign of a similar process here. The SNP vote in Anniesland, a seat where these great byelection fighters must have had some hope of making a splash, was down on May 1997. The Tories were no real threat to Labour - even in West Bromwich, where because of the reintroduction of party politics after the Boothroyd years they should have been raring to go.

In that context - and especially after the autumn of discontent which shook Labour so badly - Mr Blair today may be feeling a sense of reprieve. On the other hand, when he turns to the morning papers, and the headlines on Europe and beef and petrol prices (once more), he may well have started to feel queasy again.

In these circumstances it makes sense to look at the figures in a less conventional way, and concentrate less on each party's share of the vote than on the proportion of the electorate which bothered to turn out for each of them. Analysed in this fashion, the story at Preston was this: around 13% of those entitled to vote took the trouble to go to the polling stations and mark their crosses for Labour. Some 7% did the same for the Tories; while 70% stayed at home. In West Bromwich, the figures were very similar: 14% of those entitled to vote gave their support to Labour, 9% turned out for the Tories, 72% stayed away. In Glasgow Anniesland, the figures for the Westminster election show 20% turning out for Labour, 8% for the Scottish National Party and 4% for the Tories, with 62% preferring to do something else. In the election for the Scottish parliament, the SNP did rather better than in the Westminster contest and Labour a little worse, but again the stayaways were the majority tendency at 62%. So these contests were very much a minority preoccupation. In so far as one can detect the mood of the nation it seems to be this. People are not enthusiastic about this government. Of those who voted Labour in May 1997, roughly 70% defected in Preston this time, (a figure which no doubt reflects disputes in the local party over who should be its candidate), roughly 60% in West Bromwich, and just about half in Anniesland. But there is no great enthusiasm either for trying to turn Labour out. In the great byelections of the Thatcher years, which helped engineer her eviction from office 10 years ago this week, what struck terror in Conservative hearts was not just Tory defections but the positive surge in Labour or Lib Dem support. There was little sign of a similar process here. The SNP vote in Anniesland, a seat where these great byelection fighters must have had some hope of making a splash, was down on May 1997. The Tories were no real threat to Labour - even in West Bromwich, where because of the reintroduction of party politics after the Boothroyd years they should have been raring to go. In that context - and especially after the autumn of discontent which shook Labour so badly - Mr Blair today may be feeling a sense of reprieve. On the other hand, when he turns to the morning papers, and the headlines on Europe and beef and petrol prices (once more), he may well have started to feel queasy again. webTitle: Auditors back council control of school budgets

fields.headline: Auditors back council control of school budgets
fields.standfirst: Schools are having difficulty with the administrative burden that control of finances imposes, according to an audit commission report
fields.trailText: 2pm: Schools are having difficulty with the administrative burden that control of finances imposes, according to an audit commission report. Simon Parker reports.
fields.body:
There will be a certain air of satisfaction surrounding many local government education officers this afternoon. Councils have always maintained that the government's policy of handing increasingly large chunks of school funding directly to head teachers was a bad idea. But council arguments were, until this morning, easily dismissed with the charge that local government was simply trying to protect its highest spending responsibility.

The audit commission has changed all that with a report that echoes many of the arguments deployed by local government. Money Matters emphasises the important role councils play in targeting education funding according to local needs and priorities, and calls on the government to think again before it decides on any increase in the amount of money authorities have to delegate to school heads. Schools currently have control over 82% of the money the government spends on them. A decade ago, most controlled less than 5%.

The report says that up to 15% of schools are having difficulty dealing with the administrative burden of the funds they control, and that head teachers only have a limited amount of time to spend on financial matters. In short, the commission underlines the case for having a local authority to support schools, provide them with strategic coordination and direct resources to where they are most needed.

"Schools have the primary purpose of teaching and learning. Shopping for the best school meals caterer or the most suitable insurance policy is not high on their list of priorities. Local government can provide a far more cost effective service," says Local Government Association education chair Graham Lane.

The report also urges ministers to reconsider whether the ringfenced standards fund - one-off additional grants designed to deliver national priorities and so undermine local discretion - is the most effective way to supplement school budgets. The report says heads find that the short-term nature of standards fund money makes it difficult to plan ahead.

This report will not cheer those head teachers who still hope for a national funding formula for schools in the belief that it will iron out what they see as regional funding inequalities. The commission admits that there are wide funding variations between schools - per pupil funding can vary by up to £1,500 a year in secondary schools. It adds, however, that two thirds of similar "typical" secondary schools are funded within a range of £200 per pupil.

There is a wider issue here that the commission chooses not to address. The current slew of regeneration policy documents, urban and rural white papers included, is a sign that the government is staking a large chunk of its credibility on renewing the country's towns and cities. Schools can play a major role in this process, acting both as a route out of poverty for the disadvantaged and, at best, as community centres bringing parents and children together. They can fulfil this role most effectively in partnership with other local agencies, but that kind of working is undermined if schools do not have any kind of strategic or financial coordination from an education authority.

Chris Waterman, secretary of the Association of Chief Education Officers, says: "This report is spot on. It puts its finger on the issues that education officers have been raising with the government. This should significantly influence the debate we've been having with the department of education."

Council chiefs throughout the country might be tempted to sum that statement up in just four words: "We told you so."

webTitle: Ministers demand greater efficiency from NHS trusts

fields.headline: Ministers demand greater efficiency from NHS trusts
fields.standfirst: NHS league tables reveal wide variations in cost of care
fields.trailText: NHS league tables reveal wide variations in cost of care. Patrick Butler reports.
fields.body:
Ministers have ordered NHS trusts to improve efficiency in the light of a report which shows wide variations in the cost of delivering care at hospitals and community health services in England.

The trust with the highest costs - Birmingham Children's Hospital - is 73 per cent higher than the England average, while the lowest cost trust, North Hampshire Loddon Community, comes in at 37 per cent below average.

The report also reveals wide variations in the cost of individual treatments: the mean cost of a successful caesarean section at Barts and the London trust is £4,385 compared to £471 at Premier health trust in Staffordshire. The cost of varicose vein procedures ranges from £2,801 at St Mary's hospital trust in London to £116 at the Chorley and South Ribble trust.

Ministers are keen to emphasise that while the cost rankings are a useful measure of cost efficiency and "identify scope for improvement", they do not necessarily reflect the quality of care that each trust provides.

"Cost is only one part of the picture. Good quality and high costs do not always go together, nor do low costs and low quality," said health minister John Denham. He said the report was "essential to raise standards across the NHS and address the unacceptable variations in performance in a co-ordinated way."

The report says the differences in costs reflect "underlying differences" in cost efficiency between trusts, but it says a range of factors should be taken into account when studying the its efficiency league tables. Factors include the complexity of care provided - a high proportion of care provided by specialist trusts such as Great Ormond Street hospital for Children for example, consists of comparatively rare, high-cost operations.

"Just as a high position in the index may not neccessarily suggest inefficiency; a low position on the index should not be a cause for complacency," it says. The five most costly trust in England are, in rank order: Birmingham Children's Hospital trust; Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children; Preston Acute Hospitals trust; National Hospital for Rheumatic Diseases; and Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital trust.

The five least costly trusts are: North Hampshire Loddon Community; Moorfields Eye Hospital, London; Weston Area Health (Weston Super Mare); Nottingham City Hospital; and Countess of Chester Hospital.

webTitle: Nov 24: Diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: Plastering over the cracks
fields.standfirst: Lambeth social services director Lisa Christensen attends a roadshow about the performance assessment framework, which no one seems to be comfortable with
fields.trailText: Lambeth social services director Lisa Christensen attends a roadshow about the performance assessment framework, which no one seems to be comfortable with.
fields.body:
Well, the ceiling is replastered, now the lights just need fixing, so we're still stumbling around in dim lighting no, I won't pursue that simile too far.

Grateful to start the week with my regular meeting with a selection of staff and managers during which we discussed the newly adopted vision and values for the organisation. I think they are very powerful and will help put the heart and vigour back into the authority if we use them effectively. Interestingly, they have been developed by the staff and customers. Some senior managers have slight ownership problems, as they didn't lead this process. Many staff, of course, would observe these reactions with wry smiles as this has all too often been their experience.

Attend a celebration of the 105th birthday of a resident of one of our homes for older people. This lady was born in Lambeth and has lived here all her life - gives me a regal wave and dismisses me in favour of having her photo taken with the mayor.

Attend roadshow about the performance assessment framework - nobody (Department of Health or social services departments) yet seems to be entirely comfortable with it, although I think we all applaud the intentions behind it. All made more difficult by the inevitability that the press and some members will take a lazy approach and judge performance solely on the basis of star ratings and league tables. The concept that a low-star rating might be applied to very high performance because "questions should be asked" is a bit too subtle for Fleet Street.

Ended the week with a meeting that I approached with trepidation but actually found both useful and constructive. This was the inevitable follow-up meeting to the "Directions" with the chief inspector of social services and her team at Richmond House. I was accompanied by the chief exec, leader and lead member for children's services.

Regular readers will know I am keen on omens - and as we waited in the lobby of Richmond House I was surprised and delighted to meet up with an old colleague from my days working in the health service in Bradford. This boded well for the meeting.

Denise Platt, as always, was clear and completely focused on improving services on the ground for children and other users of our services. We had a thorough discussion and left (I think) with everyone feeling clear about what needs to be done, what is being done, and how we are doing it. It will become clearer as the months pass how well we are doing.

fields.headline: No real online music industry
fields.standfirst: Eminem and Radiohead may have won awards for innovation in online music, but it will take more than clever PR for a 'new music industry' to flourish, writes Simon Jeffery
fields.trailText: Eminem and Radiohead may have won awards for innovation in online music, but it will take more than clever PR for a 'new music industry' to flourish, writes Simon Jeffery.
fields.body:
Eminem and the members of Radiohead may have woken up in marginally better moods than usual today after the bad tempered rapper and caricature-like serious rockers collected awards last night for their websites.

Eminem, notorious for appalling middle America's parents while he sells records to their teens, won the international artist category and Radiohead picked up the alternative crown in the inaugural British Online Music Awards (Omas).

You would be forgiven at this point for wondering what the awards are and, more importantly, what they mean.

The Omas were set up by Music Week magazine to highlight "creativity, innovation and technical wizardry" in a business better known for its lawsuits against anything of the sort.

According to Steve Redmond, Music Week's publisher, there is a "new music industry developing", built on "bits, bytes and the internet". He claims the Omas are "the first truly 21st century music awards".

Fittingly Napster, the internet music sharing (or pirating) software, won the online pioneer award.

This is significant because Napster is one of the few true movers and shakers in the online music world. In fact it could only exist online. Instead of selling mail order CDs or advertising tour dates it bypassed the massive distribution networks of the multinational music industry, if only for a short time.

The industry took Napster to court, unhappy that the promise of free music would eat into its profit margins. The alternative - that exposure to new artists and genres might tempt the listening public into buying more CDs - was never entertained. To avoid paying punitive damages, Napster sold out to the media giant Bertelsmann but its free spirit continues on many imitator P2P (peer to peer) sites.

This is where the awards fall down. Arguably, a "new music industry" based on the net does not exist. True, there are individual operators, but by no means an industry in the conventional sense. If one is to flourish its chief executives must recognise that the net's strength is its ability to move information around the world quickly. That is all Napster did, the information just happened to be music.

It will be a long journey. Radiohead and Eminem's web presence are both what surfers would call "cool sites" but not necessarily good music sites. They are, fundamentally, merely pieces of PR: from Radiohead's site we know, for example, that they are serious artists who share a common political ground with anti-capitalist protesters. That may make us want to click on the next link to buy their t-shirts and CDs.

As often in the music business, innovation is left to come from the bottom up. Napster showed a way for consumers to use the net but the onus now switches to the producers. Dance producers can exchange samples and drums patterns using Napster-style sharing technology and - at the other end of the spectrum - Adam Burrows, guitarist with a Bristol-based band, Big Joan, says that being on a small internet label, Sink and Stove Records, allows him to network with other musicians without, as he puts it, going all out to impress a "record company's toilet cleaner" .

The net may change the way we create and listen to music. But if it does not, then the industry's "creativity, innovation and technical wizardry" online will be wasted.

fields.headline: The Fiver
fields.standfirst: In today's Fiver: Mad, Sad, and Bad.
fields.trailText: RIO 30 GRAND
fields.body:
RIO 30 GRAND

What would you do with £64.3m? With that sort of money the Fiver would be talking classic cars, loose women and a bid for Brazilian wild man Edmundo - if only to keep the staff on its toes, of course. However David O'Leary of Leeds has instead decided to spend - or waste, depending on your point of view - his £64.3m on players like Mills, Matteo, Viduka, Dacourt and Wilcox instead. And today, he really got extravagant and signed £18m man Rio Ferdinand.

We say signed, although technically Ferdinand still has to pass a medical. Coming from Ibrox these would be worrying words, but Leeds doctors aren't quite so picky, and so Ferdinand will almost certainly become the world's most expensive defender tomorrow, before being unveiled before Sunday's game against Arsenal.

And Ferdinand will be well rewarded for moving north. He will sign a five-and-a-half year contract worth an estimated £30,000 a week - £9,000 more than he was on at West Ham. So he's happy. And Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale, who says he has managed to sign the West Ham starlet without going outside the existing wage structure, is also happy. But the Fiver can't help thinking that for £18m quid Leeds could have got a real Brazilian rather than just a bloke with a Brazilian name.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

MARADONA CHEATED

Imagine being the best footballer of the 1980s. Every Saturday or Sunday at 3pm you squeezed into the tightest shorts imaginable, thrilled a bunch of mullet-headed psychopaths with your mazy dribbles, before leaving the field to snort mountains of coke with your new-found friends. Now imagine, ten years after the decade when greed was good, you learned that Fifa have slimmed down the player of the century list so you don't figure, and you'll have some sense of the pain felt by 'Don't cry for me, Argentina' 80s man Diego Maradona today.

"It's because I defended footballers' rights against Fifa officials who were stealing money" was Maradona's explanation for the shock news. But the roly-poly star wasn't finished there, insisting that nothing would stop him going to Fifa's ceremony in Rome in December. "I will go to the ceremony," he thundered. "I wish I could have the honour of receiving that award - it would have been for Argentina."

Later, though, Diego's anger seemed to subside, and tried to put a reflective gloss on things. "At least at home I have a prize that Havelange, Blatter, Pele and Beckenbauer can't take from me - the respect of the Argentinian people," he whispered, putting on a brave and patriotic face before it again collapsed, along with his septum.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"My favourite subject was drama"

Rio Ferdinand reminisces about his school days.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

PRIZE TURKEY

It's not often the Fiver conducts a prayer vigil for the supporters of Trabzonspor. But today is no ordinary day. So come join us readers: and bring your scented candles, your rosary beads and your God with you. Because over Trabzonspor a dark and strangely permed shadow is being cast - by none other than England's Kelvin Koogan! Now after the various debacles with the national side the Fiver thought Koog was finished. And so did the rest of the world. But Trabzonspor's directors obviously have different ideas.

They want a big name to replace their under-fire coach Giray Bulak, whose poor run of results and strange man-management skills have left him on the brink of the sack - remind you of anyone circa September 2000? - and his team languishing among the also-rans (oh, the similarities!). And they are prepared to pay Koog an astonishing £2m a season as well.

But Kelvin isn't a shoo-in to bring his special brand of tactics and his £40,000 card schools to north Turkey. Well not just yet. Because former Spain manager Javier Clemente - my the Trabzonspor directors do know how to pick them - is also up being lined up. Meanwhile Bulak is fighting for his coaching life. "I am still the Trabzonspor coach," he insisted. "I have not met the board and discussed resigning. President Mehmet Ali Yilmaz is like a father to me. I don't think we have lost the championship by just losing a few games," he continued, as the dark and strangely permed shadow began to envelope him.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Fiorentina's coach Fatih Terim has been offered the job of coach of Milan, according to onefootball.

Leicester City have rejected another Celtic bid for Neil Lennon.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

The Leeds captain Lucas Radebe has won the Fifa Fair Play Award for 2000. The South Africa defender has been given the award for his work with children in his home country and for his commitment to the fight against racism in football. Luis Figo, Rivaldo and Zinedine Zidane have been confirmed as the three nominees for the World Player of the Year Award.

Kevin Keegan is wanted by Derby. No, Jim Smith is not looking for yet more tactical acumen on his coaching staff. This KK is a 20-year-old Northern Irish youth international midfielder who plays for Coleraine.

Stuart Barlow, who scored 23 goals for Wigan last season, has been put on the transfer list after only four months at Tranmere.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Live Schoolboy Football - Northern Ireland v Wales (7pm)

Come on, it is Friday night! Go out and party.

Sky Sports 3: Hold the Back Page (10pm)

And remember - if you're feeling a bit too excited, just think of Brian's bouffant. Trust us - it never fails

"It's because I defended footballers' rights against Fifa officials who were stealing money" was Maradona's explanation for the shock news. But the roly-poly star wasn't finished there, insisting that nothing would stop him going to Fifa's ceremony in Rome in December. "I will go to the ceremony," he thundered. "I wish I could have the honour of receiving that award - it would have been for Argentina." Later, though, Diego's anger seemed to subside, and tried to put a reflective gloss on things. "At least at home I have a prize that Havelange, Blatter, Pele and Beckenbauer can't take from me - the respect of the Argentinian people," he whispered, putting on a brave and patriotic face before it again collapsed, along with his septum. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "My favourite subject was drama" Rio Ferdinand reminisces about his school days. * * * * * * * * * * * * * PRIZE TURKEY It's not often the Fiver conducts a prayer vigil for the supporters of Trabzonspor. webTitle: Germany reports first positive BSE test

fields.headline: Germany reports first positive BSE test
fields.standfirst: Special report: BSE
fields.trailText: A cow born and slaughtered in Germany has tested positive for mad-cow disease for the first time, authorities said today.
fields.body:
A cow born and slaughtered in Germany has tested positive for mad-cow disease for the first time, authorities said today.

It was a blow to longstanding German claims that home-grown cattle are BSE-free.

The cow was tested after its slaughter in the town of Itzehoe on Wednesday, authorities in Schleswig-Holstein state said. The probability of error in the preliminary test on the animal, born in 1996, was between 5 percent and 10 percent, they said.

German testing had previously only detected the brain-wasting disease in animals imported from Britain and Switzerland. Scientists believe infected meat could be the cause of a similar ailment in humans, the usually fatal Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease.

The announcement overshadowed a government bid to head off growing public alarm at the spread of the disease in Europe when it announced Friday it wants to ban the use of meat and bone meal in all animal feed.

A ban should be implemented "as soon as possible," said Sigrun Neuwerth, a spokeswoman for Agriculture Minister Karl-Heinz Funke. The new regulations must first be approved by lawmakers in the upper house of parliament, where Germany's 16 states are represented.

Germany outlawed the use of the meal in cattle feed in 1994. That ban would now be extended to feed for other animal feeds including pigs and poultry. Funke had previously insisted that Germany's stringent treatment of meat and bone meal for feeding to animals made it safe.

New cases of mad cow disease in countries including France, which banned the use of meat and bone meal in animal feed earlier this month, have made consumers across Europe concerned about possible health risks from eating meat, especially beef.

German officials have said they don't have any plans to ban the importation of beef from other countries, but have demanded clearer labeling on beef from Britain, where more than 80 people have died of the human form of the disease.

Related audio
French authorities are delighted that Britain has not imposed an outright ban on French beef, says Jon Henley in Paris. (2mins 48)

fields.headline: Union Pictures merges with West 175
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Union Pictures, the production company launching Johnny Vaughan's sitcom career, has teamed up with AIM-listed West 175. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Union Pictures, the TV production company that is launching Johnny Vaughan's sitcom career, has formed a joint-venture with an international TV distribution company.

Union has teamed up with AIM-listed media group West 175, to form Union 175, which will develop, produce, and distribute TV programmes in the UK and worldwide.

Bradley Adams, chairman of Union, said his company would provide the creative input in the new venture, which will give it the financial firepower to put more programmes on screen.

Union's biggest hits include the long-running MasterChef series and the BBC adaptation of Iain Banks' Crow Road.

Johnny Vaughan's comedy-drama, called 'Orrible, will be broadcast on BBC2 at the end of next year.

Mr Adams said: "We have been a successful production company, but a very small one. When you reach a certain critical mass, you tend to just bump along with old ideas.

"This deal gives us the money to recruit more staff and develop more programmes." said Mr Adams.

The company already has 10 programmes in development, and West 175 will use the deal as a UK launchpad for its smash-hit Dream Home programme.

The New Zealand series invites couples to renovate derelict houses, with the best attempt being decided by a viewers' phone poll.

West 175, which has production units in the US and New Zealand, will stump up initial development funds of £2m for the new venture.

John McEwen, the chief executive of West 175, said: "We were looking for someone to be our broadcaster in the UK and Union were the perfect fit for us."

Mr McEwen added that the new venture will not get involved in feature films.

This is despite Union's close links with Natural Nylon, the film production company owned by Mr Adams and Brit-pack stars Jude Law, Jonny Lee Miller and Ewan McGregor.

fields.headline: Israelis will hinder western intervention
fields.standfirst:
While the Israelis are beginning to realise that intervention in the conflict is inevitable, they will surely do their utmost to make it as ineffective as possible, writes Brian Whitaker

Special report: Israel & the Middle East
fields.trailText: While the Israelis are beginning to realise that intervention in the conflict is inevitable, they will surely do their utmost to make it as ineffective as possible, writes Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Belatedly, western governments have begun to accept the need for intervention in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. This is what the Palestinians and Arabs have been calling for, and the Israelis - though still protesting - are beginning to recognise that it may now be inevitable. But if it is going to happen, the Israelis will surely do their utmost to make it as ineffective as possible.

There are two basic options: an observer force or a protection force.

An observer force would be small (possibly no more than 200 people) and unarmed, or lightly armed - for its own protection but not to stop violence between the two sides.

This is a lot less than the Palestinians have been seeking, and its chances of success are uncertain. Observers were sent to Hebron a few years ago and, in the words of the Palestinian spokeswoman Hanan Ashrawi, "they have been entirely useless".

"What we want," she told the Guardian yesterday, "is an international force with a mandate to protect the Palestinians and hold the Israelis responsible. It should be mobile and have the ability to intervene ... We want Israel to be accountable and subject to international law."

On the other hand, an observer force is better than nothing. Some Palestinians see it as a bridgehead which will eventually lead to more active intervention. So do the Israelis, which is one reason why they object to it.

A lot depends on what the observers would be expected to do and how they would operate. Their most obvious function would be to monitor and document the violence, and to publish their evidence in full with a view to prosecution of anyone who commits crime under local or international law.

This, in itself, might deter some of the excesses, though equally it could result in the excesses simply continuing behind the observers' backs.

The personality and determination of the observers would also be important. Would they be nervous Norwegian policemen or characters like Scott Ritter, who plagued the Iraqis for years with his nuclear inspections?

A protection force would entail a far bigger commitment. To be effective, it would need to be large enough and sufficiently well armed to restrain the Israelis. That is not impossible - witness Nato's defence of Kosovo - but it looks unlikely at this stage.

A weak protection force would probably not help at all. It could easily end up as the meat in a sandwich - squeezed between the warring sides, as happened in southern Lebanon.

Another problem is that a protection force might stop the fighting but consolidate the status quo. For example, besides protecting Palestinians it might be trapped into protecting Israeli settlements, which the international community regards as illegal. That would certainly please the Israelis but would not move the situation forward towards a sustainable peace.

An initial intervention by observers, in sufficient numbers and with a proper mandate, would at least create an opportunity to cool the situation.

It would also send a powerful signal from western countries that the disproportionate, and often hysterical, use of force by the Israelis over the last few weeks is intolerable.

Finally, multinational involvement would be a sign that America's lopsided domination of the peace process - which has been a large part of the problem - is coming to an end.

fields.headline: Blair praises Balkan peace moves
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today hailed moves towards peace and stability in the Balkans as an example of the value of a strong and united European Union.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today hailed moves towards peace and stability in the Balkans as an example of the value of a strong and united European Union.

Mr Blair, speaking at an EU-Balkans summit in the Croatian capital Zagreb, told fellow heads of government: "When people attack the EU, they ask: what is the good of it? I say to them - look at this meeting and see the purpose and achievement of the EU."

The summit involved the 15 EU nations and the Balkan states of Bosnia, Croatia, Albania, Macedonia and Yugoslavia. It is the first occasion they have all met together since bitter ethnic conflict exploded in the region. Mr Blair said: "The 15 member states of the EU - countries that in the lifetime of my father were at war with one another - are now working in union, with 50 years of peace and prosperity behind us.

"... And now, holding out the prospect of bringing the same peace and prosperity to the Eastern and Central European nations and even to the Balkan countries."

The prime minister's words were designed to pave the way for Britain's approach to the forthcoming controversial European summit in Nice where leaders will agree on changes to the EU's structure to allow enlargement.

Mr Blair went on to tell the summit: "The very word Balkan has for centuries tragically been synonymous with destruction and racial conflict. Yet today, the vision of a united Europe, secure, free and prosperous, offers for the first time the chance of a new history for the region.

"Let no one say nothing ever changes. Europe, the present EU and the EU of the future, is the standing example that the past need not repeat itself."

A new beginning was possible, Mr Blair said, provided an enlightened patriotism replaces the fear and prejudices of that narrow nationalism. "This is the common goal we proclaim today - an historic commitment to enhancing and enlarging the European family. To achieve for the Balkans the security and prosperity that the EU has brought to Western Europe.

"To build a new Europe that rejects discrimination and narrow minded nationalism and bases itself instead on responsibility, dignity and democracy."

The prime minister was determined to hammer home the need for enlargement of the EU, with the prospect of lasting peace in the Balkans as one example of its benefits, ahead of the Nice gathering.

Mr Blair reminded today's meeting of the terror that had swept through the region in the past, saying: "The human cost has been horrific. Tens of thousands of our fellow Europeans killed, often in unspeakable massacres. Many people still missing. Hundreds of thousands made homeless ... piles of bodies in Bosnia unidentified to this day.

"These horrors have dishonoured all of us as Europeans."

Mr Blair called for a return to the rule of law and democracy in the region with trade barriers being relaxed to bring increasing economic prosperity.

The summit will discuss spending £2.4bn of EU aid in the region. But there was still ample evidence of tensions in the region.

The United Nations special representative in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, told the meeting: "There is a wall of blood between Serbs and Albanians. These are not my words. I was told these very words by the Kosovo Serb representative only four days ago."

Outside, a small, peaceful demonstration protested against the presence of the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, accusing him of being guilty of war crimes.

Hundreds of police and soldiers, equipped with water cannons, stood by in side streets in case trouble flared.

Later today, Mr Blair will have his first detailed discussions with Mr Kostunica before flying on to visit British troops still based in the region. He was flying back to London this afternoon.

fields.headline: Apathy sweeps to victory in byelection test
fields.standfirst:
Labour held on to the four contested seats, but most people chose not to vote at all, writes Guardian columnist David McKie

Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: Labour held on to the four contested seats, but most people chose not to vote at all, writes Guardian columnist David McKie
fields.body:
There's no doubt who came best out of last night's round of byelections, in Preston, West Bromwich and the Anniesland division of Glasgow, where vacancies had to be filled both for Westminster and for the Scottish parliament. This was a very good night for the Can't Be Bothered party, and a pretty dispiriting moment for anyone else.

It is easy to tell the story in terms of Labour majorities slashed: down from 18,680 to 4,426 in Preston; down from 15,154 to 6,337 in the Westminster contest at Anniesland. (You can't make any comparison for West Bromwich, since in May 1997 Betty Boothroyd stood as the Speaker Seeking Re-election and the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats did not put up candidates against her).

But these aren't the statistics that really matter. The lower the turnouts in byelections, the less figures for majorities and for swing from one side to the other tell you about the real electoral world. And these turnouts were very low: not as abject as at some of the previous byelections in this parliament, but a mere 38% in Scotland, 30% in Lancashire and 28% in the Midlands.

In these circumstances it makes sense to look at the figures in a less conventional way, and concentrate less on each party's share of the vote than on the proportion of the electorate which bothered to turn out for each of them. Analysed in this fashion, the story at Preston was this: around 13% of those entitled to vote took the trouble to go to the polling stations and mark their crosses for Labour. Some 7% did the same for the Tories; while 70% stayed at home.

In West Bromwich, the figures were very similar: 14% of those entitled to vote gave their support to Labour, 9% turned out for the Tories, 72% stayed away.

In Glasgow Anniesland, the figures for the Westminster election show 20% turning out for Labour, 8% for the Scottish National Party and 4% for the Tories, with 62% preferring to do something else. In the election for the Scottish parliament, the SNP did rather better than in the Westminster contest and Labour a little worse, but again the stayaways were the majority tendency at 62%.

So these contests were very much a minority preoccupation. In so far as one can detect the mood of the nation it seems to be this. People are not enthusiastic about this government. Of those who voted Labour in May 1997, roughly 70% defected in Preston this time, (a figure which no doubt reflects disputes in the local party over who should be its candidate), roughly 60% in West Bromwich, and just about half in Anniesland.

But there is no great enthusiasm either for trying to turn Labour out. In the great byelections of the Thatcher years, which helped engineer her eviction from office 10 years ago this week, what struck terror in Conservative hearts was not just Tory defections but the positive surge in Labour or Lib Dem support. There was little sign of a similar process here. The SNP vote in Anniesland, a seat where these great byelection fighters must have had some hope of making a splash, was down on May 1997. The Tories were no real threat to Labour - even in West Bromwich, where because of the reintroduction of party politics after the Boothroyd years they should have been raring to go.

In that context - and especially after the autumn of discontent which shook Labour so badly - Mr Blair today may be feeling a sense of reprieve. On the other hand, when he turns to the morning papers, and the headlines on Europe and beef and petrol prices (once more), he may well have started to feel queasy again.

In Glasgow Anniesland, the figures for the Westminster election show 20% turning out for Labour, 8% for the Scottish National Party and 4% for the Tories, with 62% preferring to do something else. In the election for the Scottish parliament, the SNP did rather better than in the Westminster contest and Labour a little worse, but again the stayaways were the majority tendency at 62%. So these contests were very much a minority preoccupation. In so far as one can detect the mood of the nation it seems to be this. People are not enthusiastic about this government. Of those who voted Labour in May 1997, roughly 70% defected in Preston this time, (a figure which no doubt reflects disputes in the local party over who should be its candidate), roughly 60% in West Bromwich, and just about half in Anniesland. But there is no great enthusiasm either for trying to turn Labour out. In the great byelections of the Thatcher years, which helped engineer her eviction from office 10 years ago this week, what struck terror in Conservative hearts was not just Tory defections but the positive surge in Labour or Lib Dem support. There was little sign of a similar process here. The SNP vote in Anniesland, a seat where these great byelection fighters must have had some hope of making a splash, was down on May 1997. The Tories were no real threat to Labour - even in West Bromwich, where because of the reintroduction of party politics after the Boothroyd years they should have been raring to go. In that context - and especially after the autumn of discontent which shook Labour so badly - Mr Blair today may be feeling a sense of reprieve. On the other hand, when he turns to the morning papers, and the headlines on Europe and beef and petrol prices (once more), he may well have started to feel queasy again. webTitle: Global warming: 'no deal possible' at Hague

fields.headline: 'No deal possible' at Hague
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Head of UN global warming summit says broad agreement is the best that can be hoped for.Special report: global warming
fields.body:
The head of a UN climate conference has told delegates no final deal on fighting global warming is possible at negotiations due to end tomorrow. It measn that a broad political accord is the best that can be hopde for.

Conference president Jan Pronk is now reported to be hoping for a political agreement on compromise proposals that he had submitted, setting out a broad outline of what countries sought to do.

The comments dimmed prospects for achieving the conference's formal goal - a legally-binding technical pact setting out concrete measures by developed countries to reduce global warming. Mr Pronk made his proposals in a paper aimed at breaking a deadlock between the United States and the European Union over ways to stop global warming.

With the deadline for an agreement to tackle global warming looming, both of the two main negotiating blocs at the UN climate conference criticized an emergency proposal as unacceptable. European Union delegates said the plan tabled by conference chairman Mr Pronk last night to break a deadlock over fundamental issues was bad for the environment, allowing countries too much leeway to avoid honouring greenhouse gas reductions they committed to three years ago in Kyoto, Japan.

The United States, which leads the other main negotiating group and was widely seen as the main beneficiary of the new proposal, released a statement saying it considered the plan "unacceptably imbalanced." The delegation canceled its daily press briefing, saying it did not want to jeopardise negotiations by airing details at that stage.

French environment minister Dominique Voynet, representing the EU, said the plan would actually permit greenhouse gas emissions to increase, instead of forcing them to decline.

However, both sides pledged their commitment to reaching a deal.

The major contentious issues surround US-sponsored proposals that involve so-called 'flexible mechanisms' - ways to meet the emission reduction targets with alternatives to scaling back the burning of fossil fuels.

The United States, along with Canada, Japan and Australia, known as the "umbrella group," want no limitations on alternatives such as the international trade of pollution allowances and the counting toward reduction targets of farmlands and forests because they take carbon dioxide out of the air.

Opponents say such programs give credit for doing nothing and would mean countries could pollute more than they otherwise would have been allowed to.

Under the Pronk plan, "you tolerate a 3 percent across the board increase in emissions by 2010," Voynet said. "We had an agreement for minus five point something. We are not here to undo that."

Environmental organizations were resting all their hopes on the EU. As delegations remained behind closed doors formulating their positions on the latest proposals, activists marched to the EU discussion room chanting: "EU stay strong; You can do it; save the climate."

"We believe this is a win for the United States," said Jennifer Morgan of World Wildlife Fund.

Negotiations have to finish tomorrow.

Roda Verheyen, of Friends of the Earth, told delegates: "Don't eat, don't sleep. The EU should salvage this proposal. The EU cannot give up now. It has to sit down and negotiate hard and not come home with a bad deal. This is totally unacceptable."
