webTitle: Bisto to put back the 'ahhh' in its marketing

fields.headline: Bisto to put back the 'ahhh' in its marketing
fields.standfirst: Click here for a still from the campaign
fields.trailText:
8am: Bisto is reviving the "Ahhh Bisto" tagline in a new £8m marketing drive, writes Claire Cozens.
Click here for a still from the campaign
fields.body:
Bisto is reviving the "Ahhh Bisto" tagline made famous by the Bisto kids in a new £8m marketing drive.

Owner Centura Foods dropped the line in the 1980s, when the urchin-style cartoon children also fell under the axe.

But the line is being revived in a modern format with a new TV campaign that focuses on family gatherings.

The advertising coincides with the launch of a new-look Bisto.

The gravy brand has undergone a redesign to give it a more modern and colourful look and will receive heavy in-store promotion.

Head of marketing Sue Knight said: "We've even reintroduced the 'Ahhh' as we know it still holds a warm place in the hearts of Bisto fans.

"The new packaging will differentiate our products from competitors and the accompanying in-store promotion support will ensure that retailers can clearly see that Bisto is a driving force."

The ads will appear during peak-time programmes, including Coronation Street, Emmerdale Farm, Brookside, Stars in their Eyes and Blind Date.

fields.headline: Raw talent
fields.standfirst: His photographs reveal more bare flesh than clothes - yet fashion editors can't get enough of him.  Josh Sims  meets Terry Richardson
fields.trailText: His photographs reveal more bare flesh than clothes - yet fashion editors can't get enough of him. Josh Sims meets Terry Richardson
fields.body:
For a top-flight fashion photographer, Terry Richardson has a somewhat over-developed love of nudity. Clothes often take second place to bare skin. He is perennially in a season of flesh tones, transparency so see-through it's invisible and micro-minis so micro they don't exist. Add to this his tendency to eschew the traditional glitz and glamour of fashion photography - in which every colour is techni, every lip glossed and every blemish airbrushed - in favour of the raw and undercooked, and it's a strange state of affairs that these days fashion editors just can't get enough of him.

Indeed, Richardson, whose first solo UK exhibition opens this week, is a gawky 35-year-old with mutton-chop sideburns and tache, dishevelled dress, seedy specs and a disarming line in being direct - more errant artist than fashion type. But though he has only been shooting fashion since the early 90s, his trademark technique has - along with those of Wolfgang Tilmans and Juergen Teller - played a key role in changing its ethos from one favouring images of heightened superficiality to ones that hastily catch a moment or begin a narrative. He takes the kind of intriguing, sometimes voyeuristic pictures in which no model is ever ready for her close-up, Mr De Mille.

"Fashion is all showbusiness and people hype but my work brings a sense of humour to fashion photography," Richardson says. "I aim to have that in everything I do. A lot of fashion photography can be very serious, very precious. The pictures don't make you smile, or horny, or anything really. They don't even seem human. They just record clothes. But to me photography is a document of what's going on in my life that day. It's personal, about whatever I'm feeling, whether it's fashion or nudes."

It was this individualistic attitude that in 1992 took Richardson from his home town of Hollywood, leaving the too-distant glimmerings of a career as a bassist in a hip-hop metal band, to Manhattan, with his camera. There his sometimes brutal coverage of the East Village underground scene in the early 90s had editors at first puzzled, then dismissive - and finally knocking down his door.

Richardson had always understood photography: his father is Bob Richardson, a seminal fashion photographer of the 60s and 70s. But his big break came when, after spending the early 90s slumming around the Big Apple with barely anything to eat but always something to shoot, he produced a story for the American music magazine Vibe. This was shown at the International Festival de la Mode in Paris in 1994, which led to a job shooting an ad campaign for Katharine Hamnett.

From there Richardson's documentary style took off in a flash - of the kind that creates plenty of red-eye. Work for i-D, Harper's Bazaar, Arena Homme Plus and several Vogues followed, as did ad campaigns for brands as giant and diverse as Levi's, H&M and West Cigarettes, and music videos for Death in Vegas and Primal Scream. His next projects include a third issue of Richardson, the magazine he launched last year to equal amounts of acclaim and tittering, a move into film and a shoot for the famed swimsuit issue of Sports Illustrated. Perhaps sadly for Richardson, the cossies will have to stay on.

"I just like the way men's and women's bodies are," he says. "They are all so different. They fascinate me. It can be sexy and everyone relates to sex. Most people have had it at least once in their lives. I like sex and I like women, and I guess any photographer wants to take pictures of the things they like. But there's also an innocence to nudes. After all, that's the way we enter the world. And it's a real beauty in that muscle, flab, hair, skin, texture. I just think it's cool, man!"

Not all the publications Richardson has worked for have felt the same; some have been uncomfortable with his nipple count, not to mention that of even more private parts of the anatomy, while the censor's scissors and magic markers have occasionally come out in force prior to publication of books of his work. But he likes "to shake things up a bit," he says. "And what one person takes offence at makes another giggle. You know certain images are going to ruffle conservative people and that's fun. I once took a picture of me that suggested I was having sex with a sheep, which caused all sorts of outraged responses, but to me and people who know me it was just fun."

Less gratuitously, it is more his eye for the bumps, dips, slides and hills of people's bodies that is exercised in his new exhibition. Sometimes anatomical, sometimes sculptural, this series of nudes goes beyond sheer shock value to capture an intimate dynamic between subject and sharp-shooter. For him, exposure means much more than light meters and film stock. One series, taken at a nudist camp, even features Richardson unclothed.

"I would never ask anyone to do what I wouldn't do myself," he says. "And besides, getting naked is kind of exhilarating. It's a trip. It makes you nervous but you move through it. It's strange but liberating. And when you take a picture of someone naked, it's interesting to see their reaction: some, usually the ones you least expect, are really shy and others get really excited. And I like to get right in there because they have to be comfortable with you - that's when you get a certain connection. And that can make for a beautiful moment."

fields.headline: Rumours unlimited
fields.trailText: Chelsea and Leeds are trying to bring Robbie Keane back to the Premiership, the Mail reports. Internazionale are reluctant to sell so soon after signing the Republic of Ireland striker for £13m from Coventry but are looking to loan him out. They would prefer to get him some Serie A experience at Reggina but Keane is "not thought to be enthusiastic" about going there. If he does return to England - and the Mail does not think it likely - Chelsea would appear to be the favourites to land him. They already have Christian Panucci on loan from Inter.
fields.body:
Chelsea and Leeds are trying to bring Robbie Keane back to the Premiership, the Mail reports. Internazionale are reluctant to sell so soon after signing the Republic of Ireland striker for £13m from Coventry but are looking to loan him out. They would prefer to get him some Serie A experience at Reggina but Keane is "not thought to be enthusiastic" about going there. If he does return to England - and the Mail does not think it likely - Chelsea would appear to be the favourites to land him. They already have Christian Panucci on loan from Inter.

Alen Boksic, the Middlesbrough and Croatia striker, has had talks with Panathinaikos, says the Mirror. He is top of the Athenian club's wanted list, says the Sun. But Bryan Robson "will attempt to see off any approach".

Leicester City have rejected another Celtic bid for Neil Lennon. The Express says it was £4m. Teamtalk says it was £8m.

Middlesbrough have had a £3m bid for the Republic of Ireland midfielder Rory Delap rejected by Derby County, the Express reports. Jim Smith has told Bryan Robson that the offer falls at least £1m short.

Aston Villa, the Star reports, are ready to unload their Israeli international left-back Najwan Ghrayib, a £1m signing from Hapoel Haifa who has started only one Premiership game in 16 months at Villa.

Fatih Terim is due to be the next Milan coach, Onefootball claims. Alberto Zaccheroni is due to succeed Sven-Goran Eriksson at Lazio, leaving the Milan job open for Terim, who is currently coaching Fiorentina. Barcelona, meanwhile, are chasing Fabio Capello, whose hand is thereby strengthened in his negotiations for a new contract at Roma.

Kevin Keegan is a target for Trabzonspor, Onefootball reports. The Turks are desperate for a big-name coach and have drawn up a short list that also includes Javier Clemente, the former Spain coach recently sacked by Real Sociedad.

Derby are also chasing Kevin Keegan, Team Talk reports. That is the 20-year-old Coleraine midfielder and Northern Irish youth international.

webTitle: Internet spreads word as networks shun adverts for Buy Nothing Day

fields.headline: Internet spreads word as networks shun adverts for Buy Nothing Day
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Today is America's Buy Nothing Day. An event that was started to poke pointed fun at consumerism is now being celebrated in more than 40 countries, embarrassing television networks and demonstrating the power of the internet as a political organising tool.
fields.body:
Today is America's Buy Nothing Day. An event that was started to poke pointed fun at consumerism is now being celebrated in more than 40 countries, embarrassing television networks and demonstrating the power of the internet as a political organising tool.

The campaign was the brainchild of Kalle Lasn, the founder of a Vancouver-based magazine, Adbusters, "the journal of the mental environment", and author of Culture Jam, an exploration of consumerism, globalisation and advertising.

The day, which encourages people not to bother shopping for what they do not really need, began in the Pacific north-west in 1993 and was taken up on the internet in 1995. Now it has expanded, from events in 30 countries last year to 45 this year.

In America, it takes place on the day after Thanksgiving Day, traditionally the biggest shopping day in the calendar, while in Europe it is held on the last Saturday in November, which this year falls tomorrow.

"Every year it gets bigger," said Lasn yesterday. "A lot of it is word of mouth." He said that many events were now being organised by groups with no connection to Adbusters.

In the best traditions of consumerism, the organisers had hoped to advertise the day on television. When they made their first attempt, last year, every major network found reasons why it could not run a commercial telling people not to buy anything.

A CBS spokesman told Adbusters: "This commercial is in opposition to the current economic policy of the United States."

Only CNN agreed to run the commercial after being told that a refusal would lead to an embarrassing story in the Wall Street Journal. This year the network agreed to run the ad, said Lasn, only to have an apparent change of heart.

"It was a very strange experience," he said. "When we first approached them they said 'no worries, no problems, there's plenty of time.' Then they told us all the spots were sold out."

Finally a compromise has been reached and the 30-second ad was due to be screened once only last night.

The commercial's voice-over explains why the networks might not have been keen to run it alongside other advertisements: "The average North American consumes five times more than a Mexican, 10 times more than a Chinese person, and 30 times more than a person from India.

"We are the most voracious consumers in the world ... A world ... could die because of the way we North Americans live. Give it a rest. November 24 is Buy Nothing Day."

But Lasn, an Estonian-born former documentary film-maker, said not everyone was impressed by the idea. "On radio talk-shows there are chamber of commerce types who can't believe what we're doing and they can be quite rambunctious. And people phone up and say 'if you don't like it in this country, then get out'."

But he said that the majority of reactions had been positive, with many ad hoc groups being set up around the world, covering everything from small towns in Hungary to shopping centres in Japan.

Last year in New York, thousands of activists took over Times Square for a dance party, while other protesters targeted what is said to be the world's longest shopping avenue in Panama City.

This year, Adbusters' campaigns manager, Tom Liacas, said yesterday, everything from "reclaim the streets" demonstrations to the exchange of free gifts is planned.

He attributes the increase in interest to both the power of the internet and the effect of anti-globalisation protests in Seattle last year.

"Since Seattle, there's a much larger audience for this sort of thing," he said. "People have been adapting the day to their own cultures so we won't really know the scope of what has been done until afterwards."

And people phone up and say 'if you don't like it in this country, then get out'." But he said that the majority of reactions had been positive, with many ad hoc groups being set up around the world, covering everything from small towns in Hungary to shopping centres in Japan. Last year in New York, thousands of activists took over Times Square for a dance party, while other protesters targeted what is said to be the world's longest shopping avenue in Panama City. This year, Adbusters' campaigns manager, Tom Liacas, said yesterday, everything from "reclaim the streets" demonstrations to the exchange of free gifts is planned. He attributes the increase in interest to both the power of the internet and the effect of anti-globalisation protests in Seattle last year. "Since Seattle, there's a much larger audience for this sort of thing," he said. "People have been adapting the day to their own cultures so we won't really know the scope of what has been done until afterwards." fields.headline: Ferdinand agrees deal with Leeds
fields.trailText: Rio Ferdinand will become the world's most expensive defender after agreeing personal terms with Leeds today.
fields.body:
Rio Ferdinand will become the world's most expensive defender after agreeing personal terms with Leeds today.

Ferdinand will complete his £18m transfer tomorrow, provided he passes a medical. He will then be introduced to Leeds fans before Sunday's Premiership match with Arsenal.

This morning Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale admitted that Ferdinand still has a few loose ends to tie up, including the details of his share of the deal, which should be £1.8m, from West Ham. But Ridsdale said the transfer would go through.

"The deal is done with the one remaining aspect being tomorrow's medical," he said. "Personal terms have been agreed and pleasingly from our perspective we have landed a player of Rio's calibre without going outside our existing wage structure."

Ferdinand, along with his Israeli agent Pinhas Zahavi, held a series of meetings with Ridsdale yesterday in London to finalise personal terms. After concluding negotiations this morning, the centre-back will sign a five-and-a-half year contract worth an estimated £30,000 a week - £9,000 more than he was earning at West Ham.

The deal puts Ferdinand among the top earners at Leeds alongside the likes of Harry Kewell and Nigel Martyn.

Zahavi confirmed: "Talks have been completed with Leeds and everything is okay. There were no problems on either side."

Ferdinand and Zahavi will sit down with the West Ham chairman Terry Brown today in the hope of settling the pay-off details.

The fee Leeds have paid shatters the previous world best for a defender of £13m paid by Roma for the Argentinian Walter Samuel and represents a British record after the £15m deals for Alan Shearer and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink.

Leeds had hoped the deal would be completed in time to beat today's noon registration deadline, allowing Ferdinand to make his debut against the Gunners. But he is now due to make his bow at Leicester in eight days' time.

The Ferdinand deal takes O'Leary's transfer spending in just over two years in charge at Leeds to an extraordinary £64.3m, with a net deficit of £42.35m.

fields.headline: Timeline of the rail crisis
fields.trailText: Here is a timeline of the rail crisis which has ensued since the Hatfield crash last month.
fields.body:
Here is a timeline of the rail crisis which has ensued since the Hatfield crash last month.

17 October: The Hatfield rail disaster kills four and injures 33. The Railtrack chief executive, Gerald Corbett, tenders his resignation.

18 October: It emerges that Railtrack knew for six months that the GNER line, which had a broken rail, was faulty.

19 October: Paddington rail crash survivors urge Mr Corbett not to resign. Mr Corbett's resignation is later refused by Railtrack.

20 October: Mr Corbett secures a £5bn grant from the regulator for safety.

22 October: There is a memorial service for Hatfield victims. Mr Corbett attends.

24 October: Railtrack shuts Scottish end of the West Coast Mainline from Glasgow to London with no warning to commuters. A total of 165 speed restrictions are imposed.

26 October: Another derailment at Virginia Water in Surrey when four carriages carrying 150 to 200 passengers on the 8.21am South West trains service from Weybridge to Staines went through a red light. The number of speed restrictions increased to almost 300 and 2,000 cracks are found in railways around the country.

27 October: Mr Corbett is summoned to Downing Street to discuss safety.

30 October: Mr Corbett's claims about the duration of repairs prove incorrect and it emerges that work will take two months longer than expected. The worst storms since 1987 begin. The proportion of track disrupted hits 70%, some 20,000 miles. Just 10% of GNER services run.

1 November: Mr Corbett gives evidence to the Select Committee for Transport and blames Balfour Beatty, the maintenance firm, for not detecting the damage.

2 November: The deputy prime minister, Mr Prescott, refuses to back Mr Corbett.

5 November: Allegations are made in The Mirror that Railtrack execs went on a drinking binge hours after the Hatfield disaster.

9 November: The prime minister, Tony Blair, meets Mr Corbett and other rail executives and orders them to produce a Christmas timetable within a week.

10 November: Mr Corbett apologises to victims of the Paddington and Southall rail crashes after reducing some to tears by saying that rail safety was "like a journey where you never arrive."

11 November: The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, criticises Railtrack for a "culture of complacency" over the broken rails.

13 November: Railtrack announce 5% increase in dividends to shareholders, despite a 31% slump in profits to £175m.

15 November: Railtrack pledges to bail out the train operators to keep them in business and cancels parties because the company is in "corporate mourning".

16 November: Mr Corbett and other rail chiefs meet Mr Blair again to discuss compensation for passengers. It is revealed that delays will continue into next year.

17 November: Mr Corbett resigns.

24 November: A rail expert is reported to have told ministers that the speed restrictions might actually be prejudicial to safety. It also emerges that some rail firms may be "let off" paying poor performance penalties as the industry reportedly loses £2m a day.

fields.headline: You bet your life: week 15
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. How long can it last?
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.13, Sean Ingle = £110.77, Football Unlimited punters collective = £62.50 and Paul MacInnes = £56.46.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £160.13, Sean Ingle = £110.77, Football Unlimited punters collective = £62.50 and Paul MacInnes = £56.46.

Scott Murray is on holiday.

Sean Ingle Eintracht Frankfurt to beat Hertha Berlin. £10 @ 6/5

At first - and perhaps even on second - glance, Eintracht Frankfurt's match against Hertha Berlin has a huge "avoid like the plague" sign around it. Eintracht are fifth in Bundesliga, while Hertha lie third. It could be anybody's game, couldn't it? Well

Dig a little deeper and - like any good episode of Poirot with David Suchet - a different story emerges. Eintracht boast the second best home record in the Bundesliga - with five wins and a draw - while Hertha are horrible away from home, with two wins and four defeats.

What's more, Hertha have yet to beat a side from the top half of the table (three draws and four defeats) this season, and last week lost 4-0 at home to Schalke 04. Therefore I think it's entirely reasonable that Eintracht will beat Hertha more than five times out of 11, which is why I'm staking a tenner on it.

Mark Slade is this week's member of the Punters Collective. £5 Treble: Manchester City v Ipswich: Ipswich to win @ 13/8, Middlesbrough v Bradford: Boro to win @ 5/6 and Rangers v Celtic: Celtic to win @ 6/4.

Monday's night rather dour affair against Coventry also showed that Ipswich know how to grind out a result while not playing at their best. As for Man City, well, they are that common Joe Royle breed a kick-and-rush side, who have struggled against worse teams than Ipswich (notably Coventry) and I think they are there for the taking on Saturday. 13/8 is too big a price to be ignored.

You might be thinking: "Has Slade lost his marbles?" But Middlesbrough will not play a worse team this season at the Riverside than Bradford. If Boro were in any sort of form at home, they would be a much shorter price than what Blue Square are offering (maybe around 4/7), and as such, I think the 5/6 is worth taking the risk on.

My final bet is Celtic to beat Rangers. Auld Firm derbies are always interesting affairs, and this one more so - given what appears to be such a wide gulf between the two teams this season ... but can we apply the maxim here of throwing the form book out of the window with derby matches? Well, in a word, no. Form must come into it somewhere along the line. And Celtic ARE in form, while Rangers, quite patently, are not, and 6/4 for Celtic in any Scottish game is not to be sneezed at - especially in an Auld Firm game where they have a fantastic chance of winning. It may not be 6-2 again, but who cares as long as the Bhoys win? Get on that 6/4, I'm telling ya.

Paul MacInnes Spurs v Leicester: £5 draw @ 9/4

A good holiday, they say, recharges the batteries like nothing else. Well they have obviously never spent two weeks contracting gastric diseases in a Thai backwater. But there you go. What matters most of all is that I'm back and ready to fritter more of somebody else's money on wagers that look perfectly reasonable before the event.

And this week is no different. A fiver has been placed on a draw between Spurs and Leicester at White Hart Lane. It's Spurs' great home record against Leicester's imperious defence and I believe neither will be enough to get a result. Of course, the fact that there has been only one draw between these two sides in the past three seasons might suggest otherwise, but I'm not listening.

fields.headline: Rail firms losing £2m a day
fields.trailText: The rail industry is losing £2m in revenue a day because of the chaos caused from flooding and post-Hatfield crash repairs and some rail experts believe current speed restrictions are actually prejudicial to safety, it was revealed today.
fields.body:
The rail industry is losing £2m in revenue a day because of the chaos caused from flooding and post-Hatfield crash repairs and some rail experts believe current speed restrictions are actually prejudicial to safety, it was revealed today.

A sense of rail meltdown was compounded as cash-strapped train companies were revealed to be in urgent talks with the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority to see if they can be "let off" penalty payments for poor performance.

One company - GB Railways, which runs the Anglia route - is seeking new franchise terms to ease its financial plight.

The extent of the daily financial losses was revealed by the Association of Train Operating Companies.

It came after a report in the Economist magazine which said the SSRA chairman, Sir Alastair Morton, had privately told government ministers that passengers would be safer if post-Hatfield speed restrictions were removed and trains allowed to run normally.

On the question of penalties, the SSRA today dismissed the Economist report as "idle speculation", but did confirm it was talking to a number of train companies about the possibility of waiving penalty payments.

A spokeswoman for the authority said: "One of our jobs is to try to assist train operating companies (TOCs) where this is necessary.

"We have said that each TOC, if they feel they are in a financial situation due to the events of October, if they put a case to the SSRA, their case will be looked at and judged."

She added: "If we feel it is necessary, we will relax the penalty payment rules, because of the unusual circumstances of October. A lot of the problems are not down to the TOCs.

"It is not a blanket relaxation. Each company will be dealt with on a case-by-case basis."

A spokesman for the Association of Train Operating Companies said: "Passengers should be reminded that although some companies have been particularly badly hit by the delays, there are 10 companies who have been relatively unaffected.

"Companies offering inter-city routes have faced the biggest financial loss, while some lines have escaped with only very few temporary speed restrictions."

Drivers are currently having to consult up to 16 pages of special directions on changes to speed limits introduced after the Hatfield crash, increasing the chance that they might pass a red signal, the Economist also claimed.

Professor Andrew Evans, of University College London, a transport expert, said the rail improvement programme was costing lives as it forced passengers on to the much more dangerous roads.

Asked to estimate the effect the switch from rail to road was having on fatal accident figures he said: "I think about one a week, possibly one fatality a week.

"It certainly does not make sense if the object of the exercise is to minimise the number of premature deaths."

The shadow transport minister, Bernard Jenkin, said the work being carried out did not make sense. He blamed the government for forcing the train companies to act irrationally.

Meanwhile, disgruntled rail passengers, sick of months of delays, stormed off of a train and began walking across the tracks, a traveller said today.

The revolt came after a failed train, said to have run out of fuel, held up the service on the Leeds to Skipton line in West Yorkshire, which has been plagued by delays since July.

Passengers feared they were once again going to be abandoned at the station at Keighley, West Yorkshire.

One group, including regular commuter Keith Norris, went to warn the driver that he must complete his journey.

But others simply quit the train in dismay, Mr Norris told the BBC Radio 4 Today programme.

He said: "I do understand people did actually get off and cross the track which, to be honest, I have been travelling by train for 12 years and nobody I know would have dared attempt that. It was stupidity really."

fields.headline: Robson Green makes case for ITV
fields.trailText: 12.45pm TV overnights:Robson Green handed ITV an easy triumph over BBC1's Holby City last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Robson Green's latest turn as a Geordie lawyer in Close and True gave ITV an easy triumph over BBC1's drama opposition, Holby City, last night.

Close and True - featuring Billy Elliot star Jamie Bell in his TV debut - stars Robson as a London-based commercial lawyer who returns to his Newcastle roots to defend a friend accused of murder and ends up staying.

The 90-minute opener for a six-part ITV series averaged 8.2m and a 37% share from 9-10.30pm, according to unofficial overnights.

Holby City, which has been moved to a 9pm Thursday slot after ITV put Millionaire against it at 8pm, found no respite in its new slot.

The BBC1 drama averaged 5.2m and a 23% share.

fields.headline: Hello! in talks with Mail to fight 'common enemy'
fields.standfirst: Nov 24: Hello! scores PR coup
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: Hello! has hinted at joining with the Daily Mail on future celebrity exclusives to fight the 'common enemy' of the Express and OK!.
Nov 24: Hello! scores PR coup
fields.body:
Hello! publishing director Sally Cartwright has hinted at a link-up with the Daily Mail on future celebrity exclusives to combat the new "common enemy" of the Express and OK!.

Speaking to MediaGuardian.co.uk, Ms Cartwright confirmed that she had held preliminary talks with the Daily Mail.

She said: "We don't have any specific plans at the moment but we have discussed the fact that we now have a common enemy."

Ms Cartwright shrugged off suggestions that the fact that pictures of the wedding of Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas, a supposed OK! exclusive, also appeared in Hello! would discourage celebrities from doing lucrative deals in future.

She said: "I don't think the incident will have a major impact on celebrities in the UK.

"Although celebrities do have a certain amount of control with Hello! and OK!, there have always been things they have no control over. They have never been able to prevent people taking photographs in a public place.

"If this helps to bring down the market rate for celebrity exclusives I'll be very happy."

Hello! scored a coup when a court threw out an application by Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones and OK! publisher Northern & Shell to prevent publication of some "snatched" wedding photographs.

Ms Cartwright said the case - which invoked the new Human Rights Act - had "considerable ramifications" for the UK media.

She said: "The difficulty the court had in making a judgement was that they were looking at a new area of law, invoking the new Human Rights Act.

"Whatever decision was made would have a massive impact on UK media in the future."

She said she had been told by people in publishing that a victory for OK! magazne would have set a precedent, making it very difficult for newspapers, magazines and even book publishers to publish anything "unauthorised".

"Magazines and newspapers scoop each other all the time. It's just the way we operate. A leopard can't change its spots.

"One publisher told me that if OK! had won a book publisher would not have been able to run unauthorised biographies.

"The courts weren't saying we were necessarily right, just that an injunction is not an appropriate way to deal with the situation."

Over the past three years the price of exclusive star deals has rocketed with OK! paying a reputed £1.2m into a charitable trust set up by Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas.

She denied speculation that Hello! had done a deal with the Sun, which today splashed on one of the pictures from the issue, and added that she did not know who had taken the snaps.

The stakes have been raised for Hello! by the acquisition of the Express Group by Northern & Shell, which owns its arch-rival OK! magazine.

New owner Richard Desmond has told his staff he wants the Express titles to work more closely with the magazine.

"Although celebrities do have a certain amount of control with Hello! and OK!, there have always been things they have no control over. They have never been able to prevent people taking photographs in a public place. "If this helps to bring down the market rate for celebrity exclusives I'll be very happy." Hello! scored a coup when a court threw out an application by Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones and OK! publisher Northern & Shell to prevent publication of some "snatched" wedding photographs. Ms Cartwright said the case - which invoked the new Human Rights Act - had "considerable ramifications" for the UK media. She said: "The difficulty the court had in making a judgement was that they were looking at a new area of law, invoking the new Human Rights Act. "Whatever decision was made would have a massive impact on UK media in the future." She said she had been told by people in publishing that a victory for OK! magazne would have set a precedent, making it very difficult for newspapers, magazines and even book publishers to publish anything "unauthorised". "Magazines and newspapers scoop each other all the time. It's just the way we operate. A leopard can't change its spots. "One publisher told me that if OK! had won a book publisher would not have been able to run unauthorised biographies. "The courts weren't saying we were necessarily right, just that an injunction is not an appropriate way to deal with the situation." Over the past three years the price of exclusive star deals has rocketed with OK! paying a reputed £1.2m into a charitable trust set up by Catherine Zeta Jones and Michael Douglas. She denied speculation that Hello! had done a deal with the Sun, which today splashed on one of the pictures from the issue, and added that she did not know who had taken the snaps. The stakes have been raised for Hello! by the acquisition of the Express Group by Northern & Shell, which owns its arch-rival OK! magazine. New owner Richard Desmond has told his staff he wants the Express titles to work more closely with the magazine.

webTitle: Bitter memories linger for Saatchi brothers

fields.headline: Bitter memories linger for Saatchi brothers
fields.standfirst:
The rivalry between M&C Saatchi and Saatchi & Saatchi has a dark history, which makes Maurice and Charles' latest victory extra sweet.
Nov 24: Saatchi brothers overtake arch-rivals
fields.trailText:
12pm: Rivalry between M&C Saatchi and Saatchi & Saatchi has a dark history, which makes Maurice and Charles' latest victory extra sweet, writes Jade Garrett.
Nov 24: Saatchi brothers overtake arch-rivals
fields.body:
Memories of M&C Saatchi's birth, amid the bitterness of the biggest bust-up in UK advertising history, are hard to forget.

The brothers, Maurice and Charles, who are of Jewish-Iraqi origin, set up Saatchi & Saatchi in 1970.

By 1986, it had become the world's largest advertising agency, with clients including the Conservative party, for whom it crafted the "Labour isn't Working" campaign.

The controversial campaign, featuring a lengthy dole queue, clinched the brothers' position as Lady Thatcher's favourite advertising bosses.

Their creativity continued in slogans for British Airways, "The world's favourite airline", and Castlemaine lager, "Australians wouldn't give a XXXX for anything else".

Maurice and Charles were ousted from S&S in 1995 and since then have built M&C into one of the UK's most successful ad agencies.

Today, Maurice is the Conservative party's treasury spokesman in the House of Lords, while Charles has become an important patron of the arts.

M&C Saatchi's performance during 1999 led it to be named Campaign magazine's agency of the year.

An outstanding new-business record - which included the capture of Rover cars, along with a great deal of work from Sainsbury's and BT - saw it outshine any other agency in London.

M&C had proved it could contest and win significant new business on its own merits and not only because of the high-level contacts of its founding partners.

The agency has gone from a standing start in 1995 to the number six spot in the agency billings table, one place above Saatchi & Saatchi, with a 7.3% rise in the year to September 2000. (Figures from AC Nielson.)

Its success has made the agency an attractive target for potential buyers but Maurice vowed this year that he will never sell a majority stake in the agency.

webTitle: Saatchi brothers beat namesake rival for billings

fields.headline: Saatchi brothers overtake namesake in billings table
fields.standfirst: Bitter memories: comment by Jade Garrett
fields.trailText:
10.30am: M&C Saatchi has stormed up the ad agency billings table to overtake old rival Saatchi & Saatchi. By Jade Garrett.
Bitter memories: comment by Jade Garrettl
fields.body:
M&C Saatchi has stormed up the latest ad agency billings table to overtake its old rival Saatchi & Saatchi.

Maurice and Charles Saatchi, the advertising brothers, were at the centre of the biggest bust-up in UK advertising history when they were famously ousted from Saatchi & Saatchi in 1995.

The same year they launched M&C Saatchi and went on to secure big business from British Airways, Rover Cars, Sainsbury's, Sega Europe and NatWest.

The latest advertising billings league table from AC Nielson for the year to September reveals that M&C has overtaken S&S for the first time in its history.

M&C has climbed two places to sixth position with billings of £243m, an increase on the year of 7.3%.

Meanwhile, S&S has slumped two places to seventh position with billings of £234m - a fall of 13%.

Although the gap between the two agencies is small, the change in rankings is an important psychological victory for the Saatchi brothers.

Maurice Saatchi said today: "I am very proud of both the companies that we have created. The new agency was a very happy accident. It was never planned on our part so consequently, we never had a plan.

"The average age at the agency is 28 so there is a certain youthful energy. We seem to have hit on a format that works very well and operates well in the age of global consolidation so it may well be possible to continue as an independent.

"This is a very happy ship and to keep it that way is some achievement."

The rise still leaves the brothers a long way short of the table leader, Abbott Mead Vickers, which has billings of £399m.

webTitle: Lucy Liu's passion for Man U

fields.headline: Lucy Liu's passion for Man U
fields.standfirst: Plus: Mike Myers and Bryan Singer team up for biopic of TV star with a secret life; Joanne Harris follows up Chocolat with another script - but not for three years
fields.trailText: Plus: Mike Myers and Bryan Singer team up for biopic of TV star with a secret life; Joanne Harris follows up Chocolat with another script - but not for three years
fields.body:
Charlie's Angel and Ally McBeal star Lucy Liu has admitted to an unlikely passion - for Manchester United. In keeping with most of the club's fans across the world, however, Lucy has yet to set foot in Manchester, let alone see her side play. On her first visit to the UK, she told reporters that she started supporting the Red Devils when she found out that she had relatives in northern England. Her all-time favourite player is David Beckham. "I think he's lovely. "He's definitely the best player." Posh had better watch out.

 Mike Myers and X-Men director Bryan Singer are negotiating to star in and direct, respectively, Confessions of a Dangerous Mind. The $35m (£25m) project, which is scheduled to start shooting next February or March, has been written by Being John Malkovich scribe Charlie Kaufman. The film will tell the bizarre story of Chuck Barris, the host of the 1970s TV hit The Gong Show who also led a secret life as a CIA hitman.

 Following the acclaimed big screen version of her 1999 best-selling novel Chocolat, which will be released in the UK on February 16 2001, Joanne Harris is adapting her next work for the big screen, three years prior to its publication. Production company Contagious has bought the film rights to the book, entitled Coastliners, at the first draft manuscript stage, ahead of its planned publication in 2003.

webTitle: US election: A general without an army

fields.headline: A general without an army
fields.standfirst:
Al Gore wants the White House more than George W Bush, but the Democrats are reluctant, writes Martin Kettle in Washington

Special report: the US election
fields.trailText: Al Gore wants the White House more than George W Bush, but the Democrats are reluctant, writes Martin Kettle in Washington.
fields.body:
This battle for the White House can now be expressed in two complementary but unequal propositions. Al Gore wants the presidency more than George W Bush, while the Republicans want the presidency more than the Democrats.

The contest has now become a battle not just of votes but of wills. No one can doubt that Mr Gore has the will to win it. He has spent his life attempting to win the White House. He is nothing if not focused. He calls himself a fighter, and he believes that fighting is admirable. Every report from behind the Gore lines tells of a man wholly engaged, commanding every move, utterly dedicated to the goal of victory.

The same cannot, however, be said of his party. Sure, the Democrats wanted to win the White House on November 7 rather than lose it. But the enthusiasm was always a little bit forced. Mr Gore never commanded hearts as opposed to minds. Even since November 7, the party's mood has ebbed and flowed.

Within only a couple of days of the recount starting in Florida, there were words of caution coming from Dick Gephardt, Bob Torricelli and John Breaux. Don't push it too far, they said. Don't go beyond the limit.

In the second week of the Florida dispute, Democratic ranks mostly pulled together. Doubts were swallowed for a few days. But by last weekend, reluctance was sniffing the breeze once again. Even as he went to Florida to speak up for Mr Gore on the military vote dispute at the start of this week, Senator Bob Kerrey was signalling an amber light. This must not go on indefinitely, he said. He even hinted that Mr Gore agreed with him.

If there is one man in this whole drama who looks to be right out of it, that man is George W Bush. Everything he says and does speaks of the mirror image of Mr Gore. Mr Bush is not engaged. He is marginal. He is not even, one senses, entirely on top of what is going on in Florida. His minders want to create the impression of a dignified and patient man, reading the new biography of Joe DiMaggio, but what comes over is a man somehow out of his depth. Are you going to appeal against the Florida Supreme Court ruling, he was asked in Austin on Wednesday morning? Ask Jim Baker, he replied. Jim's a good man, he's in charge of that. This is the Mr Bush who campaigned as a leader, remember.

Among senior Republicans, on the other hand, the mood is for war. The anger is visceral. The determination to prevail is wholehearted and genuine. They are going to fight by any means to hand - which now includes trying to get the federal courts to crush a state court, something which until November 7 would have been apostasy for the entire party.

But not now. Where the Democrats on Capitol Hill are anxious not to be drawn into a battle they may not win, the Republicans are uninhibited. The crowds on the streets are Republicans now, not Democrats. The Florida legislature is bursting to continue its fight with the state Supreme Court. In Washington, leaders of the Gingrich battalions like Dick Armey and Tom DeLay are itching for another scrap with the Clinton-Gore AntiChrist, prepared if necessary to use their narrow majority in the House of Representatives to pitch Mr Bush into the White House. If Mr Gore had any sense he would pray for the Republicans to do precisely that. Nothing would diminish Mr Bush's presidency more than to receive it from the hands of Mr DeLay.

The mood of political America was well captured in a poll that came out, largely unremarked, at the start of the week. Democratic voters were asked if they would regard Mr Bush, should he prevail, as an illegitimate president. Some 25% of them said yes. Then, Republican voters were asked the selfsame question about Mr Gore, should he become the president. This time, 41% said they would regard him as an illegitimate leader.

It's important to realise what all this means. Whoever wins, most Americans say they will accept the result. We're not on the verge of civil war, or even of civil disorder. But the sense of outrage is much stronger on the right than it is on the left. In a battle between a general without an army and an army without a general, force of numbers seems the more likely to prevail.

webTitle: First signings for fledgling dance music site

fields.headline: Dance music site revealed
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Online media company Que Pasa Media yesterday launched the first phase of its youth-focused website, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Online media company Que Pasa Medi yesterday launched the first phase of its consumer website, burnitblue.com.

It plans to fully launch the dance music website, targeted at 16 to 34-year-olds, at the beginning of December.

In addition, Que Pasa is planning to set up a sales network for other youth-focused music sites, on which Que Pasa Media will sell advertising and sponsorship.

A cross-media campaign, handled by Naked Communications, Mother and specialist music buying agency MJ Media, is to support the launch.

Burnitblue will be advertised in the dance music press and through posters, student and online media and club promotions.

Que Pasa was set up by a team of former youth publishers, including Mark Maddox, former managing editor of music publisher DMC, who is chief executive officer.

Nick Green, previously at the Guardian's New Media Lab (the precursor to Guardian Unlimited) and DMC, is creative director.

Hugh Burrows, formerly music advertising director at Emap, is commercial director.

The company is seeking new backers, having received seed funding from incubator Brainspark. increasing. Last week, United News & Media's new media division, Xilerate, bought a 46.5% stake in clubbing portal Spaced.

webTitle: What the Middle East papers say

fields.headline: What the Middle East papers say
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel & Middle East
fields.trailText: A burgeoning cyber war is one result of the current violence, reports Derek Brown, while the newspapers swing from intolerance to reason.
fields.body:
One of the main factors to have bedevilled the Holy Land for generations is that each community sees itself as the entirely innocent victim of the other's aggression. This comes across clearly on webpages like those of the Al-Quds Intifada information site which offers an up-to-the-minute updating of Israeli army actions.

On the other side of the looking glass, the Jerusalem Post lays all the blame for the violence on Palestinian president Yasser Arafat. This morning's editorial argues that Arafat is aiming to extract concessions by force, and drive Israel back behind its pre-1967 borders [in other words, giving up the West Bank, East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip, all occupied since the Six Day War].

The paper pleads for a government of national unity to convince Arafat - and the Americans - that Israel will give up nothing more. The much more liberal daily, Ha'aretz, pours scorn on the rightwingers whom the Post wants to see in government. Today's editorial says the right is calling for military action, but points out the rather obvious fact that the Israeli Defence Forces are already in full cry.

The paper urges prime minister Ehud Barak not to ally himself with those seeing only a military solution: "Barak does not have to co-opt political partners who see giving military advice as their main role. He was chosen, and received a public mandate, to seek a permanent peaceful agreement on the basis of an orderly political program. Barak, who all through the period of the Intifada has tried to calm down the hotheads, and to respond with an eye on the negotiating table, even as the shooting goes on, does not need more hotheads sitting at his table."

The excellent fortnightly news magazine, Jerusalem Report, has a fascinating account of a new front in the conflict: attempts by Palestinian and Israeli computer hackers to attack each other's sites. The magazine quotes an Arab email message which is flashing round the cyberworld: "The more money they [the Israelis]lose in fixing and strengthening their systems means less money to buy bullets and rockets for use against our children... Maybe you can't hold a gun and fight, but you can contribute to the struggle."

The magazine says the 'electronic jihad' is working: more than 60 Israeli-linked websites, including those of the army, the prime minister and the parliament, have been broken into and defaced, or else saturated with email. Israeli hackers have responded in kind.

In one attack, they deposited a caricature of Yasser Arafat as a pig, on an Arab business site. Such childish antics, the magazine fears, could be the harbinger of "Cyber War I", with full scale assaults on sensitive military, political and commercial computer networks.

The first-class Arabia.com website also examines what it calls the "cyber intifada", which has developed rapidly from being a simple means of sharing views on the net: "As Intifada activities continued on the ground, the Intifada of the Internet began moving away from simply sharing news items and expressing anger over bias articles often located in mainstream western media, to a greater level of networking.

"Palestinians, Arabs, Muslims and their sympathizers began spontaneous yet elaborate channels of contact regarding scheduled protests and rallies, mainly in the United States and Europe. Activists instructed each other where and when pro-Palestinian demonstrations were taking place, how to get there and many other details. Some activists composed special instructions on the most effective styles of demonstrating, while others advised how even small demonstrations can get media attention."

Such sophisticated inquiries are not for the likes of al-Ahram weekly, published in Cairo. Its latest issue is full of venomous attacks on Israel - and on Jews: "The Israeli army has apparently given Jewish settlers free rein to torment and murder Palestinians, particularly in areas adjacent to Jewish settlements in the West Bank. The settlers, armed with automatic rifles and submachine guns, are not only complicit in violence but have whole-heartedly taken part in Israel's bloody rampage. But what is perhaps the most disturbing is their fanatic ideology that dehumanises non-Jews."

fields.headline: France makes u-turn on BSE
fields.standfirst: France has done a staggering about-turn on BSE - and nobody in the UK has objected, writes Andrew Osborn
fields.trailText: France has done a staggering about-turn on BSE - and nobody in the UK has objected, writes Andrew Osborn.
fields.body:
There are u-turns and there are huge u-turns, but France managed to pull off what must rate, by even its own standards, as an astonishing volte-face this week over BSE and nobody in the UK objected - not even the Tories.

As fears over the safety of French beef multiplied and countries such as Italy and Spain queued up to say "non" to Gallic meat imports, Paris began to panic and look for a way out of the crisis which threatens to decimate its farming industry.

Jean Glavany, France's pugnacious terrier-like farm minister, led the charge: the import bans on French beef were unfair and must be lifted forthwith, he thundered at a marathon meeting of EU agriculture ministers in Brussels.

Desperate to appease his country's militant farmers and anxious to bolster consumer confidence in French beef, which is draining away by the hour, the Frenchman demanded that countries which slap a unilateral ban on his country's meat must produce scientific evidence to support their action.

Seventeen hours later a deal was struck: EU veterinary experts would evaluate the evidence provided by the offending countries and make their own minds up on whether a ban on French beef could be scientifically justified.

"It's a miraculous result, an unhoped-for success," Glavany crowed after the all-night talks wound up. "I certainly hope that these measures can be lifted as soon as possible on the grounds they are not justified."

No wonder he was pleased - he had just completed a u-turn of jaw dropping proportions and got away with it. For the principal reason why France says it cannot lift its own illegal ban on British beef imports is because it regrets that it cannot accept the opinion of the very same panel of EU experts.

Instead, Paris steadfastly maintains that the only people worth listening to are its own scientists who continue to think that "le boeuf britannique" is still not safe.

It was only last year that the EU scientists issued their opinion that British beef is in their view safe to eat and said there was no justification to ban the meat.

But France disagreed and remains the only member state to keep a ban in place, and, as a result, faces legal action in the European Court of Justice.

So how, you may wonder, can France choose to disregard the EU scientists' advice on British beef but all of a sudden be ready to abide by their opinion on French beef?

Double standards, crushing hypocrisy and naked opportunism have all been suggested as possible motives in the past week by various observers, but Monsieur Glavany for one was keeping mum on the night and repeatedly refused to be drawn on the issue.

He could, however, be in for a nasty shock. For if EU scientists decide that a member state is justified in restricting French imports, the European Commission could turn the action into an EU-wide measure, applying it to all countries.

The scientists have until the end of the month to pronounce on the bans. But if they do agree with countries such as Italy, Spain, Austria and the Netherlands, which have all moved to restrict French beef imports in the past weeks, will France still continue to have faith in their judgement or will it return to its former scepticism?

webTitle: Internet giving race-hate groups new lease of life, EU watchdog says

fields.headline: Internet giving race-hate groups new lease of life, EU watchdog says
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Racism and anti-semitism has proliferated on the internet, spawning more than 2,100 websites, the European Union's racism monitoring unit reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Racism and anti-semitism has proliferated on the internet, spawning more than 2,100 websites, the European Union's racism monitoring unit reported yesterday.

Most of the sites are based in the US, but in Germany alone, the internal security service recorded the existence of 300 registered hate websites last year, up from 200 in 1998.

"What was proscribed, undercover, shameful and liable to prosecution in the past is today readily available and viewable on the net," the European monitoring centre on racism and xenophobia said in its annual report.

"Movements which were in decline in both Europe and the US have received a new lease of life thanks to the sites they have created."

Increases in violent racially motivated incidents were reported last year in France, Germany and Sweden, but differing definitions and statistical methods made EU-wide comparisons difficult, it said.

In Britain, racist incidents recorded by police rose by 66% per cent to 23,05. This was believed to be a result of better recording and the wider definition applied to such incidents after the inquiry into the 1993 murder of Stephen Lawrence in London.

The report also said that racism in police and security forces was a problem across the continent. In Belgium, for example, one in nine violent incidents was blamed on police and gendarmes.

Beate Winkler, the centre's director, pointed to worrying discrepancies between official and unofficial reporting of racist violence: the Netherlands figure was 200 incidents for 1999, but the Anne Frank Foundation estimated that the true number ranged between 800 and 8,000.

The EU centre had an uncomfortable few months this year because it is situated in the Austrian capital, Vienna, the target of unprecedented sanctions by all 14 other member states after Jörg Haider's anti-immigrant Freedom Party entered government after doing well in national elections.

In the 1999 election campaign in Austria "a climate of fear and intolerance was ... stoked up against the immigrant and Jewish community," the report said.

Jean Kahn, director of the Vienna centre, said he wanted anti-racism measures agreed in the EU's Amsterdam treaty - which was ratified in 1997 - fully implemented in all member states. And the chairman of the European parliament's citizens' rights committee, Graham Watson, argued that clear rules had to be set governing when a member state could be suspended for failing to meet accepted standards on democracy and human rights.

Some governments want this written clearly into the treaty of Nice, due to be drawn up at the EU summit on the Cte d'Azur next month.

fields.headline: Who is Jonathan King?
fields.standfirst: Jonathan King charged with child sex abuse
fields.trailText: Jonathan King, a veteran of the British music industry, inundated the charts throughout the 1970s with a string of "bubblegum" pop  hits.
fields.body:
Jonathan King, a veteran of the British music industry, inundated the charts throughout the 1970s with a string of "bubblegum" pop hits.

In a career that spanned 15 years, the millionaire pop mogul, 55, who lives in London's Bayswater, got into the Top 30 time after time with "hits" including Paloma Blanca, Lick A Smurf For Christmas, Loop di Love by Shag, and Leap Up And Down And Wave Your Knickers In The Air, by St Cecilia.

The flamboyant dresser, famed for his large round glasses, T-shirts and baseball caps, rose to meteoric success whilst still at student at Cambridge University.

It was at the tender age of 15 that the then Kenneth King decided he wanted to be a pop singer, and changed his name to Jonathan.

In 1965, at the age of 21, while reading English at Cambridge, he had his first Number One record, Everyone's Gone To The Moon. At 22 he became manager of Decca Records, and at 25 launched his own record label, UK Records, going on to churn out hit records, some under his own name and many under pseudonyms.

King once claimed that he had 20 records in the Top 30 under 20 different aliases. In the 1980s, fed-up with the pop world, he moved into the media, devising the TV show Entertainment USA, which he presented on BBC2, and the teen music programme No Limits.

He also dabbled in writing, with his novel, Bible Two, and as a controversial pop columnist for The Sun. But he was dropped as a radio DJ by Talk Radio after his show proved to be a ratings flop.

The talkative music industry maestro once dubbed pop success Robbie Williams "talentless". In 1995, King took it upon himself to make the year's British entry to The Eurovision Song Contest more credible than previous entries, with Dublin band Love City Groove.

His band and pop act discovery successes have included Genesis, Peter Gabriel, The Bay City Rollers and 10cc. King was born in Godalming, Surrey and educated at top public school Charterhouse. His father died when he was only 12.

He has always claimed to have been a shy child, but that he tried to conceal his shyness by being an extrovert. He has also readily admitted that he has never wanted to marry or to commit himself to any relationship where he would feel "tied".

King classes veteran TV presenter Jimmy Savile as one of his closest friends - they have known each other for 25 years. Savile once said of him: "He's a sabra. A sabra is an Israeli fruit that's prickly on the outside and all soft and lovely inside. That's Jonathan King."

fields.headline: The importance of being Merlin
fields.standfirst: It is 100 years since Oscar Wilde's death. Stephen Moss  meets the man responsible for keeping the legacy alive - Wilde's grandson. While below,  Geoffrey Wheatcroft wonders why so much fuss is made over an author who only wrote one great work
fields.trailText: It is 100 years since Oscar Wilde's death. Stephen Moss meets the man responsible for keeping the legacy alive - Wilde's grandson - and Geoffrey Wheatcroft wonders why so much fuss is made over an author who only wrote one great work
fields.body:
This is Oscar Wilde's moment. Next Thursday is the centenary of his death, and it is being marked by a themed set of programmes this evening on the BBC's Knowledge channel, by exhibitions at the British Library, the Barbican and the Geffrye Museum in east London, and by a welter of books on Oscariana - his trials, tabletalk, wit, sexuality, even his wallpaper. Ireland is taking the occasion even more seriously: issuing Wilde stamps and devoting three weeks of programmes, including productions of all the plays, to one of Dublin's great literary sons. It is a long way from Wilde's ignominious and self-pitying death in Paris in 1900.

It is his grandson Merlin Holland's moment too: his new edition of Wilde's letters has just been published, he co-curated the exhibition at the British Library, and he is dashing between the UK, France, Ireland and the US, co-ordinating the Wilde commemoration and appearing at conferences and seminars to discuss his fabled forebear. For Holland, it is the culmination of a gradual coming to terms with his grandfather's legacy.

There was a moment of hesitation before Holland would agree to this interview. A reporter called on him recently to discuss the letters but spent most of her article describing the shabby gentility of his circumstances; or more precisely the leaking ceiling of his flat in Tooting, south London. So I must first put on record that his airy, spacious, book-lined flat overlooking Tooting Common is actually very nice, despite the leak.

Holland is 54, fleshy (I would say like Oscar, but he would hate that), and shaggy-haired. He frequently flips back his fringe with his hand, wears multi-coloured slippers and smokes a lot considering it is nine in the morning, but otherwise the bohemianism is kept in check. Being the grandson of Oscar Wilde has not been an easy role, and only in the past few years has he worked out how to play it.

When he left university he wanted to write, but worried that people would compare his efforts unfavourably with Oscar's, so he went to work in the Middle East for five years before disappearing in the deserts of academic publishing.

Only in the mid-80s, when he began to help his mother to administer the Wilde estate, and then in 1987 when he fell out with Richard Ellmann over aspects of his biography of Wilde (in particular, whether he had died from syphilis), did he begin seriously to study his grandfather's life.

His father, Vyvyan, had gone through a similar process of denial and, late in life, accommodation with Wilde's legacy. Vyvyan had been a child when Wilde was imprisoned and never saw him again after 1895. Vyvyan's mother, Constance, died in 1898, and her family tried to obliterate the memory of Oscar and his homosexuality. Vyvyan was educated abroad, separated from his elder brother, Cyril (who was killed in the first world war), had his surname changed and spent 40 years trying to embrace the memory of his father.

Eventually, marriage late in life to Merlin's mother and the need to earn money after he was declared bankrupt in 1950 allowed (or compelled) him to acknowledge Oscar, and he wrote several books about his father, including the highly regarded Son of Oscar Wilde. Even in the 50s, when Merlin was growing up, Wilde was still notorious enough for parents to ensure that their precious children didn't get too close to him at school.

"My father led a very difficult life up until the time he married my mother in 1943," says Holland, "and it was largely down to her that anything was done about the Wilde legacy. He started to acknowledge it, but there wasn't a great deal of difference between the attitude to Wilde in the 50s and that in the 20s and 30s. There had been revivals of his plays and he was a bit more acceptable, but homosexuality was still illegal and he was still seen as tainted."

Before meeting Holland, I had assumed that he would merrily play the part of Oscar's representative on earth, but the reverse is true. He dislikes the fact that people want to shake his hand as a way of getting in touch with the great man's DNA, and recalls being offhand with a woman who had come up to him after a lecture and said how proud he must feel to be Wilde's grandson.

"She looked terribly crestfallen at my rudeness and said: 'But you should see it from our point of view.' I apologised and said I would try, but I feel very uncomfortable with it because it doesn't allow me to be me. It puts on me the necessity to be an appendage to somebody else, answering your grandfather's fan mail. My father chose not to do it, and, anyway, it wasn't really necessary then; I hope my son won't have to do it; I'm halfway between the two.

"I've never wanted to go to conferences and simply be treated as a living descendant of the person being studied. I would find that deeply disturbing: this monkey in a cage, throw him a handful of peanuts, what's he going to do? Do you look like him, are you capable of turning words in his way, can you be humorous? People come up to you at book signings and say: 'Can you write something funny?' A greater killer than that you can't imagine. I suppose what I wanted at some stage was an acceptance of the fact that what I was doing had a value." With the publication of his expanded edition of Wilde's letters, he hopes he finally has that.

Holland's 21-year-old son, Lucian, studied classics at Magdalen, Oxford, where Wilde had himself been a brilliant classics scholar. When Lucian was allocated a room in 71 High Street, where Wilde had lived for a term, Holland thought the similarities were getting out of hand. "I said to Lucian at the time: 'I don't give a damn about your sexuality, but for goodness sake keep out of the courts.' The coincidences had gone far enough."

Holland is by no means an uncritical flag-waver for his grandfather, but he stresses the undeniable fact about Wilde - his agelessness. Whereas Ruskin, say, feels like a seer from a distant era, Wilde is like the caustic wit you saw on television yesterday. What fees he would now command on chat shows and for articles in the broadsheets. Tom Wolfe, Gore Vidal and every other elegantly erudite essayist would be left scrabbling and scribbling in the dust.

"There is an awful thought at the back of my mind that it's the emperor's new clothes," says Holland. "But I dismiss it. One has to remind oneself that, as he said, he 'roused the imagination of the century'. He is a bridge between the Victorian world and our own, and people always think he lived more recently than he did. By the start of the 1990s people thought he had died in the 1920s and been a contemporary of Noël Coward. There's an element of wanting to have him in the 20th century, as part of our century, because of his vibrant modernity."

So is he now firmly established in the literary canon? "I hope not," says Holland. "The one thing that has made him survive are the ups and downs of his reputation. The insecurity of his reputation has ensured that he has always been talked about. Both his champions and his detractors want to have their say."

Holland is working on a book about the ebb and flow of Wilde's reputation, and thinks then he will draw a line under his excursions into family history. "Ultimately, the one thing that all this has taught me is that there is a razor's edge between being somebody biologically and having to accept that fact, but at the same time putting yourself in a comfortable position. To deny one's genetic make-up is a long road to mental anguish. My father suffered by denial, but you can also suffer by being a monkey in a cage. You have to find a way between the two."

'The Picture of Dorian Gray is complete tosh'

By Geoffrey Wheatcroft

He was a great something, but a great what? John Carey's question about Shaw applies even better to his contemporary and fellow Dubliner, Oscar Wilde. It is one thing to admire Wilde, across the reach of that 20th century which he said pedantically he would not live to see, just before he died in November 1900. But it is a mistake to hero-worship him, to idolise him as a gay martyr or to treat him as a deep thinker and great writer. Or almost wrong. There is a twist in Wilde's career which makes his ghastly destruction all the more bitter.

The new edition of his letters shows Wilde as a complicated mixture of good and bad, admirable and dislikeable. His last letters are horribly depressing, so many of them about the money he desperately needed. But poverty and desperation rarely have a good effect on anyone's character. When he fell out with Carlos Blacker, one of the few people who had maintained their friendship with him after his fall, Wilde wrote spitefully: "Of course, the fact of his being a Jew on his father's side explains everything."

In an objective sense, Wilde is a victim: a stupid and cruel law imprisoned him and broke him in body and spirit. But he would not at all have wanted to be remembered as a martyr for gay rights. Until he allowed the horrible Alfred Douglas to egg him on to the fatal suit against Queensberry, Wilde had been a rather successful careerist, keeping just within the bounds of convention. In court he insisted that his love of Bosie was pure and platonic.

Nor does Wilde cut a convincing figure as political or social thinker. The Soul of Man Under Socialism is a charming work, without an ounce of serious economic theory in it, and for that reason has worn rather better than many heavier tracts. A utopian fantasy of a world with no disease, toil or ugliness is all very well, and more attractive than Fabian blueprints for a planned society, but Wilde doesn't begin to explain how this idyll will be achieved, simply and wrongly assuming that there were enough material goods in the world to go round without anyone doing much work.

The only thing less convincing is any attempt to invoke Wilde for the cause of Irish nationalism, as is now the fashion. He just wasn't an ideologue. What he was, at his best, was a man of deeply humane and generous instincts. Nothing he ever wrote was nobler than a letter for publication immediately after his release from Reading jail, describing the horrors the prison system inflicted on children and the weak-minded.

Wildely uneven might describe Oscar as an imaginative writer. His children's stories are delightful: The Happy Prince on an old 78 disc with picture book still brings tears to my eyes, very many years on. But The Picture of Dorian Gray is complete tosh, a foolish imitation of some pretty silly French writing.

Recently the plays have been enjoying another revival, but this only serves to show something Richard Ellmann missed in his somewhat lifeless life of Wilde. The difference between Lady Windermere's Fan and An Ideal Husband on the one hand and his last play, The Importance of Being Earnest, on the other is one of kind and not degree. Too much in the earlier plays is another sort of tosh, tedious paradox-mongering and epigram- cracking. It's often hard to distinguish Wilde's lines - "One should never trust a woman who tells one her real age. A woman who would tell one that would tell one anything" - from the Wildean Lady Dundown in Alan Bennett's Forty Years On. ("All women dress like their mothers. That is their tragedy. No man ever does. That is his.")

As for Wilde's tragic drama and "serious" poetry, they are beyond parody. As he might himself have said, you would have to have a heart of stone not to laugh at Salome. But then, just before catastrophe enveloped Wilde, something happened. He wrote The Importance of Being Earnest. This transcendent work suddenly springs to life, not with laboured phrase-making but with a pure spirit of comedy and a verbal magic which make it a prose opera, in Auden's felicitous phrase.

Of all the "ifs" of literary history, none is sadder than this: if only Oscar Wilde hadn't been brought down by malice and cruelty and his own recklessness, he might have lived to give us half a dozen more "Earnests".

 The Complete Letters of Oscar Wilde, edited by Merlin Holland and Rupert Hart-Davis, is published by Fourth Estate, priced £35.
