He started to acknowledge it, but there wasn't a great deal of difference between the attitude to Wilde in the 50s and that in the 20s and 30s. There had been revivals of his plays and he was a bit more acceptable, but homosexuality was still illegal and he was still seen as tainted." Before meeting Holland, I had assumed that he would merrily play the part of Oscar's representative on earth, but the reverse is true. He dislikes the fact that people want to shake his hand as a way of getting in touch with the great man's DNA, and recalls being offhand with a woman who had come up to him after a lecture and said how proud he must feel to be Wilde's grandson. "She looked terribly crestfallen at my rudeness and said: 'But you should see it from our point of view.' I apologised and said I would try, but I feel very uncomfortable with it because it doesn't allow me to be me. It puts on me the necessity to be an appendage to somebody else, answering your grandfather's fan mail. My father chose not to do it, and, anyway, it wasn't really necessary then; I hope my son won't have to do it; I'm halfway between the two. "I've never wanted to go to conferences and simply be treated as a living descendant of the person being studied. I would find that deeply disturbing: this monkey in a cage, throw him a handful of peanuts, what's he going to do? Do you look like him, are you capable of turning words in his way, can you be humorous? People come up to you at book signings and say: 'Can you write something funny?' A greater killer than that you can't imagine. I suppose what I wanted at some stage was an acceptance of the fact that what I was doing had a value." With the publication of his expanded edition of Wilde's letters, he hopes he finally has that. Holland's 21-year-old son, Lucian, studied classics at Magdalen, Oxford, where Wilde had himself been a brilliant classics scholar. When Lucian was allocated a room in 71 High Street, where Wilde had lived for a term, Holland thought the similarities were getting out of hand. "I said to Lucian at the time: 'I don't give a damn about your sexuality, but for goodness sake keep out of the courts.' The coincidences had gone far enough." Holland is by no means an uncritical flag-waver for his grandfather, but he stresses the undeniable fact about Wilde - his agelessness. Whereas Ruskin, say, feels like a seer from a distant era, Wilde is like the caustic wit you saw on television yesterday. What fees he would now command on chat shows and for articles in the broadsheets. Tom Wolfe, Gore Vidal and every other elegantly erudite essayist would be left scrabbling and scribbling in the dust. "There is an awful thought at the back of my mind that it's the emperor's new clothes," says Holland. "But I dismiss it. One has to remind oneself that, as he said, he 'roused the imagination of the century'. He is a bridge between the Victorian world and our own, and people always think he lived more recently than he did. By the start of the 1990s people thought he had died in the 1920s and been a contemporary of Noël Coward. There's an element of wanting to have him in the 20th century, as part of our century, because of his vibrant modernity." So is he now firmly established in the literary canon? "I hope not," says Holland. "The one thing that has made him survive are the ups and downs of his reputation. The insecurity of his reputation has ensured that he has always been talked about. Both his champions and his detractors want to have their say." Holland is working on a book about the ebb and flow of Wilde's reputation, and thinks then he will draw a line under his excursions into family history. "Ultimately, the one thing that all this has taught me is that there is a razor's edge between being somebody biologically and having to accept that fact, but at the same time putting yourself in a comfortable position. To deny one's genetic make-up is a long road to mental anguish. My father suffered by denial, but you can also suffer by being a monkey in a cage. You have to find a way between the two." 'The Picture of Dorian Gray is complete tosh' By Geoffrey Wheatcroft He was a great something, but a great what? John Carey's question about Shaw applies even better to his contemporary and fellow Dubliner, Oscar Wilde. It is one thing to admire Wilde, across the reach of that 20th century which he said pedantically he would not live to see, just before he died in November 1900. But it is a mistake to hero-worship him, to idolise him as a gay martyr or to treat him as a deep thinker and great writer. Or almost wrong. There is a twist in Wilde's career which makes his ghastly destruction all the more bitter. The new edition of his letters shows Wilde as a complicated mixture of good and bad, admirable and dislikeable. His last letters are horribly depressing, so many of them about the money he desperately needed. But poverty and desperation rarely have a good effect on anyone's character. When he fell out with Carlos Blacker, one of the few people who had maintained their friendship with him after his fall, Wilde wrote spitefully: "Of course, the fact of his being a Jew on his father's side explains everything." In an objective sense, Wilde is a victim: a stupid and cruel law imprisoned him and broke him in body and spirit. But he would not at all have wanted to be remembered as a martyr for gay rights. Until he allowed the horrible Alfred Douglas to egg him on to the fatal suit against Queensberry, Wilde had been a rather successful careerist, keeping just within the bounds of convention. In court he insisted that his love of Bosie was pure and platonic. Nor does Wilde cut a convincing figure as political or social thinker. The Soul of Man Under Socialism is a charming work, without an ounce of serious economic theory in it, and for that reason has worn rather better than many heavier tracts. A utopian fantasy of a world with no disease, toil or ugliness is all very well, and more attractive than Fabian blueprints for a planned society, but Wilde doesn't begin to explain how this idyll will be achieved, simply and wrongly assuming that there were enough material goods in the world to go round without anyone doing much work. The only thing less convincing is any attempt to invoke Wilde for the cause of Irish nationalism, as is now the fashion. He just wasn't an ideologue. What he was, at his best, was a man of deeply humane and generous instincts. Nothing he ever wrote was nobler than a letter for publication immediately after his release from Reading jail, describing the horrors the prison system inflicted on children and the weak-minded. Wildely uneven might describe Oscar as an imaginative writer. His children's stories are delightful: The Happy Prince on an old 78 disc with picture book still brings tears to my eyes, very many years on. But The Picture of Dorian Gray is complete tosh, a foolish imitation of some pretty silly French writing. Recently the plays have been enjoying another revival, but this only serves to show something Richard Ellmann missed in his somewhat lifeless life of Wilde. The difference between Lady Windermere's Fan and An Ideal Husband on the one hand and his last play, The Importance of Being Earnest, on the other is one of kind and not degree. Too much in the earlier plays is another sort of tosh, tedious paradox-mongering and epigram- cracking. It's often hard to distinguish Wilde's lines - "One should never trust a woman who tells one her real age. A woman who would tell one that would tell one anything" - from the Wildean Lady Dundown in Alan Bennett's Forty Years On. ("All women dress like their mothers. That is their tragedy. No man ever does. That is his.") As for Wilde's tragic drama and "serious" poetry, they are beyond parody. As he might himself have said, you would have to have a heart of stone not to laugh at Salome. But then, just before catastrophe enveloped Wilde, something happened. He wrote The Importance of Being Earnest. This transcendent work suddenly springs to life, not with laboured phrase-making but with a pure spirit of comedy and a verbal magic which make it a prose opera, in Auden's felicitous phrase. Of all the "ifs" of literary history, none is sadder than this: if only Oscar Wilde hadn't been brought down by malice and cruelty and his own recklessness, he might have lived to give us half a dozen more "Earnests".  The Complete Letters of Oscar Wilde, edited by Merlin Holland and Rupert Hart-Davis, is published by Fourth Estate, priced £35.

webTitle: Jonathan King charged with child sex abuse

fields.headline: Jonathan King charged with child sex abuse
fields.standfirst: Who is Jonathan King?
fields.trailText: Jonathan King, the millionaire pop mogul, was today charged with three sex offences after being quizzed by detectives over allegations of child sex abuse.
fields.body:
Jonathan King, the millionaire pop mogul, was today charged with three sex offences after being quizzed by detectives over allegations of child sex abuse.

The 55-year-old, who became a star while at Cambridge University, was charged with buggery, attempted buggery and indecent assault, according to police sources.

Surrey police refused to discuss the charges but confirmed that he was released on conditional bail to appear before Staines magistrates court on November 30.

Mr King has "categorically" denied what he called "absurd allegations" against him.

Detectives made the arrest yesterday after police swooped on his home in Bayswater, west London. The serious sex offenders unit of the national criminal intelligence service has been gathering information on Mr King for months.

Sources said that the matters being investigated were of a "very serious nature".

Some of the incidents of alleged abuse go back to the late 1970s and 1980s, when Mr King ran a successful recording and publishing company.

The former public schoolboy, who shot to fame at the age of 21 with the song Everyone Has Gone To The Moon, discovered a number of bands including Genesis and 10cc.

His arrest comes after several men approached police with claims that they were abused as youngsters.

Detectives searched Mr King's home yesterday and removed a number of items for analysis.

Surrey police said in a statement: "We can confirm that Jonathan King has been charged with three offences and released on conditional bail to appear before Staines magistrates' court on November 30."

Staines magistrates' court

fields.headline: Travolta tops the turkey list
fields.trailText: John Travolta, Demi Moore and Madonna make it into 10 worst movies of the year list
fields.body:
As the end of the year approaches, so do the endless lists of best and worst films, and of course the Oscar hype. One film that we can safely say is unlikely to be featuring on any Oscar list is Battlefield Earth.

Entertainment site Hollywood.com has come up with its list of the 10 worst movies of the year, and John Travolta's big budget flop is at the top.

"Nothing this year has banded the Hollywood.com staff closer together than the John Travolta sci-fi fiasco," write the team gleefully. "It's one of the worst movies ever made."

Travolta's scientology-inspired tale is in good company. Madonna and Rupert Everett's collaboration The Next Best Thing earned a high ranking - "Think of this as one more reason for Madonna to stick with music," as did Demi Moore's 'comeback' movie Passion of Mind.

But despite the critical drubbing that Travolta's vanity project received, he is rumoured to be embarking on plans to make a sequel.

fields.headline: United PR chief to depart
fields.standfirst: 11am: New roles cement Granada takeover
fields.trailText:
12pm: Sue Robertson, director of corporate affairs at United Broadcasting & Entertainment, has been made redundant. Claire Cozens reports.

11am: New roles cement Granada takeover
fields.body:
Sue Robertson, director of corporate affairs at United Broadcasting & Entertainment, has been made redundant.

The move follows the acquisition of United by Granada Media earlier this year.

Ms Robertson, who was on a six-figure salary, will leave the company at the end of the year and has not yet decided what she will do after that.

She said: "I haven't got to the point of making that decision yet. It didn't really work out with Granada because they already have someone in doing that job."

A Granada spokeswoman said it had not been possible to find a position for Ms Robertson in the merged company.

She said: "She's helped us a great deal with the integration programme, but that has now finished.

"Sue is very highly regarded but obviously we've already got Susan Donovan in the same position here."

Ms Robertson joined United a year ago from Channel 4, where she was head of corporate affairs. She had been with Channel 4 for four years.

In a separate development, Tracey O'Connor, head of factual press at United, has quit to join Channel 5 as head of entertainment.

She replaces Greg Day, who has left the station to set up his own PR company.

webTitle: Waiter, there's a spy in my soup

fields.headline: Waiter, there's a spy in my soup
fields.standfirst: One great recipe can make a chef's fortune - so it's hardly surprising that rivals will go to any lengths to steal it.  Victoria Moore  on the murky world of culinary espionage
fields.trailText: One great recipe can make a chef's fortune - so it's hardly surprising that rivals will go to any lengths to steal it. Victoria Moore on the murky world of culinary espionage
fields.body:
The men came every night. Striding through Soho, shutting off their senses to the aromas of cheap Chinese food and traffic fumes that curled into their nostrils and threatened to contaminate their palates. For two solid months they made the same journey eastwards from their base in Notting Hill, west London, and every night they entered the same doorway.

Inside, the restaurant was small but it was lively and the food was good. Methodically, the men ate their way through the menu from top to bottom: chewing slowly; holding each mouthful for a few moments; letting the flavours seep through their saliva; analysing the taste; committing it to memory.

They made no secret of their mission. "We are spies," they told the restaurant manager, and explained how they had come to work out how to make his specialities, and in particular his signature dish, spaghetti-lobster, so they could copy them in their own restaurant on the other side of town.

Aldo Zilli, the victim of this attempt at plagiarism, was not impressed by the results. He has since opened a restaurant, Zilli Fish, in Notting Hill and close to the restaurant he claims tried to copy his food. So did it succeed? "It's not so good, of course it is not. How do I know? Because I went to try it. They haven't got a clue. For example, with my spaghetti-lobster they boil the lobster before they put it in the sauce."

Well they won't now. Not if they're reading this, at least.

But Zilli's story offers a fascinating insight into a world of culinary intrigue and espionage few know exist. And the stakes are high - not just because a restaurant lives or dies by the food it serves. In the age of the celebrity chef and lucrative television and publishing deals, there are millions of pounds to be made.

Some chefs are brazen. "I rarely want to eat restaurant food unless I'm looking for new ideas or recipes to steal," says the American chef and writer Anthony Bourdain, in his book Kitchen Confidential.

Nevertheless, recipe theft can be a sensitive subject. The fabled French chef Jacques Maximin once mounted an unsuccessful campaign to prevent chefs copying each other's recipes. And some of our most eminent chefs have been openly accused of theft, among them the treble-Michelin- starred Marco Pierre White who worked for a spell under the chef Pierre Koffmann at La Tante Claire.

In his unauthorised biography of White, Charles Hennessy writes: "Pierre Koffmann says, 'Marco only came to steal my recipes. But he's one of the best chefs I ever had - always looking, always listening, wanting to absorb as much as possible as quickly as possible.' "

White's defence is straightforward. "The best pupils go to the best teachers," he says. "By definition, things rub off. I worked for Pierre Koffmann and for the Rouxs. I learned from them and I developed my own distinctive style. But I also credit my sources. On my menu at the Oak Room I have Pied de Cochon Pierre Koffmann. At Drones, which will open in December, there is Crème Brulée Boxtree." (Boxtree is a restaurant in Ilkley, West Yorkshire, where White worked at the beginning of his career.)

Perhaps White has learnt the hard way. There is at least one dish - oysters with champagne jelly and watercress - that most would agree he invented but when Marco was resident at the restaurant at the Hyde Park Hotel every dish on the menu was dated, apparently signifying the year he considered he created it. Alas, it only encouraged other chefs to point out his unacknowledged sources.

There are two issues here. The first is the creative aspect of cooking; the personal stamp or flair brought by an individual chef to a menu. The second is the science in recipe - the nature and quantity of the ingredients, the precise cooking times, the peculiar method used for, say, soaking and draining parsley.

The situation is made infinitely complex by ambiguities in the law. An inventor can patent his work, giving him sole right to make use of and sell his invention. The creations of a chef are not protected in the same cut and dried way. Hence the tantrums, accusations and counter-accusations of theft that from time to time burst out of the basement pressure cookers that are restaurant kitchens.

Let's deal with the creative aspect first. In English law you cannot copyright an idea for a recipe or anything else. It is impossible to copyright a combination of food such as the serving of pan-roasted Bresse pigeon with chestnuts (the River Cafe Cookbook). Even if you could, it would be next to impossible to prove that, among the millions of versions of recipes evolved over thousands of years, the idea was definitely yours. Unless you opt for the truly outlandish - like Aldo Zilli's sushi pizza or the Birdcage restaurant's foie gras and coconut soup - there is very little that is new. As Alastair Little, whom one food writer once called "the most plagiarised chef of our time", says: "There are only so many different ways to apply heat and only so many combinations of flavours."

To illustrate his point, Little refers to a recipe that can be found in Soho Cooking, his most recent cookbook, for Pain Perdu or "lost bread". It is a version of a nursery favourite, eggy bread with apple. "I got it out of a French cookbook by a guy called Marc Meneau," Little admits freely. "I adapted it slightly and started serving it. My co-chef, Juliet [Peston], adapted it further and, when she left, made a feature of it in another restaurant. What really annoyed me was when I read in a newspaper that I had appropriated the idea from Juliet when in fact I was an intermediary between Juliet and the original, which anyway is a recipe in the common domain. Everyone does eggy bread in some form or another. You can't attribute its invention to anyone."

This is perhaps just as well. Wouldn't it be dull not to be able to eat chicken wrapped in prosciutto or spaghetti with anchovy sauce because some chef in Portsmouth had nabbed the patent? It's when you try to protect the nuts and bolts of a recipe that things get complicated. While it is true that a trainee chef will learn hundreds of "classical methods", the idea of a secret recipe that people would kill to lay their hands on is not entirely ridiculous. The formula for Coca-Cola is closely guarded. The internet is overflowing with supposed secret recipes that people have bothered to put there, including one that claims to recreate KFC as you find it in the bucket.

It is whispered that some restaurants guard their secret recipes so jealously that when they publish restaurant cookbooks they leave out a crucial detail in each. The recipe will still work, but it will not be quite as good as it should be.

Under English copyright laws, as long as a recipe is written down it is protected as a literary work, in the same way as a poem or a play. This is essential in safeguarding the phraseology of the method, the bits that baby you through the caramelising of onions, for example. It is why Delia can publish and protect her recipe for how to boil an egg. But what if someone completely rewrote the method but it could be seen that it was fundamentally the same way of egg-boiling, only expressed differently. Where would Delia stand then?

"A grey area, I think," says Charlie Swan, a partner at the Simkins Partnership, a media law firm. Food copyright is full of such areas but fortunately one thing is clear cut - making your own food based on a recipe is perfectly legal. Judges ruled long ago that you do not infringe the copyright on Mrs Beeton's Cookery Book if you make a rabbit pie using one of her recipes. But what of list of ingredients? Can you steal a recipe, add half a teaspoon of salt and pass it off as your own? The answer is, probably not. "The definition of a literary work includes compilations, such as the telephone directory. You might argue that the list of ingredients was a compilation," says Swan.

Chefs have another legal saviour in the laws of confidence which protect trade secrets. "If, for example, you poached someone from a restaurant kitchen and asked them to spill all its secrets then there would be questions about industrial espionage," says Swan.

"And if you've got a restaurant with its own secret recipes and they are written down, if someone physically makes a copy of them either with the photocopier or by hand then that is a copyright infringement."

This does happen, as Sally Clarke of Clarke's bakery and restaurant in Notting Hill, London, found out a few years ago when one of her kitchen staff was discovered photocopying recipes a week before she was due to return to New Zealand. Clarke took legal advice and battled with her employee until she admitted to having made the copies and returned them. "It was a very nasty experience," says Clarke, "but I wouldn't be surprised if she was in New Zealand now, running her own bakery and using our recipes."

These days Clarke is careful. Only recipes used for the bakery are written down because they require precision and do not change seasonally, as the restaurant food does. She keeps just one copy of each under lock and key in her office.

In the end, creativity and precision merge. Be as scientific as you like but without flavour you will get nowhere. For Sally Clarke's secret recipes are not so much original as adapted. Like fashion designers, chefs will go on resurrecting old ideas - from polenta to pot-au-feu - and adding a twist.

"You take an idea and then you refine, refine, refine it," says Marco Pierre White, "until it is as good as it can be and that is what it's all about."

And perhaps that is what the spaghetti-lobster thieves are missing: a soupçon of inspiration.

"A grey area, I think," says Charlie Swan, a partner at the Simkins Partnership, a media law firm. Food copyright is full of such areas but fortunately one thing is clear cut - making your own food based on a recipe is perfectly legal. Judges ruled long ago that you do not infringe the copyright on Mrs Beeton's Cookery Book if you make a rabbit pie using one of her recipes. But what of list of ingredients? Can you steal a recipe, add half a teaspoon of salt and pass it off as your own? The answer is, probably not. "The definition of a literary work includes compilations, such as the telephone directory. You might argue that the list of ingredients was a compilation," says Swan. Chefs have another legal saviour in the laws of confidence which protect trade secrets. "If, for example, you poached someone from a restaurant kitchen and asked them to spill all its secrets then there would be questions about industrial espionage," says Swan. "And if you've got a restaurant with its own secret recipes and they are written down, if someone physically makes a copy of them either with the photocopier or by hand then that is a copyright infringement." This does happen, as Sally Clarke of Clarke's bakery and restaurant in Notting Hill, London, found out a few years ago when one of her kitchen staff was discovered photocopying recipes a week before she was due to return to New Zealand. Clarke took legal advice and battled with her employee until she admitted to having made the copies and returned them. "It was a very nasty experience," says Clarke, "but I wouldn't be surprised if she was in New Zealand now, running her own bakery and using our recipes." These days Clarke is careful. Only recipes used for the bakery are written down because they require precision and do not change seasonally, as the restaurant food does. She keeps just one copy of each under lock and key in her office. In the end, creativity and precision merge. Be as scientific as you like but without flavour you will get nowhere. For Sally Clarke's secret recipes are not so much original as adapted. Like fashion designers, chefs will go on resurrecting old ideas - from polenta to pot-au-feu - and adding a twist. "You take an idea and then you refine, refine, refine it," says Marco Pierre White, "until it is as good as it can be and that is what it's all about." And perhaps that is what the spaghetti-lobster thieves are missing: a soupçon of inspiration.

webTitle: Middle East: Britain ready to commit observers

fields.headline: Britain ready to commit observers
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The British government is preparing to commit troops as part of an international observer force in the troubled Gaza Strip and West Bank.
fields.body:
The British government is preparing to commit troops as part of an international observer force in the troubled Gaza Strip and West Bank.

Although Israel remains opposed to it, the idea, put forward by France and Britain, is gathering momentum. The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, and the US pushed the Israeli and Palestinian delegations into discussing it secretly in New York this week.

Britain is prepared to contribute to the mission despite its forces being stretched by their involvement in Sierra Leone, Bosnia and Kosovo.

The Palestinians have been pressing for an international force in the region, where daily clashes have claimed about 250 lives, mainly Palestinian.

To make the proposal more acceptable to Israel, the British and French have avoided using the word "force", stressing that the mission would be made up of unarmed observers.

A Foreign Office spokesman said: "They would not be peacekeepers inserting themselves between warring factions; they would be observing what was going on: a visible presence reporting back."

About 100-200 observers are envisaged, with the hope that their presence would act as a psychological deterrent.

The spokesman stressed that Israeli agreement was essential.

Mr Annan met the Israeli and Palestinian delegations at UN on Wednesday, and he and US representatives persuaded the two sides to sit down together. "The Israelis are still resisting, but at last they are talking, and that has to be good," a UN source said.

Talks on the form the mission should take, and on the number of personnel, are continuing.

A French government source said: "We want to be flexible. It is to find a mechanism for saving everyone's face and reducing tension."

Western diplomats reported that senior Israelis were wavering, but that the increase in violence this week hardened the opposition of the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak.

However, an article in the liberal Israeli newspaper Ha'aretz yesterday called for an international observer force, and suggested that Israel's real objection stemmed from a fear that its behaviour in the conflict would be studied under international standards.

Another Israeli objection is that its acceptance of the force would amount to rewarding the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, for the violence.

Privately, the Israelis have been warning Britain and France that in the past such international missions have become targets, as in Beirut.

The prominent Palestinian spokeswoman Hanan Ashrawi said yesterday that thepresence of observers had proved useless in Hebron.

"What we want is an international force with a mandate to protect the Palestinians and hold the Israelis responsible. It should be mobile and have the ability to intervene," Ms Ashrawi said.

 Prime minister Ehud Barak was set last night to meet Ariel Sharon, the hardline leader of the opposition Likud party.

Palestinians accused Israel of assassinating a leader of the Islamist Hamas movement yesterday in the West Bank. Meanwhile yesterday, two Israeli soldiers were killed in Gaza, and a third was reportedly killed at Anata village near Jerusalem.

webTitle: Two major big screen roles for Alfred Molina

fields.headline: Two major big screen roles for Alfred Molina
fields.trailText: Tipped for an Oscar nod in Chocolat, Alfred Molina is set to take a leading role in forthcoming Frida Kahlo biopic
fields.body:
British actor Alfred Molina is to take a lead role in one of the competing biopics of Mexican painter, Frida Kahlo, opposite Salma Hayek.

The 47-year-old Molina is in final negotiations to play Kahlo's husband, artist Diego Rivera, reports entertainment site unmissibleTV. Latin American actress Salma Hayek is to play the feminist painter, who was forced to do much of her work from her bed due to a childhood attack of polio and a severe accident at the age of 18 when her stomach and pelvis were pierced by a pole.

Also lined up to appear in the film, due to go into production in January, are Antonio Banderas, Ed Norton and Ashley Judd. Jennifer Lopez's as yet untitled Frida Kahlo biopic is also scheduled to begin production early next year, but the casting process is less advanced.

Meanwhile, Molina is being mooted as a possible Oscar nominee for his role in the forthcoming film about love and confectionery, Chocolat, in which he stars alongside Juliette Binoche and Johnny Depp. The film, due for release in the UK early next year, is an adaptation of Joanne Harris's best-selling novel which tells the story of a young mother (Binoche) who opens a chocolate factory in a small French town - much to the dismay of the town's other businessmen. Molina plays the Comte de Reynaud, a repressed character who is so confused by the sensual influence that the woman has on the people of the town, that he starts a campaign to have her thrown out.

Molina, a longtime resident of California, is best known for his lead role as Sergei in the 1985 British hit, Letter to Brezhnev, and as Joe Orton's lover Kenneth Halliwell in Prick Up Your Ears. Since moving to America, he has appeared in a number of TV movies and big screen flops, but his career has enjoying something of a renaissance with his recent appearances in Magnolia and Boogie Nights.

fields.headline: In the best possible taste
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort on cookbooks
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort on cookbooks.
fields.body:
Is there room in the world for another cookery book? Can there be anything left to say? Any recipe that hasn't been recycled a dozen times? Well, yes, there just might be.

Let's deal with the old stagers first, Appetite by Nigel Slater (Fourth Estate, £25 Buy it at BOL) and How To Be A Domestic Goddess by Nigella Lawson (Chatto & Windus, £25 Buy it at BOL). I am getting rather fed up with writing nice things about Nigel Slater's books. Why can't the fellow be human like the rest of us, and do something duff for a change? Perhaps because he's a genius, his food is scrummy and his voice more personal than usual - that of a good friend.

I am assured that How To Be A Domestic Goddess is an ironic title. I am not so sure, partly because Nigella Lawson clearly is one - or at the very least the Shirley Conran of our time. The latest volume does not have the clarity and freshness of her first volume, How to Eat, but it includes lip-smacking stuff nonetheless, in characteristically crisp prose.

Among restaurant chefs there are some pretty lively goodies, notably Cooking At The Merchant House by Shaun Hill (Conran Octopus, £20 Buy it at BOL), Rick Stein's Seafood Lovers' Guide (BBC, £20 Buy it at BOL) and Real Greek Food by Theodore Kyriakou and Charles Campion (Pavilion, £25 Buy it at BOL). Each is a highly personal book, with most recipes well within the compass of an average-to-decent home cook. Terrific pictures, too.

The world has waited a long time for No Place Like Home by Kensington Place chef and one-time Guardian cookery writer Rowley Leigh (Fourth Estate, £25 Buy it at BOL), but the wait has been worthwhile. Leigh writes with grace, precision, wisdom and wit, and his food hits just the right balance between classical rigour and down-home edibility. Let's hope we don't have to wait so long for the next volume.

Easily the most visually idiosyncratic cook book of the year comes from South Africa. Provocative Cuisine by Braam Kruger (Zebra Press, £15.99 Buy it at BOL) - aka Kitchenboy, a seriously ironic nickname - is a madcap multimedia autobiography and ego trip. The recipes are on the wild side, too, what with Tarzan roast, rabbit with raspberry-Campari sauce and brandy and Coke marinade. A big hit in SA, and quite refreshing in the well-behaved world of British cookery books.

This has also been an exceptional year for non-cookery food books. Bridging the divide is The Science of Cooking (Springer, £19.95 Buy it at BOL) by another quondam Guardian writer, Peter Barham, reader in physics at the University of Bristol. This is more than just an update of Harold McGee's epoch-making Science and Lore of the Kitchen, now at least a decade old. If you want to know how to cook a fish with scientific precision, this is the book. Written in an admirably lucid, accessible prose, it includes recipes.

Top of the league is the mighty Cambridge World History of Food edited by Kenneth F Kiple and Kriemhild Conee Ornelas (Cambridge University Press, £95 Buy it at BOL). Half of historico-socio-gastro academia seems to have been involved in this magnificent project, and there is enough in the two volumes to keep the curious happy for Christmases to come. No doubt nit-pickers will pick nits, but as a work of reference it is prodigious.

And finally a volume from one of the finest radio journalists ever to grace the airwaves, Derek Cooper. Snail Eggs & Samphire (Macmillan, £16.99 Buy it at BOL) bears the subtitle "Dispatches from the Food Front", and that's just what it is - trenchant, funny and wise observations, written with an elan that is every bit as distinctive as his broadcasting voice.

fields.headline: PR Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 24.
fields.trailText: November 24: BSMG Worldwide has bought the City PR firm Square Mile, in a deal worth up to £10m.
fields.body:
BSMG Worldwide has bought the City PR firm Square Mile in a deal worth up to £10m. The agency will merge its corporate division with BSMG in London but will keep the Square Mile name.

The Department of Health has hired the Forster Company to spearhead a £1m national mental health awareness campaign. The PR blitz is designed to stamp out the stigma of mental illness.

Sainsbury's has dropped Fishburn Hedges as its public affairs agency and has handed the brief to Lexington Communications.

The Bradford and Bingley Building Society has turned to financial PR specialists Cubitt Consulting to handle all investor relations surrounding its IPO and conversion to bank status next month.

Scottish Power has dropped Brunswick as its financial PR agency and hired Tulchan Communications to handle the task.

Global marketing group Incepta is to acquire corporate PR specialists Key Communications for £6.8m.

HSBC and Merrill Lynch have hired Financial Dynamics to handle the PR for their joint online investment and banking venture, set to launch by Christmas.

Microsoft has handed its newly created senior corporate affairs role for Europe to former European Commission adviser Jacques Lafitte.

fields.headline: DoubleClick marketeer Gerrard leaves
fields.trailText: 11.15am: DoubleClick European marketeer Andrew Gerrard has left to set himself up as a digital marketing consultant. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
DoubleClick has lost one of its top European marketeers.

Andrew Gerrard, European, Middle East and Africa marketing director of technology solutions, has left to set himself up as a digital marketing consultant.

Mr Gerrard, who boasts more than four years of top-level interactive marketing experience, will work on a freelance basis for dot.coms looking to boost their sales and marketing efforts.

He plans to forge a number of alliances with key companies and may recruit other consultants at a later stage.

Mr Gerrard said: "The industry is so unstable at the moment. What fledgling dot.coms need is good expertise and knowledge in marketing to help them through the tough times.

"There are not that many independents offering this kind of advice so there's definitely a gap in the market."

Mr Gerrard was formerly European marketing manager at NetGravity, which was bought out by DoubleClick last year.

Before that he worked as interactive marketing services manager at CompuServe, having set up the ISP's online advertising business in 1996.

webTitle: West Bromwich: Labour victory in former speaker's seat

fields.headline: West Bromwich: Labour victory in former speaker's seat
fields.standfirst:
Labour hold, majority 3,232

Special report: elections 2000
Full results
fields.trailText: West Bromwich West was not contested by Tories and Lib Dems in 1997 as it was the seat of then Speaker Betty Boothroyd.
fields.body:
West Bromwich West was not contested by Tories and Lib Dems in 1997 as it was the seat of then Speaker Betty Boothroyd.

Labour's Adrian Bailey won West Bromwich West with 9,640 votes, over the Conservatives' Karen Bissell on 6,408 and the Lib Dems' Sadie Smith on 1,791.

The seat was not contested by the Tories and Lib Dems in the 1997 general election, as it was held by the Speaker, Betty Boothroyd, who stood down from the Commons on its return from summer recess last month.

Conservative chairman Michael Ancram said: "I am pleased with the West Bromwich West result. This is a 2% swing to us from 1992, when we won the general election.

"It is a significant result compared to where we would have been at the last general election had the seat been contested.

"It is a bad result for Labour in their heartlands and a good result for Conservatives in the West Midlands. We had a good local candidate who fought an effective and relevant campaign."

After the declaration, Mr Bailey said voters in West Bromwich West had sent a message to Tory leader William Hague that people did not want to see cuts in public services.

He said: "People want this Labour government because it shares their priorities - delivering more money for pensioners, more bobbies on the beat, more jobs, improving schools and more money for a bigger and better NHS.

Defeated Tory candidate Karen Bissell said the by-election represented an exceptional result for the Conservatives.

"In the heart of the Black Country - in an area that should be safe Labour territory - the Labour Party have just managed to cling on. The general election can't come soon enough."

There have been boundary changes since she fought as a Labour candidate in the 1992 General Election when Tories won a narrow majority in the Commons.

However notional figures calculated for PA News by Colin Rallings and Michael Thrasher of Plymouth University suggested Labour would have had a 13% lead at West Bromwich West if the alterations had been in force that year compared with 17% this time.

Just 27.6% of the electorate in West Bromwich West went to the polls.

fields.headline: Preston: splits mar Labour victory
fields.standfirst:
Labour hold, majority 4,426

Special report: elections 2000
Full results
fields.trailText: In Preston, Lancs, there was a 9% net swing away from Labour, but the benefit was shared by Tories and Liberal Democrats who both  improved their showing compared with the 1997 General Election.
fields.body:
In Preston, Lancs, there was a 9% net swing away from Labour, but the benefit was shared by Tories and Liberal Democrats who both improved their showing compared with the 1997 General Election.

Conservative and Liberal Democrat candidates in Preston branded Labour's win in the seat as a "hollow victory" with the party's 15% vote share drop.

There were also signs of the division that marred the Labour campaign when winner Mark Hendrick, a 41-year-old Blairite former MEP and college lecturer, was jeered by left-wing opponents as he made his victory speech.

Splits in the Labour camp were caused by opposition to the selection of Mr Hendrick to fight the seat ahead of the late left-wing MP Audrey Wise's daughter Valerie.

But Mr Hendrick later denied that the result showed a swing of more than 9% from Labour to the Conservatives.

He said: "It is a 9% swing away from Labour but only 5% of that went towards the Conservatives. On that result there would not be a Conservative government by any stretch of the imagination."

The Conservative vote rose by 3% and the Liberal Democrats' by one and a half per cent. That is hardly a shattering result for us or good news for them."

Mr Hendrick described the reported divisions in the Labour ranks in the constituency as "a splinter not a split". He said: "Many of these people were never in the Labour Party and belonged to other left-wing organisations. We are not concerned about it.

"I am a new person but I will fight just as hard for this constituency as Audrey Wise did with policies that are relevant to the new Millennium we are in, not the 1980s or 1990s."

fields.bodyText: In Preston, Lancs, there was a 9% net swing away from Labour, but the benefit was shared by Tories and Liberal Democrats who both improved their showing compared with the 1997 General Election. Conservative and Liberal Democrat candidates in Preston branded Labour's win in the seat as a "hollow victory" with the party's 15% vote share drop. There were also signs of the division that marred the Labour campaign when winner Mark Hendrick, a 41-year-old Blairite former MEP and college lecturer, was jeered by left-wing opponents as he made his victory speech. Splits in the Labour camp were caused by opposition to the selection of Mr Hendrick to fight the seat ahead of the late left-wing MP Audrey Wise's daughter Valerie. But Mr Hendrick later denied that the result showed a swing of more than 9% from Labour to the Conservatives. He said: "It is a 9% swing away from Labour but only 5% of that went towards the Conservatives. On that result there would not be a Conservative government by any stretch of the imagination." The Conservative vote rose by 3% and the Liberal Democrats' by one and a half per cent. That is hardly a shattering result for us or good news for them." Mr Hendrick described the reported divisions in the Labour ranks in the constituency as "a splinter not a split". He said: "Many of these people were never in the Labour Party and belonged to other left-wing organisations. We are not concerned about it. "I am a new person but I will fight just as hard for this constituency as Audrey Wise did with policies that are relevant to the new Millennium we are in, not the 1980s or 1990s." fields.headline: Overexposed...
fields.standfirst: ... men in sheepskin
fields.trailText: ... men in sheepskin
fields.body:
OK, let's get this straight right now, guys. A sheepskin coat: it doesn't make you look hard, it doesn't make you look sexily retro and it gives you no animal magnetism. In fact, the only quality shearling can guarantee is that you will smell like a damp Welsh hillside when it rains.

And yet, and yet. Raggedy, grotty sheepskin coats are adorning the backs of the most style-conscious of men this season. Last week's MTV European Music Awards looked like a walking dustbin from the local abattoir. We had Ricky Martin in his leather trousers, Ronan Keating in his leather stage outfit, and so on. And then there were the Backstreet Boys and dear old Bono, determinedly sporting their sheepskin apparel. Backstreet and Bono may be fine to hum along to in very, very private moments, but they are hardly style gods.

Perhaps these poor things are deluded by sepia-tinted childhood memories of football matches. Clad in shearling, standing about on cold fields, smoking a fag and... gosh, those managers looked great. If only we were as cool as that, the young lads cried. Sadly, this was never to be, but their aspirational, if sentimental, tendencies are apparent in their choice of sheepskin coats.

The trend is sure to escalate with the New Year release of the Cameron Crowe film, Almost Famous. Kate Hudson looks glowing in her white sheepskin and both girl and coat seem to be irresistible to male audiences. This is where fashion reveals its sexist tendencies. Whereas shearling works on the girls (they look sweet, cosy, cuddly), on boys it makes them look like strangely overstylised grandads.

Boys, I'm sorry, there is only one thing to do with your sheepskin coat: give it to your girlfriend.

fields.headline: Pauric Sweeney
fields.trailText: Poor old Posh. Not only did she not reach the longed-for number one spot with her solo song, but the Pauric Sweeney jewellery she wore in the video has overtaken her little tune in terms of longevity. Who remembers the name of that song? Thought as much. But high street copies of the bracelet and belt she wore, composed of a series of adjacent gold squares, have become some of this season's most popular accessories.
fields.body:
Poor old Posh. Not only did she not reach the longed-for number one spot with her solo song, but the Pauric Sweeney jewellery she wore in the video has overtaken her little tune in terms of longevity. Who remembers the name of that song? Thought as much. But high street copies of the bracelet and belt she wore, composed of a series of adjacent gold squares, have become some of this season's most popular accessories.

Designer Pauric Sweeney is not your typical fabulous fashion fanatic. The down-to-earth Irishman actually started off in architecture, working in the decidedly unfashionable city of Philadelphia, before drifting into accessories in 1996 and fashion in 1998; he treats both as extensions of his earlier grounding in design, rather than forays on to planet fashion. OK, his work does veer towards the eccentric at times (airplane safety card cuff, anyone?) but, despite his plain-speaking assertions to the contrary, it is very trendy. Check it out next month when he and partner Ali open their new shop at 25A Pitfield Street in London's Hoxton.

Sweeney moved from Dublin to London in 1996 and he and Ali began selling accessories from a stall on Portobello Road, as well as through stores such as Janet Fitch and Kokon To Zai, the now traditional route for young London-based designers. They later opened the now defunct store Root on Brick Lane, a launchpad for Sweeney's work as well as that of other young designers and artists. This year he showed during Paris fashion week and his collection cocked its nose at chic Parisian pretensions with its fun mix of extreme tack (Paris wristbands, Eiffel Tower trinkets) and expensive materials, such as silky soft leather and delicate lace.

As his fame has grown, his accessories have been spotted on the lovely likes of Zoe Ball, Cat Deeley and Eva Herzigova - the mark of true fashion success in London town. He has never shown here, but with the combination of celebrity fans and his shop opening next month, you know it won't be long before the former architect from Donegal is touted as one of London's brightest fashion hopes. Fashion: it's a funny old world.

webTitle: Anniesland: victors pay tribute to Dewar

fields.headline: Anniesland: victors pay tribute to Dewar
fields.standfirst:
 Westminster seat: Labour hold, majority 6,337
 Edinburgh seat: Labour hold, majority 5,376

Special report: Election 2000
Full Anniesland results
fields.trailText: Anniesland's new MP John Robertson and MSP Bill Butler paid tribute in their  victory speeches to their predecessor, Scottish first minister Donald Dewar, whose shock death on 11 October prompted the by-elections.
fields.body:
Anniesland's new MP John Robertson and MSP Bill Butler paid tribute in their victory speeches to their predecessor, Scottish first minister Donald Dewar, whose shock death on 11 October prompted the by-elections.

Mr Butler said: "No-one will be able to fill Donald's shoes but I consider it a huge honour to be given the chance to follow in his footsteps.

"The people of Anniesland voted for decency, fairness and social justice - Donald Dewar's values and New Labour's values."

And Mr Robertson said: "I cannot be another Donald Dewar. I can only be John Robertson.

"But I promise the people of Anniesland that I will represent them to the best of my ability."

Later, the SNP's Westminster seat candidate Grant Thoms said: "We've achieved a 6% swing in Labour's safest seat in a by-election that no-one wanted. Translated nationally that means 13 Labour seats would go to the Scottish National Party."

A spokesman for the Scottish Liberal Democrats said: "Our share of the vote has increased substantially in both Glasgow seats. The swing was around 6% from Labour to the Scottish National Party in both the Westminster and Holyrood polls.

"We know that the real losers tonight are the SNP and the Tories. They have failed to make any improvement. This must be extremely worrying for the SNP so close to the General Election."

webTitle: Scottish TV wins exclusive Rugby Union rights

fields.headline: Scottish TV wins exclusive rugby rights
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Scottish TV and its digital spin-off S2 today clinched an exclusive Rugby Union deal. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Scottish TV has today clinched a Rugby Union deal giving the channel, and its digital spin-off S2, exclusive access to all BT Scotland Premiership and BT Cellnet cup matches until 2002.

Donald Emslie, Scottish Televison managing director, predicted that the deal could herald more home-grown sporting material and original programming for S2.

S2 currently takes most of its material from ITV digital channel ITV2, but supplements it with local programming.

Scottish, Grampian and S2 have access to sporting material from ITV sports deals as well as a £10m, four-year rights deal with the Scottish Premier League through to 2002.

Mr Emslie predicted that rights to Scottish sporting events would drive take-up of S2, which currently goes out to 3,000 homes.

He added: "Live domestic club rugby brings us to the heart of local communities."

Scottish TV is planning to beef up the original programming content on S2 and will launch a marketing drive early next year.

fields.headline: Fancy footwork
fields.standfirst: Look at them. Aren't they lovely? Stitched or slingback, cone-heeled or pointy-toed...  Jess Cartner-Morley  falls in love with winter's most wanted shoes
fields.trailText: Look at them. Aren't they lovely? Stitched or slingback, cone-heeled or pointy-toed... Jess Cartner-Morley falls in love with winter's most wanted shoes
fields.body:
Never a day goes by when I do not get asked the question: "Can you walk in those?" If I had the proverbial dollar for every time I'd been asked that - well, I probably wouldn't be any better off but Jimmy Choo would have a yacht bigger than Valentino's. Along with many, many otherwise rational people (mostly women, it must be said), I have a weakness for fancy shoes. Even when I try on clothes barefoot, I find myself standing on my tiptoes in invisible high heels, like Barbie.

All this despite the fact that I have an extremely practical approach to clothes. Batwing sleeves may be back (new silhouette, blah blah, you don't have to tell me) but I'm not convinced because I can't help worrying about how you'll get your coat on over the top. Short-sleeved (or, even worse, sleeveless) jumpers I can't be doing with because who wants a hot, itchy neck and cold arms? Yuck. And when I'm going out - I mean properly out, dancing and everything - I couldn't care less about the return of the mini because I always wear jeans so I can keep money, keys and lip balm in my pockets and don't need to carry a bag.

If you're now picturing me in an anorak and feeling sorry for me, however, I wouldn't worry too much. I mean, we're not talking any old jeans here, honey. And the good news is, when it comes to shoes, there is now quite an embarrassment of trimmed, glossed and ribboned delicacies available on the high street.

Until a few years ago, shoes were black or brown, and that was that. But after more than a decade of trainer design, in all its Technicolor glory, stealing a march on "proper" shoes, colour has exploded into shoe stores. In LK Bennett, it's actually quite difficult to find a black shoe among the autumnal blaze of rust and gold. What's more, high street shoe designers have woken up to the quick-fire catwalk copycat techniques that now rule the high street, so that the currently vogueish cone-shaped heel, for instance, was in Faith almost before it was in Harvey Nicks.

Last winter, there was a particularly vicious trend for going bare-legged. During February's New York fashion week, the terrifyingly tough local fashion sorority braved the blistering wind and snow-piled sidewalks with naked shins. Compared with that, this year's fishnets are positively cosy. And if you're worried they look a bit sluttish, rest assured you can now buy them in M&S. What could be more respectable than that?

fields.headline: Oversubscribed...
fields.standfirst: ...  pop star T-shirts
fields.trailText: ... pop star T-shirts
fields.body:
Put Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana next to the beer hatch at Brixton Academy on Tuesday, when Madonna performs in the UK for the first time in seven years, and the pair would do a roaring trade in their slashed and glittered Britney and Kylie tops. The T-shirts they designed for Madonna on her jaunt around the world, so far seen in New York and at the MTV awards in Stockholm, are the most wanted pieces of cloth in fashion.

Dolce could be the catalyst for a style frenzy, since it's nigh on impossible now to buy genuine pop T-shirts. After a post-grunge slump in the market, and teen girls more interested in bling-blings than fan clubs, record stores rely on metal-heads to support their ailing clothing trade. Combine the scarcity of product with the influence of Madonna, and you've got the makings of a major trend.

Heaven forbid we recommend unlicensed vendors, but your best chance of finding a ready-to-distress pop T-shirt is probably to nip down to your dodgiest local market. Get one with the name as a logo or (our favourite) a badly airbrushed picture, then pull the side seams and safety-pin it back together, and cut into the collar to create a cleavage-revealing V-neck.

Meanwhile, debate has turned to the next victim of Madonna's homage. We know she has an All Saints version, but that could still be in the wash pile. She could go retro and aim for Debbie Gibson, or big up Christina Aguilera or our own Billie Piper. But maybe Madonna should listen to her kids and pay tribute to a different genre of pop culture icon. D&G Tweenies, anyone?

webTitle: Clean sweep for Labour in election test

fields.headline: Clean sweep for Labour in election test
fields.standfirst:
Special report: elections 2000
Full results
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was still on course early today for a second general election victory next May after Labour held on to three "heartland" byelection seats against the hopes of the Conservatives and the Scottish Nationalists.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was still on course early today for a second general election victory next May after Labour held on to three "heartland" byelection seats against the hopes of the Conservatives and the Scottish Nationalists.

But the party's successful defence of West Bromwich West, where the vacancy was created by Betty Boothroyd's resignation as Speaker, as well as in Preston and the late Donald Dewar's seat in Glasgow Anniesland, was won on low voter turnouts among Labour loyalists - which led to modest swings against the government.

"Apathy is the winner," conceded one Millbank party official as the turnout was found to be 27.6% in West Bromwich, 29.7% in Preston and a healthier 38% in Anniesland where Mr Dewar's Westminster and Edinburgh parliamentary seats were at stake.

As party strategists on all sides pored over the runes there was consolation for them all. The Tories, who had quietly nursed hopes in Miss Boothroyd's West Midlands industrial villages, claimed the two English results - including a 9% swing in Preston, but only 2% in West Bromwich - would severely dent Mr Blair's 179 Commons majority.

In reality, only defeats might have made Mr Blair rethink his expected strategy of calling the election next spring, probably on May 3 after another generous budget from Gordon Brown.

The poll upset after the September fuel protest and the pensions row - which put the Conservatives ahead for the first time since 1992 - has been reversed since the pre-budget report. But Labour will be nervous at the low turnout.

The SNP also claimed to have hurt Labour in Glasgow. But neither leftwing chal lenges from a Socialist Alliance candidate who got 1,210 votes in Preston, nor the British National party's 794 votes in West Bromwich made as much of an impact as some Labour MPs feared.

In Glasgow the Scottish Socialists also polled a modest 1,429. The UK Independence party also slipped back in the face of William Hague's robust efforts to reconsolidate the core Tory vote behind his team.

Labour's Adrian Bailey, a former librarian who is also deputy leader of the local Sandwell council, won West Bromwich West with 9,640 votes, over the Conservatives' Karen Bissell on 6,408. The Lib Dems' Sadie Smith came in third with 1,791. The seat was not contested by the Tories and Lib Dems in the 1997 general election, because Miss Boothroyd, now a peer, was Speaker.

In Preston, Labour's Mark Hendrick, a 41-year-old former Liverpool MEP and Blair loyalist, won the seat held by the late Audrey Wise with 9,765 votes, over the Tories' Graham O'Hare on 5,339 with the Lib Dems' Bill Chadwick on 3,454.

fields.bodyText: Tony Blair was still on course early today for a second general election victory next May after Labour held on to three "heartland" byelection seats against the hopes of the Conservatives and the Scottish Nationalists. But the party's successful defence of West Bromwich West, where the vacancy was created by Betty Boothroyd's resignation as Speaker, as well as in Preston and the late Donald Dewar's seat in Glasgow Anniesland, was won on low voter turnouts among Labour loyalists - which led to modest swings against the government. "Apathy is the winner," conceded one Millbank party official as the turnout was found to be 27.6% in West Bromwich, 29.7% in Preston and a healthier 38% in Anniesland where Mr Dewar's Westminster and Edinburgh parliamentary seats were at stake. As party strategists on all sides pored over the runes there was consolation for them all. The Tories, who had quietly nursed hopes in Miss Boothroyd's West Midlands industrial villages, claimed the two English results - including a 9% swing in Preston, but only 2% in West Bromwich - would severely dent Mr Blair's 179 Commons majority. In reality, only defeats might have made Mr Blair rethink his expected strategy of calling the election next spring, probably on May 3 after another generous budget from Gordon Brown. The poll upset after the September fuel protest and the pensions row - which put the Conservatives ahead for the first time since 1992 - has been reversed since the pre-budget report. But Labour will be nervous at the low turnout. The SNP also claimed to have hurt Labour in Glasgow. But neither leftwing chal lenges from a Socialist Alliance candidate who got 1,210 votes in Preston, nor the British National party's 794 votes in West Bromwich made as much of an impact as some Labour MPs feared. In Glasgow the Scottish Socialists also polled a modest 1,429. The UK Independence party also slipped back in the face of William Hague's robust efforts to reconsolidate the core Tory vote behind his team. Labour's Adrian Bailey, a former librarian who is also deputy leader of the local Sandwell council, won West Bromwich West with 9,640 votes, over the Conservatives' Karen Bissell on 6,408. The Lib Dems' Sadie Smith came in third with 1,791. The seat was not contested by the Tories and Lib Dems in the 1997 general election, because Miss Boothroyd, now a peer, was Speaker. In Preston, Labour's Mark Hendrick, a 41-year-old former Liverpool MEP and Blair loyalist, won the seat held by the late Audrey Wise with 9,765 votes, over the Tories' Graham O'Hare on 5,339 with the Lib Dems' Bill Chadwick on 3,454. webTitle: At a glance: the parties' response to the results of 'super Thursday'

fields.headline: At a glance: the parties' response to the results of 'super Thursday'
fields.standfirst: Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText:
Labour
Trade and Industry secretary Stephen Byers said it was a good night for Labour but admitted "concern" over the low turn-out.
fields.body:
Labour
Trade and Industry secretary Stephen Byers said it was a good night for Labour but admitted "concern" over the low turn-out.

He accused the Conservatives of deliberately sowing disillusionment with politics in a bid to be voted in through the "back door".

"What we are increasingly seeing, I think, is a clear Tory strategy that they want to develop cynisism amongst the public about then body politic," Mr Byers said.

He denied a suggestion that ministers' contempt for parliament, particulrly from Prime Minister Tony Blair, had left voters feeling their voice did not count.

"What we are seeing is a Conservative approach which basically wants to turn people off of politics so they don't bother to vote, that's really the strategy," Mr Byers said.

"They (voters) are not going to have a poster put up by the Tory Party which has William Hague smiling on the doorstep of Number Ten. They want to get him in by the back door. That is the Conservative strategy."

Conservatives
Tory leader William Hague claimed today his party was making steady progress and had all to play for in a General Election despite Labour's string of four by-election victories.

"It's the Conservatives who increased their share of the vote across the constituencies, particularly the two in England," he told reporters at the start of a visit to a school in Dunblane, central Scotland. "That is steady progress on top of what we have achieved in elections earlier in the year and that is encouraging to us. We have to work still harder for the General Election - but it shows it is going in the right direction."

The Tory leader claimed the results were similar to 1992, when Tories failed to win those seats but won the subsequent General Election. He insisted: "We have made a dent with a strong swing to the Conservatives in Preston and West Bromwich. These are heartland Labour areas, traditional Labour seats that Labour has won for as long as anybody can remember. "

"But it shows the election is all to play for. The election is wide open. Labour could not turn out their votes in heartland areas, the Conservative share of the vote went up, and the Liberal Democrats got nowhere"

Liberal democrats
Liberal Democrat Leader Charles Kennedy said: "The by-elections show no enthusiasm for Labour, no hope for the Tories and a steady advance for the Liberal Democrats. Liberal Democrats have increased our share of support in all three constituencies compared to 1997 and 1999 (the date of Scottish parliamentary elections).

"It is a considerable achievement to advance from third place in parliamentary by-elections. This bodes well for Liberal Democrats' prospects in the General Election."

Scottish National party
Commenting on the Anniesland by-election results at a news conference in Glasgow this morning, the leader of the SNP John Swinney MSP said: "The SNP made clear progress in Anniesland, in by-election contests that no-one would have wished for.

"In what is Labour's safest Scottish Parliament seat in the whole country, the SNP vote moved forward, and Labour fell back.

"The swing achieved would result in the SNP moving ahead of Labour in voting intentions for the Scottish Parliament - and would see at least 13 Labour first-past-the-post Holyrood seats fall to the SNP, and three additional Westminster seats won by the SNP.

"In each and every electoral contest, the SNP are moving forward, and that was clearly achieved in Anniesland.

"Labour can have no grounds for complacency when their majority was halved for Holyrood, and more than halved for Westminster, in what was their safest seat in Scotland last May.

"We now look forward to winning in what will be the very different circumstances of the Falkirk West by-election."

webTitle: New roles cement Granada Media's takeover of United

fields.headline: New roles cement Granada Media's takeover of United
fields.trailText: 11am: Granada Media has appointed directors of production and business affairs for its LWT and United Productions divisions, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Directors of production and business affairs have been appointed to work across Granada Media's LWT and newly acquired United Productions divisions.

Tamara Howe, director of production for LWT and daughter of broadcaster Darcus Howe, will expand her role to work across United Productions, which has programme-making bases in Southampton, Norwich and Bristol as well as London.

Jane Turton, controller of commercial affairs at United, is to become director of business affairs across both Granada Media programme-making divisions.

She will take over the LWT business and commercial affairs brief from Simon Jones, who is leaving the company at the end of the year to join Pearson TV.

Ms Howe and Ms Turton will report to John Willis and Marcus Plantin, LWT and United Productions managing director and director of programmes respectively.

webTitle: Hello! again: back with those snaps

fields.headline: PR coup for Hello! as tabloids splash on wedding snaps
fields.standfirst: Nov 23: Hello! wins appeal
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Hello! magazine won a PR coup today as the tabloids splashed its photos of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones over their front pages, writes Claire Cozens.
Nov 23: Hello! wins appeal
fields.body:
Hello! magazine appeared to have achieved a PR coup today after the tabloids splashed its pictures of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones over their front pages, many ignoring the coverage in rival magazine OK!.

The Sun carried a picture of the blushing bride under the headline, "Bride Zeta, the wedding pictures they tried to ban". And the Daily Mail headlined its story, "Wedding picture war ends in victory for Hello!".

The Express kept its coverage of the wedding of the year low-key, even though its new sister title, OK!, hit the newsstands today.

The paper appeared to have missed a trick as news that Express readers would be treated to an exclusive look at "genuine photographs from the wedding album" on Monday was relegated to the final paragraph in a story on page 24.

But the evidence of a link-up with OK! was evident on page 3 of the Express with exclusive pictures of OK! regular star-turns Posh and Becks. Up to now the Express would have been barely in the running for pictures of the couple.

The Sun's fulsome coverage of the Zeta Jones wedding will have infuriated both the Express and Daily Mail bosses. The Mail was expected to carry the pictures from Hello! on Saturday, but it appears the Sun beat them to it.

Hello!'s pictures, which were branded "surreptitious" in the courts, were made available to the newspapers yesterday following a landmark ruling by the Court of Appeal.

It lifted an earlier, temporary, injunction on Hello! that had preventing it releasing 750,000 copies of this week's edition to newsagents.

This morning both Hello! and OK! have redoubled efforts to persuade readers to buy copies of the magazine. Newsstand copies of both magazines have their covers Sellotaped together in a bid to stop readers flicking through copies without buying them.

webTitle: Gore blow as court rules out key recount

fields.headline: Gore blow as court rules out key recount
fields.standfirst:
Vice-president must try to win without Miami-Dade

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText:
Al Gore made it plain last night that he is gearing up to
push the United States into a third week of uncharted
post-election territory.
fields.body:
Al Gore made it plain last night that he is gearing up to push the United States into a third week of uncharted post-election territory.

Sixteen days after the country voted inconclusively, his campaign team responded to its latest reverse in the courts by saying that it would challenge the results from the Florida county that refused to carry out the recount he had hoped would ease his passage to the White House.

His decision to fight on, whether or not he is ahead when the final Florida recount comes in on Sunday, means that this weekend is now unlikely to see a final decisive moment in the bitterly disputed election.

Yesterday the Florida supreme court declined to order election officials in Miami-Dade to recount the votes in the strongly Democratic county.

They had refused to do so because, they said, there was no way of meeting the 5pm Sunday deadline.

But the Gore camp said it would launch a fresh appeal in the US supreme court in the state capital Tallahassee on Monday, challenging the result in Miami-Dade, where more than 600,000 votes were cast, probably on the grounds that evidence material to the outcome of the election had not been taken into account.

The winner in Florida gains the state's 25 members of the electoral college, enough to make him president.

Ron Klain, a Gore adviser, said: "It's important that there be a full, fair and accurate count of these votes. We would prefer that it would be sooner rather than later, but it's going to happen.

"If Miami-Dade files a return that leaves out these votes we are going to contest that return, probably on Monday."

The Democrats say they still believe that they will find enough votes to overcome George W Bush's official lead of 930 votes in Florida.

But Mr Gore is not picking up the extra support he had expected in the two counties still working towards the Sunday deadline. By last night he had acquired an extra 88 votes in Broward county, which takes in Fort Lauderdale, making a net gain there of 225 against Mr Gore's lead. Broward has almost finished working its way through 2,000 disputed ballots.

Palm Beach, the county that introduced the world to the vagaries of Floridian elections, took a day off from counting yesterday for the Thanksgiving holiday and will be back at work today. It has re-examined but not finalised 300,000 ballots and must complete work on a further 10,000 disputed papers. There, Mr Bush has picked up a net 14 votes, leaving him with an unofficial lead of 719.

A Palm Beach county judge has said that "dimpled chad" - ballot cards which show an indentation but no perforation - must be counted, provided that the voter's intention is clear.

Meanwhile the Republican vice-presidential candidate, Dick Cheney, was in a Washington hospital recovering from "a very slight heart attack" - his fourth. He had surgery on Wednesday to implant an artery-clearing device.

"I can tell you they didn't find any pregnant chads," Mr Cheney, 59, quipped on television. He said the incident would not affect his ability to serve and that he hoped to leave hospital in a day or two.

Mr Bush also filed suit in a Florida court, asking to order 13 counties with heavy large military populations to count overseas ballots. But in most of America, consideration of Messrs Gore and Bush, dimpled ballots, chads, court hearings, election theft, hand-counting, machine tallies, military votes and whether Warren Christopher is the most lugubrious mouthpiece in the history of spin were largely set aside in favour of Thanksgiving Day and its concommitent perils.

These include friends, family, the tension induced by trying to get in front of the television before the Minnesota Vikings-Dallas Cowboys football game begins and securing the best bargains at the holiday sales, and massive ingestion of turkey, stuffing, cranberries and pumpkin pie.

Mr Bush started the day with a jog, had lunch with friends in Austin, and then headed home to the ranch near Waco. Mr Gore stayed indoors at his official residence in Washington.

fields.headline: Channel 4 recommissions Top Tens
fields.standfirst: Nov 23: Chrysalis TV restructures
fields.trailText:
Channel 4 has commissioned a new run of Top Ten 'rockumentaries' in a bid to establish the Saturday night show as one of its top brands, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Nov 23: Chrysalis TV restructures
fields.body:
They have been Channel 4's biggest Saturday night success stories for years.

Now the station has commissioned another batch of the hit Top Ten "rockumentaries" in a bid to establish the slot as one of its top brands.

Themes expected to feature in the new series include Teen Idols, Progressive Rock, Guitar Heroes, Easy Listening, Electro-pop and X-rated rock.

The episode on progressive rock will feature Chris Wright, the chairman of Chrysalis Entertainment, the production company behind the series.

In a separate development, sister company Chrysalis Visual Entertainment is rationalising its TV division to create new "centres of excellence".

Three new managing directors have been appointed to head up the divisions. Elaine Bedell takes over light entertainment, Neil Duncanson will look after sport and factual and Brian Truemay will handle drama.

Mr Wright and other Chrysalis executives admitted that the Visual Entertainment division had not performed as well as other TV production business, but refused to deny reports that they were considering selling the division.

Chief executive Richard Huntingford said: "Visual Entertainment is managed around the creative process. We have established a strong presence.

"We are now focusing on making sure that we run the business as well as we can and that we extract higher margins."

fields.headline: Taliban: no subversive gateaux
fields.standfirst: As Titanic fever grips Kabul, hardline militia proves no match for ... iced cakes
fields.trailText: Afghanistan's Taliban regime is trying to crack down on a craze for the Hollywood blockbuster Titanic which has swept through Kabul in an unlikely display of resistance to the militia's hardline rule.
fields.body:
Afghanistan's Taliban regime is trying to crack down on a craze for the Hollywood blockbuster Titanic which has swept through Kabul in an unlikely display of resistance to the militia's hardline rule.

Cinema, television and music have been banned in the capital since the Islamic movement seized power four years ago. But underground video shops run a healthy trade in films, with action movies and Bollywood dance classics particular favourites.

Now a people whose lives have been devastated by two decades of war have fallen for a love story and Titanic fever has gripped the city.

Under the counter at market stalls traders have been doing brisk business in clothes, perfumes, lipsticks and shoes all carrying pictures of the ill-fated ship. One variety of rice has been named Titanic.

Hairdressers have been offering a Leonardo DiCaprio cut, short at the back with a floppy fringe, though all men are also required to have untrimmed beards.

"Everyone has access to films but you have to keep a low profile," said one Afghan aid worker. "People used to watch Indian movies because they could understand the language. Now they have American films, and Titanic is everywhere."

Taliban leaders have complained about this spread of foreign culture, which has even reached the cake shops of the main shopping street. "It should be emphatically said," the official Shariat Weekly newspaper declared this month, "that the Chicken Street food stores should know that moulding their wedding cakes in the shape of the Titanic ship, the Eiffel Tower, the Taj Mahal and other designs is something against our national and Islamic culture."

Bakers should choose designs from the few traditional Afghan monuments still standing despite all the fighting, the paper suggested. Such cakes would "show the growth of our culture and prevent the sway of alien and infidel culture".

Before the 1979 Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, Kabul was fun. Pakistanis would drive up for the weekend to escape their more conservative society and enjoy Hindi movies and dances at the ballroom of the Intercontinental Hotel on a hillside above the city. Now the hotel is empty, its walls pocked with bullet holes, its ballroom locked, its swimming pool dry. Afghans go to Pakistan for their holidays.

fields.headline: Media Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 24.
fields.trailText: November 24: Northern & Shell Media has shocked the industry with its £125m acquisition of Express Newspapers.
fields.body:
Northern & Shell Media has shocked the industry with its £125m acquisition of Express Newspapers.

Media Campaign Services has been appointed to handle the £4m P&O Stena Line national press advertising account, replacing MindShare, which parted company with the shipping and cruise company earlier in the year.

MediaCom TMB is tipped to land the prized £100m Royal Bank of Scotland planning and buying account after a lengthy pitch process.

TSMS chief executive Jerry Hill is to take over as group chief executive of Initiative Media when the former United News & Media sales house is disbanded in the new year. Initiative Media is due to merge with fellow Interpublic Group agency Western Media next February.

Publicis Blueprint has added women's consumer magazine Voila to its burgeoning portfolio.

Microsoft is finalising the agency pitchlist for the European launch campaign of its Xbox games console. The overall global spend on the brand is around £354m, with the European launch campaign worth around £106m.

Vodafone is considering holding a pan-European pitch for its media business early next year, following the recruitment of new global brand director David Haines from Coca-Cola and the appointment of Carat to work on media planning for a one-off international branding task.

Orange is in talks with Conde Nast about providing Wap content.
