fields.headline: Fund delegation 'hampers schools'
fields.trailText: The government's spending watchdog urges ministers to think again before ordering councils to delegate more money to schools
fields.body:
Ministers are hampering schools by making too much of their funding short term, with strings attached, the government's spending watchdog reports today.

The audit commission calls for a halt to extra spending through the standards fund, the main lever used by the education secretary, David Blunkett, to inject cash into priorities such as literacy and numeracy.

The commission urges the government to take stock before ordering councils to delegate more money to schools. Ministers ordered councils to devolve 80% of their education budgets to schools last year and 85% this year, and want most councils to reach 90%.

The commission also criticises some headteachers for failing to link their budgets to their priorities and reports that up to 15% of schools have significant weaknesses in financial management.

Some £1.9bn, or 8%, of school spending will be directed by central government this year in England and Wales and will easily top £2bn next year. But the commission says: "Government should evaluate whether it is the best way to deliver national priorities. In particular, they must ask whether schools will be able to plan ahead effectively if a large proportion of their funding is short term and for specific activities."

Rather than extending the use of standards funds, government should evaluate whether they were the most effective way to deliver national priorities, it says

According to a commission survey, most headteachers welcomed the extra money in the standards fund, but complained of confusion about when it could be spent, a lack of flexibility and problems with planning ahead.

The report also urges a let-up in pressure on councils to release more money to schools - from government on the one hand, and from headteachers' associations on the other.

Many schools "had limited benefit" from the latest round of delegation.

Headteachers and governors in England and Wales now control 82% of money spent on schools - 10 years ago most controlled less than 5%. Ministers have been ratcheting up the requirements on councils to devolve money to schools but the commission reports that three-quarters of headteachers were happy with their local education authority's level of delegation.

It is "unlikely" that much greater gains could be made by pushing delegation further, the commission says. Instead the government should clarify what it expects from LEAs.

The commission rejects calls by headteachers' associations for a national funding formula for schools. Although it notes wide variations in the funding of schools of up to £1,600 in primary schools and £1,500 in secondary schools, about two-thirds of typical schools are funded within £200 of each other. "Funding choices are being made at the most appropriate level and most similar schools are getting comparable funding."

Andrew Foster, controller of the audit commission, said: "The present funding system needs to be made to work better, not replaced."

Estelle Morris, minister for school standards, said: "The audit commission has failed to recognise the key role the standards fund plays in providing ring-fenced support for national priorities." But reforms from next year would give schools more certainty about funding and more freedom on how to use the money.

She added: "We agree there are limits to how far delegation can be pushed ... but we do not accept delegation has gone too fast, or too far."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "I reject the criticism that secondary schools are not able to manage their budgets.

"The job of secondary schools is much harder until the government starts putting more money into core budgets."

webTitle: Hospital hygiene rules flouted, say doctors

fields.headline: Hospital hygiene rules flouted, say doctors
fields.standfirst: Three-quarters of doctors believe that hospital hygiene rules are routinely broken, according to a survey released yesterday
fields.trailText: Three-quarters of doctors believe that hospital hygiene rules are routinely broken, according to a survey released yesterday
fields.body:
Three-quarters of doctors believe that hospital hygiene rules are routinely broken, according to a survey released yesterday.

The survey, conducted by Medix, a website for registered doctors, found that 83% of the 831 respondents believed that it was not unusual for hygiene rules to be broken, and that as many believed NHS hospital hygiene was a serious problem. More than half the responses were from hospital doctors.

The survey coincided with the release of a report by a parliamentary spending regulator which found that 5,000 patients died every year from infections picked up in hospitals, at a cost to the NHS of £1bn a year. The reports are a blow to the government which this year pledged to crackdown on poor hospital hygiene.

Almost one in five doctors in the Medix survey said that disposable equipment was often re-used. Three-quarters said that poor infection control was putting lives at risk unnecessarily, and more than half said they did not believe the NHS was on course to reduce the problem of patients picking up life threatening infections.

Rino Coladangelo, of Medix, said: "What is very worrying is that so many doctors say that the infections are not due to antibiotic resistance but a failure in standard hygiene. They know hygiene rules are being broken and that they are contributing to it."

The scale of the threat of hospital acquired infection, revealed in yesterday's Commons public accounts committee report, was estimated to affect 100,000 hospital patients in England a year.

The report, Management and Control of Hospital Acquired Infection in NHS Acute Hospitals in England, said the NHS did not have a grip on the extent and costs of hospital acquired infection and was unlikely to have the information it needed for a further three to four years.

The government has allocated an extra £5m to combating the problem over the next two years, and additional infection control nurses have been appointed. However, the committee said that more funds were needed. It stressed that doctors and nurses, not just infection control specialists, must be more scrupulous about hygiene.

The committee said that it was "inexcusable" that compliance with guidance on hand washing was so poor.

David Davis, committee chairman and Conservative MP for Haltemprice and Howden, said: "While it will never be entirely preventable there is more the NHS could do to combat the problem."

A hospital acquired infection, which can be caused by viruses, bacteria, fungi or parasites, may develop from surgical procedures, catheters in the urinary tract or blood vessels, or from bugs in the air. They may be present in the patient's body or come from healthcare workers, other patients, contaminated hospital equipment or the environment.

An average patient with a hospital acquired infection spent more than double the time in hospital and cost the NHS an extra £3,000 to treat according to a report this year by the London school of hygiene and the public health laboratory.

John Denham, the health minister, said that infection control teams, minimum standards and a mandatory reporting system had been introduced to every hospital during the last three years.

"There is too much hospital acquired infection and that is why action is being taken, now across the NHS to fight them," he said.

webTitle: Man with cancer 'left to die in hospital'

fields.headline: Man with cancer 'left to die in hospital'
fields.standfirst: Health trust launches investigation after family claims patient suffered treatment 'worse than an animal' in Victorian ward. Vikram Dodd reports
fields.trailText: Health trust launches investigation after family claims patient suffered treatment 'worse than an animal' in Victorian ward. Vikram Dodd reports
fields.body:
An NHS trust yesterday launched an investigation into allegations that a man with cancer was left to die on a mental health ward.

The family of Lawrence Jordan say he was given only paracetamol to relieve his pain, and was so neglected he was covered in his own excrement, and bruises from falling out of bed.

Leicestershire and Rutland Healthcare NHS trust admitted having a shortage of nurses and will meet Mr Jordan's family next week.

Mr Jordan,73, died in August after being admitted for tests after the onset of dementia.

He was treated for seven weeks on ward five at Leicester general hospital.

The 20-bed ward to assess older people with mental health problems was Victorian, according to Mr Jordan's family who say it reeked of urine.

He was found to have a tumour behind his eye that was so large it caused his eye to bulge and was pressing on his brain. He also had cancer of the bowel, lungs and liver.

Mr Jordan's daughter, Joanne Silverwood, 35, said: "If it had been an animal the RSPCA would have been called in to investigate that ward. He was treated worse than an animal."

"One nurse said that they couldn't move him as there would be too much paper work. Another nurse was in tears and said 'sorry he's not getting the care he should be getting'."

The family say they had to battle to get Mr Jordan a specialist cancer nurse and a private room for his last few days.

Joanne's sister Alicia Jordan, 33, said: "They made him wear incontinence pants even though he wanted to go to the toilet. They wouldn't clean him for hours. He was only given one bath in seven weeks.

"They didn't treat him for the cancer, there was no radiotherapy or chemotherapy, they just let him die. On a cancer ward he'd probably be on a morphine drip and have had better care.

"I cried every time I saw him. Towards the end he was covered in his own excrement. It was on his pillow and his hands, it was just horrible."

In a statement Leicestershire and Rutland healthcare NHS trust said: "The issues raised in August by the family concerned were investigated at the time and the family was provided with a full response and details of our findings.

"We are naturally anxious that any new concerns expressed by the family are fully understood and are thoroughly investigated by the trust.

"All complaints received by the trust are dealt with as very serious matters and we ensure that they are properly and fully investigated."

The statement said the trust was worried about the effect of adverse publicity after Mr Jordan's family's allegations were broadcast by BBC Radio 4's You and Yours programme.

"Staff working on ward five are naturally upset about the recent publicity and the trust is offering them support and reassurance."

The government has vowed to improve the treatment of cancer, pledging more money, doctors and nurses.

On a cancer ward he'd probably be on a morphine drip and have had better care. "I cried every time I saw him. Towards the end he was covered in his own excrement. It was on his pillow and his hands, it was just horrible." In a statement Leicestershire and Rutland healthcare NHS trust said: "The issues raised in August by the family concerned were investigated at the time and the family was provided with a full response and details of our findings. "We are naturally anxious that any new concerns expressed by the family are fully understood and are thoroughly investigated by the trust. "All complaints received by the trust are dealt with as very serious matters and we ensure that they are properly and fully investigated." The statement said the trust was worried about the effect of adverse publicity after Mr Jordan's family's allegations were broadcast by BBC Radio 4's You and Yours programme. "Staff working on ward five are naturally upset about the recent publicity and the trust is offering them support and reassurance." The government has vowed to improve the treatment of cancer, pledging more money, doctors and nurses.

fields.headline: Tate Modern seeks new ad agency for guerrilla campaign
fields.trailText: 8.15am: The Tate Modern museum is looking for an ad agency to create its first guerrilla advertising campaign, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
The Tate Modern is looking for an ad agency to create its first guerrilla advertising campaign.

The museum, which opened in May, has ended its four-year relationship with TBWA\London and is close to appointing a new agency.

This time the Tate will shun conventional advertising in favour of something that uses alternative media.

It has shortlisted four agencies to pitch for the business and a decision is expected before Christmas.

The new work will launch early next year.

Damien Whitmore, director of communications at the Tate Modern, said: "There is a very different job to be done now.

"We will be looking for a very different creative style using different media and different messages from an agency that can work quickly. They will need to maximise our very limited resources."

The campaign will be used to promote upcoming exhibitions such as the William Blake, Century City and Victorian Nude shows.

The number of visitors to the Tate Modern in its first year have hit 3.5m. The campaign is expected to help maintain figures around the 3-4m mark.

webTitle: Leader: The Express has a new saviour

fields.headline: Catching a fallen star
fields.standfirst:
The Express has a new saviour. Again

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Daily Express was once a paper whose journalism thundered out across country and Empire. For more than 15 years it sold more than 4m copies a day. Its proprietor, Lord Beaverbrook, liked to think of his main paper as a weapon. "When skilfully employed at the psychological moment," he wrote, "no politician of any party can resist it.
fields.body:
The Daily Express was once a paper whose journalism thundered out across country and Empire. For more than 15 years it sold more than 4m copies a day. Its proprietor, Lord Beaverbrook, liked to think of his main paper as a weapon. "When skilfully employed at the psychological moment," he wrote, "no politician of any party can resist it. It is a flaming sword which will cut through any political armour. Many newspaper are harmless because they do not know how to strike or when to strike ... But teach the man behind them how to load and what to shoot at, and they become deadly."

The Daily Express today is more a peashooter than an Armalite and one may be tempted to shrug at the news that it has, in its twilight years, fallen into the hands of one Richard Desmond, who made his name and fortune publishing such magazines as Big Ones, Asian Babes and Readers' Wives. But to be indifferent to the fate of a newspaper is to be complacent about democracy itself. The Express - sadly diminished though it may be, compared with its glory days - is still read by more than 2.4m adults a day. That is, by any standards, a considerable audience. Who owns the paper, and why they own it, matters. Beaverbrook's military metaphors may seem boastfully grandiose until one reflects that Mr Blair's colleagues appear to have spent much of yesterday's cabinet meeting fulminating about one article in that morning's Daily Mail. Some papers still fire armour-piercing shells.

In the absence of competition issues, there is probably no satisfactory regulatory mechanism to have prevented Mr Desmond from buying the titles. It is fair to suspend judgments on him until we have a clearer picture of whether his intentions extend beyond a wish for more celebrity journalism. But we should not pretend that the fact of one of our daily national newspapers changing hands doesn't matter. It does.

fields.headline: Sobering images to discourage drink-drivers
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Graphic images of real road accidents will feature in a stark series of government-sponsored television advertisements to discourage drink-driving this Christmas.
fields.body:
Graphic images of real road accidents will feature in a stark series of government-sponsored television advertisements to discourage drink-driving this Christmas.

At the launch of the campaign in London yesterday, the winner of the Channel 4 Big Brother contest, Craig Phillips, told how his father died when he was hit by a car driven by a drunk driver in 1984.

"I am backing the campaign because I know from bitter experience how drink-driving can wreck lives. I was 13 when my dad was knocked down and killed by a drink-driver," Mr Phillips said.

"His death shattered our family. The memory of his loss is often hardest to bear at Christmas because it's a time when families traditionally come together.

"People must realise that drinking and driving kills. My message is simple. Don't drink and drive this Christmas. Don't take the chance of destroying a life and a family."

In the campaign, Christmas favourites Mistletoe and Wine, by Cliff Richard, and I Wish It Could Be Christmas Every Day, by Roy Wood and Wizard, will be played over scenes of road carnage.

The adverts were shown for the first time last night and will run until New Year's Eve.

At the launch, the transport minister Lord Whitty said: "We hope this hard hitting campaign will serve as a reminder to people of the very real dangers of drink-driving.

"These commercials contain very harrowing images, which we believe will hammer home the message that drinking and driving can wreck lives."

Pauline Clare, the vice-chairwoman of the Association of Chief Police Officers' road policing committee, said: "Drivers have the responsibility to think before they drink and drive and not combine the two.

"This responsibility doesn't just rest with the driver. Society needs to reject drink-driving as an option."

This year's campaign is aimed at all drivers although past efforts have concentrated on young male motorists and a hard core of middle-aged drivers who have ignored the anti drinking and driving message.

Successive governments have been pleased with the decline in the number of people killed annually in drink-drive related crashes.

But ministers are anxious for a greater reduction in the fatality rate. In the early 1980s this was as high as 1,500 a year. The figure for 1999 was around 420 - a decrease from the 1998 figure of 460.
Press Association

webTitle: Radio 1 celebrate first online music award

fields.headline: Radio 1 celebrates first online music award
fields.trailText: 8am: Radio 1, Peoplesound and the ubiquitous Napster were among those celebrating last night at Music Week's online music awards. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Radio 1, Peoplesound and the ubiquitous Napster were among those celebrating last night at Music Week magazine's inaugural online music awards.

Peoplesound beat off competition from MusicUnsigned and Vitaminic to pick up the award for best A&R site.

Radio 1 picked up the award for best company website, trumping Music Week's own website, dotmusic, and BTGetOutThere, iCrunch and The Box.

Hardly the biggest surprise of the evening was the news that Napster was confirmed as the only real online pioneer in the music industry.

Radiohead won best alternative website and Eminem romped home with best international artist website.

Not to be outdone, Toploader picked up the best pop artist website award and Supergrass landed the award for best rock artist website.

Event director Steve Redmond said: "We started these awards because we recognise there's a whole new music industry developing, one that isn't based on the single or the album, vinyl and CD, but on bits, bytes and the internet."

Other winners include: best dance artist website - Deejay Punk-Roc; best label website - INCredible; best online promotional campaign - Fat Les "Turn Your Mobiles On For England"; best e-flyer - Sisqo Twang A Thong.

webTitle: Party leaders presented with terms for TV election debates

fields.headline: Party leaders presented with terms for TV election debates
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC and ITV last night laid down a non-negotiable deal for Britain's three main political party leaders to take part in the country's first televised election debate.
fields.body:
The BBC and ITV last night laid down a non-negotiable deal for Britain's three main political party leaders to take part in the country's first televised election debate.

Setting aside their recent squabbles, the broadcasters outlined plans for two live prime time clashes between Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy.

Labour and the Liberal Democrats reacted positively, but the Conservatives appeared to place a stumbling block in front of the plans by repeating their call for three one-on-one debates between the leaders.

If the deal goes ahead, it will be the first time that such an event has happened in Britain. Some observers believe live debates can make or break a leader's chances of electoral success, and they tend to favour challengers rather than incumbents. But Mr Blair is thought to believe he would come off best in a clash with either or both of his opponents.

Under the plan, the three leaders would face each other in two live debates, screened separately on BBC1 and ITV. The BBC's version would be chaired by David Dimbleby, and ITV's would be fronted by his brother, Jonathan.

The debates would be staged in front of a representative audience picked by an independent polling organisation. The guests would be able to applaud, but would not have an opportunity to ask questions. Each debate would cover three key subjects, and the leaders would making brief opening and closing statements, before taking questions from the presenter. They would be able to cross-examine each other.

Parties in Scotland and Wales have also been invited to take part in debates screened on the networks in the two nations. Proposals for Northern Ireland are in the pipeline.

Previous attempts to stage a set piece election debate have foundered on disputes over the format - the BBC-ITV deal is an attempt to present a united front.

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, has already hinted that Mr Blair would be willing to take part in a TV clash. He has already agreed to take part in an Ask the Prime Minister debate for ITV, to be presented next month by Jonathan Dimbleby. A Labour spokesman said yesterday's proposal would be considered. The Liberal Democrats were also positive. But while the Tories said they would consider the plan, the party chairman Michael Ancram repeated his call for a series of three one-on-one debates between the leaders and expressed opposition to the three-way format.

Executives at the BBC and ITV said the three-way clash would produce a more cohesive debate. Writing to the politicians, they said it would "engage the electorate in the significance and excitement of democracy in action".

Tony Hall, director of BBC News, said: "Televised leaders' debates are a familiar part of the electoral landscape across the democratic world and it's time British voters had the same opportunity to see the politicians in action."

Steve Anderson, ITV's controller of news and current affairs, added: "That is why we are setting aside the usual trench warfare between news broadcasters and uniting behind this important project."

The BBC and ITV have given the three leaders a deadline of the end of January to respond to the challenge.

Other broadcasters, including Sky News, will be given free access to the debates if they go ahead.

fields.headline: The best cell scene
fields.standfirst: Chopper
fields.trailText: Chopper
fields.body:
Pentridge Prison, Australia, 1978. Mark "Chopper" Read (Eric Bana) has been plotting an escape with his cell-mates, Jimmy (Simon Lyndon) and Bluey (Daniel Wyllie). As the three pace around their shared cell, with Chopper hand-rolling a cigarette, Jimmy suddenly spins round and punches him in the stomach.

Chopper reels back, aghast.

"It's a bit early in the morning for kung fu isn't it Jim?"

Jim punches him again. Chopper takes another step back.

"What's the matter with you Jim?"

Chopper glances down at his stomach. Seeing blood seeping through his shirt, realisation dawns that he hasn't been punched, but stabbed. He places his hand over the wound.

"Now, just hold on a minute..."

He places his part-rolled cigarette in his top pocket, and nonchalantly eyeballs Jimmy.

"What are you doing?"

Without replying, Jimmy lunges forward and stabs Chopper a third time. Chopper looks baffled.

"What's got into you?"

Jimmy stabs him again. Chopper takes a step towards him, his arms held out.

"Come here, mate. Come here..."

He gives Jimmy a warm, sincere hug. Jimmy starts to weep.

"Sorry, Chop."

Chopper pats Jimmy on the back.

"It's all right."

Jimmy stabs Chopper a fifth time.

"Shit! Look, Jim, if you keep stabbing me, you're going to kill me, all right?"

See also:
The Shawshank Redemption, Face/Off, Each Dawn I Die

Don't see also:
Caged Heat

Pointless trivia:
In his native Australia, sometime stand-up comedian Eric Bana has his own TV series, called Eric.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Any Given Sunday  | Relative Values | Reservoir Dogs (DVD)
fields.trailText: Any Given Sunday | Relative Values | Reservoir Dogs (DVD)
fields.body:
Any Given Sunday
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Warner Cert 15
**

Hollywood's most macho director, Oliver Stone, takes on that most macho sport, American football. The end result is every bit as bombastic and bloated as you'd expect: 150 minutes of bone crunching, shouting and sentiment, and reams of set-piece declamatory "dialogue" of the kind nobody actually says: it's an Ollie war movie by other means. Al Pacino does his thing as the ageing coach and repository of integrity. He balances out great movies like The Insider with overblown schlock like this and Devil's Advocate, and he supplies what few touching moments the movie has (like a losing attempt to interest a rap-crazed black team member in John Coltrane and Miles Davis). And Pacino plays the inevitable big speech likening life to football with brusque authority. As usual, Stone fills the screen with montage, freeze frames and jump cuts, but he can't avoid the inevitable sport-on-film problem: sport's trump card is that you don't know what will happen next, that it defies the coaches' attempts at stage-management. A match climax directed by Oliver Stone could hardly be more predictable.

Relative Values
Rental Alliance Atlantis
Cert PG
**

There's an odd kind of pleasure from this Noël Coward adaptation in the sheer unlikelihood of anyone wanting to do one or watch one in the year 2000. It's set in a swoonsome English country house (with even more gorgeous grounds) on the return of young sir with an American actress in tow and marriage in mind. Stephen Fry gets some Sir Humphreyish circumlocution as the butler, Julie Andrews is in control as matriarch, William Baldwin the pursuing "bourbon-soaked oaf". A light touch makes it at home on TV.

Reservoir Dogs
DVD (£19.99) Momentum
Cert 18
*****

You won't need me to review Tarantino's skilful, scary and very funny debut, in retrospect surely the most influential film of the 1990s. This widescreen DVD debut comes complete with an introduction from the director, whose inspiration seems to have been a dearth of good heist movies in his video store. Tarantino also does impressions of Tim Roth and Harvey Keitel, whose persistence and kindness did so much to get the film made - appropriately, as Keitel is the film's only moral centre. It's very bloody but there's very little violence - though Michael Madsen is still terrifying: the only time the internet made me jump was when it suddenly spoke his "little doggie" speech at me.

webTitle: Judy Berlin director Eric Mendelson on his island of lost souls

fields.headline: Island of lost souls
fields.standfirst: Artists, socialites, poets and murderers - Long Island has had them all. Now Edie Falco of Sopranos fame stars in a new film celebrating this remarkable finger of land just off New York.  Howard Feinstein  tours the neighbourhood with director Eric Mendelsohn
fields.trailText: Artists, socialites, poets and murderers - Long Island has had them all. Now Edie Falco of Sopranos fame stars in a new film celebrating this remarkable finger of land just off New York. Howard Feinstein tours the neighbourhood with director Eric Mendelsohn
fields.body:
Long Island. Well, it is long: 120 miles long to be exact, though most of it is less than 20 miles wide. Few have been able to aptly describe life on this finger of land east of Manhattan (population 2.6m) or to find apt metaphors for its unique combination of the bizarre and the ordinary.

In Massapequa in 1992, Amy Fisher, the Long Island Lolita, shot the wife of her lover Joey Buttafuoco in the head; and in Garden City in 1993, Colin Ferguson killed six commuters in a shooting rampage on the Long Island railroad. Yet it was also on Long Island that a pioneering new planned town of cookie-cutter houses known as Levittown, now a generic term, opened for business in 1947.

We're talking suburbia. Between the western New York City boroughs of Queens and Brooklyn and the fertile agricultural plots and chic resorts in the eastern section, Long Island is suburbs. Some wealthy, others strictly working-class, its towns are a mixed bag of old and new, textured and tacky, substantial and empty. The fictional Jay Gatsby lived in a mansion on the north shore, Jackson Pollock painted on the south shore, Walt Whitman was born in the centre. But the Gold Coast mansions frequented by the Fitzgeralds have deteriorated; Pollock's rustic Hamptons are now an almost parodic retreat for the newly rich; and the huge Walt Whitman mall overshadows the poet's small clapboard house in Huntingdon.

Long Island has its apologists. Among them is New York City-based film-maker Eric Mendelsohn, whose debut feature, Judy Berlin, is set completely on the island, and earned him the best director prize at Sundance last year, He grew up there with the movie's leading lady, Edie Falco, now of Sopranos fame.

"Because there is such conformity on Long Island, there are weird expressions of individualism," says Mendelsohn, a dark-haired 36-year-old with an angelic face. "On a block where houses are exactly the same, someone will have put in a pagoda or a goldfish pond. A lot of people in the Long Island suburbs are self-conscious about feeling stupid, but I find that charming."

Falco, part Italian and part Swedish, was born in West Islip, then moved to upper-middle-class Northport. "We were part of the lower echelon there," she says. Her accent is strong Long Islandese, as in "lawn giland". She feels that Long Islanders get a bad rap in movies. "They're an easy target. I object to the stereotype. They're close enough to Manhattan to be in the loop, but far enough away to have a civilised life. The way they're portrayed in movies is kind of a drag: not being particularly intelligent, not being aware of what's going on in the world around them."

Hal Hartley is Long Island's best-known independent film-maker, and his second movie, Trust, is set in his native Lindenhurst, a working-class town. It features an angry Martin Donovan carrying a hand grenade wherever he goes, a more memorable presence than confused teen Adrienne Shelly, or even tacky older sister Edie Falco. Then there's Edward Burns's overrated Sundance winner The Brothers McMullen. (The John Hurt starrer Love and Death on Long Island hardly counts - it certainly wasn't shot on the island - and the protagonists of Greg Mottola's The Daytrippers and Jonathan Demme's Married to the Mob are shown fleeing the place.) Trees Lounge, Steve Buscemi's liquor-soaked directorial debut, remains a rare sympathetic high point of Long Island lore, and you have to go back to Frank Perry's 1985 black comedy Compromising Positions for a bearable, and funny, portrait of Long Island life.

"Films about Long Island focus more on the men than the women," Mendelsohn complains. "In a place that is forgotten and maligned, there's no greater candidate for patron sainthood than the women of Long Island, who are also forgotten in films. They are enormously strong, interesting people." He has turned the genre upside-down, in large part because his mostly female characters have a stoicism and grace lacking in Hartley's work.

The focus of Judy Berlin is the eponymous Babylon resident, a part he wrote for Falco. Judy is an ebullient, overeager aspiring actress of 32 with huge braces on her teeth and a one-way ticket to Hollywood in her handbag. Most of Judy's scenes are with her former high-school pal, David Gold (Aaron Harnick), a sad cynic who says he makes documentary films but has returned, feeling a failure, to his parents' home. His folks are even unhappier than he: his mother, Alice (Madeline Kahn, in her last role), is a housewife with nothing but time on her hands.

On an unseasonably cold Sunday morning in late October, Mendelsohn and I take the train out to the areas where he shot the $200,000 film. We get out an hour later in Farmingdale, the old three-storey, brick-and-wood train station of which is the setting for Judy Berlin's opening and closing scenes. In a bakery filled with pastel-coloured cup cakes, screaming children and parents in baseball caps, we discuss the film's surreal structure. About 20 minutes in, a full eclipse begins, and does not go away. The characters act out their frustrations in the same darkness that envelops the audience. The device is, Mendelsohn insists, a "problem solver", one of many terms he learned from Woody Allen while working on costumes for all his films from Crimes and Misdemeanours to Everyone Says I Love You.

"I wanted a disruption," he says. "I wanted to show this little place and take one step to the left of absolute reality, which an eclipse conveniently provides." In most of the neighbourhood scenes, the "little place" is his native suburb of Old Bethpage, where his Bronx-born parents - Jay, a retired research scientist for an aeronautics company, and Marlene, a schoolteacher - raised him and his three brothers and sister. We leave the bakery and hire a taxi. Mendelsohn whispers to me that our driver Randi, a hefty, affable young woman, is very Judy Berlin-ish. We drive over to Old Bethpage, passing the redbrick strip mall where, in the film, David reluctantly re-encounters Judy in the film after a 14-year hiatus. Then we go past the Mendelsohn family home in a carefully-planned neighbourhood chock full of sycamore, maple, and pine trees.

Randi lets us out at the visitor centre. Snow falls. Geese wander; cows and bulls are penned in the distance. "This is the one place on Long Island that hasn't been touched by commercialism, that doesn't feel like Disneyland," says Mendelsohn. "Part of growing up here was looking for something more mysterious than the town. So much of Long Island seems prefabricated, but I knew there had to be a history, so I loved coming here." We pass the Williams farm where Judy worked, then on to the Noon Inn, home to the Noons 150 years ago, now populated by a fiddler, bartender, and assorted women in period gear, some with non-period parkas on top.

The restoration, though something of a rupture, fits into Mendelsohn's masterplan: nothing in the film looks or seems quite real. He shot the film in a pristine black and white that is almost as artificial as Technicolor, and the harpsichord on the soundtrack reinforces the feeling of estrangement. "I'm not interested in vérité," he says.

We are now back in Farmingdale; Randi has taken us to the Library Cafe, a library-turned-diner where a football game plays on four suspended screens and, for no apparent reason, carousel animals hang from the ceiling. "Judy Berlin is a fairy tale about real life and suburban hard knocks," he continues. "On top of its Jewish humour and serious melancholy is the science- fiction aspect of an eclipse. Black and white helps loosen people from their preconceived notions of what the suburbs are. With colour, you would have seen the FedEx trucks going by, the Häagen-Dazs logo. It would have all been familiar. The easiest way to direct an audience's eyes to a performance is to eradicate colour."

And he is proud of the performances he gets. "Madeline Kahn's work in this film stands up with any of the studio films she's done, or the stage performances she's given." Mendelson says he learned to trust actors from Woody Allen. "He lets them go," he says, citing Allen's confidence during the showing of dailies. "What I began to realise is that you are renting out an actor's unfinished, compelling personality for a month. That's what they are selling: something unexamined about themselves that people find interesting to look at."

He saw this especially in Kahn. "She was nervous and delicate and fragile. But those moments when she was being Alice Gold, she was hot, she was on, and she knew it. At rehearsals in her apartment, I once said, 'It must be so hard to be you,' and she said, 'Thank you for saying that.' I do think it was hard for her to get through the day sometimes." Kahn was diagnosed with cancer a few months after filming wrapped.

"For me, Judy Berlin is a success from the beginning of the movie. I'm in love with people like Judy who are real believers. Whatever is put in front of them in life, they go through with a machete."

Falco sees her differently. "I think she would give LA a shot for a while. It probably wouldn't work out, and she would go into something else and be very good at it." I proceed to tell her about Randi the cabbie. "That's it!" she yelps into the receiver. "That's what she ends up doing in LA! She drives a taxi!"

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: The winter yule crisis

fields.headline: The winter yule crisis
fields.standfirst: Jim Carrey does Dr Seuss in bland-o-vision - where are the real holiday blockbusters?
fields.trailText: Jim Carrey does Dr Seuss in bland-o-vision - where are the real holiday blockbusters?
fields.body:
It seems like only yesterday it was Halloween. Now it's Thanksgiving and the biggest movie of the week is How the Grinch Stole Christmas. All our holidays seem to have been concertinaed into one never-ending spending spree. No sooner have we finished filling our faces with turkey - which we do here on Thanksgiving - than we are all collectively shoved down that long, steep, greased chute of consumer mania that leads to the Little Lord Jesus's annual birthday knees-up.

Already my neighbours have spent entire afternoons laboriously hoisting illuminated Santa sleighs - complete with beardie fat blokes and full complements of reindeer - up on to the roofs of their suburban houses. Green lawns are dotted with plastic snowmen and angels, plus nativity scenes with supplicant shepherds, beaming wise men bearing pressies, Mary and Joseph, ox and ass, and the manger containing the Wee Feller himself. A week from now the main street winding through my neighbourhood will look like a miniaturised version of the Las Vegas strip.

Everyone tries to outdo their neighbour's decorations - except me. The only thing on my front lawn so far is a rotten pumpkin left over from Halloween. I must try harder.

Which isn't something that needs to be said about How the Grinch Stole Christmas. The Ron Howard vehicle boldly staked its claim to the pre-Thanksgiving weekend leisure dollar and came away with a staggering 55m of 'em. Everywhere I went last weekend there were large family groups setting out with deliriously animated children to see Jim Carrey as Dr Seuss's famous green monster. I also attended, wearing my One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish T-shirt in honour of the good doctor, and struggled to find a seat, finally ending up in the extreme front right of the auditorium.

Thanks to the rotten design of the theatre, watching the movie was like trying to stare into someone's living room when you're standing on the pavement seven doors down the street. To be honest, the movie didn't much improve the experience for me, but I can't deny that I was in the middle of a pretty happy audience.

At the very least it proved Carrey's broad appeal. Here, under piles of livid green make-up, Carrey is about a million miles from the Farrelly brothers' Me, Myself and Irene. For a moment I fantasised about storming the projection booth, tying up the projectionist and substituting Irene for The Grinch, just to see what would happen if 1,500 under-nines were suddenly to see a psychotic Carrey enjoying sexual congress with a pierced grapefruit.

Which perhaps shows Grinch's limitations: I shouldn't have to improve the movie with my imagination. Dr Seuss - or Ted Giesel - is one of the patron saints of American childhood, but surprisingly few attempts have been made to transfer his universe of cats in hats to the big screen.

The most famous is The 5,000 Fingers of Dr T, made back in 1953 when America was so straight and so pre-ironic that its surrealism must have seemed 10 times as demented. Dr T (short for Terwilliker) is a megalomaniacal music teacher who - in a pupil's dream - imprisons 500 little boys to play his composition on an endless piano keyboard.

Unlike The Grinch, Dr T probes the layers of Freudian weirdness inherent in Giesel's inimitable imagery, and adds some of the campest musical numbers ever filmed. Of course, in its straitlaced time it was largely ignored, though it now endures as a masterpiece of... well, something pretty strange. It belongs in the same cult-classic company as Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, the 1971 Roald Dahl adaptation starring Gene Wilder, which also failed at the box office - but also found a new home among stoned college students and on the old midnight-movie circuit that was killed off by video. I saw them both on a midnight double-bill in the early 1980s with an audience that, so far as I could determine, was blitzed on recreational hallucinogens.

Elsewhere this weekend I was encouraged to note that The 6th Day did no better with two Arnold Schwarzeneggers than it might have done with just one. This is an attempt by Schwarzenegger to return to Total Recall territory. He wakes up one morning and finds he's been illegally cloned, with the other Schwarzenegger enjoying all the things he thinks should be rightfully his - sexy wife, sexy life, etc. Risky business, all this cloning: it lays Schwarzenegger open to the accusation that all his recent film endeavours have been clones of his previous hits - and with Terminator 3 and True Lies 2 somewhere over the horizon, it seems like nothing's about to change.

And Adam Sandler took a mighty plummet down the charts with his moronic son-of-Satan comedy Little Nicky. The word-of-mouth has been abysmal and the second-week drop-off in attendance may signal Sandler's consignment to oblivion.

Which now leaves us waiting for the big seasonal blockbusters, which are now lined up mooing and crapping in the stalls like rodeo bulls ready to be unleashed into the arena. I'm looking forward to Cast Away, which I hope will redeem Robert Zemeckis after his lame Hitchcock rip-off What Lies Beneath.

And this week we'll get Unbreakable, M Night Samalyan's follow up to his surprise hit The Sixth Sense. Maybe we'll end up with a merry Christmas after all.

fields.headline: Singin' in the Rain review
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There’s no arguing with a classic of this substance
fields.body:
There's no arguing with a classic of this substance, and no missing the opportunity to re-visit on the big screen Stanley Donen and Gene Kelly's brilliant Technicolor vision of innocence, happiness, and masculine grace - available with the BFI's re-issue on new 35mm prints.

It's idle to mutter about them not making them like this any more: this is a film about the industry ruthlessly turning its back on the old silent movies for the new talkies. Singin' in the Rain is about cinema's capacity for re-invention - its hunger for its own future.

webTitle: Woody Allen: on Mia, movies and self-mockery

fields.headline: 'My bust-up with Mia would have made a great movie'
fields.standfirst: Woody Allen offended many people by running off with Mia Farrow's 21-year-old adopted daughter, Soon-Yi. Some of  Molly Haskell's friends won't even go to see his films. What, she asks him, does he have to say about that?
fields.trailText: Woody Allen offended many people by running off with Mia Farrow's 21-year-old adopted daughter, Soon-Yi. Some of Molly Haskell's friends won't even go to see his films. What, she asks him, does he have to say about that?
fields.body:
A three-room suite at New York's Regency hotel has been booked for the weekend so that the foreign press can interview Woody Allen for the European opening of Small Time Crooks. When I arrive on Saturday, the video cameras are whirring, journalists are stacked in orderly fashion like planes waiting for take-off at La Guardia, and a variety of accents can be heard as questions technical and metaphysical are volleyed across the language barrier and answers are graciously batted back.

I'm reminded of the scene in Notting Hill where Julia Roberts is being interviewed by representatives of any and every publication, from the most illustrious to the most obscure - the funniest and most far-fetched being Horse and Hound's Hugh Grant. As reporters clamber over each other for a moment with the Hollywood diva, Grant tries to convince her of her importance to the fox-hunting and steeplechasing set.

Allen's rapport with the European press is a love-fest - rather more so than is the case with American journalists. The French, the English, the Italians adore him unreservedly and, as someone points out in Wild Man Blues, Barbara Kopple's affecting 1997 documentary about his jazz tour of Europe, his films are greeted and loved there as equals, all of the same stature. In America, some are hits, some are flops. Critics draw sharp distinctions among them. "Maybe they gain something in translation," he says wryly.

His wife Soon-Yi, who accompanied him on the Wild Man Blues tour, confesses disarmingly she didn't much like Interiors. She was very young, she blushes, and found it tedious. "So did the American critics," he hastens to assure her. And when Soon-Yi, emboldened, adds that "it drones on and on", Woody replies that Europeans like films that drone on and on.

It's that gift for self-mockery, a razor-sharp appreciation of life and his own neuroses - even as he is struggling in their vice-like grip - that makes him at once so endearingly contemporary and at the same time so extravagantly one-of-a-kind. He's a genius at pinning down the incongruities of life lived as a peculiar sort of hybrid: a New York Jewish comic who grew up entranced with serious foreign films; a hypochondriac who nevertheless makes film after film in the riskiest and most extroverted branch of show business; a lover of show tunes from an earlier era who regularly plays New Orleans jazz in a New York club. His movies range in tone and ambition from the serio-comic and angst-ridden, to pure frippery, and even a musical. But through them all runs the sweet-sour tune, part romantic, part melancholy, of the phobic but irrepressible artist-lover.

We first met in the early 1980s, introduced by mutual friends as we stood on a sidewalk after lunch, and afterwards we walked up Madison Avenue together. Somewhere along the way, we were stopped in our tracks: a group of Hadassah ladies from Philadelphia swooped on him, screaming accusations that he had failed to show up for a scheduled appearance at their club; they had waited for hours! It was a bizarre spectacle - Allen shrinking in terror as the mob erupted in self-righteous indignation. It was straight out of Stardust Memories, that Fellini- esque extravaganza, from 1980, of monster fans and carping critics, and a movie I'd thought shrill and overdone at the time but which now made perfect sense.

He comes into the Regency hotel room, looking neat and self-possessed. He has a cold but no thermometer in view (in Wild Man Blues, when he's coming down with a cold, Soon-Yi accuses him of taking his temperature every few minutes, hoping it'll rise). We shake hands warmly, but he looks puzzled. "What are you doing writing for the Guardian?"

"They asked me. I'll write an article none of my friends will see. How would you feel about making movies that none of your friends would see?"

"That's an interesting question." He pauses. "I think I already am."

I ask him if he remembers the Stardust Memories-like encounter with the Hadassah ladies. "Oh, yes. They had it wrong. I never accept those things. It had to be some kind of misunderstanding. But yes, Stardust Memories was about all that. It's no exaggeration, well a slight exaggeration. That's really what happens. They come up to you with their different kinds of supplications, and you very often feel for them, but there's nothing you can do."

"New Yorkers," I say, "and Jews in particular, feel they own you, you're one of them."

"Yeah, they did until I wrote a piece for the [New York] Times saying the Israelis shouldn't go from door to door breaking peoples' hands. I thought it was the wrong thing to do, just from the Israeli point of view of giving a propaganda victory to the other side."

She shouldn't have tried that ploy because it was doomed to failure. The one she should have tried was the one that was ultimately more successful and that was, 'This person did a terrible thing to me and I trusted him and he made off with my daughter from under my nose'; which is not really what happened. But that was the one that had the total sell and ultimately did better for her. She shouldn't have wasted time with the first one..."

In this, as in so many things, he's a figure of our times, emblematic of an era of confessional art - movies, memoirs, autobiographical novels - in which artists must, in order to keep going, distance themselves from, even disavow, the personal implications. The original "facts" (ambiguous at best) and emotions (complex and mixed) are twisted, amplified, suppressed, exaggerated, transformed into a simplified high-stakes confrontation which unfolds according to "how it plays". He reiterates: "The false accusations of child molestation was the wrong thing for her. "But why would your girlfriends never see my movies?" he asks in genuine astonishment.

fields.headline: Childish criticism
fields.standfirst: What are the best movies to take the children to this Christmas? Joanna Moorhead put together a panel of film experts (all aged 10 or under) and asked for their verdicts
fields.trailText: What are the best movies to take the children to this Christmas? Joanna Moorhead put together a panel of film experts (all aged 10 or under) and asked for their verdicts
fields.body:
Pokémon 2000
Kids' rating: 9/10
Parents' rating: 6/10
Dirs: Kunihiko Yuyama and Michael Haigney
102 mins
Cert PG

"Isn't Pokémon a bit old-fashioned?" asked six-year-old Sam Walker as we made our way through the revolving doors of Warner Bros for our preview screening of Pokémon 2000. It wasn't what the publicist wanted to hear, but the word among the cool under-10s is that Pokémon has peaked. Question is, can the movie give Pikachu and his funny little friends a new lease of life?

Ironically, the new offering is a lot better than its predecessor, Pokémon The First Movie. "There's just a lot more to it," said Charlie, 10. "More action, and great graphics - the way the river flowed was amazing. And the music was excellent too. I really liked it - and I don't even like Pokémon."

The new movie sees the screen debut of six Pokémon characters, and at times the screen is awash with endless varieties of the creatures. "There definitely seemed to be more Pokémon in this film than the first one," said Joe, eight. Like the first film, the new release is two movies in one - a short and sweet, dialogue-free explosion of colour entitled Pikachu's Rescue Adventure followed by The Power of One, in which Ash, the hero of the first movie, has to save the planet from metereological destruction.

Sounds familiar? "It was a bit of a coincidence that it was all about the weather having gone out of control," said Rosie Smith, eight. "I think some people who watch it will probably be reminded of the last few weeks here." But in Pokémon 2000, it's not greenhouse gases which have caused the crisis, it's the big baddie Lawrence III, a Pokémon collector who wants to capture the birds Moltres, Zapdos and Articuno in the hope of luring the even more prized Lugia, a mysterious Pokémon who lives beneath the ocean waves. The birds, however, control earth's meterological balance, so the evil plan puts the planet at risk.

The plot got a definite thumbs-up. "The story is much better than the first movie," said Kirsty. "There was lots more to it, but not so much that you couldn't follow what was going on. There were lots of smaller plots inside the main story, which made the whole thing more interesting and gave you more to get your teeth into."

Nathan Goodman, nine, particularly liked the evil Lawrence III. "He was a good character - I liked how bad he was, and when he was talking he spoke in a very calm voice which made him seem very realistic. That's how people talk when they are being very bad." Sam Walker's favourite bit was "when they read a poem about the world turning to ash and realised that it meant that Ash the boy had to save them all".

The moral of the tale is that even a kid can make a difference. "It was saying that if you want to try something, you should go ahead - even if the chances don't look that good, that you'll succeed," said Charlie. "It was also telling you about how much you mean to your parents, because at the end Ash's mum says if she'd lost him, she'd have lost her whole world."

So will the movie bring their friends back to the craze? "I think it will - if they come to see it," said Kirsty. "It's lots of fun, and it does make Pokémon seem exciting again."
 Opens Dec 22.

The Grinch
Kids' rating: 8/10
Parents' rating: 6/10
Dir: Ron Howard
105 mins
Cert PG

Jim Carrey is a hairy, pea-green monster called the Grinch in a movie which was a bit of a trial for the parents in our party, but a hit with the kids.

Basically, the story (courtesy of Dr Seuss of Cat in the Hat fame) is that the Grinch hates Christmas, and this year, he decides he's finally had enough and is going to pull the plug on the seasonal pig-out planned by the weird inhabitants of his nearest town, Whoville. But he's stopped in his tracks by Cindy Lou, who refuses to believe that even someone terrifying as the Grinch doesn't have a bit of goodness hidden somewhere under all that nastiness.

The Grinch parodies our overblown, over commercialised Christmas and finds it wanting, which should be a good idea although the moral gets a bit lost in a sea of snow and slush. But the kids seemed to get it: "It taught you a lesson, that Christmas things aren't what matter, it's the people you are with. You don't need presents to make a good Christmas," said Joe Walker, aged eight. And Kirsty O'Donnell, 10, noticed something else: "It was trying to get you to think that you shouldn't just judge people by what you see on the outside. The Grinch isn't very likeable and a lot of people would have given up on him but Cindy Lou doesn't and that's what brings him round."

Like all the best scary monsters, the Grinch lives on his own on the top of a steep mountain, so a big chase down the hillside on a sledge is inevitable. "I really loved the action bit where the Grinch and Cindy Lou sleighed down the mountain," said 10-year-old Charlie d'Auria. "It wasn't really frightening but it was very fast and you almost felt like you were on the sledge with them sometimes."

The Grinch himself was deemed a suitably awful character, at least in his pre-reformed state. "He was great - really funny," said Kirsty. "He loved causing chaos so much, he was so bad, and you knew that whenever he turned up, all sorts of things were going to go wrong, like when all the cars crashed into one another in Whoville."

Eleanor Wittet, nine, liked it best when the Grinch dressed up as Santa Claus and went on his own Christmas Eve spree down people's chimneys. "He was stealing all the presents instead of leaving them there."

Joe thought the film scored best on its visual appeal. "It was hard to believe that the Grinch was a real actor underneath all that make-up," he said. "Also, the scenery and the way the Grinch's house was shown, with lots of gadgets and things, was really good."
 Opens Dec 1.

Merlin: The Return
Kids' rating: 9/10 Parents' rating: 8/10
Dir: Paul Matthews
88 mins
Cert PG

If you've got a nine-year-old boy to entertain during the Christmas holidays, you aren't going to regret a trip to the cinema to see Merlin: The Return. "Absolutely brilliant," said Joseph Hand, nine. "There was loads going on, lots of sudden action, and a good story with plenty of surprises. I'm going to tell all my friends to see this."

Ancient and contemporary are entwined when Mordred, the evil sorcerer of King Arthur's times, is given an opportunity to break into modern times through the time-travel experiments of scientist Joan Maxwell. But Merlin, played by Rik Mayall, is on hand to do battle with him again, as he did in the past when he managed to banish him to the netherworld. Whether he can do so this time depends on whether young Richie, who has come to live in Britain after the death of his father, can do enough to help him.

"You just never know what's going to happen next," said nine-year-old Matthew Deacon. "Also, the action starts right at the beginning - one thing I don't like about some films is that people are just talking for the first 15 or 30 minutes. It's scary - in fact it's so scary I'm quite surprised it got a PG certificate. The storyline is really exciting and keeps you guessing, and though there is some swordfighting there isn't much violence where you actually see someone harmed."

James Robertson, nine, said he thought he'd find the story hard to follow at the beginning of the film, but he soon got it sorted out. "I think it helped to know a bit about the history of King Arthur and to understand who people like Queen Guinevere were," he said. "I recognised Rik Mayall and he was really good as Merlin. He was a perfect person to play him."

Mordred, played by Craig Sheffer, was another character who came in for comment. "He was a very bad man, but in some ways, he was almost like a child in his tantrums and his behaviour," said Rosie, eight. "I liked it but I did find it a bit hard to follow at times, especially because it was moving between the olden days and the time we're living in now."
 Opens Dec 22.

102 Dalmatians
Kids' rating: 8/10
Parents' rating: 7/10
Dir: Kevin Lima
100 mins
Cert U (tbc)

Walt Disney have added precisely one dalmatian puppy to their hit of 1996. In almost every way, the new film is an echo of the old: dogs everywhere, Cruella out to do her worst, and a romance between a couple (Ioan Gruffudd and Alice Evans) who seem more in love with their dalmatians than with one another.

But for Glenn Close, it wouldn't be back at all, and she is certainly, once again, magnificent - as is her sidekick the furrier, played by Gérard Depardieu. "Cruella is absolutely horrid, but she's a really good character," said Elinor Smith, six. "You can't take your eyes off her when the film shows her, she's amazing, really."

Sophie Robertson, six, agreed: "Cruella isn't really scary but the way she says things is a bit frightening sometimes. Her helper (butler Alonso, played by Tim McInnerny) is really good - he keeps getting himself injured doing things for her and yet she doesn't say thank you or appreciate him. The dogs are lovely and cute and my favourite is Oddball, who doesn't have spots yet and keeps trying to get dirt on himself so he'll look as though he does."

"It does make you think you'd like to have a dog of your own," said Rosie, eight (parents beware!). "But I think they do look cuter on the screen than they are when they're running around your own house."

Lovely shots of London are another repeat hallmark from the earlier movie, and there's a completely dotty sequence when Cruella has a funny turn and sees Westminster bridge and everything on it covered in Dalmatian spots. But the film has you hooked from the word go with a wonderfully zappy title sequence, and the music continues the upbeat theme.

"I think it was funnier than 101," said James, nine. "The parrot was my favourite character, he said some really funny things and he thought he was a dog, which made him even funnier." Cruella, as ever, gets her comeuppance in the stickiest, messiest ways possible. "It reminded me a bit of what happens in Chicken Run where the bad woman goes into the oven and comes out as a pie," said Rosie.
 Opens Dec 8.

fields.headline: Pourquoi Pas Moi?
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Wearisome, derivative, politically correct, and evidently based on an Anglo-Saxon model of "relationship"-driven novels and TV shows
fields.body:
Stéphane Giusti's film about gay twentysomethings and their straight friends is wearisome, derivative, politically correct, and evidently based on an Anglo-Saxon model of "relationship"-driven novels and TV shows.

Hip young city-dwellers all invite their parents for dinner at an elegant country villa to come out to the old folks en masse. A midsummer night's sex comedy gets creakily underway. It's uphill work, and the insouciant pop-culture chat about Star Wars, superheroes, and football is seriously past the sell-by date.

fields.headline: Ready to Rumble
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A terrible sub-Adam-Sandler grossout comedy about wrestling
fields.body:
This is a terrible sub-Adam-Sandler grossout comedy about wrestling, clearly hoping to tap into its lucrative young male fanbase in America.

It's not even saved by the presence of Martin Landau, Joe Pantoliano, and the personable Oliver Platt as The King, a down-and-out ex-star of the ring coaxed back to greatness by two young dudes.

Compared to the recently released documentary Beyond the Mat about the reality of the WWF, this just looks stupid.

fields.headline: The Skulls
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: So fatuous and boring it almost defies description acting, plot and characterisation have the consistency of damp cardboard
fields.body:
Add the prefix "numb" and you're getting there. This is a film so fatuous and boring it almost defies description.

Good-hearted college student Luke (Joshua Jackson) is seduced into joining the oh-so-elite secret society the Skulls, a creepy bunch of pouting Wasp pretty boys with - guess what? - a terrible secret. Luke could use the cachet, not mention cash, that membership brings. But he's got a real problem with their sinister, murderous doings, a moral dilemma signalled by a frown indenting his cute plump face.

Acting, plot and characterisation have the consistency of damp cardboard, and the film closes disconcertingly by appearing to endorse the Skulls' survival in a nebulous "reformed" state, without needing to get the police involved.

fields.headline: Confessions of a Trickbaby
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: An anti-triumph for Vincent Gallo, a magnificent fiasco of a performance . . . Weirdly lacking both any humour and any discernible commitment to seriousness
fields.body:
This can only be described as an anti-triumph for Vincent Gallo, a magnificent fiasco of a performance. The kind of acting you watch, wincing and flinching, through gaps in your fingers.

Weirdly lacking both any humour and any discernible commitment to seriousness, Gallo is in drag as a cannibalistic nun called Sister Gomez: a wicked-witch type figure with pointy chin and nose who presides over the destinies of two teenage girls who have bust out of reform school.

Cyclona (Maria Celedonio) is a dyke serial killer who masturbates in her cell all day, moaning: "I love you Sporty Spice!" Natasha Lyonne plays White Girl, a bulimic with a latent talent for projectile vomiting. They are both abuse victims; they have both got attitude; they are both not as good as Angelina Jolie; they are upstaged by their bizarre male co-star in whose honour this film should be re-named Being Vincent Gallo.

fields.headline: Chopper
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A fictionalised but dourly effective account of [Chopper's] violent life in and out of prison. . . Eric Bana is outstanding and often very funny
fields.body:
Mark 'Chopper' Read is unknown outside Australia, but indulged there as an equivalent to our own profoundly unfunny and uninteresting Mad Frankie Fraser: a colourful ex-criminal, raconteur and fantasist.

This last aspect of his bubbly personality notwithstanding, Andrew Dominik's film appears to have taken at face value Chopper's own autobiography and made it the basis of a fictionalised but dourly effective account of his violent life in and out of (but mostly in) prison.

Australian comic Eric Bana is outstanding and often very funny as the appalling rogue himself - alternately garrulous and self-pitying - transforming himself on Jake LaMotta lines from slim young tough guy into plump, self-satisfied media personality. If Eric Bana can do an American accent, then a new Hollywood star might well be born.

fields.headline: East-West
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A rich and varied but nonetheless slightly indigestible meal of a film
fields.body:
This is a rich and varied but nonetheless slightly indigestible meal of a film directed by Régis Wargnier (Indochine) about the post-war Soviet emigrants in the west, whom Stalin promised forgiveness and a citizen-hero's welcome if they returned to the USSR, only to force them into poverty and labour camps. (In the unfinished autobiographical novella Memoirs of a Bootlegger's Son, Saul Bellow has his Aunt Julia ferociously warn the emigrant father against precisely this dangerous homeward yearning: "The old country was sealed up in doom and death.")

There is something plodding and grandiloquent about the doomed homecoming of Alexei (Oleg Menshikov) and his French wife Marie (Sandrine Bonnaire), and their bid to escape once more. But the movie has passion and a welcome sense of historical sweep.

fields.headline: The Original Kings of Comedy
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: There are some good gags and routines here, but loads of them have been done with far more invention and wit by Richard Pryor and Eddie Murphy
fields.body:
Spike Lee's two-hour concert movie captures the live set of four mainstream black comics: Steve Harvey, DL Hughley, Cedric the Entertainer, and Bernie Mac. Freed from the iron-clad constraints of American network TV, the Kings of Comedy here unleash the MF-word in such impressive abundance it almost obliterates anything recognisable as "material". The audience, meanwhile, like all American comedy audiences black and white, do not laugh so much as whoop.

There are some good gags and routines here, but loads of them, particularly the one about what it was like being eight and getting hit by your mother, have been done with far more invention and wit by Richard Pryor and Eddie Murphy. What is extraordinary is that they make a plea for the sweet humanity of "old school" soul music as against the harsh aggression of rap - yet their comedy often sounds squarely in the second category.

Eventually a justification is advanced for universal MF-usage on the grounds that correctly interpreted, the "conversation makes sense like a motherfucker!" But is it funny like a motherfucker?

fields.headline: Flawless
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It's a predictable odd-couple scenario with the mutual antagonists learning to love each other - and themselves - but it's saved by a cracking performance from Hoffman
fields.body:
After his deeply dodgy porno-drama 8MM, Joel Schumacher has gone a good way to redeeming himself with this humane and well-acted comedy. Walt, an ageing ex-cop played by Robert De Niro, finds himself thrown together with his neighbour Rusty (Philip Seymour Hoffman), a witty, hysterical and neurotic drag queen.

Having yelled homophobic abuse at Rusty and his fabulous friends, Walt nevertheless attempts to intervene when one of them is attacked; the stress gives him a stroke, and he winds up getting singing lessons from Rusty as a form of therapy.

It's a predictable odd-couple scenario with the mutual antagonists learning to love each other - and themselves - but it's saved by a cracking performance from Hoffman, who must surely collect a Best Supporting Actor next spring.

webTitle: Into the Arms of Strangers: The Story of the Kindertransport

fields.headline: Into the Arms of Strangers: The Story of the Kindertransport
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The stories. . . have insupportable poignancy and heartache in every detail, and the subject is further saturated with political irony and ambiguity
fields.body:
The story of the Kindertransport - the Neville Chamberlain government's pre-war asylum in Britain for 10,000 Jewish children from Germany and neighbouring countries - is presented here in the classic Holocaust documentary style, most recently seen in the Spielberg-produced The Last Days. Elderly survivors tell their stories, interspersed with black-and-white footage and family photographs showing the deponents now looking heart-stoppingly like their parents.

It is a gentler variation on a theme: at one remove from the direct horror of Holocaust testimony, the stories of the Kindertransport have insupportable poignancy and heartache in every detail, and the subject is further saturated with political irony and ambiguity. The British took in children but refused adults. We could have done more, should have done more. But it was still more than the United States, who did nothing - on the ostensible grounds that it was unnatural to accept children without their parents. And many grown-up Kinder are emotionally unable even now to decide if, in being separated from their parents, they were saved or abandoned.

fields.headline: Top of the chops
fields.standfirst: Airborne kung-fu fighting - even in slow-motion - keeps Charlie's Angels rollicking along, writes  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: However silly it gets, Charlie's Angels is an exuberant and entertaining film which brings off the amplification of an old TV show far more successfully than John Woo or Brian De Palma managed with the Missions Impossible
fields.body:
Only a churl would not feel his heart leap like a salmon at the sight of Cameron Diaz, Lucy Liu and Drew Barrymore - a trio of echt Hollywood exquisites - in such a lavish range of fantastic locations, outfits and hairpieces. Here they are in a 21st-century version of the small-screen Angels: the three gorgeous secret agents who do the bidding of "Charlie", an unseen, fatherly presence who prefers to make contact through the medium of a museum-piece 1970s speakerphone.

Cameron, Lucy and Drew show us their moves. They show us what they've got. And after training eight-hour days with a Chinese martial arts expert, what they appear to have got is the most unconvincing array of kung-fu poses ever seen on the big screen. Lucy is forever removing helmets and sundry other disguises, shaking out her fabulous hair in slo-mo, and then launching into an airborne display of fighting powers showing the kind of uninhibited joie de vivre with which, in another context, she might rollerblade along the beach pulled by a couple of Afghan hounds.

In homage to The Matrix, Cameron floats in slow motion through the air towards some hapless bad guy doing a bicycle-kick move with her feet - and ends up strangely looking like she's playing Tinkerbell at the Palace Theatre, Watford. Drew poses for a production still with fists up and her right leg stuck out at an improbable Pythagorean angle, as if she's dislocated something and will have to hop everywhere for the rest of her life. But armed with their martial-arts training, the Angels take on some bad guys. These men are ruthless, aggressive, fanatically dedicated to destroying Charlie and his Angels - but never so ungallant or unsporting as to produce a firearm at any stage.

Compared to Cynthia Rothrock, a genuinely tough martial-arts star, Cameron, Lucy and Drew look like refugees from Planet L'Oreal. But there's a twinkle in their eye - largely Drew's eye - that tips you off they're not exactly taking it that seriously.

However silly it gets, Charlie's Angels is an exuberant and entertaining film which brings off the amplification of an old TV show far more successfully than John Woo or Brian De Palma managed with the Missions Impossible. The secret is actually that, for the all the stunts, detonations and body-double deployment, Charlie's Angels keeps it pretty simple and small-scale. It has a storyline that doesn't feel much heftier than the half-hour format of the old television series. Director Joseph McGinty Nichol - a former commercial and music-video specialist who styles himself "McG" - keeps it fast and light and understands how humour at once leavens the action sequences and validates their existence as part of the fun. Unlike, say, The Brady Bunch Movie, Charlie's Angels does not include the original principals in cameo roles. (One of them could have been the villain, for example - and might still be in a future CA2 - but casting one without the rest would feel unbalanced. And Farrah's Bride of Wildenstein presence might be scary in the wrong way.)

The humour in the film is very largely the responsibility of Bill Murray, who has some funny lines in the role of Bosley, Charlie's representative on earth. Trapped in a grim cell at one point, he radios the Angels for help describing his position: "It looks like Cher's bedroom!" But very often Murray looks resigned, and more than a little out of it. There's some perceptible puffing as the old boy heaves himself onto the couch next to the girls to listen to Charlie's instructions, and his face has that raddled, comedy-martyr look that he wore as he bombed into the pool in Rushmore. (Not surprising that Lucy Liu, like Robert De Niro before her, found working with the great man a little trying.) But writers Russell Carpenter, Ryan Rowe and Ed Solomon don't solely entrust Bill with the gags. When Lucy Liu is posing as a masseuse, manipulating the villainous Tim Curry, he murmurs: "You have great hands. I could use someone like you on my staff." Liu replies tartly: "My hands aren't going anywhere near your staff."

Sensibly, the movie doesn't try to make the girls much more "empowered" than they were in the first place, simply making them kick-ass heroines who nevertheless have a sweet tooth for their various (unworthy) boyfriends. Some of the music on the soundtrack makes you pause, though. At one point, the Angels cruise sexily along to the accompaniment of the Vapors' pop classic Turning Japanese. Is it an intentional echo of Cameron's classic role as the masturbation-target in There's Something About Mary?

Later, the trio go after the sinister Thin Man (Crispin Glover) to the rousing accompaniment of the Prodigy's Smack My Bitch Up. I suppose there's no real irony intended: they have turned the tables and absorbed the male prerogative as the bitches doing the smacking. That's all.

It has to be said: McG and co-producer Drew Barrymore have come up with an enjoyable picture, possibly the genesis of a profitable action-comedy franchise. However fraught with potential disaster that is, I'm looking forward to it a whole lot more than the moribund non-events being readied in the Bond pipeline.

fields.headline: Hooray for Harold
fields.standfirst: Rob Mackie  hails a rare British success
fields.trailText: Whatever Happened to Harold Smith?
fields.body:
Whatever Happened to Harold Smith?
Rental Universal Pictures Cert 15
***

It's been a grim year for British films but, in its modest little way, this is another triumph for Peter Hewitt, the underrated director who made a cracking version of The Borrowers, and for Tom Courtenay. This is Courtenay in his element as a cloth-capped working-class everyman with hidden depths, not dissimilar to his lovely recent TV two-hander with Albert Finney, A Rather English Marriage.

It's the kind of part most actors would coat with condescension or sentimentality, but Courtenay does ordinary with the sort of dignity we haven't seen much since Alec Guinness's heyday. After years content with his pipe and TV, his eponymous suburban father rediscovers a youthful ability to do a bit of spoon-bending and clock-stopping. Soon he is called upon to perform at a local old people's home, where his gift at stopping timepieces kills three pensioners with pacemakers stone dead, leading to national fame and infamy.

This is only one of the plots entertainingly juggled: Courtenay's lad (Michael Legge) is torn between disco, punk and a hormonal inclination for Laura Fraser, whose middle-class father (Stephen Fry) is undergoing an American Beauty-style mid-life crisis; Courtenay's wife is a shocking slapper played with great vigour and relish by Lulu; an unrecognisable David Thewlis is the hardline boss of the insurance firm where both Legge and Fraser work.

A range of other plots waft through - there's some Saturday Night Fever, a soupçon of Grease, a hint of Summer of Sam and a pinch of East is East - but Harold Smith is always its own beast, often very funny (Fry hasn't had a turn this good in ages). It fits the "feelgood" category in a dopey, idiosyncratic way full of detours and diversions, works its way towards a lovely climax and pays its way in chuckles.
