fields.headline: Five euro tests 'irrelevant'
fields.standfirst:
Duisenberg dismisses Brown policy

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Europe's top central banker, Wim Duisenberg added to the government's mounting difficulties over the single currency yesterday when he described the government's five tests on the euro as "irrelevant".
fields.body:
Europe's top central banker, Wim Duisenberg added to the government's mounting difficulties over the single currency yesterday when he described the government's five tests on the euro as "irrelevant".

Amid government attempts to reduce tensions over the proposed European rapid reaction force, Mr Duisenberg dismissed Gordon Brown's carefully crafted "wait and see" criteria and insisted that the yardsticks laid out in the Maastricht treaty were all that mattered.

Mr Duisenberg indicated that, despite the government's problems in convincing a sceptical electorate of the benefits of the euro, that there would be no special deal for Britain. He ruled out becoming a member of monetary union without rejoining the exchange rate mechanism, from which Britain was humiliatingly ejected on Black Wednesday eight years ago.

Mr Duisenberg's remarks were instantly dismissed by a Downing Street spokesman.

"I haven't seen his [Duisenberg's] comments," said a spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair. "But we have set out very clearly the judgments against which British membership of the single currency will be assessed.

"They are the five economic conditions, the five economic tests," the spokesman continued. "Should the government recommend joining, then it will be for parliament and the people to decide in a referendum."

But Mr Duisenberg, speaking earlier in the day to a European parliament committee, said the British tests were "somewhat different" from the requirements as set out under the Treaty of Maastricht. "And it is only the Maastricht criteria which I regard as relevant for eventual entry of the UK into monetary union," he said.

One of the Maastricht requirements is for a country's currency to be part of the ERM for two years prior to entry. Mr Duisenberg said there would be "no derogation of the ERM for would-be entrants"

Opponents of the euro seized Mr Duisenberg's comments as proof that Britain could not avoid rejoining the ERM if it wanted to become a member of the euro zone.

"This year is the 10th anniversary of Britain joining the ERM, which cost 100,000 business bankruptcies, 1.75m homes in negative equity and a doubling of unemployment," said Nick Herbert from the lobby group, Business for Sterling. "It's not surprising that the goverment doesn't dare try that currency experiment again."

Mr Duisenberg said it was "much too early" to say if the euro had been a success. Speaking at a news conference, he added: "Of course it will be a success. To my mind, it is a success, but... it's too early to say that."

He added that inflation in the euro zone could return to 2% or below during 2001 and even within six months.

But some analysts took this as a hint that the ECB is considering cutting borrowing costs in the euro zone from their current level of 4.75%, a move which is likely to weaken the single currency further.

The euro declined further against other world currencies in thin trading yesterday, with New York markets closed for the Thanksgiving holiday.

It slid below $0.84 in late London trading, as traders became confident that the ECB was not planning a repeat of this month's three unilateral interventions in the market.

webTitle: What I liked about Mrs Thatcher

fields.headline: What I liked about Mrs Thatcher
fields.standfirst:
She spoke against the spirit of managerialism. Blair hasn't quite


The Thatcher era
fields.trailText: She spoke against the spirit of managerialism. Blair hasn't quite
fields.body:
Six years is a short time in politics. It seems only the other day that Tony Blair, a newly elected Labour leader, was wooing the mythical kingdom of Middle England with the words, "I believe Margaret Thatcher's emphasis on enterprise was right", not to say the curiously repetitious "Britain needs more successful people who can become rich by success through the money they earn".

Perhaps the prime minister really has now at last discarded Lady Thatcher and her ism with his angry attack on Wednesday, which brought such cheer to old Labour. For me, on the contrary, this week saw a reminder of why I was once attracted to what might as well be called Thatcherism.

Twenty-two years is a long time in politics, but one of yesterday's byelections, in Glasgow Anniesland, brought back vivid memories. It was caused by the death of Donald Dewar, who returned to parliament in 1978 by winning this seat, then known as Garscadden, in a byelection. Covering it had a profound effect on me. What was unforgettable - shattering even - wasn't the contest, or the quiet, couthy Dewar, it was the place.

At that time, Garscadden held a record among constituencies in Britain for the proportion of its inhabitants living in council dwellings: 96%. And what dwellings. It was a prime example of an "inner-outer suburb" which had been knocked down and rebuilt by municipal planners. A great forest of tower blocks had been erected in the 1960s, though many were dirty and decaying by the end of the next decade. It might have been Magnitogorsk.

In that great age of social engineering, the poor of central Glasgow had been siphoned out of their old tenements and decanted into these blocks. This had happened throughout the country, but nowhere was it done more thoroughly than in central Scotland, under Labour's mighty municipal one-party statelet. There were plenty of other places nearly as bad as Garscadden, but few worse. I don't think anywhere had depressed me more, or made me want to live there less.

At the time of that byelection, the Labour party was approaching a crisis. The following year the Callaghan government was to fall, ushering in 18 years of Tory rule. Plenty of prominent Labour supporters had abandoned the party, or were about to. Some would move far to the right, while others left three years later to form the SDP. These defectors had, or gave, varying reasons for their defection - union power, the rise of a Trotskyist left, Europe, nuclear multilateralism.

What no one ever said was that there might have been something fundamentally wrong with the whole spirit of Labour rule, in national or local government. That spirit wasn't a revolutionary dream of hope, or Marx's kingdom of freedom, or any brand of libertarian socialism (which has always been at a discount in this country). It was Fabian managerialism: the belief that the gentleman in Whitehall - or the Scottish Labour apparatchik - really does know what is good for people better than the people themselves.

There was a time when, seen in a favourable light, Margaret Thatcher looked as if she defied that spirit and spoke for a new mood of individual freedom and responsibility. Maybe that was an illusion, though if her government had done nothing else it should be honoured for selling council houses and trying to break up those vast, awful Soviet estates.

Then again, maybe there was a similar illusion about Blair's "modernising". He got rid of Sidney Webb's clause four, and Labour no longer pretends that it wants to secure for the workers by hand and by brain the full fruits of their industry and the most equitable distribution thereof (a sentence which Blair the moderniser, or rebrander, replaced with something much less lucid and comprehensible).

But it was the great managerialist Webb who, on another occasion, summed up the social philosophy with which he wanted to imbue Labour in less inspiring but all too accurate words: "The perfect and fitting development of each individual is not necessarily the utmost and highest cultivation of his own personality, but the filling, in the best possible way, of his humble function in the great social machine." That was the spirit in which Labour once ruled, and that was how Garscadden was run.

In the early days when he kissed the Iron Handbag, Blair lauded "the Thatcher-Reagan leadership" of the 1980s in his usual verb-starved prose. It had "got certain things right. A greater emphasis on enterprise. Rewarding not penalising success. Breaking up vested interests." What he never said, while he apostrophised wealth creation in this vulgar way, was whether he truly wanted to leave behind "the great social machine" humbly served by an inert populace. I am not sure that he has told us since.

What he never said, while he apostrophised wealth creation in this vulgar way, was whether he truly wanted to leave behind "the great social machine" humbly served by an inert populace. I am not sure that he has told us since. wheaty@compuserve.com

webTitle: Top general caught up in Euro row

fields.headline: Top general caught up in Euro row
fields.standfirst:
 Cabinet fury at attack on chief of defence
 European force dispute erupts again
fields.trailText: Tony Blair stoked the government's counter-offensive against the forces of Euroscepticism for the third day running yesterday when he denounced a Tory-inspired attack on General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, as a disgraceful act of "utter desperation".
fields.body:
Tony Blair stoked the government's counter-offensive against the forces of Euroscepticism for the third day running yesterday when he denounced a Tory-inspired attack on General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, as a disgraceful act of "utter desperation".

Widening his attack from the single issue of British participation in a so-called "European army", the prime minister complained in cabinet that the right's reluctance to accept the legitimacy of a Labour government meant it would target "anyone who works in public service" for Labour.

The fact that Mr Blair and his cabinet colleagues expressed particular outrage over a Daily Mail character assassination of Britain's senior serving soldier during their weekly meeting was less significant than the decision to publicise the prime minister's remarks within an hour.

Angered in particular by yesterday's Mail article headlined "Tony's crony general who kept his head below the parapet", Mr Blair protested that Gen Guthrie, a former SAS soldier with a fearsome reputation in the field, had served both Labour and Tory governments "with absolute distinction".

After the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, described Gen Guthrie as "a first-class professional soldier who has never been afraid to give first-class advice" and the international development secretary, Clare Short, spoke up in a similar way, Mr Blair went significantly further.

In a rehearsal for the coming election campaign he said: "The problem with the right is that they cannot accept there's a Labour government and they will attack anyone who works in public service under a Labour government. It's quite disgraceful, totally unwarranted and evidence of their utter desperation."

In the argument over the government's commitment of 12,500 British troops to a future EU rapid reaction force (RRF) for peacekeeping purposes, Mr Blair received a significant boost when the former Tory chancellor, Kenneth Clarke, intervened to back Labour.

Conservative opposition was thrown into disarray when the pro-European Tory told parliament the RRF was something the party had worked to achieve when it was in power.

Mr Clarke said: "The last government ... embarked on a process of evolving Nato towards a different shape that also involved strengthening the European element."

Amid ironical cheers from the Labour side he explained: "I regard yesterday's announcement as the latest stage in quite a protracted process that has been going on of deciding how Nato should be shaped in future."

That amounted to a "slightly different" recollection of events from that expressed by John Major 24 hours earlier, when he called the RRF "a misconceived political proposal that should never have been made".

Mr Clarke and Mr Major are friends and political allies. But the ex-chancellor insisted the 1991 Maastricht treaty had "clearly committed us to the development of a European defence/foreign security policy. We always, in my opinion - and I was in the government throughout - were contemplating producing something of this kind".

Mr Blair said much the same in his clash with the Tory leader, William Hague, on Wednesday. Yesterday he repeated his theory in cabinet that the Conservatives and their media allies were "scaremongering" about Europe because it was the only shot in their political locker which resonated with voters.

"The Tories have given up speaking about the economy, they have nothing positive to say on unemployment, they are terrified of the public services because of their £16bn cut - all they have left is Europe and scaremongering," he said.

Mr Hague hit back with the jibe that the prime minister had become arrogant and out of touch - that he was a man who "gets hot under the collar when he is criticised and when he is losing the argument".

Labour strategists insist their efforts to appease Middle England's media - the Sun and Daily Mail - have not ended and that this is a tactical reaction to a particularly mendacious attack on the RRF concept - "a betrayal of British interests", the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, called the offensive in last night's parliamentary debate. But with the EU summit in Nice looming, the strategists have decided not to take such attacks lying down.

Last night the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, returned to the fray. He told the Commons that the Tories supported better European defence capabilities and greater defence cooperation. But he said: "We already have a European defence organisation - it's called Nato. It's existed for more than 50 years. It's been the principle means by which America remains engaged in our continent. There are real concerns here that what is proposed will undermine and defy Nato."

Mr Blair and his allies are trying to get across the crucial message that unanimity will be needed within the European council before any military initiative is taken. It will then be up to individual countries to decide whether to commit forces. "The notion that you have a European army with troops subcontracted to Brussels is absurd," he told colleagues.

As the prime minister flew to the Balkan summit in Zagreb, Mr Cook told MPs: "Britain has a strategic interest in the stability of the continent. Britain, therefore, has a strong national interest in a greater ability of Europe to manage instability in and around Europe."

webTitle: In the grip of vested interests

fields.headline: In the grip of vested interests
fields.standfirst:
It isn't America's citizens who want the US to be the dirty man of the planet: it's the oil companies who have captured their democracy

Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The United States is villain of the piece at the Hague environmental conference this week. Is it because the American government is merely anxious to avoid doing anything which might be unpopular with voters?
fields.body:
The United States is villain of the piece at the Hague environmental conference this week. Is it because the American government is merely anxious to avoid doing anything which might be unpopular with voters?

They do not take kindly to paying more for their petrol or to protect the environment and they will punish any administration which introduces green policies. As a result, American negotiators offer token concessions unlikely to have any impact on climate change. The fact that Ralph Nader, the Green candidate in the presidential elections, attracted only 3% of the vote surely indicated their indifference to environmental concerns.

But is that right? Evidence on public attitudes to environmental issues in the US says not. Light on American attitudes is thrown by the world values study, undertaken by political scientists in more than 60 countries. Its data, collected in 1997, show that a majority of Americans are very conscious of environmental problems and feel action must be taken to deal with them.

Respondents were asked the three questions in the chart. Some 56% expressed a willingness to see taxes increased in order to protect the environment; 52% thought that environmental protection should have priority over economic growth and 55% disagreed with the idea that environmental problems can be solved without international agreements. In each case a majority of Americans supported the environmentally-friendly option.

Additional questions in the survey strengthen this conclusion. About a quarter of Americans gave money to an environmental organisation in the previous 12 months. Nearly three-quarters of them chose household products for environmental reasons and nearly a fifth took political action by attending a meeting, writing a letter or signing a petition aimed at protecting the environment.

Young Americans are more likely to support such taxes than the old; women support them more than men; the educated more than the uneducated; the affluent more than the poor; and whites more than blacks.

These patterns occur in other societies as well. They are explained in part by the "post-materialist" thesis. This is the idea that early life experiences condition individuals' attitudes to environmental issues. Those with early life experiences of economic security and material wellbeing are likely to attach a greater priority to environmental concerns than those brought up in economic insecurity and poverty. The latter are more concerned with achieving material wellbeing for themselves and their families rather than with saving the planet.

Intriguingly, the research shows that people acquire these attitudes in early adulthood and tend to carry them for the rest of their lives, even if their material circumstances change. Thus the self-made millionaire brought up in poverty is likely to remain indifferent to environmental concerns in middle age. On the other hand, people brought up in economic security retain their green credentials even if they subsequently lose social status and income. This implies that the tremendous economic growth experi enced in the US in recent years should reinforce the environmental concerns of Americans in future, even if that prosperity is blighted by pockets of poverty. Green politics is likely to grow more important in the US as time goes on.

If this is true, why are American negotiators at the Hague dragging their feet? Why are they not responding to the environmental concerns of their own citizens? Part of the reason is that negotiations have become entangled in presidential politics, with the American team unwilling to do anything until the impasse over the occupancy of the White House ends. In the past, Al Gore has expressed more concern with environmental issues than George Bush, although Ralph Nader's claim that the Clinton administration did little about the environment has a lot of validity. It is also the case that Democrats tend to be rather more concerned than Republicans about this issue; 62% of them agree with environmental taxation compared with 58% of Republicans. With a Republican-controlled Congress and White House in prospect, this might influence the American negotiating position.

But this is not the whole story. The truth is the concerns of most American citizens are being bypassed because American democracy is captured by special interests, such as the oil companies with their vested interests. The achilles heel of American democracy is that candidates for office have to raise huge amounts of money to stay in the race and since corporate donors provide the bulk of this money, politicians are increasingly in hock to them. Big oil is in denial over global warming, much as big tobacco is in denial over the carcinogenic properties of its products, so nothing changes.

As Mancur Olson showed in his book The Rise and Decline of Nations, special interests create institutional sclerosis which inhibits change and in the long run reduces economic performance. We might also add that they subvert democracy. Unfortunately, until their hold on the American political system is weakened, the US is likely to continue to try to free-ride on the efforts of others to slow global climate change and as a result the issue will not be effectively tackled.

• Paul Whiteley is director of the Economic and Social Research Council programme on democracy and participation P.Whiteley@sheffield.ac.uk

fields.headline: The glamour model and the MP's winklepickers
fields.trailText: It's not just the end of a session; we're coming to the end of the parliament. MPs become obsessed with one topic, their own re-election.
fields.body:
It's not just the end of a session; we're coming to the end of the parliament. MPs become obsessed with one topic, their own re-election. You can see their interest in events in the chamber drizzle away. Their minds are in their constituencies. Back at the coalface, things become faintly surrealist, slightly unexpected, curiously weird.

Take Theresa May's footwear. The Tory education spokeswoman was wearing glossy black shoes so pointed that the old term winklepickers cannot do them justice. If you sterilised them you could perform keyhole surgery, from the far side of the operating theatre. I've never seen such shoes, except on the wicked witch in a panto, or the windows of specialist shops in Soho.

Famously, Ms May is sometimes confused with her near namesake, the "glamour model" Teresa May. Perhaps the two are in the process of merging their personalities. On the starlet's website I found many pictures of her wearing unusual shoes, though there was very little educational material, at least in a political sense; I found nothing like: "'time to assess new LEA funding levels with respect to special educational needs,' says lovely, pouting Teresa May, who likes meeting people and romantic fireside evenings with Chris Woodhead".

Actually Mr Woodhead cropped up several times at education questions yesterday. The Tories are pretty sure that David Blunkett couldn't stand him, but was forced to keep him on by Tony Blair. "Were you very disappointed," asked David Ruffley in a silky voice, "to see Mr Woodhead resign?"

Mr Blunkett hummed and hawed and finally found a formula which almost an swered the question without actually fibbing. "Chris Woodhead and I have been through a great deal together," he said (you could say the same of Tom and Jerry), "therefore, having recently been responsible for his reappointment, I was very disappointed."

"So that's a 'no', then!" the jubilant Tories yelled back.

Next I pondered why education questions are infested with jargon. I'm always suspicious of New Labour when they start to talk in breeze-block phrases and capital letters. It means that someone has taken a real problem and turned it into a committee or a project or a roll-out or a strategy, which may or may not engage the problem in the end, but is certainly no substitute for a solution.

So yesterday we learned of "threshold assessments"; "pupil-progress targets"; the "national input league table"; the "environmental task force option" and the "changed system to income-contingent loans basis". Oh, and somebody is working on a "longitudinal study," and an "inclusion project to identify best practice", whatever they might be.

Does it matter? I think it does. So often this government confuses decision with achievement, proposals with accomplishments. These grand, intangible phrases are hopes and dreams given fine names, but little more.

Later Margaret Hodge produced a wonderfully bonkers moment. James Clappison, a Tory, asked her whether class sizes were "higher or lower in 1979, or now? Higher, or lower?" he demanded.

She drew herself up to her full height (just below the dispatch box). "The answer to that question is yes!" she barked, her certainty matched only by the utter meaninglessness of the reply.

But the most marvellously mad moment came later in the Europe debate when Kenneth Clarke, the fomer chancellor, was cheered to the roof by Labour MPs for declaring that the new Euro reaction force was a product and an aim of Tory policy. The man who got rid of Thatcher, 10 years and two days ago. What a hero he is!

webTitle: Founder Joe de Saram absent as Rhodium folds owing £1m

fields.headline: Founder Joe de Saram absent as Rhodium folds owing £1m
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A flamboyant e-business pioneer, once ranked among the richest young millionaires in Britain, has seen his encryption technologies company fold with more than £1m of debts after a series of allegedly broken promises to creditors.
fields.body:
A flamboyant e-business pioneer, once ranked among the richest young millionaires in Britain, has seen his encryption technologies company fold with more than £1m of debts after a series of allegedly broken promises to creditors.

Joseph de Saram, 28, who last year shared 18th place on the Sunday Times' young rich list with David and Victoria Beckham, founded Rhodium in 1995 after just two years as a graduate IT consultant. But this week more than five suppliers have secured the company's liquidation after it failed to pay for a number of hardware orders.

Proceedings were first brought against the Sheffield-based firm by hardware sup pliers Info Techtronic, which is owed £205,000 and had received a number of "bouncing" cheques and promises of payment from Rhodium that were not kept.

A spokesman for the Leeds District Registry Court confirmed that Rhodium, which employed seven staff, had been compulsorily wound up. Next week a liquidator would be appointed and Mr de Saram, who is thought to be visiting friends in Sri Lanka, will be interviewed over the possible ways of retrieving creditors' money.

Mr de Saram, who claims via the Rhodium website to be worth "in excess of $200m", reportedly gave up his childhood ambition to become a neurosurgeon in order to "stretch his mind" by starting his own business.

In March he told the Sunday Times that he was sceptical about the future of some internet firms.

"They lack substance," he said. "They don't have a balance sheet and their valuations are artificially high, based on hype.

"There's a lot of euphoria about now. I can see a Wall Street crash or South Sea Bubble burst."

Rhodium will now join CitiKey, a wireless provider of restaurant and city guides, which has also been put into liquidation after burn rates reached an estimated $1m a month.

About 90 workers across Europe are expected to lose their jobs.

CitiKey filed for bankruptcy proceedings on Monday after plans to restructure the firm failed to get the backing of a two-thirds majority of the board.

The founders of the company, which was set up in 1998, were among those who rejected financial proposals from venture capitalist. It is thought that Atlas Venture and Crescendo Ventures had wanted to dilute some non-venture-capitalist shareholdings by up to a factor of ten.

webTitle: Comment: Martin Woolacott on western politics

fields.headline: There is a dying fall about the political life of the west
fields.standfirst:
The generation that reinvented postwar Europe is passing on

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The generation that reinvented postwar Europe is passing on
fields.body:
It may seem a long way from Florida, where the tussle for the American presidency is in its final stage, to the south of France, where European Union leaders will meet in Nice next month to decide on various reforms. But the problems of the two unions are not as different as might at first appear. The loss of legitimacy in the new world is matched by a failure to gain it in the old. And, in each case, a probably illusory remedy is sought in institutional changes which may not deal with underlying causes.

The US is suddenly full of plans to reform the electoral college and, after a money- driven campaign, there are many Americans who want campaign-finance reform, although they know they are unlikely to get it in this coming term. Europe is talking of constitutional changes like those for a new European second chamber or for the direct election of the president of the commission. Such ideas are not for discussion at the Nice summit, where the proposals on the table concern the re-weighting of national votes, the reduction of national veto powers, and the redistribution of commission portfolios.

These, if agreed, may make the union more efficient and occasionally allow a majority of members to push through decisions unpalatable to a minority. But they will not make the union one whit more democratic in terms of accountability to its citizens. That is why the broader reform proposals, recently revived by Joschka Fischer, the German foreign minister, will be in the background as a possible means of redressing Europe's democratic deficit.

That phrase may underestimate the difficulties. Nick Clegg, a Liberal Democrat member of the European parliament, warns in a recent pamphlet of the possibility of "a full-scale rout of the EU institutions". Turnout for European elections, he says, may sink as low as 20% in many countries in the next decade. In Clegg's view, the emergence of the council of ministers as a directorate, issuing orders to commission and parliament alike, can only reinforce this tendency.

Yet he is not warm to the idea of a second chamber, which he thinks would add complexity without enhancing democracy and which would be dogged by absenteeism. He recommends instead a common sense trimming of the European commission's tasks, so that it could revert to its innovatory and strategic role, while a more rigorous parliament kept both commission and council under effective surveillance.

National parliaments and governments have more legitimacy in the eyes of citizens than the union's institutions, yet this too is eroding, as the review of voting levels in European countries earlier this week in the Guardian showed. Rather than contrasting the faith citizens have in national governments with that in the European Union, it may be more appropriate to conceive of a spectrum of distrust of politicians wherever they are located. The level of distrust has been rising in both Europe and America for a long time. In 1960 three out of four Americans agreed that politicians in Washington could be trusted; by the 1990s three out of four agreed they could not be trusted.

The question would-be reformers have to ask themselves, of course, is whether political disillusion is a product of the misbehaviour of politicians or of the malfunctioning of constitutional arrangments, or whether it has deeper causes. The work of Robert D Putnam, whose studies of civic engagement began in Italy, where he described profound differences between the north and south, and continued in the United States, suggest that political disillusion is a function of a general shift away from almost every form of social connection, from playing bridge or entertaining at home to going to meetings or standing for office.

Social capital, the accumulation of habits and attitudes that build trust in economic and political life and which, among other things, school people in democracy, has accordingly diminished, he argues in his book, Bowling Alone. The causes he assigns, in various tentative proportions, to generational change, television, suburban sprawl, and new ways of working. Others have examined some of these changes in many countries, as the prevalence of the term "civic society" indicates. But Putnam's is an outstandingly comprehensive, painstaking, wise, and historically aware investigation.

His thesis is that Americans born between 1910 and 1940 represent a "long civic generation" who were more engaged than either their predecessors or their successors for a variety of historical reasons. It was this generation which maintained community in American neighbourhoods through a thick web of social connections and sustained churches, charitable organisations, veterans' bodies, business groups, sporting clubs, and political parties.

As they pass from the scene, all these suffer or are transmuted into associations that may have huge "memberships" but which are, in fact, professionally led advocacy organisations, whose members contribute only money. Political parties come to depend more on paid staff rather than unpaid volunteers and active members, and more on advertising and media management rather than on citizens attempting to convince one another. It is not at all clear, Putnam adds, that the hopes that the internet will supply some of these deficiencies will be justified.

Putnam is editing a book which examines trends in European and other countries. The picture, he says, is one of a continent not yet "exhibiting anything like the same dramatic decline" but nevertheless moving in a similar direction. "On some core features of civic society - religious involvment, union membership, party membership, voting, trust in public institutions - the figures are going the same way."

Lack of long runs of data on such habits as entertaining at home make it difficult to track the more informal social connections of Europeans, but intuition suggests they too are going the same way. In some countries an equivalent to the American "long civic generation" may be identifiable; in others, like Germany, the opposite might be deemed to be the case.

Yet in a much more patchy way, it can be argued, such a generation can be discerned more diverse than its American equivalent because of the different experiences of European states and running on a different time scale, but one that has also been giving way over the years to less engaged successors. This would be the generation whose leaders reinvented much of European politics after the war and who created the European Community. If the kind of analysis which Putnam and other social scientists offer is accepted, the central political problem in both continents is civic rather than constitutional or legal. How to overcome it is, naturally, the hardest part of any analysis, but recognition of the priority of that task would be a good start.

fields.headline: Into the whirlpool
fields.standfirst:
Where the US falters, others should act

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: In the Middle East, another day, another atrocity. With accelerating fury, the cycle of violence spins. In Gaza, in occupied Palestine, four men are machinegunned to death by Israeli troops.
fields.body:
In the Middle East, another day, another atrocity. With accelerating fury, the cycle of violence spins. In Gaza, in occupied Palestine, four men are machinegunned to death by Israeli troops. "Fatah will not let this crime pass," declare Yasser Arafat's militiamen. In Hadera, in Israel's broken heartlands, a car bomb kills, dismembers, destroys. "The state of Israel will get even," declares its half-dove, half-hawk prime minister, Ehud Barak.

Mutilated children; endless funerals; bitter, hardening enmity; blood soaking into the soil that both sides claim as their own: this is is the daily butcher's bill, the price paid for the failure of peace. And just when it seems it cannot get worse, it does. "Only war, that is all we can do," says a shell-shocked Jewish woman in Hadera, quoted by our correspondent Suzanne Goldenberg. "We have the power. We must do it." But she is wrong. Israel cannot win this "war". It does not face an army. It faces a people. Nor can the Palestinians "defeat" their enemy. For both, the choice has long been clear. They either live together - or die together.

Another day, another radiating ripple of mindless mayhem, deepening hate, and political impotence. Was the explosion in Riyadh that injured three Britons, after the killing in the Saudi capital of a British man last Friday, the work of Islamic militants enraged (and encouraged) by the Palestine morass? Given the way the wave of anti-Israeli feeling in the Arab world has swelled into a broader, anti-western ire, it seems last month's attacks on a US warship and the British embassy in Yemen certainly were. The FBI appears to think so. Its inquiries point even further afield, to fundamentalist Afghanistan and the terrorist training camps of the Saudi renegade millionaire, Osama bin Laden. In Cairo, the recalled Egyptian ambassador to Israel twiddles his thumbs; another pathway to peace has just closed. In Jordan, a destabilised government puts bilateral relations into deep-freeze. In Jerusalem, they get a call from Washington. A new initiative is under way! But within hours, live fire drowns out the talk of truce.

Another day, another geopolitical own goal. Here is the news from Baghdad: Saddam Hussein's triumphant rehabilitation continues apace. While the US counts chad, and Europe plays soldiers with an imaginary army, Iraq reopens its oil pipeline to Syria in further mockery of UN sanctions. Here is the news from Damascus: Bashar Assad, after a brief window of opportunity for the west, has decided to play the hard man, just like his old dad. Who lost Syria? Better ask the guys at the state department (but only when the Palm Beach recount is finished). And what is the Arab League saying? It says, with growing conviction, that the entire Arab and Islamic world is on the brink. . . and the west should remember who controls its oil.

With each day that passes, the damage caused by the failure to end Israeli-Palestinian violence and resume peace talks grows and spreads exponentially. If the principal antagonists are incapable of stopping it themselves, and if the US is as devoid of new ideas and new energy as it now appears to be, then radical solutions must be sought. Plans to send in British, French and other "observers" to try to calm the two sides, now under discussion at the UN, should be expedited. But that can only be a first step. The big, imaginative leap would be for Britain and the EU, plus Russia, to replace a discredited and distracted US as lead mediator and jumpstart the Oslo process - lest it die the death of a thousand, daily cuts and finally expire amid an explosive, widening conflagration.

webTitle: Another bad day in the Brink affair

fields.headline: Another bad day in the Brink affair
fields.standfirst:
World Online board confronts shareholders in attempt to sell Italian takeover

Net news
fields.trailText: For much of this year World Online has been on the ropes. The Dutch internet group has been hit by claims of insider trading and an incomplete listing prospectus. Its share price has collapsed. Its talismanic chairman and founder, Nina Brink, left after selling shares for six euros ahead of a float where punters paid 43 euros.
fields.body:
For much of this year World Online has been on the ropes. The Dutch internet group has been hit by claims of insider trading and an incomplete listing prospectus. Its share price has collapsed. Its talismanic chairman and founder, Nina Brink, left after selling shares for six euros ahead of a float where punters paid 43 euros.

This at a time when the company, backed by IT giants such as Intel, is in the throes of being taken over by an Italian group - a move that has left some World Online shareholders questioning why the roles are not reversed.

Many are smarting from heavy losses. World Online was worth £7.3bn when floated; now it is valued at less than £2bn. Some shareholders are threatening legal action, and to add to the company's cup of woe Dutch prosecutors are taking a close interest in what happened around the time of the stock market flotation earlier this year.

But yesterday World Online came out fighting. At a dramatic and at times ill-tempered shareholders' meeting in Rotterdam the board confronted its critics. True, there was one early concession. Proceedings were to be conducted "as far as possible" in Dutch - investors' feathers had been ruffled by the extensive use of English at an earlier meeting.

Thereafter the platform party was on the offensive. Although the meeting was to discuss the planned deal with Tiscali, supervisory board chairman Victor Bischoff sought to pre-empt the inquisition. The claims were "totally unfounded", he said. The directors had written to the prosecutor's office stating that none of them had dealt in World Online shares before, during or after the flotation. World Online was "hoping for a speedy conclusion to clear the air once and for all".

Some hope. The prosecutor's office says it will take a couple of months to organise the papers acquired in a recent series of "visits" and another couple of months to interview all those who may shed light on what has become known in some circles as the Brink affair.

Mr Bischoff's initiative did not head off a grilling from shareholders.

Even the chairman of the executive board, James Kinsella's eloquent efforts to sell the Tiscali deal - "we are aiming to become the AOL of Europe" - was barely finished before the board's chief tormentor, Peter Paul de Vries, a director of the Dutch investor group VEB, was on his feet.

Mr de Vries had an arsenal of questions. In part they focused on the Tiscali deal but he clashed repeatedly with World Online legal adviser Peter van Schlifgaarde over threatened legal action for compensation for previous events.

At one point it seemed as if Mr van Schlifgaarde might invite Mr de Vries to step outside, and subsequent efforts to separate Mr de Vries from the microphone failed.

The next shareholder on his feet to ask questions simply declined the offer to speak, saying he preferred to hear Mr de Vries in action.

Eventually the VEB man did concede the floor, but that merely cleared the way for others. World Online was a Dutch company, said one; if it was taken over by Tiscali the Italian company's shares should be listed in Amsterdam.

Others asked why, given the €1.59bn cash on World Online's balance sheet, their company was not buying Tiscali. Somebody else took umbrage at press reports that Mr Schlifgaarde was threatening legal action against anyone who damaged the company. "If we complain we are threatened with counterclaims. It is the shareholders who are the victims," he said, to applause.

All this finally got on top of Mr Kinsella, who displayed exemplary patience for most of the three-hour meeting.

"Come down to my office and you will see how much time I have to spend every day dealing with claims, rumours and innuendo," he said.

After three hours came a lighter note. One shareholder asked if a summary of the proceedings could be sent to shareholders to help them to decide on the Tiscali offer. World Online would try to put it on the net, he was told.

"I don't have access," he said to some amusement. OK, give us your address and we will send you a hard copy.

"I don't have that, either, after investing in World Online," he countered, to much laughter from other shareholders.

webTitle: Man with cancer 'left to die in hospital'

fields.headline: Man with cancer 'left to die in hospital'
fields.standfirst:
Health trust launches investigation after family claims patient suffered treatment 'worse than an animal' in Victorian ward

Special report: NHS shortages
fields.trailText: An NHS trust yesterday launched an investigation into allegations that a man with cancer was left to die on a mental health ward.
fields.body:
An NHS trust yesterday launched an investigation into allegations that a man with cancer was left to die on a mental health ward.

The family of Lawrence Jordan say he was given only paracetamol to relieve his pain, and was so neglected he was covered in his own excrement, and bruises from falling out of bed.

Leicestershire and Rutland Healthcare NHS trust admitted having a shortage of nurses and will meet Mr Jordan's family next week.

Mr Jordan,73, died in August after being admitted for tests after the onset of dementia.

He was treated for seven weeks on ward five at Leicester general hospital.

The 20-bed ward to assess older people with mental health problems was Victorian, according to Mr Jordan's family who say it reeked of urine.

He was found to have a tumour behind his eye that was so large it caused his eye to bulge and was pressing on his brain. He also had cancer of the bowel, lungs and liver.

Mr Jordan's daughter, Joanne Silverwood, 35, said: "If it had been an animal the RSPCA would have been called in to investigate that ward. He was treated worse than an animal."

"One nurse said that they couldn't move him as there would be too much paper work. Another nurse was in tears and said 'sorry he's not getting the care he should be getting'."

The family say they had to battle to get Mr Jordan a specialist cancer nurse and a private room for his last few days.

Joanne's sister Alicia Jordan, 33, said: "They made him wear incontinence pants even though he wanted to go to the toilet. They wouldn't clean him for hours. He was only given one bath in seven weeks.

"They didn't treat him for the cancer, there was no radiotherapy or chemotherapy, they just let him die. On a cancer ward he'd probably be on a morphine drip and have had better care.

"I cried every time I saw him. Towards the end he was covered in his own excrement. It was on his pillow and his hands, it was just horrible."

In a statement Leicestershire and Rutland healthcare NHS trust said: "The issues raised in August by the family concerned were investigated at the time and the family was provided with a full response and details of our findings.

"We are naturally anxious that any new concerns expressed by the family are fully understood and are thoroughly investigated by the trust.

"All complaints received by the trust are dealt with as very serious matters and we ensure that they are properly and fully investigated."

The statement said the trust was worried about the effect of adverse publicity after Mr Jordan's family's allegations were broadcast by BBC Radio 4's You and Yours programme.

"Staff working on ward five are naturally upset about the recent publicity and the trust is offering them support and reassurance."

The government has vowed to improve the treatment of cancer, pledging more money, doctors and nurses.

webTitle: Why is the PM so defensive about his chief of defence?

fields.headline: Why is the PM so defensive about his chief of defence?
fields.standfirst: Sir Charles Guthrie The general embroiled in political controversy
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's robust praise yesterday for General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, is more than a formal display of support of someone who cannot speak out for himself, or a way of getting back at the rightwing, Eurosceptic, press.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's robust praise yesterday for General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, is more than a formal display of support of someone who cannot speak out for himself, or a way of getting back at the rightwing, Eurosceptic, press.

It reflects the prime minister's deeply personal appreciation of his top military adviser at a time when the job - of which Mr Blair has demanded so much - is being embroiled in a degree of political controversy unprecedented in modern times, when the armed forces are increasingly becoming a tool of foreign policy.

Sir Charles, not surprisingly, is an enthusiastic supporter of the Blair government's show of confidence in the military, in its role, for example, in Kosovo and Sierra Leone - and now as a potential leading player in the proposed EU rapid reaction force.

Through a series of crises, Mr Blair has formed a close relationship with Sir Charles and implicitly trusts his ability to ensure the armed forces face up to the demands made of them.

But it would not be surprising if Sir Charles, a former SAS soldier said to have killed people with his bare hands, left a private meeting with the prime minister with teeth gritted. Mr Blair's enthusiastic support for intervention, not least in the Kosovo war, combined with what the military privately regard as unacceptable Treasury parsimony, is causing serious problems for Britain's armed forces.

Sir Charles has made his concerns clear to the prime minister, according to a report leaked before this summer's spending review. Mr Blair used this to secure a last-minute rise in the defence budget, a real increase of just 0.1%.

Labour's 1998 strategic defence review geared Britain's armed forces towards an expeditionary role. Sierra Leone has demonstrated the ability of three services to mount an impressive force quickly.

British servicemen conducting humanitarian operations and rescue missions may make Mr Blair, Robin Cook and Clare Short glow with pride. But as far as the military is concerned, there is a limit.

"The government says that defence should be a force for good," Sir Charles told the Daily Telegraph in August. "But being a force for good does not just mean cuddling orphans and giving aspirins and cups of tea to old ladies."

Another senior officer who asked not to be identified echoed the sentiment. "It is attractive," he said, "to sell the armed forces to Guardian readers as 'these aren't steely-eyed fascist murderers, these are very nice people who go around cuddling orphans and being nice to widows'."

The officer warned that concentrating on the "touchy-feely" approach at the expense of training for war would mean "we're going to finish up fighting with a gendarmerie".

Senior officers are telling Sir Charles that, behind the high-profile operations, the armed forces are facing serious problems nearer home. The condition of many barracks and married quarters are rapidly deteriorating, there is a shortage of pilots, there are delays in acquiring basic equipment, tens of thousands of the army's standard rifle, the SA80, are being modified in Germany.

Does Sir Charles drive these points home to his political master? Has he been seduced too much by his personal relationship with the prime minister? These questions are being asked in Whitehall.

He has certainly warned Mr Blair about the danger of committing British troops to more operations and was initially deeply sceptical about the plans for a EU rapid reaction force. He is alleged to have told ministers after the Kosovo war: "You cannot trust the Europeans. They never turn up."

His scepticism appears to have been allayed by the pledges of troops from EU countries and the decision by many of them to increase their defence budgets and improve military training.

He is also understood to have reservations about US plans for a national missile protective shield - a project which has implications for Britain and the rest of the European allies. He goes out of his way to praise Russia's role in ending the Kosovo war by applying pressure on Slobodan Milosevic and now in Nato-led peacekeeping operations in Kosovo.

But Tories and Daily Telegraph letter-writing former service chiefs will continue to ask how this plummy-voiced, Harrow-educated, tennis-playing general, a friend to Prince Charles, can possibly be so close to a Labour prime minister.

We will have to wait until February, when Sir Charles retires, to find out what he really thinks.

fields.headline: Bomb-risk warning to Britons
fields.standfirst: Experts puzzled as expatriates hit by second car explosion in Saudi capital
fields.trailText: Britons in Saudi Arabia were urged to take extra care yesterday after two explosions in five days in the capital Riyadh.
fields.body:
Britons in Saudi Arabia were urged to take extra care yesterday after two explosions in five days in the capital Riyadh.

Three Britons - two men and a woman - were injured late on Wednesday night when their car exploded in the Suleimaniyeh district. One of the men was said to be in a stable condition in hospital with serious injuries to his right leg. The two other occupants of the car suffered minor injuries.

Sources in London said that all three worked for the Saudi al-Salam aircraft company, which is half-owned by the US plane-maker Boeing.

Last Friday Christopher Rodway, 40, a British engineer who worked at a military hospital, was killed by an explosion in his car in central Riyadh. His wife was slightly injured.

There was widespread suspicion yesterday that both incidents were the work of terrorists, though there has been no official confirmation. The explosions do not fit the usual pattern of attacks by Osama bin Laden, the fugitive Saudi Islamist, and associated groups, according to security experts.

A source at the Control Risks consultancy, which advises on business risks, said: "The bombs were relatively small, capable of seriously injuring only the driver. This suggests that a local, previously unknown group with limited capabilities was responsible.

"The motive appears to be anti-western anger over its support for Israel rather than a specific political agenda." American, Canadian and European expatriates in Saudi Arabia were at risk and should check their cars.

American forces in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Qatar were put on the highest state of alert after the USS Cole was bombed in Yemen on October 12, with the loss of 17 sailors.

Six Kuwaitis are being held in Kuwait after the discovery earlier this month of a suspected plot to attack American and British forces there. The authorities say they buried 133kg of explosives in the desert and planned to use it to bomb a US army camp and western military personnel in their homes and vehicles.

Yesterday security experts were discussing why, if the Saudi blasts were caused by terrorists, they were aimed at Britons rather than Americans.

One possible explanation is that tightened security around Americans has forced terrorists to look for easier targets and that Britain, a close ally of the US actively engaged in maintaining the no-fly zones over Iraq, is a suitable option.

Rodway had a military connection, and the three injured on Wednesday had a US connection through their employment. Between 25,000 and 30,000 Britons work in the kingdom.

Saudi officials, who often try to play down security problems in the kingdom, say they believe the incidents were personal rather than politically motivated. A British Foreign Office spokeswoman said yesterday: "The Saudi police have reached no firm conclusion about last week's explosion, though they are 95 % sure it was some kind of device. They have yet to examine any links between the two explosions."

She confirmed that no organisation had claimed responsibility and no specific threat was received beforehand.

The Saudis have turned down an offer of British help in the investigation. "They say they feel they can cope, and we're happy with what they've done so far."

A Saudi newspaper quoted the deputy interior minister, Prince Ahmed bin Abdul Aziz, as saying he did not rule out personal motives, and the authorities would "investigate any link to the previous incident, especially since circumstances were similar and so were the nationalities".

webTitle: UK to conduct BSE checks in France

fields.headline: UK to conduct BSE checks in France
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: British food standards officials will visit France next week to conduct safety checks on the country's beef industry in a high-profile move to maintain consumer and political confidence as fears about BSE spread through Europe.
fields.body:
British food standards officials will visit France next week to conduct safety checks on the country's beef industry in a high-profile move to maintain consumer and political confidence as fears about BSE spread through Europe.

The team, which begins work on Sunday, is expected to stay for two to three days and investigate whether measures to prevent the export of meat banned for domestic consumption are adequate.

The French authorities have given the visit their blessing. The unusual step was instigated by Sir John Krebs, chairman of the food standards agency, amid concerns over growing levels of BSE in France.

The move coincides with an increase in spot checks here by local authority officials, who will demand that importers have the right paperwork that enables food to be traced back fully to overseas suppliers. Unlimited fines and up to two years imprisonment can be imposed on companies that fail to demonstrate "due diligence" over food safety.

The agency and the government fear the concern over events in France is ignoring the fact that the official inquiry into BSE published last month found that Britain had exported the disease. Even with the epidemic here declining, nearly 1,150 cases have been confirmed this year, compared with 100 in France. Three French nationals are so far thought to have contracted the human form of the disease, compared with 85 Britons.

The agency is sensitive to accusations that it is more lenient towards French beef than our own, especially since there are reports that rules barring the import of beef over 30 months old from any country with a history of BSE are being evaded by the meat being processed and packaged elsewhere.

Sir John said there was no firm evidence, but added: "We have made it clear in our review that the over-30 month rules are difficult to police on imports, especially on beef products." The agency is looking at how UK rules might be made tougher, while ministers are pressing the EU to tighten rules on the labelling of country of origin.

webTitle: Hospital hygiene rules flouted, say doctors

fields.headline: Hospital hygiene rules flouted, say doctors
fields.standfirst: Special report: NHS shortages
fields.trailText: Three-quarters of doctors believe that hospital hygiene rules are routinely broken, according to a survey released yesterday.
fields.body:
Three-quarters of doctors believe that hospital hygiene rules are routinely broken, according to a survey released yesterday.

The survey, conducted by Medix, a website for registered doctors, found that 83% of the 831 respondents believed that it was not unusual for hygiene rules to be broken, and that as many believed NHS hospital hygiene was a serious problem. More than half the responses were from hospital doctors.

The survey coincided with the release of a report by a parliamentary spending regulator which found that 5,000 patients died every year from infections picked up in hospitals, at a cost to the NHS of £1bn a year. The reports are a blow to the government which this year pledged to crackdown on poor hospital hygiene.

Almost one in five doctors in the Medix survey said that disposable equipment was often re-used. Three-quarters said that poor infection control was putting lives at risk unnecessarily, and more than half said they did not believe the NHS was on course to reduce the problem of patients picking up life threatening infections.

Rino Coladangelo, of Medix, said: "What is very worrying is that so many doctors say that the infections are not due to antibiotic resistance but a failure in standard hygiene. They know hygiene rules are being broken and that they are contributing to it."

The scale of the threat of hospital acquired infection, revealed in yesterday's Commons public accounts committee report, was estimated to affect 100,000 hospital patients in England a year.

The report, Management and Control of Hospital Acquired Infection in NHS Acute Hospitals in England, said the NHS did not have a grip on the extent and costs of hospital acquired infection and was unlikely to have the information it needed for a further three to four years.

The government has allocated an extra £5m to combating the problem over the next two years, and additional infection control nurses have been appointed. However, the committee said that more funds were needed. It stressed that doctors and nurses, not just infection control specialists, must be more scrupulous about hygiene.

The committee said that it was "inexcusable" that compliance with guidance on hand washing was so poor.

David Davis, committee chairman and Conservative MP for Haltemprice and Howden, said: "While it will never be entirely preventable there is more the NHS could do to combat the problem."

A hospital acquired infection, which can be caused by viruses, bacteria, fungi or parasites, may develop from surgical procedures, catheters in the urinary tract or blood vessels, or from bugs in the air. They may be present in the patient's body or come from healthcare workers, other patients, contaminated hospital equipment or the environment.

An average patient with a hospital acquired infection spent more than double the time in hospital and cost the NHS an extra £3,000 to treat according to a report this year by the London school of hygiene and the public health laboratory.

John Denham, the health minister, said that infection control teams, minimum standards and a mandatory reporting system had been introduced to every hospital during the last three years.

"There is too much hospital acquired infection and that is why action is being taken, now across the NHS to fight them," he said.

webTitle: Europe's rapid reaction force: supporters and doubters

fields.headline: Europe's rapid reaction force: supporters and doubters
fields.trailText: Under the EU's plan, by 2003 the 15 member states will be able to deploy within 60 days up to 60,000 troops, sustainable for at least a year.
fields.body:
Under the EU's plan, by 2003 the 15 member states will be able to deploy within 60 days up to 60,000 troops, sustainable for at least a year.

Britain has agreed to commit up to 12,500 troops from a pool of about double that amount, as well as 72 combat aircraft and 18 surface ships, including an aircraft carrier. Other European countries who are not members of the EU, including Turkey, have pledged thousands of troops.

Yet many questions remain unanswered.

"The question is whether this is a virtual or a real force," said Col Terence Taylor, assistant director of International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. "The danger is if politicians start to think and behave as if they have a military capability when they don't."

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, spoke this week about dealing with "Europe's back yard". However, the EU agreed that its proposed rapid reaction force could engage in operations ranging from humanitarian and rescue missions to peacekeeping and "tasks of combat forces in crisis management, including peacemaking". It even envisages "helping to resolve a crisis between two warring countries or factions".

In reality, any EU force would be deployed for limited operations or form part of a larger UN or Nato-led force, in Bosnia, for example, or Kosovo.

For years the EU will not have the equipment to carry out much more than minor rescue or humani tarian missions.

Decisions would be by consensus; no EU state would be forced to participate.

EU operations would be agreed only if Nato "as a whole" (a euphemism for the US) did not want to get involved.



General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff

"I don't see this as a huge new commitment. We're not going to rush off and start warfighting. It will be a force that, to start with, will do simple Petersberg tasks" - humanitarian and peacekeeping missions agreed at Petersberg, near Bonn, in 1992

Lord Healey, former Labour defence secretary

"The rapid reaction force is quite a good idea as such but I'm not in favour of a European security and defence identity"

Lord Robertson, secretary general of Nato

"Frankly, if it were to undermine or endanger the North Atlantic Alliance, I would have nothing to do with it"

Lt Col Ewen Southby-Tailyour (retired)

"European military unity? Don't bother telling that to the marines"

Colonel Terence Taylor, deputy director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies

"My big worry is that they are fine words on paper. We have to be confident they are real not virtual commitments"

Richard Perle, candidate for US defence secretary in a George W Bush administration

"We were alarmed to see the UK, normally so clear-headed over the din of eurobabble, join the French. What really seems to be at work here is a French-led plan to advance its towering conceit"

Caspar Weinberger, Ronald Reagan's former defence secretary

"It will unquestionably undermine the American commitment to Nato and risk the loss of fragile public support in the United States"

William Cohen, Bill Clinton's defence secretary

"It is right and natural that an increasingly integrated Europe seeks to develop its own security and defence policy with a military capability to back it up"

Bruce Kent, vice president of CND

"EU governments seem to be setting up an independent military force without any awareness of their international obligations to the UN"

Vice admiral Sir Louis Le Bailly (retired)

"I can no longer recommend recruitment if it involves serving in this mercenary force. We are confronted with a breach of faith unequalled since the forces' pay was summarily cut in 1931"

Madeleine Albright, US secretary of state

"A European rapid reaction force is a strongly positive development we wholly support. This EU force will be available to both Nato and the EU, in those cases where the alliance as a whole is not militarily engaged. It offers a valuable complement to the efforts and capabilities of Nato"

Tim Spicer, director of private military company Sandline

"Though there is some merit in Europe standing on its own, the fact is it is going to be very expensive. Money could be better spent improving our national capability"

Justin Forsyth, director of policy, Oxfam

"While Oxfam welcomes the creation of the new European defence force, its success rests on whether Europe has the will to use it outside of its backyard. Sadly this was lacking over the Rwandan genocide in 1994 and it remains to be seen as to whether this will improve"

Neil Durkin, spokesman, Amnesty International

"How is it going to square the fact that the UK is the only country in Europe deploying under-18s into conflict situations?"

Lord Blake, constitutional historian

"My instinct is that I am against it. It will have a weakening effect on Nato, which has been a great bulwark over the past 50 years in preserving peace in Europe"

John Major, former PM

"I have always favoured European co-operation on defence but only and exclusively as the European arm of the Nato alliance. The present proposals are totally different and wholly mistaken. Can the secretary of state not understand that what is proposed has no military logic? It adds not one iota of additional capacity. It offers no secure chain of command and, in my judgment, it will undermine Nato"

Martin Bell MP

"I have seen enough of European disunity on the ground in places like Bosnia and Kosovo to be in favour of greater cooperation. Broadly speaking it is a step in the right direction. We have fought under the UN flag in the past and there will be a continuing power of veto. But it is important to remember that we are not actually recruiting 12,000 extra soldiers to such a force"

Nicholas Soames, Tory MP

"I was a defence minister and I can assure you that what is proposed is deeply damaging to Nato. Regrettably this is the beginning of the decoupling of America from Europe. I spent weeks trying to persuade the Americans to come to Bosnia. Now this means they will never need to come into a European situation ever again"

Lord Chalfont, former Labour defence minister

"I think this is entirely a political act. It is a European army formed entirely as a building block in the construction of a European state. I think the dangers are that it will overstretch our forces beyond what they can stand as they are already overstretched. It undermines our relationship with the US especially in relation to the intelligence field, which is at the heart of our special relationship"

John Monks, general secretary of the TUC

"The hysterical over-reaction of the Eurosceptics to a modest and commonsense policy, which many of them used to support, says a lot about their real politics. Forget about sovereignty, the constantly peddled Euro-myths and bogus threats to our national identity, their real position is political opposition to the European model of good welfare states, rights for people at work and concern about inequalities"

Menzies Campbell MP

"It makes nothing but good sense for the EU to acquire the ability to deal with crises such as Bosnia and Kosovo without having to rely on the Americans"

It offers a valuable complement to the efforts and capabilities of Nato" Tim Spicer, director of private military company Sandline "Though there is some merit in Europe standing on its own, the fact is it is going to be very expensive. Money could be better spent improving our national capability" Justin Forsyth, director of policy, Oxfam "While Oxfam welcomes the creation of the new European defence force, its success rests on whether Europe has the will to use it outside of its backyard. Sadly this was lacking over the Rwandan genocide in 1994 and it remains to be seen as to whether this will improve" Neil Durkin, spokesman, Amnesty International "How is it going to square the fact that the UK is the only country in Europe deploying under-18s into conflict situations?" Lord Blake, constitutional historian "My instinct is that I am against it. It will have a weakening effect on Nato, which has been a great bulwark over the past 50 years in preserving peace in Europe" John Major, former PM "I have always favoured European co-operation on defence but only and exclusively as the European arm of the Nato alliance. The present proposals are totally different and wholly mistaken. Can the secretary of state not understand that what is proposed has no military logic? It adds not one iota of additional capacity. It offers no secure chain of command and, in my judgment, it will undermine Nato" Martin Bell MP "I have seen enough of European disunity on the ground in places like Bosnia and Kosovo to be in favour of greater cooperation. Broadly speaking it is a step in the right direction. We have fought under the UN flag in the past and there will be a continuing power of veto. But it is important to remember that we are not actually recruiting 12,000 extra soldiers to such a force" Nicholas Soames, Tory MP "I was a defence minister and I can assure you that what is proposed is deeply damaging to Nato. Regrettably this is the beginning of the decoupling of America from Europe. I spent weeks trying to persuade the Americans to come to Bosnia. Now this means they will never need to come into a European situation ever again" Lord Chalfont, former Labour defence minister "I think this is entirely a political act. It is a European army formed entirely as a building block in the construction of a European state. I think the dangers are that it will overstretch our forces beyond what they can stand as they are already overstretched. It undermines our relationship with the US especially in relation to the intelligence field, which is at the heart of our special relationship" John Monks, general secretary of the TUC "The hysterical over-reaction of the Eurosceptics to a modest and commonsense policy, which many of them used to support, says a lot about their real politics. Forget about sovereignty, the constantly peddled Euro-myths and bogus threats to our national identity, their real position is political opposition to the European model of good welfare states, rights for people at work and concern about inequalities" Menzies Campbell MP "It makes nothing but good sense for the EU to acquire the ability to deal with crises such as Bosnia and Kosovo without having to rely on the Americans"

fields.headline: Letter
fields.body:
Jack Person (not my real name) writes: I would like to add to the obituary of Dr Mervin Glasser (November 21). I was a non-abusing paedophile attracted to pre-adolescent boys, and was treated by Dr Glasser at the Portman Clinic between 1972 and 1975. By the time I left his care, I no longer had that sexuality and was well within the bounds of a normal adult emotional and sexual life. It is not in the nature of a psychoanalytic relationship that one knows one's analyst, of course, but I can say this: my power to live a normal rewarding and useful life is due to that helping relationship. My freedom to love my partner is a freedom born of Dr Glasser's relationship with me.

In the current, malignant atmosphere, in which a top policeman (Commander John 0'Connor, News of the World, August 13 2000) can say "in all my long career, I have never known a paedophile to give up his compulsive lust and be cured," Dr Glasser's work stands as a monument to another, benign view of humanity. It is possible for paedophiles and other sufferers of damaging sexual distresses to self-correct, learn and grow.

Dr Glasser's work shows that the way forward to solving the problem of child sex abuse is not via the pogroms of Paulsgrove, fed by the rightwing press, but via a qualitative increase in curative facilities, not just for abusers, but for all those suffering from damaging sexual dysfunctions.

fields.headline: Carlos Cardoso
fields.standfirst: His tenacious journalism exposed corruption in Mozambique
fields.trailText: His tenacious journalism exposed corruption in Mozambique
fields.body:
Carlos Cardoso, who has been shot dead in gangland fashion aged 48, was Mozambique's best and most respected journalist. His exposés of growing and pervasive corruption had brought numerous death threats, but he told me recently he felt safe because no one had tried to carry them out.

Born in Beira in central Mozambique, Cardoso went to secondary school in South Africa, and then to the University of the Witwatersrand, where he became a student activist. When Frelimo defeated the Portuguese colonial power in Mozambique in 1974, the apartheid government expelled him to Portugal, and he paid his own way back to a soon-to-be-independent Mozambique. His father, the manager of a dairy products factory, joined the exodus of Portuguese in 1975.

Cardoso's commitment and integrity, combined with his journalistic skills and out- spoken manner, constantly annoyed the Frelimo leadership. He joined the government-run magazine, Tempo, in 1976, and was pushed into a backwater in the music section of Radio Mozambique in 1979, only to be appointed in 1980 as editor of the government press agency, AIM.

In 1982, he was jailed, probably on the instructions of President Samora Machel, for a newspaper column about the growing war with the rebel movement, Renamo. Released after six days, he returned as editor of the government press agency, and later became one of Machel's advisers. He warned of Machel's impending assassination by South Africa in 1986, and probed Mozambican links to the killing.

Frustrated by management, and what he saw as poor journalism, in 1989 Cardoso turned to painting, but three years later he was back, as co-founder of Mozambique's first independent press cooperative, Mediacoop.

Cardoso was always pouring out wild ideas: turning marijuana into a major export crop, or giving marbles to children in exchange for growing papaya. Most of these came to nothing, but he did create probably the first faxed daily newspaper in the world, when he set up Media- Fax in 1992. Detailed and accurate, it became required reading in Maputo. But, in 1997, frustrated with what he saw as the sloppiness of even the independent media, Cardoso quit Mediacoop to set up a faxed newspaper of his own.

This time he was sole owner, but he paid high wages. The paper was called Metical, after the Mozambican currency, and was a business daily, supporting local entrepreneurs against the globalising pressures of the World Bank and IMF, and the predations of a corrupt political elite. It was profitable within weeks.

Cardoso led the campaign against the World Bank's enforced closure of the cashew nut processing industry. He pushed people like me to write articles to challenge, from both right and left, orthodox economic solutions for Mozambique's underdevelopment.

His campaigning was not just journalistic. He was elected to the Maputo city assembly in 1998, as part of a citizens' list called Together For The City. But he remained totally committed to the ideals of the party; during one heated debate, he yelled across to the Frelimo bench: "You are not the only Frelimo in this room."

L ast week, Cardoso started campaigning against what he called the "gangster faction" in Frelimo, who, he argued, provoked recent violence to cover their own misconduct and inaction. When I was in his office three weeks ago, he was researching an exposé of the links of senior officials and businessmen to a £10m bank fraud and subsequent cover-up. His killing is a clear message to journalists and others of the price of asking too many questions.

Cardoso's combination of doggedness, journalistic skill and integrity were unique in Mozambique. He leaves his wife, the Norwegian lawyer Nina Berg, whom he met in 1989, and two children, Ibo and Milene.

 Carlos Cardoso, journalist and editor, born 1952; died November 22 2000

fields.headline: Maurice Wellington
fields.trailText: Maurice "Blacka Morwell" Wellington, who has died of cancer aged 50, forged a roots reggae in 1970s Jamaica, which became popular in Britain and the United States.
fields.body:
Maurice "Blacka Morwell" Wellington, who has died of cancer aged 50, forged a roots reggae in 1970s Jamaica, which became popular in Britain and the United States. He grew up in Kingston's Trench Town, between a cemetery and a sewage gully. By 1967, he was performing, and debuted in production in 1972 on Sir Harry's Last Call, with the veteran DJ of that name.

In 1973, Wellington and Eric "Bingi Bunny" Lamont formed the Morwells group. In 1974, former Versatiles member Louis Davis joined, changing the production-based duo into a vocal group. The romantic Bit By Bit was their first international success, in 1975. By the time of their album Crab Race (1978), Wellington had been recruited as a producer at Joe Gibbs's studio. Wellington discovered Joseph Hill's group, Culture, and oversaw their classic debut sets, Two Sevens Clash and Baldhead Bridge.

The Morwells albums, Cool Runnings and Kingston 12 Toughie, were well received in Britain. But in the early 1980s, the group disbanded .

Wellington continued producing, but a move to New York affected his work. Briefly married in 1984-85, he then began his relationship with Karen Rickenbach, a stabilising influence through difficult years; Eric Lamont died of prostate cancer in 1993, Wellington's son Donovan died in 1994, and Nicodeemus, a younger brother of Wellington, succumbed to diabetes in 1996.

In 1998, he returned to Kingston. But last August, Rickenbach took him to Brooklyn's Methodist hospital, where doctors found that he was suffering from the autoimmune disease, lupus, and from cancer. Karen and seven children survive him.

 Maurice Wellington (aka Blacka Morwell), musician and producer, born August 19 1950; died October 12 2000
