webTitle: Charismatic Carlos has a long road ahead

fields.headline: Charismatic Carlos has a long road ahead
fields.standfirst: Notebook City applauds supermarket boss
fields.trailText: Safeway's chief executive, Carlos Criado-Perez, yesterday hailed an about turn in the fortunes of the supermarket chain which only 12 months ago was regarded as being in its death throes. He announced impressive sales and profits growth and a plan to build a chain of Safeway hypermarkets out of the group's largest stores.
fields.body:
Safeway's chief executive, Carlos Criado-Perez, yesterday hailed an about turn in the fortunes of the supermarket chain which only 12 months ago was regarded as being in its death throes. He announced impressive sales and profits growth and a plan to build a chain of Safeway hypermarkets out of the group's largest stores.

The City applauds rapid change and analysts like the charismatic Carlos the grocer.

The shares climbed 4% as he outlined his "breakthrough vision" and have now more than doubled since February. Over 12 months the stock has proved to be the best performer in its pan-European sector.

However, supermarkets the size of Safeway cannot be transformed from a near basket case in the space of a few months. The real proof that his strategy is working will take some time yet.

Safeway, for instance, proudly boasts that it has won 1m new customers from its rivals in response to its deep discount price promotions on about 50 products, communicated to shoppers via flyers. Its market share is 0.2% higher at 9.7%.

However, the evidence so far is that the new shoppers are buying only the special offer goods - the same problem Sainsbury had with its disastrous Value to Shout About campaign.

True, Safeway does not seem to have alienated its existing customers in the same way as Sainsbury did. They are buying more, say Safeway. But there is no certainty that the vital new shoppers will carry on shopping at Safeway when the tone of the flyers changes, which Mr Criado-Perez is about to do in a bid to increase the average basket size.

Like for like sales improvements might be about to become harder to achieve.

The strategy to convert and extend the biggest stores into hypermarkets is also not without risk.

Mr Criado-Perez has decided to steer well clear of the super-tough clothing and electrical goods sectors, but the markets he prefers to wade into - which range from towels to trowels - do not exactly offer easy pickings.

The chief executive is planning to line his shelves with cookery equipment, entertainment and stationery merchandise just as Boots has decided to pull out of such markets because it cannot compete effectively. He is also planning to go into health and beauty products in a bigger way.

In addition, he is targeting the DIY market, presumably hoping to win customers in a market where size really does matter, from the likes of B&Q and Homebase.

Undoubtedly Safeway needs a bold plan. And that need comes at a time when Asda, which has recently lost its chief executive, seems to have lost its golden touch.

The supermarket business, however, remains bruising. If an idea seems good Safeway will not be left to pursue it alone. Its bigger rivals will follow suit, with more muscle and probably more panache.

Mr Criado-Perez has delivered on all his promises so far, and the City is giving him the benefit of the doubt, but the going may be about to get a great deal tougher.

Cross-pond gaze

There is only one conclusion that can be drawn from yesterday's Bank of England's report on lending to Britain's most depressed areas - the country needs its own version of America's community reinvestment act.

Given that Labour has stolen so many of its policies - elected mayors, drug czars, independent central banks - from the US, it is surprising that it has so far showed little interest in a CRA, which has been hugely successful in forcing banks in the US to stump up for regeneration projects.

According to the Bank, budding entrepreneurs in rundown areas can find finance for their new businesses, but only at a price. Interest rates are higher than they are elsewhere in the country because the banks believe there may be a lack of business experience, a lack of collateral and personal equity, remoteness, small and localised markets and high crime rates.

But actually the report rather pulls its punches, because what it does not say is that some banks are much more willing to take risks than others.

The New Economics Foundation, which has been at the forefront of attempts to find new ways of financing businesses in inner cities, says that NatWest has a much better record than its rivals. Two steps now need to be taken by the government.

First, it should not allow banks to hide behind a cloak of anonymity but insist that they reveal in full the extent of their lending - or non-lending - to inner-city London, Liverpool, Manchester and Glasgow.

Armed with that information, and details of the profits being made by the banks, Labour should then include plans for a CRA in its next manifesto.

webTitle: US regulator administers setback to BTG patent

fields.headline: US regulator administers setback to BTG patent
fields.trailText: BTG, a patenting firm specialising in commercialising hi-tech inventions, yesterday revealed that US regulators have demanded fresh trials of its therapy for varicose veins.
fields.body:
BTG, a patenting firm specialising in commercialising hi-tech inventions, yesterday revealed that US regulators have demanded fresh trials of its therapy for varicose veins.

The setback emerged as the company revealed a fivefold jump in interim losses to £3.58m and signalled that extra investment in new products would keep it in the red for another three years.

BTG's shares tumbled 260p to £13.47 on the news, wiping £270m off the firm's market value. Chief executive Ian Harvey insisted the company remained on track, however.

He described Varisolve, a method of calming varicose veins through a simple injection, as "the largest potential product we have ever had of any kind".

Phase three clinical trials of Varisolve in the US were planned for late next year, but will be delayed until 2002 following a request from American regulatory body the Food and Drugs Administration for further studies to determine dosages.

Elizabeth Klein, an analyst at Kleinwort Benson, downgraded the stock from "buy" to "hold", saying: "People were assuming it's a done deal but it's not - it's not due out until 2006."

BTG recently raised £121.5m in a rights issue, and extra spending will delay profitability. Recent patents include technology to update mobile phone SIM cards and the use of a virus to treat cancer.

webTitle: Skimpy fashions trip up New Look

fields.headline: Skimpy fashions trip up New Look
fields.trailText: Clothing chain New Look yesterday admitted making a big fashion mistake in the summer which left it nursing a big drop in sales, writes Julia Finch.
fields.body:
Clothing chain New Look yesterday admitted making a big fashion mistake in the summer which left it nursing a big drop in sales, writes Julia Finch.

Chief executive Stephen Sunnucks announced a dip in profits from £25.8m to £23.8m, saying the stores had too many skimpy high summer fashions on its rails when its shoppers were still searching for cardigans and long-sleeved tops.

The result was a 4.1% dip in like-for-like sales. But the shares - which have halved in value since July - climbed 6p to 69.5p as analysts decided the worst was over and that New Look had sorted out its stock problems.

In the last eight weeks, like-for-like sales were down only 1.6%.

Mr Sunnucks said that the group would now stock more "transitional product" either side of the main summer season. The chain is also planning to increase the choice in tailoring, "which is showing a positive fashion trend", and cut out duplication in its ranges. Mr Sunnucks said that the new stocking policy would allow the company to sell its "hot items" in greater numbers.

With other products the group performed well. Footwear sales were up 32% on the previous year and lingerie was up 42%. These lines now account for nearly one fifth of sales.

New Look investors have had a bumpy ride.

The shares were floated at 165p in June 1998, but slumped to just 51p this year.

The slide was so dramatic that there has been speculation that founder Tom Singh, who controls 33% of the company through individual holdings and family trusts, might attempt to take the company private again.

However, yesterday Mr Sunnucks denied that Mr Singh had any such plans and analysts said the chief executive had been frank about the mistakes made and the remedies put in place.

webTitle: Islands in peril plead for deal

fields.headline: Islands in peril plead for deal
fields.standfirst: Climate change Low-lying countries call for action and aid to cope with effects of rising sea levels and storms
fields.trailText: As the deadline for agreement at the stalled climate talks in the Hague approached yesterday, 40 small island states made a dramatic plea to the developed world to reach a deal on greenhouse gases and to help them cope with the problems of global warming.
fields.body:
As the deadline for agreement at the stalled climate talks in the Hague approached yesterday, 40 small island states made a dramatic plea to the developed world to reach a deal on greenhouse gases and to help them cope with the problems of global warming.

The rise in sea levels, droughts leading to water shortages, and coral bleaching are already seriously affecting the economies of some of the world's most beautiful islands.

Youlsau Bells of Palau, a chain of 200 islands in Micronesia in the Pacific with a population of 17,000, said causeways connecting the seven inhabited islands had always been dry even at high tide, but now they were covered half the time. Three islands are just above sea level and their 7,000-strong population may have to be evacuated.

"In the drought two years ago coconut trees spontaneously caught fire, something that has never happened in living memory," she said. "We have seven fresh water lakes on Palau containing unique forms of jelly fish which have evolved not to sting. Tourists come for the pleasure of swimming among them but four lakes have dried up."

Al Binger, from Jamaica, said "When things go bad, things go bad for the little people first. Our water supplies dry up, our aquifers are becoming saline, our banana crops are destroyed by storms, our beaches are disappearing.

"Beaches are our Fort Knox, our money in the bank, each square metre that disappears is serious in terms of economics.

"If we go home without an agreement we will have failed." he added. "We are very disappointed that the countries most responsible for our plight are not doing more. Our survival depends on cuts in greenhouse gases and currently the trends are all the wrong way."

The small island states want a 20% cut in emission of greenhouse gases as a starting point - 80% cuts are required to stabilise the climate, according to scientists. However, the 160 nations at the talks are struggling to agree on cuts of just 5.2% by 2010 on the 1990 levels.

Mr Binger said emissions were already 11% over 1990 levels so the situation was deteriorating fast.

Sheik Mohammed Khan, from Guyana, on the north coast of South America, said many people from the former British colony were emigrating. "Our 750,000 population has not gone up in 30 years. We constantly have disasters, floods and droughts; just coping with it uses up 30% of our national economy."

He appealed for aid to help patch up coastal defences protecting Guyana's storm-battered coastal plain, where 90% of the population lives.

Although the plight of the small island states is the most dramatic, the insurance industry is also alarmed by the global climate shifts.

Dr Andrew Dlugolecki, a climate change specialist with CGNU, the sixth largest insurance company in the world, warned that climate change could in effect reduce the world to bankruptcy by 2065.

At present world economic growth is averaging 3% a year while insurance losses because of extreme weather are increasing by 10% a year. "By 2065 the two growth graphs cross and the world economy can no longer sustain the losses, and collapse will follow," he said.

Mr Dlugolecki highlighted the difference between first and third worlds by producing a report showing that 70% of Britain's most famous links golf courses - including the home of golf, St Andrews - were threatened by erosion or flooding because of rising sea levels within 20 years.

Dr Robert Watson, head of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the UN body that advises governments, said that even if there were comprehensive cuts in greenhouse gases it would take centuries for the climate system to restore itself. Sea levels are likely to rise for another 1,000 years.

The talks continued into the night.

fields.headline: At this price?  Osmetech
fields.trailText: Health-care company Osmetech has been talking for so long about its electronic nose, which is supposed to be able to sniff out infections in bodily fluids, that it has become something of a stock market joke.
fields.body:
Health-care company Osmetech has been talking for so long about its electronic nose, which is supposed to be able to sniff out infections in bodily fluids, that it has become something of a stock market joke.

The bizarre-sounding technology has never quite got off the ground despite its great potential - Osmetech believes, for example, that it could diagnose pneumonia by sniffing peoples' breath.

However, under new chief executive Wang Chong, the Crewe-based company is finally beginning to look like a credible force.

Osmetech, formerly called Aromascan, has opted to perfect the technology platform underlying its "sniffer" rather than throwing millions of pounds at creating a specific product.

This approach paid off yesterday as a US firm, Cyrano Sciences, stepped in to provide a hand-held device which, when combined with Osmetech's sniffing expertise, could provide a useful tool in doctors' surgeries.

The first application will be in tests for urinary tract infections - uncomfortable disorders which at present require a laboratory diagnosis taking up to five days.

Osmetech's device, which looks like a handheld com puter with a needle sticking out, can produce an instant result by sniffing the fumes from a test-tube sized sample of urine.

The US food and drug administration will begin considering Osmetech's technology in January and if approved, the first products could be on sale by 2002.

Stockbroker Teather & Greenwood believes that Osmetech could have sales of £120m, and earnings of £50m, by 2005.

With a share price of 20p, the business is currently valued at just £45m, so the potential upside could be enormous.

However, Osmetech has disappointed its followers before, so the shares are really only worth a small punt, for investors in search of a high-risk bet.

fields.headline: Safeway plans continental-style stores
fields.trailText: Supermarket chain Safeway yesterday announced an ambitious plan to turn its 25 largest stores into continental-style hypermarkets as it unveiled an impressive turnaround in its fortunes.
fields.body:
Supermarket chain Safeway yesterday announced an ambitious plan to turn its 25 largest stores into continental-style hypermarkets as it unveiled an impressive turnaround in its fortunes.

The company, Britain's fourth largest grocer, plans to convert 40% of the space in the new hypermarket outlets to non-food items. But they will not stock clothing or electrical goods, which are in highly competitive sectors.

The expansion plan comes 12 months after the Argentine former Wal-Mart executive Carlos Criado-Perez took charge at the ailing retailer, which has repeatedly been tipped as a lame duck takeover target.

When Mr Criado-Perez moved in he said he would halt expansion and concentrate on rebuilding the business. But yesterday, as Safeway unveiled like-for-like sales up 5% and half year profits up 10% to £166m, he said he had stopped the rot and was planning to expand.

The results put Sainsbury's half year results, released on Wednesday, in the shade. Sainsbury reported a 23% plunge in profits in its supermarket business and like-for-like sales ahead just 2%.

"We are now laying the foundations for strong growth in our second half and beyond," said Mr Criado-Perez, who refers to the grocery business as "retail-tainment".

Analysts were impressed and Safeway's shares climbed 12p to 327p, their best level since the summer of 1998. In February of this year they were changing hands at just 160p.

The first of the new look hypermarkets, which will average 6,000 sq m, will open within six months and up to eight are planned for next year. Some 25 stores will be converted within two years and the group believes there is potential for 45 in the longer term.

At the other end of the scale, Safeway plans to remodel its smaller outlets as convenience stores concentrating on "fresh food to go". The first concept store will open in London next month.

Mr Criado-Perez has moved with speed to resuscitate Safeway. One of his first moves was to put every store manager on a bonus scheme which can double their pay if they hit growth and profit targets for their individual stores. So far they have received £7m and Mr Criado-Perez said he expected them to earn bonuses totalling £17m by the end of the year.

Yesterday he revealed the bonus system was being extended to all shopfloor staff, although their potential rewards will be much lower - around £100 every six months if they meet targets. Altogether the reward scheme is expected to cost £30m this year.

He also axed the group's loyalty card - saving £60m a year - and its high profile national advertising, pouring the money instead into low-budget flyers advertising best buys posted to one in three homes each week.

The promotion has pulled in 1m new customers, and driven sales. Mr Criado-Perez now plans to persuade those shoppers, who have so far been concentrating on the discounted goods, to buy more and increase the average basket size.

webTitle: Electronic rival to Stock Exchange doubles losses

fields.headline: Electronic rival to Stock Exchange doubles losses
fields.trailText: Tradepoint Financial Networks, the electronic stock exchange with ambitions to rival the London Stock Exchange in Europe, reported nearly doubled first-half losses yesterday.
fields.body:
Tradepoint Financial Networks, the electronic stock exchange with ambitions to rival the London Stock Exchange in Europe, reported nearly doubled first-half losses yesterday.

Although turnover rose 188% to £1.6m, the net loss after tax rose from £3.6m to £6.1m. Average daily trading volume rose 79% to £75m following the launch of the company's pan-European blue chip market in July.

The company blamed the bulk of the increased loss on the launch of its European market, advanced costs associated with its planned link with the Swiss exchange, and higher staff costs.

Tradepoint and the Swiss bourse last month announced plans for Virt-x, a new cross-border market for blue chip stocks based on the bourse's technology. It is due to begin operations by March next year.

As part of the deal, the Swiss took a 38% stake in Tradepoint, which next month will seek shareholder approval for a name change to Virt-x.

Richard Kilsby, Tradepoint's chief executive, said the successful launch of the European market and the increased daily volume was further evidence of the demand for a pan-European blue chip market.

"The proposed creation of Virt-x gives us the opportunity to take our existing European platform to the next stage of its development by creating a market with a state of the art trading system and critical mass in liquidity," he said.

fields.headline: Frankfurt feels tech pain
fields.trailText: If you think London's tech stocks have been taking a pounding, spare a thought for those who put their money into Frankfurt's Neuer Markt.
fields.body:
If you think London's tech stocks have been taking a pounding, spare a thought for those who put their money into Frankfurt's Neuer Markt.

While our homegrown Techmark 100 has fallen the thick of 50% since its peak, Germany's Nemax 50 was down 67% before a partial recovery yesterday.

Like all "growth" indexes (obviously something of a misnomer), the Nemax has been hard hit over the past two weeks. Yesterday's 266 point rally to 3,441 looked impressive but the index was threatening to top 10,000 in March.

In part this can be put down to the recent flotation of Deutsche Post, which raised about £4bn and in the process sucked money out of the Neuer Markt.

This young market has also been hit by a crisis of confidence over the quality of corporate governance at many Neuer-listed companies and the robustness of its regulation and disclosure rules.

fields.standfirst: Life in parliament

Bad day

Parliamentary democracy, according to the Tories. Leader of the house Margaret Beckett announced guillotine motions on the freedom of information bill, the countryside bill, the political parties, elections and referendum bill and the disqualifications bill. Tory Stephen Day (Cheadle) suggested shutting down the Commons. "Would it not save the taxpayer an awful lot of money if she was simply to go out into town, buy a sign and hang it on the door which says closed?"

Quote of the day

"There is clearly something amiss when as many as 30 or more per cent at some universities are dropping out" - Education secretary David Blunkett on the number of students quitting courses.

Today

fields.headline: Diary  Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: •While the eyes of the newspaper world are on the sale of the Express (of which much more below), we begin today at the Daily Telegraph. Many readers in teaching have been worrying how dear old Chris Woodhead is preparing for his new post as a leader writer, and sad to relate the answer is very slowly indeed. The big shock for Chris so far has been that he is expected to type his own articles. No minion is on hand, as he anticipated, to record his thoughts, so the paper has sent him on a computer course. However, since Chris appears never to have used one before, he has had to start at the beginning with "this is the 'on' switch", etc. Worse still, he cannot type at all, even with two fingers. Telegraph executives are looking forward to his first hard-hitting leader, but some are concerned that, at current speed, it will be anywhere between nine months and two years out of date. And all this from a man who poured such scorn on the concept of lifelong learning.
fields.body:
While the eyes of the newspaper world are on the sale of the Express (of which much more below), we begin today at the Daily Telegraph. Many readers in teaching have been worrying how dear old Chris Woodhead is preparing for his new post as a leader writer, and sad to relate the answer is very slowly indeed. The big shock for Chris so far has been that he is expected to type his own articles. No minion is on hand, as he anticipated, to record his thoughts, so the paper has sent him on a computer course. However, since Chris appears never to have used one before, he has had to start at the beginning with "this is the 'on' switch", etc. Worse still, he cannot type at all, even with two fingers. Telegraph executives are looking forward to his first hard-hitting leader, but some are concerned that, at current speed, it will be anywhere between nine months and two years out of date. And all this from a man who poured such scorn on the concept of lifelong learning.

As for the Express, new owner Richard Desmond, the porn magnate who apparently sues anyone who calls him a porn magnate (we shall see, we shall see), took editor Rizla Rosie Boycott and senior staff to a Chinese restaurant on Wednesday night to celebrate his acquisition. When the waiter came over and asked for drinks orders, the first executive in line asked for a pint of lager. The porn magnate, a teetotaller, frowned ostentatiously and asked for a soft drink. From then on, as you've doubtless guessed, every executive asked for a soft drink as well. That's the kind of fearlessness that made the Express what it is today.

There is no word yet on Mr Desmond's views on cannabis, but Rizla notably eschewed rolling a joint over the coffee and fortune cookies. One can understand her playing it safe like this, all the more so since she has been assured by Mr Desmond that her job is absolutely safe. Oh dear. Still, if she can cling on, good luck to her. There's certainly no reason why she might resign on principle, what with founding Spare Rib magazine and working for a porn magnate being such obviously compatible things.

By way of tribute to this litigious porn magnate, meanwhile, next week's Guest Magazine will be his splendid Readers Wives. I was planning to suggest that Andrew Neil should be given Mr Desmond's Asian Babes to edit as consolation for the Barclay Brothers being beaten in the Express bidding, but a so-called rival has cracked that one already in the Mail. So I won't. Nor will I mention John Moorhead's suggestion that, what with him being a top porn magnate, Mr Desmond may be the man to put the beaver back in Beaverbrook.

And so, after that overdose of media shop talk, to the World Health Organisation's suggested panacea for that and everything else, the chicken soup. In step two of my mother's recipe, take your boiling chicken (preferably kosher) and cut it into quarters, clean them well and remove any blood. Now then, pull out all the schmaltz (remove all the fat, and keep for future rendering when making chopped liver). Take a large saucepan, cover the chicken with plenty of water and bring to boil. Once it is boiling fiercely, turn flame right down and skim at least three times while it simmers. Next step: the giblets.

In Perth, John Thaw- besotted Jayne Griffiths, who has 900 photos of the actor and has never missed a thing he's done, couldn't wait for the final Morse to be screened in western Australia. So last week she phoned her sister in Llandudno, and listened for two hours with the phone placed next to the telly. With analytical powers like that (she could have had a video couriered at about a quarter of the cost), Jayne is thought to have a promising career ahead of her as a detective herself with our own Metropolitan police.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Truman Show | Cube | Sleepers | Seul Contre Tous
fields.body:
The Truman Show
(Peter Weir, 1998)

For those who find Jim Carrey a little hard to take, this is an eye-opener: his Truman Burbank is played worryingly straight, but is maybe all the better for it. The eponymous Truman lives in Seahaven, not knowing that he is the subject of a round-the-clock TV show, with his friends and family mere actors playing roles. But little doubts start to form in Truman's mind, and he has to fight for his freedom. It's an inspired idea, and director Weir plays it out superbly - a sharp satire on the media-mad 90s that is emotionally stirring too.

Cube
(Vincenzo Natali, 1997)
10pm, Sky MovieMax

Six people wake up inside a blank-walled cube; doors lead off into other cubes where perils lie. This small-scale Canadian production, performed by a cast of unknowns, builds a captivating tension - not through action but through the interplay of its mystified and panicky characters. Enigmatic and unsettling.

Sleepers (Barry Levinson, 1996)
10pm, FilmFour

Based on Lorenzo Carcaterra's big-selling autobiography. In the 60s, four kids from the New York slums are sent to a reform school ruled by sadistic paedophile Kevin Bacon; 15 years on, two of the kids, now Scorsese-style wiseguys, kill their onetime abuser and are protected by another of the four, assistant DA, Brad Pitt. Levinson lays on the prison hellhole abuse with a trowel and then settles into an overheated courtroom battle, but Robert De Niro's priest and Dustin Hoffman's faded lawyer keep the show rolling.

Seul Contre Tous
(Gaspar Noé, 1998)
12.30am, FilmFour

Philippe Nahon gives a quite mesmerising performance as the furious, misanthropic anti-hero of this brutally original drama. His unemployed butcher dumps his pregnant mistress (Frankye Pain) and trails through Paris with a loaded gun, dreaming of releasing his autistic daughter from care. It's a frantic, shocking picture of an outsider on the furthest edge of society.

But little doubts start to form in Truman's mind, and he has to fight for his freedom. It's an inspired idea, and director Weir plays it out superbly - a sharp satire on the media-mad 90s that is emotionally stirring too. Cube (Vincenzo Natali, 1997) 10pm, Sky MovieMax Six people wake up inside a blank-walled cube; doors lead off into other cubes where perils lie. This small-scale Canadian production, performed by a cast of unknowns, builds a captivating tension - not through action but through the interplay of its mystified and panicky characters. Enigmatic and unsettling. Sleepers (Barry Levinson, 1996) 10pm, FilmFour Based on Lorenzo Carcaterra's big-selling autobiography. In the 60s, four kids from the New York slums are sent to a reform school ruled by sadistic paedophile Kevin Bacon; 15 years on, two of the kids, now Scorsese-style wiseguys, kill their onetime abuser and are protected by another of the four, assistant DA, Brad Pitt. Levinson lays on the prison hellhole abuse with a trowel and then settles into an overheated courtroom battle, but Robert De Niro's priest and Dustin Hoffman's faded lawyer keep the show rolling. Seul Contre Tous (Gaspar Noé, 1998) 12.30am, FilmFour Philippe Nahon gives a quite mesmerising performance as the furious, misanthropic anti-hero of this brutally original drama. His unemployed butcher dumps his pregnant mistress (Frankye Pain) and trails through Paris with a loaded gun, dreaming of releasing his autistic daughter from care. It's a frantic, shocking picture of an outsider on the furthest edge of society.

webTitle: What the Reebok ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Reebok ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Reebok ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
A man is out jogging. He runs round a corner, and we see that he's being pursued by a giant, hairy, inflatable belly. It bounces after him down the street, into a shopping precinct, across a housing estate and up a multi-storey car park. The frantic jogger runs onto the roof of the car park and pretends to jump over the edge in a final bid to shake it off. As he dangles precariously from a ledge, the pursuing belly - now on a motorbike - accelerates over the top and plunges into a nearby canal. We zoom in on the sole of the jogger's trainer, which reads: "Lose the beer belly".

The jargon:
While Adidas and Nike are earnestly pushing people to be the best and go for gold, Reebok is trying to differentiate itself here (and in another ad, aimed more at women) by communicating the real reasons why ordinary people do sport. The new people-friendly endline for the whole campaign is: "Reebok - whatever your goal".

Personality:
You're a bloke, very probably overweight, and aged 25-35-ish. You do some exercise but you're no super-shiny-and-fit gym freak. You might just play footie once a week or go for the odd jog.

Financial status:
Everyone wears sports kit, and Reebok stuff is priced roughly the same as other leading sports equipment brands - ie, not cheap but largely affordable.

Telling lifestyle detail:
You enjoy your beers and curries. In fact, that's why you exercise - because you know you have to if you want to remain relatively presentable physically.

Other relevant data:
The creative pair who devised the campaign did several vox pops and sent an all-staff memo round the agency, Lowe Lintas, to find out why people do sport. They got back replies like "so I can fit into my size eight jeans" and "to beat my brother". "I want to lose the beer gut" was the most common male response, and provided inspiration for the lead commercial.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Suddenly, out of the dark wet woods, comes a sound which holds a knife to the wild winter night. It can thrill and chill. It rattles the bones and quickens the blood, and even after the first shuddering second when it becomes recognised and therefore safe, it still has the power to unnerve.

It's the scream of the vixen. The pitch of the scream is like a woman's or child's, and if it were human it'd be a scream of terror, pain and desperation. But it isn't. This is the start of the foxes' mating season and the scream is all sex.

Through the dark woods, the vixen is shadowed by her mate, both in their winter fur, fiery as autumn oak or beech leaves. Added to what Ted Hughes called the "sudden sharp stink of fox" is the whiff of flowers the fox leaves from his "violet glands". The vixen is only fertile for a few days each year - and tonight's the night.

The short bursts of vixen scream traverse the hanging woods. There are other throaty warbling sounds and contact calls but it's the demonic scream which holds the power. Perhaps its savageness has added to our demonisation of the fox as a creature without pity. It's as if the scream belongs to an order of wild nature that we should properly fear and, through fearing, persecute.

The female fox retains her old name and spelling (with a "v"), and this singles her out, the screamer in the night, in a similar way in which women were used to represent the feminine principle in nature - night, sex and danger. And powerful as she is in her own world, in ours the vixen becomes the victim, her passion releasing an old unreconstructed fear.

fields.headline: Can you dig it?
fields.trailText: Horizon: Extreme Dinosaurs | Dispatches
fields.body:
Oh, for the patience of a palaeontologist. They pore over dry soil, scrutinising centimetre after centimetre for some clues to a lost life from long ago. If they find such traces, they sit, for years sometimes, little toothbrush in hand, caressing away millennia of dust and earth from ancient bones. Never do they lose their composure, ditch the toothbrush in favour of a pickaxe and seek to hack their fossilised discovery from its grave with a guttural scream of rage. You get the feeling that they would be very good at those jigsaws of plates of baked beans.

Horizon: Extreme Dinosaurs (BBC2) followed Dr Phil Currie, who hoped to establish that there were really big dinosaurs of all kinds in South America, some of whom hung around together. (All right, it was a bit more complex than that, but that's the gist of it). Currie was a driven man, who could identify any meat-eating dinosaur from a single tooth. His travels and travails, along with those of equally dedicated individuals, saw him jaunt from Patagonia to the badlands of Canada in search of proof of his thesis.

And proof he eventually found. After scrutinising and scouring, he discovered a bone bed, which he thought proved that meat-eating dinosaurs lived in packs, a theory previously written off. This, together with the discovery of a ginormous herbivore in Argentina, led Dr Currie to the conclusion that conventional wisdom about dinosaur behaviour - tyrannosaurus rex and long-necked herbivores never met - was wrong. Currie's discovery, the narrator assured us, meant that "a clash of the titans", a fight between the biggest animals ever to have lived, could have happened. You hear that, Margaret? Get out the bunting.

While Horizon might have been required viewing for those interested in the bare bones of dinosaurs, for me it was a case of "And your point, caller?" Yes, it's good that scientists know how much the argentinasaurus weighed. It's important to advance new theories of meat-eating dinosaurs' behaviour. And it's amazing to imagine what a fight between the two would have been like. But really, the faux drama, the bombardment of rhetorical questions and the never-ending close-ups of scary bones was too much. "Pure science, sheer drama" is how Horizon is being promoted, but in Extreme Dinosaurs the drama was distinctly lacklustre. In the end, who cares if the two dinosaurs lived together? Who knew they didn't? What Horizon did was advance a theory, dispel it and put forward a new one which basically accorded with what people thought anyway. That's not drama, it's flogging a dead horse. Or a dead argentinasaurus. Then again, maybe I have dinosaur fatigue.

Much more dramatic and vital was Dispatches (C4). An investigation into NHS waiting lists, How To Jump The Health Queue should be compulsory viewing for anyone who'll ever need health care in the UK. (So that will be everyone, then. Apart from Madonna). Following a variety of cases, from the cosmetic to the serious, the programme was packed with shocking statistics and outrageous case studies. From the evils of answering machines and "your call has been placed in a queue" through misplaced notes to the grinding bureaucracy of the NHS, which seems deliberately designed to baffle patients, Dispatches was a triumph in investigative consumer journalism. Looking at a patient with diseased teeth and gums that had required attention for years, another with a degenerative joint disorder which desperately needed treatment, the programme showed the short cuts, the navigation of negotiation and the ways to outwit a service, the prime directive of which - heal the sick - seems to have been forgotten. (If you've been waiting ages for an operation, getting C4 involved would seem the best way to get prompt action).

To its credit, Dispatches at no point chastised the quality of care when it was actually provided. Rather, it targeted the bureaucracy which is, at the very least, destroying patients' spirits. Nor did it avoid the notion of morality, and whether jumping the waiting list was wrong. It would be wrong, experts said, if the queueing system were fair. Which it isn't.

By no means a clarion call for privatisation, Dispatches was more a solicitation for smarter working and a rallying cry for empowering patients. Sometimes, you shouldn't need the patience of a palaeontologist.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: How can I tell my partner that I no longer want a second child?
fields.trailText: How can I tell my partner that I no longer want a second child?
fields.body:
My partner and I have an 18-month-old daughter. Before her arrival, we had planned to have more than one child. However, I have now had a change of heart and would be perfectly content with a family of three. My partner, on the other hand, is very keen to try for a second child despite being aware of the increasing risks entailed as an older mother: she is 37. As one of three brothers, I realise our daughter would probably benefit from having siblings. Against this, however, is my need for some personal space - something my partner shares - and I know we both have clear limits. With the two of us working, I am fearful of the extra demands rearing another child will bring - despite the help of a good childminder, family and friends. While I feel guilty at wanting to renege on an earlier understanding, I now feel pressured into going along with my partner's wishes. It is hard to think of a mutually satisfying outcome. How have other couples dealt with this problem?

You're a control freak

You don't mention your own age but more than your concerns about a second child, it sounds like you're rebelling against the status quo. You and your partner are not married and already have one child. The thought of a second child would seem to suggest a fully functional family with the assumption of traditional roles. Do you fear that next she'll want to get married?

Do yourself a favour - give in. In life, it is often that which frightens us the most that is most rewarding. Further attempts to control the chaos of family life will only result in disaster. It's time to broaden your attentions to those around you and put aside the selfish concerns of your youth. Accept that you've reached a mature place in your life and embrace it. You're a control freak clinging to some idea about controlling your own environment and everything in it - give it up. As it stands, your "personal" space already includes a partner and one child - the idea that you can retreat from that is an illusion. Give it up. Besides, if anything, another child will occupy the other and vice-versa, aiding in their development. Is it really your wish to deny your partner and make your one sprog an only child? This is a momentary fear from which you'll never recover if you don't put it aside now. If you're truly terrified of losing your personal space, try counselling.

What you really fear is intimacy.
Name and address withheld

Two's better than one

Both my partner and I agreed we did not want a second child after we saw the changes having a first child made to our lives. But after a year we changed our minds. We both have close relationships with our siblings and highly value the impact they have on our lives to this day. We wanted this for our daughter.

I am now six months pregnant with an 18-month-old to look after. Both me and my partner work full-time. On some days I regret our decision to try for a second baby - my partner expresses his doubts too. I think it is natural to have misgivings, especially when you know the kind of attention an infant demands. But in the long run we are doing it for our daughter, so she can share the joy of a sister or brother.

Besides, many people tell me that it is not twice the work the second time around, that things seem much easier, more familiar. Instead of playing so much with the children they will play with each other. Instead of agonising over decisions on education, health or discipline, you will have already formulated a parenting plan. Instead of pinning all your hopes and dreams on one child, you can spread your love and have a more balanced family life.

By the way 37 is hardly old for mothers these days - women have had babies in their 60s. While there is increasing risk over the age of 35 you didn't mention this was a worry with the first child and your partner must have been about 35 then.
Name and address witheld

Worth the gamble

I only recommend that you overcome your misgivings. After some rocky beginnings with our first and his maturing into a very verbal and nappyless two year old, I was very reluctant to start over with a second. But I had seen marriages break up over this issue and felt my second marriage was more important than my feelings about a second child. I could not understand how I could make room in my heart for a second child. I will tell you that I am so head over heels in love with my daughter, now four, that I am always surprised. Give yourself a shot at more love and subdivide a room for yourself.
Richard Kahn, New York City

Children are a treasure

There is a simple prescription for your condition. Say to yourself three times daily with thought and deliberation the words "People, not things".

Continue the treatment for several months. If after that time you have not acquired a significant and lasting change of attitude, increase the dosage to several times a day and repeat the words regularly in the presence of your wife.

Then, have more children. Enjoy them, play with them, share their activities, teach them, love them- give up your personal space. After all, in about 20 years, they will have left home and you will have more personal space than you know what to do with.

Support your wife, encourage her, appreciate her and help her through the difficult times. If necessary let her give up work. Give her your time, and let your family enrich you more than you could ever have dreamed possible.

Failure to follow this prescription will result in a miserable, middle-aged codger, whom no one wants to spend any time with - too much personal space.
W Kinninmonth, Luton

Next week

I have a problem with which many women and, I suspect, very few men, will empathise. I am a university lecturer and am normally quite assertive and able to hold my corner in disputes. However, occasionally when I get into an argument, I find myself on the verge of tears with associated wobbly voice, runny nose and watery eyes. It is difficult for me to specify just which sort of row brings the condition on but I think it usually involves either a personal criticism of me or a feeling that I am being treated unfairly. In a professional environment, the effect of this tearfulness leaves me not just embarrassed, but unable to pursue the argument. I can only imagine how the other party reacts - anything from embarrassment to a feeling of being manipulated or even contempt. Is there anybody who has suffered this problem and mastered it? Is there anything I can do to prevent it - therapy, role play, conditioning, shock treatment or whatever? If so, please help.

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Forget the hype about whether or not Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? was rigged (it wasn't). Did no one suspect Camilla's cousin of using more than her fair share of artistic licence when she claimed to have been left on tenterhooks for a full three minutes before discovering she was The Big Winner?

Judith Keppel, you'll recall, said she spent the longest three minutes of her life waiting to hear whether she'd correctly identified Eleanor of Aquitaine's husband to win a cool million on the quiz when it was filmed last Sunday night. But Behind The Screen can reveal that filming of the gameshow - done in advance, like all gameshows - only ever halts for about 90 seconds to coincide with what becomes an ad break on transmission night. So Keppel only had about a 90-second wait before counting her winnings. What little sympathy we had for her dissipates with that liberating knowledge.

On a different note, isn't it odd how telly people always look different "in the flesh"? Mark Lawson, for example, is much taller in reality than you might think from seeing him sitting behind a beech table on the BBC. So what are we to make of the fact that aged animator Joe Barbera (he of Hanna-Barbera toon fame) is working on the first new edition of Tom and Jerry for 30 years. Will the new cat-and-mouse game look more like the jelly-ish animation technique that made TV classic Roobarb and Custard so memorable back in the 70s? Just how steady is Joe's animating hand these days?

But never fear, Barbera is working with a guiding hand on the new Tom and Jerry - another animation veteran, Karl Toerge. But Barbera will put his voice to the seven-minute special, and we'll all be tuned to the Cartoon Network on New Year's day to hear whether or not he sounds like the octogenarian madcap illustrator we all expect him to be.

fields.bodyText: Forget the hype about whether or not Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? was rigged (it wasn't). Did no one suspect Camilla's cousin of using more than her fair share of artistic licence when she claimed to have been left on tenterhooks for a full three minutes before discovering she was The Big Winner? Judith Keppel, you'll recall, said she spent the longest three minutes of her life waiting to hear whether she'd correctly identified Eleanor of Aquitaine's husband to win a cool million on the quiz when it was filmed last Sunday night. But Behind The Screen can reveal that filming of the gameshow - done in advance, like all gameshows - only ever halts for about 90 seconds to coincide with what becomes an ad break on transmission night. So Keppel only had about a 90-second wait before counting her winnings. What little sympathy we had for her dissipates with that liberating knowledge. fields.headline: Over the top
fields.standfirst: Later With Jools Holland is the hippest music show on television. Or so we're supposed to think. But, says  Jacques Peretti, what we really need is a return to the days when they showed three-hour-long Van Halen stadium gigs
fields.trailText: Later With Jools Holland is the hippest music show on television. Or so we're supposed to think. But, says Jacques Peretti, what we really need is a return to the days when they showed three-hour-long Van Halen stadium gigs
fields.body:
Television was, I believe, invented in order to capture one specific moment: David Lee Roth crashing through a giant piece of tissue paper on a massive power-trike; leaping, Evil Knievel-style, over 16 bikini-clad laydeez, lying breast-implant to breast-implant across the exploding stage below.

Forget Later with Jools Holland or Westlife on Dale's Lottery Show; the zenith of music TV came in the 80s - Roth's stage arrival, a high watermark for Cock Rock. Never again will a TV audience experience that irresistible combination of power machinery, casual misogyny and baroque guitar solo, swathed in pink smoke on a set that made Robot Wars look like Jackanory.

On Saturday, Channel 4 repeat Top Ten: Stadium Rock, a rundown of the most preposterous rock acts of all time. Nostalgia for the Van Halen mid-80s is on a roll. BBC2 plan to follow up their I Love The Seventies series with, yes, I Love Belinda Carlisle, Shoulder Pads and Ecstasy. Enjoyable though these wallows are, the problem with a show like Top Ten is that it's just too fast-moving and entertaining to do real justice to the paint-drying dullness of the era.

In 1990, it was still possible to catch stadium dinosaurs playing live on TV in all their pompous, bad-perm glory, without being the butt of a retro-show joke. Mike Mansfield's Cue The Music gave full range to the talents of T'Pau and Chris De Burgh, a crime that wouldn't be allowed in today's competitive schedule.

Another drawback with these retro-romps is how skewed the story of the past becomes in the retelling. Will the BBC's I Love The Eighties tell us that Acid House was nowhere near as big as Bananarama or Eddie Shah? I doubt it. In a tightly edited, chuckle-at-the-hairdos show, one gets little idea of just how much the past, even the MTV-paced 80s, dragged: a Wham! video looks like an Eric Rohmer movie by today's morphed, stretched, flamed-up efforts.

Ironically, today's music TV, though classier than Van Halen on power-trikes, is far less enjoyable. Just a dull parade of cool bands in low-slung denim shouting "Whasssup?!" In part, this can be explained by the homogenisation of taste. Music TV is underpinned by a false notion of consensus - Q-value. This is epitomised by the impromptu jam on Later - Björk, Texas and The Wu Tang Clan together in smug harmony.

It's uncool to admit it, but no one's really interested in the Later jam. The real musical taste of Britain is pretty much stuck in the Van Halen era. Its barometer isn't Badly Drawn Boy on the Mercury Music prize but the cassette carousel at a petrol station: Best Of Saxon; Anita Dobson Sings The Chieftains; Lloyd Cole's remaindered third album. Petrol station cassettes reflect the surreal ecleticism of ordinary people's tastes, rarely - if ever - captured on TV. This is because music TV is really a Helly Hansen-clad conspiracy against middle-aged MOR Britain.

The highest aspiration of a challenging music show today is to reflect the listening habits of dot.com man in his Clerken-loft, flipping from Coldplay to Craig David on his mahogany MP3 player. Far less exciting than watching Dave Lee Roth split his trousers. In many ways, today's equivalent of the off-limits Van Halen performance is dance music. Television is keen to digest club music and regurgitate it in a familiar TV magazine form because clubs are still, in theory, the gateway to a huge potential audience.

They can't, of course. Because clubbing is, in essence, very similar to 70s prog-rock - the open-ended experience can't be repackaged in a trite televisual way. TV and pop music are increasingly peripheral to the leisure interests of 16-year-olds, who are less likely to want to become DJs than members of a morose prog-band like Godspeed You Black Emperor! playing symphonic rock for 10-hour stretches in their bedrooms. Mainstream clubbing, the sound of stadium trance - still the teenager's weekend of choice - rarely, if ever, gets an accurate airing on TV (save in the apocalyptic Paul Oakenfold theme music to Big Brother - a clever piece of brand association with a huge youth phenomenon).

In the year 2000, funny clips of a cod-pieced Dave Lee Roth in dodgy striped legwarmers may appear to have little in common with a major shift in musical taste, but you'd be surprised. Off the back of the re-release of Spinal Tap (newly relevant to a generation schooled on self-indulgent rock clichés from the 90s), the writers have produced a spoof of online music service Napster... called Tapster. Increasingly, the teen audience are looking for longplay culture. A laid-back, less naff, less MTV-ish sensibility, delivered, ironically, at super-fast speed on the net.

TV has little hope of reflecting this shift with music shows, still hung up on teen formats little different from Ready Steady Go... or late night formats little different from The Old Grey Whistle Test. Strange as it may seem, TV's holy grail - the 16-to-34-year-old audience - is starting to look as ill-served in its tastes as an ageing metaller with a penchant for Van Halen who wants to see the whole gig. Don't worry, soon you can, but it won't be on telly. And it won't be free.

 Top Ten: Stadium Rock, Saturday, 9.05pm, C4. Later with Jools Holland, Saturday, 12.05am, BBC2

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Patterns Of Faith | Jazz Legends
fields.body:
In 1197 the owner of a pleasant stretch of Kent countryside swapped it for a Thames shoreline so unappealing that the locals dubbed it "loamhithe" or muddy landing. But it was a mere boat ride from the Royal Court at Westminster, an increasing necessity for any Archbishop of Canterbury. Lambeth Palace slowly emerged from the slime and now attracts more than 50,000 visitors a year. Mike Ford explores its treasures in Patterns Of Faith

(1.45pm, World Service and Wednesday, 4.30am, Radio 4).

A graduate of the Dizzy Gillespie and Miles Davis bands is the focus of Julian Joseph's Jazz Legends (4.0pm, Radio 3). John Coltrane (pictured) played alto saxophone during his two-year stint with an American navy band but switched to tenor after teaming up with Gillespie in 1949. The programme concentrates on his work during the subsequent 10 years, when he startlingly burst away from the accepted cool bop of Lester Young and Stan Getz.

fields.headline: The Guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | Just out |  On the menu | Food on the net
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Italian Institute, 39 Belgrave Square, London SW1. Tel: 020-7235 5208.

Must have the stateliest address of any Cheapskate yet. Track on in through the porticoed door, and make your way downstairs to the small cafe, cheerful and comfortable with a studentish air. The food is straightforward, filling and cheap. The £5 set lunch is soup, pasta, pud, all splendidly well made on the spot. Or you can scoff any one of the courses for rather less. There are toothsome pannini (or sandwiches to me), decent salads, and croissants and just about the best coffee in London. Beguilingly cheerful service. No licence, so no temptation. Open Mon-Sat, 9.30am to various closing times.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Jenny Lo's Tea House, 14 Eccleston Street, London SW1. Tel: 020-7259 0399.

Oodles of noodles, and a bit more besides. Chinese, for a change, and bright and breezy with it. Now that noodles seem to be the new universal food all sorts of differing noodle traditions are popping out of the woodwork. Here there are wok noodles and soup noodles. The helpings are reasonable, the flavours sharp and clean, the service nice and helpful and the prices cheap. There are non-noodle dishes: classy dumplings and good rolls and a range where rice takes the place of noodles. Chinese medicine guru, Dr Xu, has come up with some bespoke teas in addition to the normal ones. No booking.

Just out

Betty's Christmas Cake Wreath

Form:
Not so much a wreath, more a large, dark-brown coronet neatly adorned with nuts and glace cherries.

Diameter:
19cm.

Weight:
1.05kg.

Flavour:
Deep and dark. Sumptuous with raisins, currants and nuts.

Verdict:
A magnificent cake for Christmas or any other time of year. The ratio of fruit to cake is generous, the richness beautifully judged. Perfect balance between the dry and squidgy elements, with sweetness held in check by copious soakings in sherry. Hand me another slice.

Price: £16.95 from Betty's cafe tea rooms, (Harrogate, York, Northallerton, Ilkley) or mail order (01423 814008) or email www.bettysbypost.com Postage and packing £6. Order before December 8.

On the menu


Teppanyaki

Animal, vegetable or mineral?
None of the above. It's a Japanese cooking technique.

And what does it involve?
Grilling on an iron plate, or originally, it seems, on a ploughshare.

You mean the kind of frying done on a hotplate when cooking burgers in a motorway service station or kebab house?
Actually, there's a bit more to it than that.

Such as?
A dazzling display of virtuoso knife work as the chef cuts up the beef, fish or vegetables to go on the teppan hot plate.

Food on the net

www.brownsauce.net

Essentially, an homage to the bacon buttie. There are handy star-ratings to lead you through the minefields of bread, bacon and sauce choices, and a vote on whether the McBacon Roll really cuts the mustard. Not to mention the whole HP/Heinz debate. But there are also guides to greasy spoons, chip butties and the top 10 UK crisps (salt and vinegar McCoys coming in at number one).

Pros:
Worried about clogged arteries? Never fear, there's a healthy section about lycopene too.

Cons:
Although its greasy spoon reviews have stretched as far as Spain, Singapore and the US, there is nothing north of the Watford gap yet. Sissies.

webTitle: Rampant bush clearance may cost Australia the earth

fields.headline: Rampant bush clearance may cost Australia the earth
fields.trailText: Inez Rosser looks out from her veranda. "There's our rainforest, surrounded by potato paddocks," she says. The small dark patch of trees on the hillside, besieged by the brown scars of recently cleared land.
fields.body:
Inez Rosser looks out from her veranda. "There's our rainforest, surrounded by potato paddocks," she says. The small dark patch of trees on the hillside, besieged by the brown scars of recently cleared land.

She and her husband David bought the 790-hectare (320-acre) plot of rainforest near Killarney, south Queensland, in 1968. With the surrounding forest now slashed away, they fear for the future of the rare Albert's lyrebird confined within their forest. With no corridors of land left connecting with larger forests it will be hard to sustain the colony.

Australia is clearing its native forests at a faster rate than any other developed country in the world, hot on the heels of Brazil, Indonesia, the Congo and Bolivia. Landowners bulldozed some 2,000 square miles last year - three times the size of London - for grazing, wheat plains and urban development.

Australia also has the highest rate of mammal extinction, and many of its unique marsupial species are threatened with extinction. Charlie Sherwin of the Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) fears the country will lose 50% of its bird species in the next century. "The biggest problem is land clearing," he says.

According to the Wilderness Society's Barry Traill: "You can go to these patches of woodland and still have the birds in them, but the populations are so small they are biologically dead. They'll only last another one or two decades."

Mammals and birds at most risk include the northern hairy-nosed wombat, the rat kangaroo, the golden blackbird, the regent honeyeater and the grey-crowned babbler.

The rotting and burning of vegetation on cleared land accounts for 13% of Australia's greenhouse pollution but land clearing is also behind the growth of the country's devastating salinity problem, which threatens the livelihood of the very farmers clearing the land.

Ripping out deep-rooted forest vegetation and planting shallow-rooted crops is causing groundwater to rise to the surface. The salt it brings poisons farmland, pollutes streams and damages roads and buildings. The National Dryland Salinity Programme predicts that by 2050 the area ruined by salt could treble to 22,000 square miles - an area almost as large as Tasmania.

Queensland is the clearing capital of Australia. The world's largest landholder, Stanbroke Pastoral Company, owns 50,000 square miles in Australia and 500,000 cattle. It holds permits to clear 400 square miles of bush in Queensland alone.

The state is also "frontier" country, colonised by small farmers battling against the bush. "There is a very strong culture of independent rights, of individuals being able to do what they want with their own land," says Felicity Wishart of the Queensland Conservation Council.

Mr Traill said: "It's easy to pigeonhole the archetypal Queensland farmer as a redneck, concerned with land rights, God, and guns. They are a significant minority, but there are also some of the most sophisticated land-managers I've ever seen, trying to keep the trees and birds, as well as the cows. Unfortunately, they tend to live where the clearing has finished."

Jo Wearing is one such farmer. She and her husband raise cattle in central Queensland's Brigalow Belt. While large tracts of rainforest in its tropical north are in pristine condition, protected by World Heritage listing, only 2.2% of the Brigalow Belt, a 220-mile swath of temperate woodlands, is protected.

"The land is tired. It has been over-used with little understanding of the impact of our use on it," says Ms Wearing. She thinks it can recover but not to fertility levels achieved after clearing.

She has allowed the regrowth of forest on her land and uses a system of cell grazing, rotating cattle around more than 80 small paddocks to prevent exhausting the land.

Ms Wearing agrees with farmers' demands for "compensation" not to clear land. But no such scheme exists. Indeed, until recently, crown land was leased to farmers on condition that they cleared a certain amount each year.

The Queensland Conservation Council accepts that grants are needed to encourage sustainable land management. Leaving uncleared corridors of deep-rooted woodland can prevent salinity. In the longer term, it says funds should encourage sustainable land use, such as the production of sandalwood, nuts or wild flowers and the farming of kangaroos and ostriches, which have a lower impact on the environment than cattle.

But the states and the federal government clash over who should fund such "compensation". Constitutionally, land management is a state issue, but its consequences - damaging biodiversity, causing salinity and greenhouse gases - are federal.

The ACF wants tough new laws brought in. "Clearing has never stopped anywhere in the world without sternly enforced regulations," says the Mr Sherwin.

Despite opposition, Queensland introduced legislation to control land clearing. But the state's Labor government refused to ratify the new law for nine months. The attempt to force funding from the rightwing federal government triggered "panic clearing", as farmers raced to rip up trees before the curbs became law.

The new law, preventing the clearing of endangered ecosystems on freehold land, could protect 3.5% of Queensland's vegetation, says the ACF.

Inez Rosser is pessimistic about her rainforest. But Ms Wearing hopes for a revolution in land management. "We're using resources unsustainably and not earning enough from them to pay for the cost of the degradation we are causing," she says. "But I do believe it is being increasingly recognised. One has to be optimistic. The alternative is too awful to imagine."

But the states and the federal government clash over who should fund such "compensation". Constitutionally, land management is a state issue, but its consequences - damaging biodiversity, causing salinity and greenhouse gases - are federal. The ACF wants tough new laws brought in. "Clearing has never stopped anywhere in the world without sternly enforced regulations," says the Mr Sherwin. Despite opposition, Queensland introduced legislation to control land clearing. But the state's Labor government refused to ratify the new law for nine months. The attempt to force funding from the rightwing federal government triggered "panic clearing", as farmers raced to rip up trees before the curbs became law. The new law, preventing the clearing of endangered ecosystems on freehold land, could protect 3.5% of Queensland's vegetation, says the ACF. Inez Rosser is pessimistic about her rainforest. But Ms Wearing hopes for a revolution in land management. "We're using resources unsustainably and not earning enough from them to pay for the cost of the degradation we are causing," she says. "But I do believe it is being increasingly recognised. One has to be optimistic. The alternative is too awful to imagine." www.acfonline.org.au/ index.htm Australian Conservation Foundation www.qccqld.org.au Queensland Conservation Council

fields.headline: 'Phantom' sheep pay-out cost £87m
fields.trailText: The Conservative chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, David Davis, today accuses the ministry of agriculture under the former Tory minister, Douglas Hogg, of "gambling with taxpayers' cash" in paying out £87m in subsidies to sheep farmers which could not be reclaimed from the European commission.
fields.body:
The Conservative chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, David Davis, today accuses the ministry of agriculture under the former Tory minister, Douglas Hogg, of "gambling with taxpayers' cash" in paying out £87m in subsidies to sheep farmers which could not be reclaimed from the European commission.

The sheep farmers get £140m a year subsidy from the EU. The money is paid by the ministry and claimed back from the EU.

The report by the public accounts committee said £87m - the highest of any EU member country - was disallowed by the commssion up to 1996 because Britain could not provide the evidence that the "phantom" sheep existed.

But the money had already been paid out by Whitehall and cannot be claimed back. Figures are not available for later years as the EU is still checking Britain's claims. The main reason for the uncertainty of Britain's sheep population is that the rest of Europe has a policy of tattooing or putting an earring in every lamb at birth.

Britain mainly relies on paint that rubs off in bad weather. There have only been eight fraud prosecutions against farmers in six years.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, is planning compulsory tagging for all sheep from the end of this year to end the system, and because it will help trace them should there be a fresh BSE scare.

Mr Davis said the revelation was "an idictment" of the ministry of agriculture. "Their inability to clarify the European commission's expectations and their failure to take prompt action when problems became evident were, in effect, a gamble with taxpayers' money. It did not pay off."

fields.headline: Benn's wife Caroline dies at 74
fields.trailText: Caroline Benn, the wife of the veteran Labour politician, Tony Benn, has died in hospital after a long illness, her family announced yesterday. She was 74.
fields.body:
Caroline Benn, the wife of the veteran Labour politician, Tony Benn, has died in hospital after a long illness, her family announced yesterday. She was 74.

Mrs Benn, who had been married for 51 years, died on Tuesday night after a five day family vigil at Charing Cross hospital in west London. The vigil was broken only by the need to dispatch two of the Benn sons to receive public awards on their father's behalf and to explain the reason for his absence. On Tuesday Stephen Benn told a dinner of the Political Studies Association that his mother was close to death. Next day his brother, Hilary, himself an MP, brought the same message to the Spectator/Highland Park awards where Tony Benn was again being honoured with Sir Edward Heath for their 50 years in the Commons.

Hilary Benn delivered a double message from his father, one his belief in the power of democratic politics, the other the avowal that his marriage had produced "the most important personal and political relationship in his life". Throughout his turbulent political journey from blue-eyed boy of the Gaitskellite establishment to the anti-establishment left, friends and enemies endorsed that judgment of the Benns' intense and happy domestic life. Mr Benn's own diaries confirmed it.

An American who met the future Lord Stansgate - as Mr Benn briefly became in 1960 - after coming to London as a student in 1948, Caroline DeCamp immersed herself in the world of progressive British politics. She also raised four children while keeping out of the public limelight in which - had she so chosen - her wit and vivacity might have thrived.

A lecturer and author of a well-received biography of Keir Hardie - and other books - as well as president of the Socialist Education Association, Mrs Benn had been suffering from cancer before her husband announced he would stand down as an MP at the coming election. A private family funeral is to be held and a "memorial meeting" will be held in the new year.

webTitle: Four-day weekend to mark Queen's golden jubilee

fields.headline: Four-day weekend to mark Queen's golden jubilee
fields.standfirst:
Palace keen to keep down cost of celebrations
Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: There is to be an extra day's bank holiday in June 2002 to mark the Queen's golden jubilee, Tony Blair announced yesterday.
fields.body:
There is to be an extra day's bank holiday in June 2002 to mark the Queen's golden jubilee, Tony Blair announced yesterday.

As the centre point of several weeks of official and unofficial celebrations, Tuesday June 4 will be a bank holiday, replacing the normal late spring bank holiday, which should have fallen the previous week on May 27. Monday June 3 will also become a bank holiday, creating an extended four day weekend. On the Tuesday the Queen will attend what Downing Street described as a national service of thanksgiving at St Paul's Cathedral.

The celebrations will however fall neither on the actual 50th anniversary of the Queen's accession - which will occur on February 6 that year - nor on the anniversary of her coronation which was 49 years previously on June 3 1953.

Schools will receive an additional day's holiday, recommended to be tacked on to the start of the following month's summer break, because local education authorities are expected to arrange half-terms to coincide with the jubilee bank holidays.

No GCSE and A Level examinations will be scheduled for the jubilee week.

David Blunkett, education secretary, said: "This is more than a gesture of goodwill to our hard-working teachers. It is a positive way of recognising the efforts they make and helping them and their pupils share and benefit from this special occasion like the rest of the country."

The Queen will become the fourth British monarch to celebrate half a century on the throne, following the medieval Henry III, George III, who by his jubilee in 1810 was hopelessly mad and confined to Windsor, and Victoria, whose jubilee in 1887 was the last opportunity for golden anniversary celebrations - though she then went on to even more lavish ceremonials 10 years later for her diamond jubilee.

There are plans for the Queen, who by then will be 76, to undertake several trips around the United Kingdom that summer, including at tending the opening and closing ceremonies for the Commonwealth Games in Manchester and also a tour of Commonwealth countries, probably including Canada, in the autumn.

The prime minister, giving the details in a Commons written answer, spoke of the jubilee as a joyous occasion and a very special milestone. "It will be a time both for looking back at the central part which the Queen has played in the affairs of this country and the Commonwealth... and for looking forward to the continuation of Her Majesty's unique contribution for many years to come."

The statement added that it was the Queen's "express wish that there should be no undue expenditure from public funds on the programme of celebrations".

fields.headline: Teamtalk charges ahead
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: British sports news supplier Teamtalk.com yesterday revealed it hoped to start charging customers for the use of its website within two years.
fields.body:
British sports news supplier Teamtalk.com yesterday revealed it hoped to start charging customers for the use of its website within two years.

The company, which posted a pre-tax loss of £1.8m for the six months to end-September, said that once micropayment technology enabling simple charging was operating all quality content providers would be following suit.

Chairman and chief execu tive Bill Wilson said: "There can be nothing for nothing. If people want quality content they will have to pay for it eventually. I see this happening in the next two years."

He said he expected the company to be profitable by 2003 or 2004. Teamtalk, which has about 60 in-house reporters and 225 freelancers around the globe, covers cricket, formula one, golf, greyhound- and horse racing, both rugby codes, football and tennis.

Mr Wilson said 30% of Teamtalk's £5.1m half-year revenue came from the business-to-business supply of specialist maritime information, with a further 30% from fixed line, premium rate, telephone-based news. Around 20% came from content sales and the rest from other sources.

He said the company had significant cash reserves from its flotation in April this year and was looking to acquire more content businesses.

Yesterday, Teamtalk's share price closed down 3.5p to 34p.

webTitle: Tapeworm threat to beef, claim EU vets

fields.headline: Tapeworm threat to beef, claim EU vets
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: EU vets are recommending a big increase in indoor factory farming of beef cattle, currently almost unknown in Britain, to protect consumers from another health threat: parasites that can be passed to humans through raw or undercooked meat.
fields.body:
EU vets are recommending a big increase in indoor factory farming of beef cattle, currently almost unknown in Britain, to protect consumers from another health threat: parasites that can be passed to humans through raw or undercooked meat.

They say animals might need to be kept indoors throughout their lives to prevent them picking up tapeworms.

The vets want new checks on the extent of the problem, but they believe tapeworms are significantly under-reported by embarrassed humans and that infected meat is slipping through in slaughterhouses.

The vets' call for a fundamental reappraisal of farming methods throughout the European Union was immediately rejected by animal welfare campaigners, who said the public liked seeing cattle roaming freely in the countryside. Farmers suggested the vets were "taking a sledgehammer to crack a nut".

But the recommendation, from one of the European commission's veterinary committees, is likely to sharpen political rows over whether Brussels intends to impose uniform "farm to fork" policies on member states and cause a backlash through excessive hygiene enforcement.

Opponents of the EU will see the latest report as evidence that the traditional British way of life is under threat from the continent. Earlier this summer vets warned that organisers of events from pop festivals to car boot sales should be more careful about using livestock pastures because of the risk of contamination by E. coli.

The vets want to break the life cycles of tapeworms which live in the human intestine, spread eggs through human excrement and are picked up by cattle from streams containing effluent from sewage farms, or sludge spread on fields or even people using the countryside as an outside lavatory.

Many people do not know they are harbouring tapeworms, although they can suffer diarrhoea and abdominal discomfort. Usually cattle show no external symptoms.

Signs of the parasites' presence are meant to be identified in abattoirs so that the affected meat can be frozen to kill the worm before it is allowed in food.

In Britain, between 50 and 60 people a year are identified as having the tapeworms concerned, sometimes picked up abroad.

The vets suggest that livestock could gain certificates as being free from the parasites if certain measures were enforced, including cattle living completely indoor lives and being given specially treated feed. A public education programme was also needed for doctors, farmers, vets and consumers.

"Other aspects such as implications for animal welfare should be kept in mind but are not within the mandate of this report."

Indoor cattle farming is more common in France and Spain. Public opposition to raising calves here in crates for the veal market abroad had cut the practice significantly, even before the ban on live cattle exports during the BSE crisis.

Robert Smith, of the public health laboratory service, said he thought the change in farming methods "would realistically be rather extreme. In this country it would be unnecessary".

Peter Rudman, of the National Farmers' Union, said: "This sounds a bit draconian, but if evidence is produced that there is more of a problem than we think there is, we would have to revise our judgment."

Justin Wilkes of the group Compassion in World Farming said: "Any factory farming for cattle would be strongly opposed by the public."
