fields.headline: Rail restrictions 'increase risk'
fields.standfirst:
Speed limits and disruption make driver error more likely, Railtrack says
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Britain's rail passengers may have been put at increased risk by the safety measures which were introduced to protect them in the aftermath of the Hatfield crash, it emerged today.
fields.body:
Britain's rail passengers may have been put at increased risk by the safety measures which were introduced to protect them in the aftermath of the Hatfield crash, it emerged today.

Fears that the widespread speed restrictions and timetable changes on the rail network increased the risk of drivers inadvertently going through red lights were set out in a confidential Railtrack document, the Financial Times reported.

Railtrack has already applied to lift 50 of the speed restrictions on the network in response to concerns that the severe disruption of routines could lead to drivers making dangerous mistakes, the paper claimed.

Drivers are thought to be abiding by a list of special directions on speed changes which runs to 16 pages and has prompted concerns that it could lead to confusion and error.

Signals passed at red (Spads) are 10 times more likely to lead to a fatal accident than trains encountering broken rails, the problem which the speed restrictions were designed to avoid.

The health and safety executive is understood to be waiting for a new internal risk assessment to be carried out by Railtrack before the application for speed restrictions to be lifted is considered.

The network operator was also believed to have expressed concern about the danger of overcrowding on platforms and trains due to restricted services, the FT said.

The strategic rail authority chairman, Sir Alastair Morton, has expressed similar fears about the dangers of the new safety measures to government ministers, according to a report in the Economist.

Mr Morton was advised by SRA safety experts that not only were travellers abandoning the rails for the roads, where they were statistically more likely to be killed in accidents, but dis ruption to train drivers' routines was making them more likely to make mistakes, the weekly said.

A spokeswoman for the authority said last night: "The strategic rail authority, the government and the rail industry are doing everything they can to make sure that safety is paramount on the network."

She added she was unaware of Sir Alastair making any such comments, and dismissed the report as "idle speculation". But the Economist quoted safety experts as estimating that the growth in road traffic resulting from frustrated passengers giving up on the trains was likely to cause five extra deaths and 75 serious injuries.

Meanwhile, as passengers continued to desert the rail network in record numbers, rail companies began to fearfully count the cost - already believed to have reached £200m.

Some companies were be lieved to have already approached John Prescott to ask for help amid fears that the shortfall could force them out of business completely.

A spokesman for the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions denied reports that the deputy prime minister was preparing to rescue the worst-hit companies with taxpayers' money.

It also emerged that trains on a branch line in West Yorkshire ground to a halt when passengers left a commuter service after a series of delays, saying it was quicker to walk home along the track. But the mutinous commuters on the Northern Spirit 17.04 service from Leeds to Skipton caused further delays to other services.

The train stopped outside Keighley station on Wednesday night after other services broke down up the line. When the driver announced that due to signal failure the train would return to Leeds, 20 miles back, the passengers left the train and set out on foot.

webTitle: Labour relief at easy election victory

fields.headline: Labour relief at easy election victory
fields.standfirst: Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: The government last night breathed a sigh of relief when Labour's candidate held off a determined Conservative challenge to win the West Bromwich West byelection created by the retirement of Betty Boothroyd as Speaker of the Commons.
fields.body:
The government last night breathed a sigh of relief when Labour's candidate held off a determined Conservative challenge to win the West Bromwich West byelection created by the retirement of Betty Boothroyd as Speaker of the Commons.

In a depressingly low turnout of 27.6% on a wet day in the West Midlands, Adrian Bailey, a former librarian and deputy leader of local Sandwell council, held on to the seat with a majority of 3,232 over a fellow councillor, Tory Karen Bissell.

Labour had 9,640 votes, more than half the total cast, the Tory candidate 6,408, the Lib Dems took 1,791, the British National Party just 794, despite a strong local council showing in May. The UK Independence party, now in internal disarray, won 246.

With two other byelections results also due early today, Labour had been expected to hold West Bromwich West, Preston and Anniesland in Glasgow where both of the late Donald Dewar's seats, as a Westminster MP and Scottish MSP, were at stake.

But the row over fuel prices and this week's battle over the EU rapid reaction force made ministers nervous that heartland disaffection might produce a surprise. The persistent presence of the British National party, added to those jitters.

Full result: Adrian Bailey (Lab) 9,640 (51.06%); Karen Bissell (C) 6,408 (33.94%); Sadie Smith (LD) 1,791 (9.49%); Nicholas Griffin (BNP) 794 (4.21%); Jonathan Oakton (UK Ind) 246 (1.30%). Battle fatigue: Emails dry up as party fears losing more than it can gain

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: During the long presidential campaign, Al Gore's energetic and innovative media team fired off around a dozen emails a day to journalists covering the election.
fields.body:
During the long presidential campaign, Al Gore's energetic and innovative media team fired off around a dozen emails a day to journalists covering the election.

They rubbished speeches made by his Republican rival George W Bush, they quoted every statement Mr Gore made. They provided figures that proved the emptiness of Mr Bush's claims and touted Gore's record on everything from the environment to prescription fees.

Now the guns are silent. And while the main reason is obviously that the campaign is over, there is a feeling that Gore's backers are gradually losing the stomach for the fight.

Maureen Dowd, who with Gail Collins has been providing some of the wittiest commentaries in the New York Times on the Florida events, summed up Mr Gore's problem in a column this week: "Al Gore wants the presidency more than the Democrats do. And the Republicans want the presidency more than W does.

"Mr Gore is more rabid than his campaign team and party. Mr Bush's campaign team and party are more rabid than him. Each side will do what it takes. But the Bushes prefer to let the help get their hands dirty."

The "help" that is working for Mr Gore has faced an uphill task since the moment he made his phone call to Mr Bush to withdraw his concession of defeat on election night two and a half weeks ago. For every twist and turn that has gone Mr Gore's way, there seem to be two that have been to the Bush camp's advantage.

The Democrats are worried that the continuing fight shows Mr Gore as a bad loser. They know they could be punished in the Congressional elections in two years time if Mr Gore wins the vote but loses the argument. They know, too, that if Mr Bush wins, the Democrats chances of taking seats in those elections will be substantially increased as an electorate seeks to right the imbalance. They fear the worst possible scenario: that Mr Gore loses both the presidency and the argument.

The people who bankrolled Mr Gore's campaign are still writing cheques to fund the costly business of hiring the country's most expensive lawyers to mount the legal challenges in Florida. But there is a sense that the time is coming when they will wonder if the money is being poured down a Palm Beach drain.

When the Florida supreme court ruled that recounts taking place would stand, Mr Gore decided to let it be known that he was quietly planning his own administration. "I believe it's now appropriate for both of us to focus on the transition," he said on Tuesday night.

But since then, potential victory seems to be slipping away, and with it the support. While Mr Gore's most loyal aides say they still find it hard to believe that a convicted drunk driver who seems more at home playing with his dog Spot than tackling international issues could possibly become president, there is a weariness about the whole process and a feeling that this weekend the long battle may be over.

Rightwing commentators have joined the process of moulding public opinion against Mr Gore. "We know the whole thing has been rigged and we've known from the get-go," said rightwing talk show host Rush Limbaugh in his widely syndicated show this week. While the claim may be a piece of dishonest partisan propagandising, it is one that is being taken up across the country.

The Democrats who are taking the temperature in the states may still be publicly backing Mr Gore's challenges but they will be noting shifts in public sentiment against their man. The financial markets have been giving their own verdicts on Mr Gore's chances. When it emerged that he would not get the Miami-Dade recounts, shares in tobacco, pharmaceuticals and Microsoft - industries or organisations that all believe they would benefit from a Bush victory - suddenly rose.

Many Democrats feel Mr Gore misplayed the challenge made by Green party candidate Ralph Nader and there are still recriminations under way over his role. This week, Mr Nader came up with his own solution. He told the Denver Post that the best way to decide the election would be to spin a coin. "There is really no other way to end this," he said. "At this point, no one will ever know who really won Florida."

Mr Nader's suggestion is that the coin-toss be televised live and the commercial air time used to finance the next presidential campaigns so that parties did not need other contributions.

Mr Gore might well settle for such a solution right now. But over the next few days he will have to decide whether he wants to risk the political equivalent of a Mafia garroting or bow out with dignity and live to fight another day.

webTitle: Gaza running out of money for food

fields.headline: Gaza running out of money for food
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Israel and the Middle East

UN agencies appeal for aid to alleviate Israeli blockade
fields.trailText: Half the Palestinian population in the West Bank and Gaza - 1.5m people - could go hungry because of Israel's military and economic blockade, UN agencies are warning.
fields.body:
Half the Palestinian population in the West Bank and Gaza - 1.5m people - could go hungry because of Israel's military and economic blockade, UN agencies are warning.

The ring of steel around Gaza and the West Bank has been tightened further this week to exclude fuel and all commodities except food and medicines.

The UN's Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA) and the World Food Programme have issued urgent appeals for help.

"My impression is that donors are not responding," said an official of one international agency. "In the past, they linked assistance to the peace process. Now there is no peace process, so they tend not to respond."

During the last eight weeks of bloody confrontation, Israel's blockade on the West Bank and Gaza has been the unseen second front of a conflict which has claimed about 250 lives, pummelled the Palestinian economy and brought 3m people - the overall population of the two territories - to the point of ruin.

In Gaza, where hundreds of thousands of refugees are penned into miserable concrete warrens, the population is especially vulnerable. A third of the labour force has been turned out of jobs in Israel, and tens of thousands of others have lostlocal work in the building industry because of a blockade on concrete.

By next month about 892,000 people in Gaza, including 635,000 refugees, will have exhausted their savings and will need food aid, UNRWA and the WFP predict. Some 554,000 of their Palestinian cousins in the West Bank, who include some 450,000 refugees, are in simi lar trouble. By conservative estimates, that means 1.45m of the 3m people in Gaza and the West Bank will need food aid.

To feed them, and to rebuild homes and infrastructure, UNRWA is asking donors for $39m (£27.5m) for the next three months. The WFP wants $4m (£2.8m) to cover next month's food aid.

"They do not have any stocks. It is really hand to mouth, and every day finds the situation more tense in the camps," said Karen Koning AbuZayd, the deputy commissioner for UNRWA in Gaza.

Outside the blue gates of the UNWRA field office in Jabaliya refugee camp, desperate women queue from early morning. The officials inside have exhausted their quotas, and have nothing to give them.

"People cannot pay for electricity, water, tuition for their children, school supplies. Some cannot buy meat," said one field officer.

Until Israel closed the borders, sealing Gaza behind an electrified fence, members of the el-Eilah family could count themselves among the more prosperous of Jabaliya's inhabitants. Rajab Mohammed Eilah would rise with his two sons every morning at 4am, wait for hours at the Erez crossing for soldiers to check his coveted pink permit to enter Israel, and then go to work as a painter just up the coast in Ashqelon. On a good day, he could count on earning 150 shekels (about £26).

Now he is owed a fortnight's wages by his Israeli boss, and is asking round local shops for credit. "I went to five grocers and asked for credit. I just hope that when the closure ends I can go to work and repay them," he said. "But God only knows."

His debts for the last month add up to nearly £440.

A few blocks away, Latifa Abdullah Muqayied's home is bare, except for a photo of her son, Lou'ai, 20, which hangs above a rough sketch of Jerusalem's al-Aqsa mosque. His head was blown off by machine-gun fire from an Israeli helicopter on October 6, robbing the 10-strong family of its one potential bread-winner.

Mrs Muqayied has firewood stacked on her asbestos roof for when her cooking gas runs out. In the last few days, gas has disappeared from the shops as the blockade bites. Mrs Muqayied says shops have run out of basics such as sugar, oil and flour.

Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, says these shortages are deliberate: economic leverage, together with the army's firepower, is meant to punish the Palestinians for firing on troops and Jewish settlements in Gaza and the West Bank.

Israeli forces have also destroyed at least 625 acres of palm, olive and citrus groves in Gaza, according to Raji Sourani, director of the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights.

The destruction - "shaving" in Israeli military parlance - is meant to clear covering foliage so that Palestinian gunmen cannot ambush army and settler convoys.

But the Israeli tractors often tear up fields far from the road. On Monday this week, hours after a mortar bomb ripped through a settler school bus, killing two teachers and maiming several children, three caterpillar tractors razed palm trees as far as 500 metres back from the site of the attack. Within 20 minutes, seven date palms, said by locals to be more than 100 years old, crashed to the ground.

In a nearby field, a cluster of local farmers gasped with every toppling tree. "They are focusing on palm trees and olives because they want to punish the people. They just want to destroy our economy," said Khalid Shaheen.

Earlier this month, Israeli army tractors ripped out 150 palms and 100 olive trees. Troops also sealed off the only road through Gaza, slicing the territory in half, and blocking people living in the south of the strip from travelling to their main city.

For Israel, all these measures are collective punishment for Palestinian protests, and the militias that have been bombing and shooting at the 6,500 Jewish settlers of Gaza when they venture out of their fortress outposts.

"We have no intention of strangling [the Palestinians]," said Nahman Shai, an Israeli government spokesman. "Just creating pressure in a careful and delicate dosage."

For the Palestinians, the approach is sheer folly. In Gaza it is practically impossible to find anyone who will openly say the time has come to resume peace talks with Israel.

"This is the harvest of the peace process - de facto apartheid and social and economic suffocation of our people," Mr Sourani said. "People have no faith in the process. They do not believe in the so-called peace, and they feel they have nothing to lose. This is the fuel."

fields.headline: Mutiny halts rail service
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Trains on a branch line in West Yorkshire ground to a halt when passengers left a commuter service after a series of delays saying it was quicker to walk home along the track.
fields.body:
Trains on a branch line in West Yorkshire ground to a halt when passengers left a commuter service after a series of delays saying it was quicker to walk home along the track.

But the mutinous commuters on the Northern Spirit 17:04 service from Leeds to Skipton caused further delays to other services by setting off on foot.

The train stopped outside Keighley station on Wednesday night after other services broke down up the line. When the driver announced that due to signal failure the train would return to Leeds, 20 miles back, passengers left the train.

Keith Norris, a technician at Leeds University who lives in Silsden, said: "We were told the wait would be five minutes." After 45 minutes, some of the passengers told the driver they would stop the train if it turned around.

"I didn't jump off the train myself as I think that's crackers. But it proves that people are totally worn down by delays. I have not had a train on time for six months. People have had enough, " he said.

Northern Spirit said the wait was caused by train failure, exacerbated by signalling problems. A spokeswoman denied that speed restrictions had disgruntled passengers, saying 98% of services were running on normal timetables.

But a spokesman for British Transport police said there was a build-up of "unhappy people" at Leeds station on Wednesday night because of delays. He said Railtrack had stopped the Skipton train due to operational problems. When the passengers walked on the track, other trains had to be delayed.

Railtrack said timetables would be back to normal in January - but passenger numbers are not expected to recover for a year. Chief executive Steven Marshall said his company aimed to have the network back to normal next year.

Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains, predicted it would take "most of next year" to get back to the growth in passengers of the past four years.

fields.headline: Water contamination kept under wraps
fields.standfirst: Chiltern Hills firm did not reveal presence of bacteria in bottles, believed caused by flooded bore hole
fields.trailText: The bottlers of one of the UK's most popular mineral waters knew that a batch had been contaminated with faeces as long ago as November 9 but did not to inform the public until Wednesday, it has emerged.
fields.body:
The bottlers of one of the UK's most popular mineral waters knew that a batch had been contaminated with faeces as long ago as November 9 but did not to inform the public until Wednesday, it has emerged.

The Chiltern Hills Mineral Water Company recalled all Chiltern Hills natural mineral water and Ashridge natural spring water and urged consumers to return unused bottles after discovering bacteria during regular tests. It stressed that the recall, which applies to both still and sparkling water, was merely a precaution.

But the firm first experienced the problem earlier this month and a batch had to be recalled from retailers. The company did not inform the public because it knew none of the bottles had been sold.

When the problem recurred early this week it retested samples from previous batches and discovered low levels of bacteria in some, prompting the suspension of production and yesterday's recall.

The company, based near Hemel Hempstead in Hertfordshire, produces 200,000 bottles a week. It believes the problem may have been caused by flooding which contaminated its bore hole.

"We test water every day and first picked it up on November 9, following the pretty torrential rain we had," said managing director David Kearns.

"We stopped production and recalled that batch. We checked all products with that batch code had been returned and they were. We then started getting further readings from current production on Tuesday this week. So we tested different bottles from the batches going back to October 1. Some revealed a very low level of bacteria and we decided to withdraw all of the production."

He added: "The food standards agency themselves say the levels are so low, and are not spread evenly, that you could find a reading in one bottle from a batch but not at all in the next six. It's so low that it's actually quite random whether you will find it.

"We had no reason to have any problems at all with the product. Our prognosis suggested it was tied to the flooding and we had covered it. Hindsight is wonderful."

It seems rising groundwater may have allowed the bore hole at Toms Hill in Aldbury to become contaminated by the faeces, which have not been identified as animal or human. The hole goes 100 metres through the chalk of the Chiltern Hills.

Mr Kearns said that tests were showing negative results again, but the firm would not resume production until it was sure the problem had been solved.

"Sales are the last thing I'm concerned about," he said. "From a commercial point of view I would like [resumption of production] to be sooner rather than later, but obviously safety is the primary concern. I think this demonstrates that we did checks and the product is well monitored and safe."

The FSA is advising people not to consume the water though "the most likely ill effect, should one occur, from consuming the product would be a stomach upset".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hunt for bogus paramedic
fields.body:
Hunt for bogus paramedic

Police in east Devon are trying to track down a bogus paramedic who is reported to have arrived at road accidents in the area in a car with flashing lights, wearing a uniform similar to St John Ambulance volunteers, and trying to help injured people.

John Wood, of Devon and Cornwall police, said: "Anyone who comes across someone giving first aid who they suspect isn't qualified is urged to contact the police immediately."

Hospital offer to entice nurses

Derriford hospital in Plymouth is offering nurses a free weekend family break in an effort to entice them back on to the staff.

The hospital has placed an advert in a nursing magazine offering a two night break at a Plymouth Hoe hotel. Around 20 nurses are due to take up the offer this weekend.

Return of Tom and Jerry

Tom and Jerry are to return to British television in their first new cartoon for more than 30 years. The cartoon, Mansion Cat, is to be screened as part of a 24-hour Tom and Jerry special on the Cartoon Network on New Year's Day.

Juror bitten by police horse

Barbara Peterson, 44, had to stand down from jury service yesterday after a horse ridden by the assistant chief constable, Bernard Hogan-Howe, bit her hand outside Liverpool crown court. She had stopped to pat the horse.

Man tortured to death

Detectives were last night unravelling the last days of property dealer Mark Drummond, 55, before he was tortured to death. Following a party last Monday, he was found dead in his Manchester flat. He was formally identified yesterday.

Trawlermen feared dead

Four trawlermen were feared dead last night after their boat ran into trouble off the Irish coast. A day long search for the men was called off as darkness fell. Wreckage was spotted in the area of the search in Co Cork.

Court lifts ban on magazine

The court of appeal yesterday lifted a ban on publication of Hello! magazine which contains "surreptitious" photographs of the wedding of Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta Jones. The stars signed a £1m deal with OK! magazine for exclusive pictures.

webTitle: More rain to come for flood-hit regions, warns met office

fields.headline: More rain to come for flood-hit regions, warns met office
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: As life appeared to be returning to normal for flood stricken households across Britain, forecasters yesterday warned that heavy rain would continue well into next week.
fields.body:
As life appeared to be returning to normal for flood stricken households across Britain, forecasters yesterday warned that heavy rain would continue well into next week.

For the first time in weeks there were no severe flood warnings, although 16 flood warnings remained on rivers in the midlands, the south and the south-east.

But with predictions of up to 30mm (1.2in) of rain within 24 hours, there was little hope that the worst was over.

Yesterday rain swept across the south before moving towards the midlands and into parts of Yorkshire.

"There's more rainfall to come and for people living in low level areas it's really not going to help," said Martin Rowley, national forecaster at the meteorological office in Bracknell, Berkshire.

"The weather systems are moving pretty smartly and what caused problems earlier on was that they were grinding to a halt and depositing heavy rainfall over a lengthy period.

"But even relatively small amounts of rain could cause problems if the ground is still wet."

Many areas are prone to renewed flooding because the ground is still saturated from the heavy rain of the past two months, which saw some of the worst weather in Britain since records began.

The government offered householders some hope for the future by announcing it would spend 50% extra on funding river flood defences.

The countryside minister, Elliot Morley, who was visiting badly hit areas around the river Severn, said that government spending would rise from £76m this year to £114m in 2003-04. He added that total spending on defences from all sources would rise from £380m to £440m over the same period.

But the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who is attending the world climate change conference at the Hague, has warned that floods will be a "regular" part of life in the future.

Flood alerts were yesterday in place on the lower river Aire at Brotherton in the north-east, the river Wye in Monmouth, Wales, and in Welney, Cambridgeshire.

Several stretches of the Severn in Shropshire and Gloucestershire were under warning, as were areas of the river Avon upstream of Rugby and the river Leam near Leamington Spa.

The Trent was on flood alert in Leicestershire and the river Vrynwy was still under careful observation in Powys, Wales.

The Beult was still under warning near Yalding, in Kent, while the Lavant at Chichester, West Sussex, and the Ems at Emsworth, Hampshire, were both on flood alert.

webTitle: British Library halts dumping of newspapers

fields.headline: British Library halts dumping of newspapers
fields.trailText: The British Library yesterday called a "temporary" halt to its policy of throwing out historic overseas newspapers after criticism from authors, scholars and the media.
fields.body:
The British Library yesterday called a "temporary" halt to its policy of throwing out historic overseas newspapers after criticism from authors, scholars and the media.

But it warned that it was running out of storage space and would have to make more difficult, possibly unpopular, decisions within six years.

The halt was ordered by its new chief executive, Lynne Brindley. It suspends a policy launched by her predecessor, Brian Lang, which was only disclosed when the American author Nicholson Baker protested last summer.

By then, it had earmarked 60,000 volumes of non-British newspapers for disposal - a tenth of its collection at Colindale, north London. They were at first offered to overseas libraries but, when a number of these had no space for them at short notice, volumes were sold at auction and to dealers, many of whom broke them up to resell illustrations as souvenirs.

It appears that about 25,000 of these volumes have already been discarded and that about 30% of these went to dealers. The losses included unique print runs of leading US newspapers from 1880-1950, German papers covering Hitler's rise to power and pre-revolutionary Russian papers.

Mr Baker, who has founded an unofficial repository to rescue some of the British Library newspapers, said he had paid $180,000 for 7,500 "brick-thick" volumes.

Ms Brindley said no more would be discarded until a full review of microfilm copies was complete. The review will investigate objections that film may deteriorate faster than paper, is often harder to read, is black and white only and often does not cover full print runs of papers.

Ms Brindley said: "I wish to ensure that all options have been properly considered and that the safeguards are robust. The long term aim was to provide copies good enough to meet the demands of users well into the future."

The library emphasised that its buildings were now 95% full and that there was space left for only five or six years.

"We are likely to have to face making further difficult decisions again in the not too distant future," Ms Brindley said.

An extra complication, although less space consuming, is the recently announced plan to set up a database which would extend the library's role as a copyright library into British digital and electronic publications.

This would include material so far available on CD-rom only. Ms Brindley said it was "of equal importance" to material in analogue or printed forms. "At the moment, precious material is being lost."

webTitle: Scientists raise hope on HIV treatment

fields.headline: Scientists raise hope on HIV treatment
fields.trailText: HIV-infected monkeys taken off HIV drugs have survived for six months - with almost undetectable levels of the virus, say US scientists.
fields.body:
HIV-infected monkeys taken off HIV drugs have survived for six months - with almost undetectable levels of the virus, say US scientists.

The research, published in Science today, raises hopes that "holidays" from HIV drugs might prompt an immune system into controlling the virus on its own.

However, Franco Lori, of the Research Institute for Genetic and Human Therapy in Washington DC, warned that people with HIV should never stop taking medication except on a doctor's advice.

The experiment arose from an unexpected discovery in someone known only as "the Berlin patient", who interrupted his therapy several times, and then stopped altogether - after which his immune system appeared to keep the infection under control without any more help.

Dr Lori and colleagues in fected rhesus monkeys with the simian equivalent of HIV. They treated six of them continuously with drugs. Another group had treatment for three weeks and a holiday for three weeks, and a third group had no treatment. After six months, the monkeys that had had "holidays" from their treatment still had flourishing immune systems.

"Our goal was to train the immune system to control the virus, and it appears this is what happened," Dr Lori said.

webTitle: Drug use among children rises to 11%

fields.headline: Drug use among children rises to 11%
fields.standfirst:
Government survey of 11 to 15-year-olds finds warnings ignored

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Drug misuse among school children is on the increase, with the number admitting using drugs up from 10% to 11%, according to a government survey published yesterday. Nearly two thirds of 15-year-olds said they had been offered drugs in the past year.
fields.body:
Drug misuse among school children is on the increase, with the number admitting using drugs up from 10% to 11%, according to a government survey published yesterday. Nearly two thirds of 15-year-olds said they had been offered drugs in the past year.

The findings, which run counter to recent claims that progress is being made in the fight against drugs, showed that more than one in 10 children aged 11-15 used drugs over the past 12 months, and suggested that government efforts to stem the flow of drugs is failing.

At the same time, the number of regular cigarette smokers was found to be on a relatively sharp decline, especially among boys, a trend that started in the mid-1980s.

Most school drug users said they had been using cannabis. Surprisingly, the greatest use had been among children in relatively affluent neighbourhoods. Users tended to be children with low expectations of good exam results and generally low esteem. The survey also found that children were eight times more likely to take drugs if their brothers or sisters did so.

"The general picture is a fairly consistent one of small increases amongst both boys and girls, particularly amongst those aged 14 and 15," said the authors.

The survey, which was conducted among more than 9,000 secondary school children aged 11-15 in some 340 schools in England, is the largest of its kind and is seen as more revealing than simple crime figures showing the number of children cautioned for possessing or selling cannabis.

The government's anti-drugs co-ordinator, Keith Hellawell, yesterday chose to ignore the increase, instead praising the common sense of the majority of teenagers who had not taken drugs.

The survey showed that boys were more likely to take drugs than girls, by 13% to 12%. But there was a growing likelihood of drug taking as children grew older.

As many as 30% of 15-year-olds had taken drugs in the previous year, but only 1% of 11-year-olds. Asian British youngsters were proportionately more unlikely to take drugs, with only 7% admitting having taken drugs in the previous year, against 12% of pupils described as white.

A sense of failure at school seemed to be likely to lead children to drugs, with 30% of those that said they were not doing well at school taking drugs. Drug misuse was heavily associated with other forms of anti-social behaviour, with drug users four times more likely to steal, and truants and those excluded from school five times more likely to take drugs.

Three-quarters of drug users said they had not told their parents. Yet even among those who did tell their parents, only half thought their parents disapproved. Brothers or sisters or close friends taking drugs was a key determinant.

Ministers can take some solace from the finding that there is no sign that drug education programmes in schools actually increase the likelihood of children taking drugs. However, other messages from the government do not seem to be getting through. Most pupils said they enjoyed the experience, 70% saying they had felt "high, fantastic, happy or giggly".

One child in every 100 had tried drugs before their 11th birthday. By the age of 16, 39% of children have tried drugs, according to the survey - which also predicted that that figure would rise; 55% have smoked cigarettes; and 73% have had an alcoholic drink.

Mr Hellawell said: "Children nowadays have to be told of the full dangers of drugs and have the details spelled out so that they clearly understand the dangers. They are young adults; advising 'just say no', which has never been our policy, does not recognise the need for the kind of structured anti-drugs education programmes the government has in place."

He said 93% of secondary and 75% of primary schools now had a drugs education policy - up from 86% of secondary and 61% of primary schools in 1997.

fields.headline: Barak courts Sharon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Frustrated at the Israeli army's failure to crush the Palestinians' guerrilla-style uprising, the prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday sought escape from the crisis by renewing his courtship of a political foe.
fields.body:
Frustrated at the Israeli army's failure to crush the Palestinians' guerrilla-style uprising, the prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday sought escape from the crisis by renewing his courtship of a political foe.

Mr Barak was due at midnight to meet Ariel Sharon, the hardline leader of the opposition Likud party, whose provocative visit to the holiest Muslim shrine in Jerusalem eight weeks ago ignited the violence.

On a day ruled by bombs and bullets, Palestinians accused Israel of assassinating a leader of the Islamist Hamas movement in the West Bank, Ibrahim Bani Odeh. In Gaza, two Israeli soldiers were killed and a third was reported killed at Anata village near Jerusalem when he lost control of his jeep on a road where Arabs had poured oil.

The prime minister's effort to reel Mr Sharon into a national emergency government is a measure of the dawning realisation in Israel that its reprisals against the Palestinians are not working. It also corresponds with renewed US and Russian mediation efforts.

For the first time yesterday, military commentators in the Israeli press cast doubts on the army's use of ever greater firepower. For all its attack helicopters, gunboats, and tanks - and the two-hour bombardment of Gaza City this week - soldiers and Jewish settlers in the territory remain under siege, and the conflict is threatening Israel's heartland.

However, Mr Sharon and other rightwing leaders still insist that Mr Barak abandon the "restraint", which has seen 260 killed in eight weeks, most of them Palestinians.

fields.headline: Roman gem
fields.standfirst: Deadline to reunite emperor and wife
fields.trailText: An export bar has been placed on a broken fragment of carved agate valued at almost £250,000, and British museums now has three months to raise the money and possibly to re-unite the emperor Octavian and his wife, Livia, who survives on the matching piece of the carving in the British Museum.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
An export bar has been placed on a broken fragment of carved agate valued at almost £250,000, and British museums now has three months to raise the money and possibly to re-unite the emperor Octavian and his wife, Livia, who survives on the matching piece of the carving in the British Museum.

The oval plaque of brown agate is believed to have been commissioned around 35BC from Solon, a Greek gemstone carver working in Rome .

It shows Octavian as the god Mercury, matched originally by Livia as Diana. The couple were separated more than 300 years ago, probably broken off a casket or miniature altar, and sold seperately until both ended up in English collections in the 18th century.

Despite its size, the quality of the work is regarded as astonishing. Art historians have suggested that it was commissioned to mark Octavian's victory at Actium.

The fourth Duke of Marlborough bought the Octavian gem in Rome in 1781. Before that it is said to have been owned by the German antiquarian and art historian Johann Winkelmann. The Livia gem came through another British collector, the second Earl of Arundel.

The arts minister, Alan Howarth, has imposed the export ban not just because of the beauty and value of the Octavian gem, but because of its long history in British collections and its importance to art historians who have studied Roman gem cutting.

The gem was recently sold at auction in London, by an undisclosed private owner, and is believed to have been bought by an American collector.

fields.headline: Witch drowns after beach ceremony
fields.trailText: A man who had been involved in witchcraft for 25 years was found washed up dead on a beach after a bizarre ceremony at Rustington, West Sussex, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A man who had been involved in witchcraft for 25 years was found washed up dead on a beach after a bizarre ceremony at Rustington, West Sussex, an inquest heard yesterday.

Derek Taylor, 60, of Bexhill-on-Sea, had been taking part in a seance on a beach during a full moon in February 1998.

His body was discovered washed up beside a symbol marked out in the sand. A sword was found nearby.

An inquest at Worthing, West Sussex, heard how Mr Taylor had been involved in witchcraft since 1975. He had lived with the former king of black witches, Alex Saunders.

Mr Taylor's former wife, Anna, said that when their marriage ended, he had become obsessed with witchcraft.

"He wanted to come back to me, but he was very ill," she said.

"He said he had killed himself in former lives on account of me and ... said he would have to kill himself again.

"He said he would have to return the children to the stars. I never believed him, he used to be an actor and was very dramatic."

She said he thought he was the corn king and would be sacrificed at the end of the year.

A statement from Gregory De-Fillipo, who drove Mr Taylor and his friend Robert Truelove to the beach, said he had been talking about witchcraft, money and inheritance.

"During the evening Robert and Derek kept talking about rituals and a sword and the fact that it was a full moon. I thought they were talking about a witchcraft ceremony."

A statement from Mr True love said: "I really didn't think that he had the bottle to do it. That's when I said: 'Do it, do it.' Then he dived into the waves and it took him right out very quickly."

A postmortem examination revealed that Mr Taylor, died from drowning. Roger Stone, the West Sussex coroner, recorded an open verdict .

webTitle: Lloyds TSB fined £100,000 for security blunders

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB fined £100,000 for security blunders
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB was yesterday fined £100,000 by a City regulator for a string of security breaches including not changing the combination of one of its safes regularly enough and failing to ensure the keys to a strongroom were held by an authorised person at all times.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB was yesterday fined £100,000 by a City regulator for a string of security breaches including not changing the combination of one of its safes regularly enough and failing to ensure the keys to a strongroom were held by an authorised person at all times.

The rule breaches involve its global custody business Lloyds TSB Securities Services, which looks after shares, bonds and other securities for customers.

Imro, the investment management regulatory organisation, said the bank "failed to maintain adequate security arrangements" for so-called bearer stocks - shares or bonds where there is no register of the owner and the certificate itself is the only proof of ownership. It also failed to perform adequate reconciliations, resulting in "insufficient protection for customer assets in its custody".

Records of the handling of some items were not maintained also. In one case, there was no record of the exact location of £30m of bearer bonds in early November 1997, though the regulator said these were held in its custody at all times.

webTitle: Boateng offers talks to stave off prisons strike

fields.headline: Boateng offers talks to stave off prisons strike
fields.trailText: The prisons minister, Paul Boateng, yesterday stepped in to head off the risk of chaos throughout the country's prisons by promising talks as the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union threatened a strike if civilian workers were disciplined for refusing to wear name badges.
fields.body:
The prisons minister, Paul Boateng, yesterday stepped in to head off the risk of chaos throughout the country's prisons by promising talks as the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union threatened a strike if civilian workers were disciplined for refusing to wear name badges.

Around 600 electricians, plumbers, fitters and heating engineers have been told by the prison service that they must wear the name tags to ensure prisoners are treated with "dignity and respect", but the civilian workers fear that they and their families could become targets for intimidation or blackmail if they are made to identify themselves.

Many have defied the instructions and the AEEU, warned yesterday that it would call a ballot for industrial action if any worker were punished.

On a visit to Woodhill maximum security jail near Milton Keynes yesterday, Mr Boateng promised discussions with the union to try to resolve the dispute, promising there was "nothing fixed in concrete" and insisting that his chief concern was the safety and security of all staff.

"We are looking at this issue very carefully and we will take all the steps necessary in order to give non-uniform staff the sense that they are valued members of the team," he said.

Mr Boateng's conciliatory remarks were welcomed by Paul Reuter, the AEEU national officer representing the prison workers, who said he looked forward to talks "so long as they are based on the principle that if prison officers don't have to wear name badges, then nor should our members have to do so."

The row surfaced in July after Martin Narey, the director general of the prison service, ordered that all non-uniformed staff wear name tags in order to emphasise his commitment to "deal openly and professionally with prisoners" - and allow them to identify staff if they are mistreated or attacked by them.

The AEEU accepts the need to identify staff but wants civilian prison workers to wear numbers - as prison officers do - rather than their names.

"Our members work alongside prisoners every day, carry out searches, lead prisoners out on working parties and can report them for punishment," an AEEU spokesman said yesterday. "They see the name badges as a real potential threat to themselves and their families. Feelings are running very high."

A prison service spokesman said the unions had been consulted about the badges policy before it was introduced and there was no intention of compromising the personal security of staff. But "staff in uniformed grades have duties in relation to the supervision and control of prisoners which place them at greater risk than their non-uniformed colleagues".

Disciplinary proceedings have already been brought against dozens of workers who have refused to wear the new name tags, but no punishments have yet been imposed.

A walkout by civilian workers would have a serious impact on the running of prisons, the AEEU says.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: 'Significant' job cuts at ICL
fields.body:
'Significant' job cuts at ICL

Fujitsu is planning significant job cuts at computer firm ICL, its poorly performing UK subsidiary.

George Hall, ICL head of corporate affairs, said that there would be cuts among management across all businesses, not a cull of jobs in a single area.

Fujitsu president Maoyuki Akikusa said earlier that ICL's operations had to be modernised and the group needed to focus more on profits.

Mothercare on the mend

Mothercare, the retailer formerly part of Storehouse, will spend £20m a year to roll out its Mothercare World format.

Following the disposal of Bhs in May and subsequent restructuring of the business, Mothercare reduced its half-year losses from £15.7m to £2.7m.

Ryanair pilots' strike averted

Ryanair said yesterday that following talks with the Dublin Pilots Committee their threatened strike in Dublin tomorrow has been called off.

The airline has negotiated a new agreement which will be presented to Ryanair's pilots before November 30. The five-year deal guarantees 3% annual pay rises and grants the pilots share options in Ryanair.

US group buys Square Mile

Financial public relations firm Square Mile ended weeks of speculation yesterday by saying it had agreed to be bought by the US group True North Communications.

The purchase price could reach £10m depending on Square Mile's future profits. The company becomes the latest of several PR firms to be snapped up by larger advertising groups.

Danone ditches bid for Quaker

French food company Danone yesterday became the third potential suitor to pull out of the bidding for Quaker Oats, the US maker of sports drink Gatorade.

The move came a day after Danone said it was interested in Quaker.

Coca-Cola and PepsiCo had failed to strike a deal for the company, said to be worth around $15bn (£10.6bn). Coca-Cola decided against bidding this week after boardroom disagreements.

webTitle: Oftel will make BT pay for shutting out rivals

fields.headline: Oftel will make BT pay for shutting out rivals
fields.trailText: Telecoms watchdog Oftel yesterday tightened the screws on BT by taking powers to force the company to pay compensation to rival operators if it fails to open its local exchanges on time.
fields.body:
Telecoms watchdog Oftel yesterday tightened the screws on BT by taking powers to force the company to pay compensation to rival operators if it fails to open its local exchanges on time.

In its latest set of proposals for "unbundling" the local loop by July, Oftel sided with the rival operators' demands for better terms and conditions for installing their own broadband internet equipment in BT's exchanges.

David Edmonds, the director general, said: "We have found in favour of the operators' complaints that the contract proposed by BT was not reasonable. BT will be in breach of its contract if it does not provide operators with the necessary services to the same timescale and quality that it does to its own business."

Under the regulator's plans, rivals will be allowed to commission an independent survey if BT claims there is not enough space in an exchange - and be repaid the assessor's fees if he finds there is enough room. They can also call in an outsider to assess BT's charges for using its space.

BT, which has agreed to open 600 exchanges by July, said it offered independent verification weeks ago - "and we would expect it".

Oftel also proposed that operators should be able to swap space to develop a presence in their preferred exchanges - a clause viewed by BT as likely to create a secondary market for trading space as a valuable commodity. Borrowing on new rugby union rules, the regulator said operators failing to install equipment in a prepared space within three months would have to give it up.

Mr Edmonds said the UK was well on the way to finally deciding the framework for "unbundling" but BT sources said the timetable for admitting rival teams to its exchanges was tight.

Yesterday's proposals are subject to four weeks of consultation. Oftel has yet to agree the process for allocating space in exchanges where demand outstrips supply and the prices BT can charge.

So far the regulator has proposed a £118 annual rental charge and a £95 connection fee. Officials insisted the deadlines could be met.

webTitle: 'Pirate Kelvin' battles Radio 2 on high seas

fields.headline: 'Pirate Kelvin' battles Radio 2 on high seas
fields.trailText: The spirit of Radio Caroline was invoked yesterday by Kelvin MacKenzie, owner of TalkSport, who took a 33% stake in a new offshore station that will broadcast across Britain.
fields.body:
The spirit of Radio Caroline was invoked yesterday by Kelvin MacKenzie, owner of TalkSport, who took a 33% stake in a new offshore station that will broadcast across Britain.

The station, named 171 The Lounge, will broadcast from a rig off the Dutch coast on long wave. But the similarity with the pirate Caroline ends there. The Lounge will have a less rebellious streak, taking on Radio 2 with an easy listening playlist including Dean Martin, The Carpenters and Gabrielle. The offshore station also has the approval of the Radio Authority. "If you like a bit of dooby, dooby doo, this will be the station for you," Mr MacKenzie said.

The Lounge will become only the fourth national analogue commercial station in Britain. The others are Virgin Radio, Classic FM and TalkSport (which is part of Mr MacKenzie's Wireless Group). It is expected to go on air in 2002.

Wireless Group already uses The Lounge brand for its digital radio services which broadcast to only a tiny percentage of the population. Mr MacKenzie said the easy listening market was potentially one of the most lucrative. "There's a lot of people fighting for the 15- to 24-year-old market but the old grey quid is very attractive."

The former Sun editor said the station would appeal to lis teners between 20 and 30 for whom easy listening is fashionable, as well as the 45-plus age group.

In return for the stake, Wireless Group will undertake management of the station, including programming and advertising sales. The company is not paying any cash for the stake but has agreed to buy out its partners in the station's parent business, Delta Radio, when it reaches break-even - expected in three years. The other partners are a group of financial investors.

The station has a licence from the Dutch government and will not be regulated by UK authorities. Wireless Group has, however, given undertakings to abide by UK copyright and broadcast content guidelines as well as regulations laid down by the Advertising Standards Authority.

Tony Stoller, chief executive of the Radio Authority, said he welcomed Wireless Group's commitment to be mindful of UK regulation. The rig is being built by Crown Castle, which runs the BBC's transmitters, and will have two masts taller than the Eiffel Tower.

Wireless Group successfully guided its flagship station through a rebranding from Talk Radio to TalkSport at the start of the year. In its maiden results as a quoted company, published in the autumn, TalkSport showed a 21% increase in revenues during the first six months to £5.1m. Male listeners accountfor 75% of the total, compared to 55% at the same time last year. Shares inched 1p higher to 208.5p yesterday.

Media group Chrysalis yesterday defied predictions of a slowdown in radio advertising, reporting a 47% increase in trading. In the year ended August 31 the group recorded a 25% increase in revenues to £168m.

Chrysalis shares closed 8.5p higher at 297.5p.

webTitle: Technique that gave form to the American dream of freedom

fields.headline: Technique that gave form to the American dream of freedom
fields.trailText: 1943 was a terrible year for the world, but a great one for art. It was the year Jackson Pollock found his voice, when he had his first one man show at Peggy Guggenheim's New York gallery Art of this Century and painted, in an overnight burst of creativity, a 20ft-long mural for her house.
fields.body:
1943 was a terrible year for the world, but a great one for art. It was the year Jackson Pollock found his voice, when he had his first one man show at Peggy Guggenheim's New York gallery Art of this Century and painted, in an overnight burst of creativity, a 20ft-long mural for her house.

Pollock had been convinced since he was very young he was destined to be a great artist but the sub-Picasso derivativeness of his early work makes you wonder how he preserved such an illusion. Only in 1943 did he discover what he could do that no one else could.

He could throw paint, and when it landed it was not just chaos down there, but beauty. Pollock, despite his slow start and early death in a drink-drive accident in 1956, gave perfect form to American dreams of freedom and self-fulfilment.

He found he could paint without a subject yet still express something universal by pouring and flicking paint on to a - usually horizontal - canvas. Like the jazz musicians who were his heroes, he could spin out a free line of improvisation and have it make some wild sense. Untitled (Composition with Pouring I) is one of the first works in which Pollock's line comes through in its freedom and glory. Underneath, you can see the remains of a figure.

Other paintings that Pollock made in 1943, such as The She Wolf and Pasiphaë, were surrealistic figure paintings. These visions look forced by comparison. Pollock, who underwent regular Jungian therapy to control his alcoholism, was too consciously picturing archetypes. The strange thing is how long it took Pollock to recognise this.

He spent the next few years experimenting with shamanistic imagery until, in 1947, he started to hurl paint again without any thought of what it meant, and entered a period of grace in which he created some of the most sensuous, overwhelming paintings of the 20th century.

fields.headline: Kosovo assassination
fields.standfirst:
Right-hand man of moderate politician is shot dead

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Right-hand man of moderate politician is shot dead
fields.body:
A senior politician who was a close adviser to one of Kosovo's most prominent moderate politicians was shot dead outside his home in the province yesterday, as European leaders gathered in the neighbouring republic of Croatia for a European Union summit on the fate of the Balkans.

Xhemajl Mustafa, a long-time aide to Ibrahim Rugova, the head of the Democratic League of Kosovo (LDK), was ambushed at the entrance to his apartment in the Dardania area of Pristina at 3pm. He was shot twice in the head and four times in the chest.

Police and British Royal Marines serving with the UN peacekeeping force K-For cordoned off the area and searched for a Mercedes-Benz spotted leaving the scene.

The assassination comes a day after the home of the Yugoslav representative in Kosovo was bombed, killing one person, and following renewed fighting in the Preshevo valley, on the border with Serbia, where it is thought that three policemen were killed in clashes with an Albanian group on Tuesday.

The principal deputy head of the UN in Kosovo, Jock Covey, said: "The murder of an LDK adviser before a regional summit discussing cooperation is a dark sign for Kosovo.

"Just last month, Kosovo demonstrated to the world that real progress is possible when hundreds of thousands of people went peacefully to the polls," he said referring to the elections held in the province at the end of October, in which the LDK won 60% of the vote.

Mustafa was held in esteem by most political parties in Kosovo, even those led by former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army, which have been critical of the LDK. Since the election several LDK men have been attacked.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Three hurt in axe attacks
fields.body:
Three hurt in axe attacks

Three men suffered head injuries in separate attacks by a man with an axe in Essex. Police said yesterday that the assaults were connected.

The attacker, wearing motorcycle leathers, struck on Wednesday evening at Thorpe-le-Soken, near Clacton, Weeley and Horsley Cross.

Thieves take off with parrots

Three parrots together worth around £3,600 have been stolen by thieves who chiselled through the wall of Petsmart in Stockport, Greater Manchester.

The cockatoos, named Fergie, Prunella and Laura, disappeared on Wednesday night.

Net gain is talk of Cornwall

A Cornish language dictionary compiled by university lecturer Ken George is taking the ancient language into the age of hi-tech with new words including internet (kesroesweyth) and website (gwiasva).

Turkey plant in GM protest

Greenpeace campaigners yesterday delivered three tonnes of turkey feed free of genetically modified ingredients to the headquarters of Norwich-based food producers Bernard Matthews.<

Judge defends 'flip' decision

A district judge criticised for pretending to grant a youth bail on the toss of coin said yesterday that he intended only to "hammer home in a vivid way" that the 18-year-old was gambling with his liberty.

Lee Blenkinsop appeared before Roy Anderson at Leeds magistrates' court after he broke a curfew order.

webTitle: Scientists watch as babies make sense of the world

fields.headline: Scientists watch as babies make sense of the world
fields.trailText: Scientists have pinpointed one of the key moments when babies start to make sense of shapes in the world about them.
fields.body:
Scientists have pinpointed one of the key moments when babies start to make sense of shapes in the world about them.

They "eavesdropped" on bursts of brainwave activity in babies who stared at a screen showing four shapes of the computer game Pacman. When these shapes are randomly dotted about a screen, they tell a viewer nothing. But when the Pacmen are placed with their four mouths together they form an illusion that psychologists call a Kanizsa square.

Six-month-old babies showed no sign they were aware of the illusion. But eight-month-old babies fired off a burst of brain signals at 40 cycles per second - telling scientists they could infer a square from the shapes.

The research helps scientists understand how infants start with what are in effect innocent brains, and then make the connections that help them understand the world about them. Gergely Csibra and Mark Johnson of the centre for brain and cognitive develop ment at Birkbeck College, London, report in Science today that they fitted a sophisticated system of detectors over the heads of 11 six-month-old and 11 eight-month-old infants. They showed them intriguing pictures on a screen to get their attention, and then briefly tested the babies' responses to the Pacman shapes.

They already knew that there was a characteristic signal at around 40Hz when adults looked at a Kanizsa square. When they saw the same pattern from babies, they deduced that the infants, too, recognised a square. The researchers were hoping to solve the old puzzle: when does a baby begin to see not the separate bits of an object, but the thing as a whole?

"The question is how they segment the world into objects, how they decide which parts of something go together, whether they can infer a whole from a part," Dr Csibra said.

Babies have short attention spans. Researchers reckoned they had on average about five minutes worth of experiment time from each child.

"These babies like the stimuli," Dr Csibra added. "We sit them in front of a computer monitor and show them different animations. They love to see them. When they are bored, they look away. That's the most important measure of infant perception: how long they look at the screen. If they are not interested, they are not looking."

webTitle: Britain lines up unlikely allies at summit

fields.headline: Britain lines up unlikely allies at summit
fields.standfirst:
Blair may be fighting France over proposed tax changes in Nice, but Chirac will be seeking his help to stop Germany's bid for more power

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Blair may be fighting France over proposed tax changes in Nice, but Chirac will be seeking his help to stop Germany's bid for more power
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the European Foreign Office minister, keeps a chart on his wall in King Charles Street of the alliances he and his fellow ministers have managed to forge in the run-up the Nice summit. For although most of the British press love to portray Britain as isolated and fighting a monolithic group of 14 other EU nations, the truth is more complex and more interesting.

During the talks at Nice, Britain hopes to protect its interests by marshalling a complex constellation of different alliances. If the Foreign Office negotiators - Sir Stephen Wall based in the Cabinet Office and Nigel Sheinwald in Brussels - have done their job they will now know the identity of Britain's likely friends at Nice. This is after all the meat and drink of diplomacy.

Surrender

But in the latest draft text of the Nice treaty, distributed by the French presidency and leaked in Brussels yesterday, there are no signs yet that Britain has made a breakthrough on the most difficult issues. Proposed changes on indirect tax and social security - both strictly no-go areas for Tony Blair - include some new ideas, but they would still require the surrender of the national veto.

But British officials are sure they will not be fighting alone . Mr Blair is backed in his strong opposition to majority voting on tax by Ireland, Luxembourg and Sweden. They may not be big countries, but as one official said: "In this game, it does not matter who your allies are. They need unanimity for change and they are not going to get it".

The Swedes are seen as the unreliable member of this group, since they might accept majority voting on environmental tax or fighting fraud. British officials vow Mr Blair will block even this incursion into British sovereignty.

Britain also fears that if it gives ground on fraud, the commission would funnel further tax harmonisation measures by claiming they were all necessary to wage the fight against fraud.

Voting

Britain is also hunting for allies to stop an innocent sounding social provisions clause becoming subject to majority voting. Officials are confident that Germany and Denmark will side with the British to block "the representation and collective defence of the interest of workers" become subject to majority voting. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, also knows that other countries want to block majority voting in areas where Britain has no objections. The Germans do not want to see the loss of veto over free movement of professionals. The Greeks oppose the loss of veto over transport liberalisation, concerned it will open their ferries to international competition. The Spanish and the Portugese do not want to see majority voting in financial regulation, fearing it will enforce northern rigour on their accounting methods. All these countries might need alliances with Britain to protect their own interests.

British officials predict the reweighting of votes on the council of ministers, necessary to prepare for enlargement, will be the most intractable issue to resolve. The issue addresses national status and naked power politics. The big four - Britain, France, Italy and Germany - believe there should be a reweighting towards them to recompense their loss of power with each past wave of enlargement.

The Spanish argue the size of their population and economy now warrant a place for them in this big league, with the same votes as the British. At the moment Britain has 10 votes and Spain has eight.

Status

The Germans are attracted by the so-called "double majority" in which a majority is measured both by member states and size of population. This would allow Germany to see its status as the most populous nation properly reflected. But the loss of parity with Germany on the council would, in French eyes, destroy part of the post-war settlement that gave rise to the EU in the first place. The issue was one of the most senstitive at the recent Franco-German summit.

So on this subject the French and the British can ally to block Germany. Presi dent Chirac - in domestic political trouble - will be urgently seeking British help.

Even within the small states there are disagreements - the Dutch would like more votes than the Belgians. Even this gives Britain room to look for allies.

British officials regard the best chance of compromise a deal giving Germany 33 votes, France, Italy and the UK 30, and Spain 27. Britain would achieve its big political objective of aquiring a blocking minority on the council, on an issue discussed under majority voting so long as it has the support of two other big states. But this proposal still might violate President Chirac's sensibilities, creating deadlock.

The Finns, on behalf of the smaller nations, are reluctant to accept such dominance by the large countries. The big countries are offering, in return for greater power on the council, that all member states would only have one commissioner each. At present the big countries have two commissioners.

Rights

It is also now clear that the charter of fundamental rights will, as Britain wishes, end up as solely a political declaration and not be incorporated into the treaty.

In this fast-moving swirl of alliances, the French draft will be discussed on Saturday by chief negotiators, including Britain's Sir Stephen Wall. The whole treaty will then be looked at again by foreign ministers on December 3, just four days before the summit itself.

webTitle: Blair changes tune to woo headteachers

fields.headline: Blair changes tune to woo headteachers
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday adopted a noticeably more conciliatory tone towards the teaching profession as he signalled plans to recruit more than 250,000 teachers over the next 10 years.
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday adopted a noticeably more conciliatory tone towards the teaching profession as he signalled plans to recruit more than 250,000 teachers over the next 10 years.

Speaking at a London conference attended by 500 newly- qualified headteachers, the prime minister promised further cash for education and other "under-invested" public services. He pledged to make teaching "the most prestigious profession" in the country, attracting the brightest and the best trainees to provide more than 250,000 extra classroom staff needed in the next decade.

In what appeared to be a significant shift in approach which was welcomed by teaching unions, Mr Blair backed personal thanks to headteachers with the commitment of significant extra cash for schools. "Your vision and your leadership are the keys to success in every school", he said. "There is no more important job in the country today."

At the same conference last year, headteachers and unions were angered by Mr Blair's call to help stamp out "the culture of excuses" in the profession. In a controversial speech, he had rounded on those unwilling to embrace change as the "forces of conservatism".

But this year Mr Blair buried the hatchet, dropping heavy hints of further help for teachers, particularly in areas such as London which has been hardest hit by recruitment problems. "The government intends to continue to make teaching more attractive in pay and rewards, particularly where it is hardest to recruit and retain."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "It is a very positive message and I warmly welcome it, in particular the commitment to invest a higher percentage of the national income in education. We are edging our way towards a better social partnership with the government."

A conference delegate, Tina Jacobs, who has been a headteacher for nine months, said: "I am not a particularly big fan of Mr Blair, but I was encouraged by what he had to say."

webTitle: Ambitious women happy with their lot

fields.headline: Ambitious women happy with their lot
fields.trailText: A woman's place is now very much in the office, according to a comprehensive 15 year survey of women's attitudes released yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman's place is now very much in the office, according to a comprehensive 15 year survey of women's attitudes released yesterday.

The national centre for social research found 74% of working women are seeking promotion. Analysis carried out between 1983 and 1998 plotted women's views on social, economic, political and moral issues.

Ten years ago 25% of women said a man's job was to earn the money and a woman's was to look after home and family. But now just 16% believe that, while 73% believe that if children are looked after well, it is good for a woman to work.

The figures show women becoming better off. In 1984, 72% claimed they were "comfortable" against 83% now. When asked what was the best way for a woman to be independent, almost 60% answered "to have a job". But while in 1989 a quarter of women found work "often" or "always" stressful, by 1997 that was up to a third.

The NCSR, based in London, carried out gender analysis among 3,500 men and women between 1983 and 1998.
Press Association

webTitle: Wilde died after radical surgery to cure longstanding ear disease

fields.headline: Wilde died after radical surgery to cure longstanding ear disease
fields.trailText: Oscar Wilde suffered from a chronic ear disease that failed to respond to radical surgery carried out in a hotel bedroom in Paris, according to a study of events leading up to his death in Paris 100 years ago next week.
fields.body:
Oscar Wilde suffered from a chronic ear disease that failed to respond to radical surgery carried out in a hotel bedroom in Paris, according to a study of events leading up to his death in Paris 100 years ago next week.

The operation was conducted in a hotel bedroom in Paris seven weeks before his death on November 30 1900, from acute meningitis.

His condition had nothing to do with syphilis, as Wilde biographers Arthur Ransome and Richard Ellman have suggested, but stemmed from a cholosteotoma, a growth in the ear which corrodes the mastoid bone and leaves festering debris in the middle ear.

Ashley Robins and Sean Sellars, of the University of Cape Town in South Africa, hypothesise in the Lancet medical journal that doctors, far from trying to remove pus from the eardrum as accounts suggest, were attempting a new procedure, which had only recently been done in France and Germany.

The surgery involved the removal of part of the mastoid bone around the ear and the little bones in the middle ear that help transmit sound to the brain.

They say the condition had plagued Wilde some time before he was imprisoned, despite assertions that it resulted from a fall in Reading prison, where he had been imprisoned for indecency in 1895.

In September 1900, Wilde, then staying at the Hotel D'Alsace, Paris, fell ill and was seen by the British embassy GP, Maurice a'Court Tucker who was an ear, nose and throat specialist. Dr Tucker visited him 68 times in the next 10 weeks and referred his case to a surgeon, whose identity remains a mystery.

The operation took place under chloroform on October 10 and cost about £3,000 at today's prices. The open wounds needed daily dressing for weeks and Wilde took morphine and opium to ease the pain. By the end of October Wilde was making brief outings into the city and appeared relatively well.

By the second week of November he had relapsed. He finally fell into a coma before dying.

Dr Robins said that Wilde may have undergone a radical mastoidectomy, an operation that may have taken two hours. "People previously thought the operation was a minor one but it was pretty extensive. It was probably done with great surgical skill for those times. It was a huge procedure, but they did not have strong light or an operating microscope."

The infection seemed to have spread beyond the plate that separates the mastoid and middle ear from the brain. Dr Robins had spent months trying to track down the surgeon through records in Paris but had failed. He could only guess that he may have been among those who had trained Tucker.

The study suggests Wilde had "unimpaired intellectual prowess" to the end but it may prompt Wilde fans to wonder whether the condition played a part in his spectacular fall from a triumphant career as playwright to bankruptcy and death in the space of just five years.

webTitle: Court battle over key Pollock painting

fields.headline: Court battle over key Pollock painting
fields.standfirst: Collector defends ownership of canvas as friend of the late artist claims the pivotal work was stolen from her home
fields.trailText: Ownership of a key painting in 20th century art history will be thrashed out in the high court next week, where a Bermudan collector will seek a declaration that he is the true owner of the Jackson Pollock bought in a London gallery over 30 years ago, not the elderly American who claims it is a wedding present stolen over half a century ago.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Ownership of a key painting in 20th century art history will be thrashed out in the high court next week, where a Bermudan collector will seek a declaration that he is the true owner of the Jackson Pollock bought in a London gallery over 30 years ago, not the elderly American who claims it is a wedding present stolen over half a century ago.

Untitled (Composition with Pouring I), made in 1943, is a tiny piece compared with the barn-door sized canvasses for which Pollock is most famous. However it is of immense importance to historians as the artist's first purely abstract work using paint poured and dripped on to canvas, a technique much mocked and parodied, and hugely influential.

Robin David Judah, who lives in Bermuda, is going to court in London to prove he has legal title to the picture, in the wake of an American supreme court case when Mercedes Matter forced the New York Museum of Modern Art to identify him as the anonymous loaner of the picture to a Jackson Pollock retrospective.

The painting was also in an exhibition at Tate Britain last year, and had previously been on loan to various American museums.

Mrs Matter, who is 87, was a friend of the artist, and claims the painting is the canvas he gave her as a wedding present in 1943. It was stolen from her New York apartment three years later, and she had not seen it since.

Yesterday her London lawyer, Helen Bowkley, said she could make no comment on the dispute, as it was sub judice.

Mr Judah's lawyer, Michael Tulloch, said: "We regard this as a private matter which can most appropriately be resolved through the courts, rather than by litigation through allegation and counter-allegation in the media."

Many recent disputed ownership cases have been triggered by art resurfacing in a high profile exhibition, something which is making both public and private owners nervous about loaning.

In the last five years rival claims to ownership of a Monet, and a Van Gogh, have emerged after they were seen in American exhibitions. This year ownership of a massive 19th century German triptych, which was included in the Royal Academy's 1900 exhibition, was formally transferred in a ceremony in the London gallery from the Austrian state collection to an elderly London brother and sister who were able to show that, before the Nazi years, it had hung in their family dining room.

Although there is no ques tion of the Jackson Pollock being in any way implicated in the Nazi art controversy, the traditional secrecy over provenance of dealers, galleries and museums is gradually being prised open by the international controversy over the stolen Jewish art.

Under English law a buyer may have legal title to a work of art even if it was originally stolen - something which has been bitterly criticised not just by campaigners on Jewish owned art, but also by those trying to block the huge international trade in stolen antiquities.

Since 1980 it has been necessary to establish that the purchase was "in good faith", but in the 1960s, when the Jackson Pollock was sold both by Sothebys, and by the Marlborough Gallery in London, simple proof of purchase was enough to establish title.

"Paintings are resurfacing all the time," said Sarah Jackson, of the Art Loss Register, which is pursuing many lost and stolen works of art. "The question of Nazi looted art has really sharpened people's minds, and if it has put into their consciousness that provenance is just as important as the traditional concentration on authenticity and condition, that can only be a good thing."
