webTitle: Letters: After the floods, the forms

fields.headline: After the floods, the forms
fields.trailText: Like many flood victims in Lewes, and no doubt in many other places in the country, my wife and I are temporarily housed in a caravan in our front garden. Imagine our surprise when a form arrived from the council asking for information to assess our liability for council tax for the caravan.
fields.body:
Like many flood victims in Lewes, and no doubt in many other places in the country, my wife and I are temporarily housed in a caravan in our front garden. Imagine our surprise when a form arrived from the council asking for information to assess our liability for council tax for the caravan.

An interesting point is that we are required to state whether we own the caravan, lease it or rent it. We do none of these things - it was provided by our insurers. I expect that we should really be considered as squatters, who tend not to pay council tax. Of course, we could be evicted by the owners of the land on which we are squatting. Oh... that's us.

The serious point, however, is that the district council ap pears to have no discretion in this matter. It also does not seem to have occurred to the flooding minister, Elliot Morley, who on Tuesday appeared on the television news announcing that Lewes and Uckfield flood victims had not been forgotten, that he could perhaps issue an instruction that all flood victims should be exempted from council tax while they are, through no fault of their own, living in difficult conditions in temporary alternative accommodation

It would be a great opportunity for the government to put their money where their mouth is and show some real concern for flood victims.

Paul Mockford
Lewes, East Sussex
mockfords@clara.co.uk

webTitle: Paris shocked by woman's 30 years in a shed

fields.headline: Paris shocked by woman's 30 years in a shed
fields.standfirst: Trial to hear story of 'lodger' made to live in garden without heat or running water
fields.trailText: The storm was terrible that night. Awake at their windows, afraid for the slates on their elegant roofs and the trees in their manicured gardens, several residents of the Avenue de Chateau de Bertin spotted the dark figure darting across Jacques and Françoise Saunier's lawn.
fields.body:
The storm was terrible that night. Awake at their windows, afraid for the slates on their elegant roofs and the trees in their manicured gardens, several residents of the Avenue de Chateau de Bertin spotted the dark figure darting across Jacques and Françoise Saunier's lawn.

The police were called; the grounds of the couple's house in the well-heeled western Paris suburb of Chatou searched. No one.

Before leaving, the policemen pushed open the door of the garden shed. A skeletal, white-haired woman sat shivering in a corner.

"It's all right," said Renée Broussard, between coughs. "I live here."

The story that has emerged since that night could have sprung from the pages of a Dickens or a Zola.

It would have been told yesterday, but for a bad fall that prevented the redoubtable Mrs Saunier, 76, from appearing in court on a raft of charges, the most serious of which was failing to come to the assistance of a person in danger.

For when Renée Broussard, now 65, was hospitalised on the night she was found in December 1999, she weighed exactly six stone (38kg) and was suffering from asthma and arthritis.

She had, it emerged, been living in the Sauniers' shed, in all but complete isolation and without heat or running water, for just over 30 years.

Now Ms Broussard, timid but determined, lives in a retirement home in nearby Le Vesinet, visited regularly by one of the Sauniers' more solicitous neighbours who brings her clothes and pays for her to take drawing lessons. Journalists, too, beat a path to her door. She puts on her lipstick to receive them.

Her life belongs to another era. She was 34 when her mother, the concierge of a apartment block in Paris, died in 1969.

"My father was a policeman," she said, "but he took to drink and we had heard nothing of him for many years. I had lost touch with my sister who had moved to Belgium. Mrs Saunier was my only chance not to end up on the street."

Both Renée and her mother had taken in piece-work for the aristocratic Mrs Saunier, who at the time ran a haute couture atelier near the Place Vendme.

"She suggested I come and lodge with her and her husband. I was to continue sewing for her, by hand, and I would be paid."

The lodging was the shed, which the Sauniers promised to fit out properly.

The water supply was the garden tap. The Sauniers informed her politely that they would rather she did not show her face when there were visitors. But Ms Broussard was grateful for her small weekly wage and two meals a day. For a while, she said, she was happy.

Then Mrs Saunier installed an electric sewing machine in the shed. "I worked like a maniac," Ms Broussard said. "From early morning to late in the evening, and through the night for the big collections. She was never satisfied with the results. I had to undo and redo almost everything, time and time and time again."

The wages fell lower and lower, then stopped altogether. The two meals a day became one.

The Sauniers stopped supplying butane for Ms Broussard's gas heater, at which point she decided to complain. "I kicked up a right fuss, a real stink," she said. But Mr Saunier turned the garden hose on her, and she retired to her shed.

There, she listened to the radio and studied her Bible. She knitted herself gloves and shawls and socks to keep warm. At night, she raided the Sauniers' dustbins for newspapers to read.

Because she was no longer working, the electricity was cut off. The single meal a day became a plastic bag of food and scraps, hung from the shed door.

Her meetings with the Sauniers became rare. When she fell badly ill one winter in the early 1980s, Ms Broussard was given aspirin, but no doctor was called.

Besides the Sauniers, it seems, no one had heard of her - not the town hall, the social security, nor the tax authorities. Renée Broussard had accomplished an extraordinary feat in bureaucracy-ridden France: she did not exist.

As her contacts with the world beyond her shed shrank, so Ms Broussard's paralysing fear of everything outside slowly mounted.

She had been given the keys to the front and back doors of the Sauniers' house, and could have left whenever she chose. In 30 years she never thought of doing so. "Where was I to go?" she asked. "I had nowhere."

In 1997, Mrs Saunier's husband was left paralysed by a brain haemorrhage. From then on she rarely left his bedside, and the waif in the shed grew thinner and thinner, and sicker and sicker.

The floorboards rotted, damp eating away the timbers. Some nights Ms Broussard cried out from the pain in her joints and her chest.

"She would not have lasted much longer," the hospital doctor who treated her told Le Nouvel Observateur magazine. "She was starving. During the four months she spent here she stole the meals meant for the others on the ward, she dipped bread in her yoghurt. She was lost. There was a lot she did not know and could not deal with."

Now Ms Broussard, who likes to be known by her second name, Pierrette, says she wants "peace and quiet, and if possible a few friends". For her part, Mrs Saunier insists the local mayor knew of her guest - which he has denied - and says she is "shattered" by the whole affair.

"It has left me disgusted with humanity," she said yesterday as the hearing was postponed until next month.

"This was meant to be a temporary arrangement ... I tried to help that woman, I wanted to help. All that trouble I went to, all those years, to land up here, in court. What have I got out of it? Bother and worry, that's all. Bother and worry."

fields.headline: Not funny
fields.trailText: Scott Capurro writes: "If I've got a good joke and a point to make, why is it bad?" (Straight jacket, G2, November 23). Can he explain, in the light of the decimation of six million Jews, the point of his line "Holocaust schmolocaust, can't they whine about something else"? And quite why this is amusing?
fields.body:
Scott Capurro writes: "If I've got a good joke and a point to make, why is it bad?" (Straight jacket, G2, November 23). Can he explain, in the light of the decimation of six million Jews, the point of his line "Holocaust schmolocaust, can't they whine about something else"? And quite why this is amusing?

I saw Capurro's show in Edinburgh and, rather than being impressed that he had the audacity to call Jesus a cock-sucker, I wondered where the humour lay. Shock tactics alone are neither clever nor amusing - anyone can make obscene observations. And if Capurro wants his audiences to view him as a comic, rather than a queer comic, perhaps he should stop harping on about his sexuality in his act.

Marianne Levy
Cambridge

webTitle: Ally seen as dupe of the Jackal

fields.headline: Ally seen as dupe of the Jackal
fields.trailText: A prominent German Green told a court yesterday that his radical comrade of the 1960s, Hans-Joachim Klein, was a disturbed, aggressive man who saw the terrorist Carlos the Jackal as a heroic James Bond figure.
fields.body:
A prominent German Green told a court yesterday that his radical comrade of the 1960s, Hans-Joachim Klein, was a disturbed, aggressive man who saw the terrorist Carlos the Jackal as a heroic James Bond figure.

The murder trial in Frankfurt was halted temporarily when the Green party cadre and European parliament member, Daniel Cohn-Bendit, wept during testimony that portrayed Mr Klein as an idealist exploited by recruiters of a terrorist group called the Revolutionary Cells.

Mr Klein, 52, is charged with three counts of murder and three of attempted murder in connection with the 1975 kidnapping of Opec ministers in Vienna. Klein denies shooting any of those slain.

Mr Cohn-Bendit helped lead 1960s student protests and knew Mr Klein in a leftwing circle that included Joschka Fischer, who is now Germany's foreign minister.

Mr Klein saw Carlos the Jackal's milieu "as a James Bond-like world with contacts with secret services and visits to Arab palaces", the MEP said.

There were two Kleins, he added: the tender one who wanted to help, and the militant one. Mr Klein over-identified with the injustices of this world and "went a bit too far".

Mr Klein was shot and seriously injured in the stomach during the kidnapping, but was treated and allowed to fly to Algiers with his accomplices and their hostages. He later took refuge in Libya before going into hiding.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: The thought of Maggie
fields.trailText: While Andrew Anderson (Letters, November 23) may disagree, when Michael White and Ian Traynor write "No 10 distinguishes..." (Angry Blair lambasts anti-EU nonsense, November 22) they are not telling us how to think, they are reporting the opinion of Alastair Campbell and the prime minister.
fields.body:
While Andrew Anderson (Letters, November 23) may disagree, when Michael White and Ian Traynor write "No 10 distinguishes..." (Angry Blair lambasts anti-EU nonsense, November 22) they are not telling us how to think, they are reporting the opinion of Alastair Campbell and the prime minister.

While saying that, I am glad that the Guardian has moments of subjective or personal reporting on issues of contention. Particularly with regard to Europe, the Guardian's journalists should be praised for taking a line that stands in sharp contrast to the kneejerk rants of its peers.

Just because Alastair Campbell says it, doesn't make it a lie. Anyway, I think we can trust Guardian readers to make their own minds up.

Tom Freke
London
tom.freke@intinsider.com

Why do we pay so much attention to Baroness Thatcher's xenophobic comments about Europe (Thatcher's EU attack marks end of affair, November 23)? If any other public figure were to make similar utterances, they'd be pilloried or simply ignored.

Not very long ago, in a speech, the baroness told us that God had separated Britain from mainland Europe "for a reason". Isn't she aware of the land bridge that used to exist, until rising sea levels drowned it? Isn't she aware of our pan-European lineage: part Roman, part Dane, part Norman French, but mostly Saxon German? Has she forgotten that our royal family is of German descent? Most importantly, does she have any appreciation of the causes of the rise of German fascism?

She talks about the "continent of Europe" as though it was a foreign realm, nothing to do with these islands. If the British Isles are not part of the continent of Europe, where precisely are they situated? Does she believe that these islands are a floating colony, drifting in the general direction of North America?

Geoffrey D Palmer
York
gdp@lineone.net

Where was I the day Thatcher resigned (Where were you on the day she quit?, November 22)? In heaven.

Dr Martin Cloonan
Musselburgh, East Lothia
M.Cloonan@educ.gla.ac.uk

Much as I love the odd walk down memory lane, I can't help but feel that, when the current government is considering privatising the tube and air traffic control, our fond look at the fall of Thatcherism might be a tad premature.

Adam Kimmel
London
adamk@zoom.co.uk

fields.headline: Please tackle rugby bias
fields.trailText: Wednesday's coverage of "rugby" in the Guardian consisted almost entirely of rugby union, apart from a couple of column inches about player strikes in rugby league. It completely overlooked the fact that the Rugby (League) World Cup final will be held on Saturday at Old Trafford. Both teams contain athletes who would leave England Rugby Union's finest floundering.
fields.body:
Wednesday's coverage of "rugby" in the Guardian consisted almost entirely of rugby union, apart from a couple of column inches about player strikes in rugby league. It completely overlooked the fact that the Rugby (League) World Cup final will be held on Saturday at Old Trafford. Both teams contain athletes who would leave England Rugby Union's finest floundering.

When are you going to represent both codes equally? When are you going to cease referring to rugby union as "rugby"?

I coach an under-14s rugby (league) team in a relatively small northern town and have 20 registered players, with more wanting to join every week. There are two other teams in the town in the same age group. The local rugby union club boasts one team and there isn't another for miles.

This local dominance of league over union appears to have some national resonance: the Australia/Samoa rugby league game attracted 3.2m BBC viewers, whereas a home nation rugby union team (Scotland) could only muster 2.2m viewers.

Do not tell me that rugby league is only a northern sport. The game is played in all of the armed services, almost all universities and the southern-based Conference League is going from strength to strength. On a national level, 16,000 people attended the game involving Wales at Cardiff's new stadium.

John Short
Keighley, West Yorkshire
KeighleyTown@aol.com

webTitle: Letters: Art is in a shocking state

fields.headline: Art is in a shocking state
fields.trailText: Nicholas Serota, in trying to explain why modern art should shock, asks: "Is this art which can have meaning for the many or is it simply for the few, those critics, curators and collectors who form an inner circle?" (Comment, November 23). Is this a genuine question open to debate?
fields.body:
Nicholas Serota, in trying to explain why modern art should shock, asks: "Is this art which can have meaning for the many or is it simply for the few, those critics, curators and collectors who form an inner circle?" (Comment, November 23). Is this a genuine question open to debate?

A group calling themselves the Stuckists (because they were accused of being "stuck in the past"), in reaction to this Tate-Serota view, put on a rival exhibition, The Real Turner Prize, to coincide with the annual Turner Prize exhibition. But Simon Wilson, curator at the Tate, claims that they have picked an unfortunate year to mount a protest because this year, paint on canvas is on show at Tate Modern. Landscapes can now be found alongside "rubbish skip art". A cynic might be tempted to ask whether this is just a case of tokenism. An optimist might see here the beginning of dialogue. But are we meant to align ourselves with one side or another if we are even to engage in this dialogue - neo-Luddite stuckism or modern, Britart "unstuckism"? What we really seem stuck with is a form of discourse so polarised it prevents us focusing on what might help illuminate our understanding of aesthetics and culture. It has been reduced to a simplistic exchange of playground taunts: my form of art is more real than yours.

Jane Green
London

That Nicholas Serota has the nerve to refer to "local enthusiasm for Antony Gormley's Angel of the North" is an affront to any right-thinking Geordie. Why does he think we refer to it as the Gateshead Flasher? Or, alternatively, a rusty aeroplane nose-diving into the hillside, an eyesore for the morning motorist struggling through traffic jams to work.

At least the butchered animals in formaldehyde and the dirty bed linen are confined to the obscurity of an "art" gallery.

Des R Hub
South Shields, Co Durham
Hub@Cardiff.ac.uk

Nicholas Serota's comparison of Matisse and Hockney to the work of the exhibitionists he is so moved by says little about the aesthetic sensibility of the British public but a lot about his inability to distinguish between art, which has the power to excite and enthuse people, and mere sensationalism, which gets people to visit his galleries.

People slow down and gawp at road accidents. It doesn't make them art.

David Pardey
Wells, Somerset
david@teamsthatwork.co.uk

Since I am an atheist, I do not believe that the wafers and wine of the Catholic mass are literally the body and blood of Christ. Why then should I accept Michael Craig-Martin's claim (Like all modern art it's here to stay, November 23) that he has transformed a glass of water on a glass shelf into an oak tree when the evidence of my senses tells me this is not true?

Just as Peter was once compelled to deny Christ, Craig-Martin was once compelled to deny his own claim - in 1976 his work was impounded by Australian customs officials because its crate was labelled "An Oak Tree" and importing plants was forbidden; to gain its release Craig-Martin had to admit that the crate did not contain an oak tree.

John A Walker
London

Interesting to read of Tracey Emin's jubilation at the demise of Margaret Thatcher (G2, November 22). It doesn't seem to have stopped her doing business with the man whose advertising agency threw its weight behind the election campaigns, Charles Saatchi.

John Keane
London

fields.headline: Men's work
fields.trailText: I work from home (not entirely a euphemism) and we let a room, usually to a foreign student (Letters, November 23). We've had dozens of them from all over Europe - men and women, mostly delightful. But, as evening comes and they see me in my apron, preparing something delectable for the huntress as she brings back the catch, I have lost count of the times I have heard them say: "My faather - e dunno where the keetchen ees," sniggering self-congratulatorily into their Jean-Paul Gaultier kerchiefs. Perhaps one of the tasks for our brave lads in the new European rapid-rebuttal unit might be to instruct our allies on this useful piece of domestic topography?

fields.headline: More fireworks
fields.trailText: Unlike Catherine Bennett (G2, November 23), I am not in the least bit interested in who is to blame over the London firework fiasco. I simply want the fireworks. And if London Underground can't or won't run a train service, then like many thousands of others, I'm happy to walk, cycle, roller-skate or bus it. I've been looking forward to this for nearly 12 months.

fields.headline: Caroline Benn
fields.standfirst: Champion of comprehensive education who guarded her privacy from the intrusions of political life
fields.trailText: Champion of comprehensive education who guarded her privacy from the intrusions of political life
fields.body:
Caroline Benn, who has died aged 74, achieved the extraordinary feat of securing an independent academic status for her work in education while winning widespread political admiration for the way in which she managed the very difficult business of being married to one of the most prominent postwar socialists in Britain, Tony Benn. And she did this while remaining a determinedly private person.

She was famous in education circles for her heroic commitment to the principles of comprehensive education. She was equally popular on the political left, among the many distinguished friends she and her husband made together, and in his constituencies, because she was personable, funny and unstinting in her support of the Labour party cause. Yet she managed to balance her public and personal life, raise four children and keep herself out of the public spotlight. It was difficult, but she did it.

She won considerable praise for doing so from a variety of sources. Dora Gaitskell, wife of the Labour leader of the late 1950s and early 1960s, once commended her to Tony Benn - and, according to his diaries, "touched my heart" - for having brought up her children without any fuss. In 1957, a group of Labour party friends, including Richard Crossman, told Tony that they had voted Caroline "the best wife for a leader of the Labour party". Susan Crosland wrote in her memoir of her late husband, the sometime Labour minister and author of The Future Of Socialism, Anthony Crosland, of the "wisecrack candour" that was part of Caroline Benn's attraction.

But, perhaps because of the intense public scrutiny to which her husband was constantly subjected, Caroline Benn went to great lengths never to reveal herself unwittingly in public. She did not give interviews, and there is scarcely a meaningful reference to her in the newspaper cuttings libraries that she and her husband learned so much to detest.

Yet even while she was performing this modern miracle role - juggling all the balls of wife, mother, political partner, academic and author, and keeping out of the newspapers - her husband was, in fact, revealing the reality. The published diaries that Tony Benn so assiduously kept across his long political career tell it all. Theirs was one of the great love matches, and it is all there in his records. Caroline is on every other page; advising him on political issues, expressing her opinion, accompanying him everywhere - abroad, to parties, and round the corner to friends.

Here we are in September 1959: "Caroline's advice was, as always, the most sensible: 'The most important thing is that you should be seen to be an easy man to work with.'" Then, in March 1960, with Labour's national executive committee (NEC) discussing rewriting clause 4: "Caroline said: 'Keep your mouth shut today.'" Again, in October 1960, when Benn himself resigned from the NEC, he noted: "Caroline was as sweet as can be, but she thought I shouldn't have done it."

She was very influential in his political career, and is personally credited with having suggested the title of the Labour manifesto for the 1964 general election; she proposed The New Britain, and it eventually became Let's Go With Labour For The New Britain.

In one volume of Tony Benn's diaries, there are no fewer than 166 page references to his wife, and neither the frequency nor the warmth about "my Caroline" diminish with the passage of the years: "Caroline was wonderful"; "Caroline, who is much braver than I am"; "She is a marvellous woman and I am quite exceptionally fortunate in being married to her"; "That is Caroline all over - tremendously modest and yet determined"; and, on August 2 1973: "25 years ago today, I met Caroline."

They met over tea at Worcester College, Oxford, in 1949 and, nine days later, Tony Benn proposed to her on a park bench in the city. Later, he bought the bench from Oxford city council and installed it in the garden of their house in Holland Park; in June 1999, on their golden wedding anniversary, she put on the red striped dress she had worn that night. They planned, some years ago, to be buried together in the garden of their house in Essex, with the bench to mark the grave.

Caroline Middleton DeCamp came from Cincinnati, Ohio, a member of a family descended from three French Huguenot brothers who fled to America in the 17th century. Her father, and both her grandfathers, were lawyers, and her maternal great-grandfather was a United States solicitor-general. She graduated from Vassar College in 1945, and got a second degree at the University of Cincinnati in 1948, the year she came to England. After her marriage, she got a master's degree at University College, London, in 1951.

In 1964, Tony and Caroline Benn decided to move their children from Westminster preparatory school to Holland Park comprehensive school, one of the first in the country. From then on, Caroline, who was to become the chair of governors at Holland Park for 13 years (and, at 35 years, the school's longest-serving governor), devoted a great deal of her time and energy to the subject of comprehensive education.

She was president of the Socialist Education Association, co-founder of the Campaign for Comprehensive Education and a member of the Inner London Education Authority (1970-77). With Professor Brian Simon, she wrote Halfway There (1970), a report on the British comprehensive system, and she followed it up with another co-authorship, with Professor Clyde Chitty, on the same subject, Thirty Years On (1997).

In the meantime, she also co-wrote Higher Education For Everyone (1982). Her best known book was a biography of Keir Hardie (1992). In 1980, she made a television film, Carry On Comprehensives, and she also wrote a novel, Lion In A Den Of Daniels, about an American girl in London. A tutor at the Open University, she was a lecturer at Ken- sington and Hammersmith Further Education College from 1970 to 1996.

She is survived by her husband, her children Stephen, Hilary, Melissa and Joshua, and 10 grandchildren.

Professor Clyde Chitty writes: I first met Caroline Benn in 1966. I was in London, just down from Leicester University and keen to get involved with the Comprehensive Schools Committee. Thus it was that I joined the CSC, then operating from the Benn family home in Holland Park Avenue. I was to work with her on education for the next three decades.

The CSC had been founded the previous year. It was the time of the new Labour government's circular 10/65, which requested local authorities to put forward plans for comprehensivisation. By the end of a CSC day, I could be pretty tired. Not so Caroline, then bringing up four children; hers was an unbelievable energy, and she had a wonderful sense of humour.

I am a person who likes order. Caroline, meanwhile, would be surrounded by vast mounds of material and seemed disorganised, but she could always find what she wanted. Anthony Crosland was then Labour's secretary of state for education and science, and civil servants - and Crosland - would ring Caroline for advice; they did so because she had developed an encyclopaedic knowledge of comprehensives around the country. Her book, Halfway There, was the first major study on the subject. From those days in the 1960s, into the late 1990s, we worked together and edited Comprehensive Education, complete with its annual survey of the state of schools.

Caroline saw the British education system with a foreigner's eyes. She hated British divisiveness and elitism, and, when her own children were at Holland Park comprehensive, she wanted the best for them, and for the school - and for that best to be extended to all. Utterly informal, with that American vitality, she was classless. With her, there was none of that "presence", that sense of being with someone important. She could relate to anyone.

I will think of her standing in front of my classes in south-east London. I think of one Friday afternoon in particular, in Penge. The students were from poor, underprivileged backgrounds, and most of that class were Afro-Caribbean. They were enthralled. The class ended. On his way out, one pupil paused; "Lovely coat, ma'am," he said. She was fabulous.

 Caroline Benn, educationalist, born October 13 1926; died November 22 2000

webTitle: Ex-king of Greece reclaims his lost palaces

fields.headline: Ex-king of Greece reclaims his lost palaces
fields.standfirst: Human rights court says estates illegally confiscated
fields.trailText: Greece's former king, Constantine, was last night basking in the afterglow of a controversial legal victory in which the European court of human rights ruled that the Greek government had been wrong to confiscate his palaces and estates six years ago and should now pay him compensation.
fields.body:
Greece's former king, Constantine, was last night basking in the afterglow of a controversial legal victory in which the European court of human rights ruled that the Greek government had been wrong to confiscate his palaces and estates six years ago and should now pay him compensation.

In a landmark decision which is expected to lead to a spate of similar claims from other deposed royals across Europe, the court in Strasbourg agreed that the contested properties belonged to Constantine as an individual and not to the Greek state.

It also declared that the socialist government of Andreas Papandreou had violated the former king's right to the "peaceful enjoyment of his possessions".

Constantine, 60, who has lived in exile in London since he was deposed by a military junta in 1967, filed the claim along with two other relatives: his sister Princess Irene, who now lives in Madrid, and his aunt, Princess Ekaterini, who lives in Buckinghamshire.

The ruling is a severe embarrassment to the current Greek government which has disputed the claim and is loath to give him a single drachma.

The margin of his victory is likely to rankle with Athens - the claim was approved by a 15 -2 margin. One of the two dissenting voices was the Greek judge on the panel.

At stake is a trio of exquisite palaces and estates which the Greek government claims were obtained by Constan tine's ancestors under dubious circumstances.

They include the sprawling estate of Tatoi, just outside Athens, where the royal cemetery is located; Mon Repos, the glorious summer retreat on Corfu where the Duke of Edinburgh was born; and the Polydendri forest estate situated in the foothills of Mount Olympus. The estimated value of the property, thought to total 34,000 acres, is around £300m.

Speaking yesterday at his home in Hampstead, Constantine, who is godfather to Prince William, proclaimed himself "extremely grateful" to the court in France.

In a statement, he denied the objective was to secure a cash settlement. "We would like to avoid any burden on the taxpayers of Greece," he said.

"That would be achieved if the government were to return our home, the graves of our parents and ancestors, and our property. That is our primary aim."

The Greek government made it clear yesterday that it was unlikely to hand back any of the disputed property but would reluctantly now start to think about some kind of financial compensation.

"I believe that the whole issue from the beginning was financial and about the hundreds of billions [of drachmas] he was asking for," Elisavet Papazoi, the country's deputy foreign minister, said.

In a sign that the Greek government may be unwilling to settle amicably with Constantine, she also claimed that the ex-king would now be liable to pay tax on the disputed properties. It remained unclear last night how much this might be.

Constantine is believed to be looking for a settlement in the region of £1bn. The Strasbourg court did not name a figure, instead giving the two parties six months to come to an agreement.

The Greek monarchy was formally abolished after a 1973 referendum and their land was expropriated. This expropriation was reversed in 1979, but in 1994, the socialist government confiscated Constantine's property to ensure that it could never be used to reestablish his family in Greece.

Ironically, Constantine has enjoyed a higher profile in Greece of late after being appointed an honorary member of the International Olympic Committee to promote Athens as a venue for the 2004 games.

But he has dared to return to his homeland only twice since 1967 - the first time for his mother's funeral in 1981 and the second time in 1993, when his yacht was chased out of Greek waters by gunboats and fighter planes.

His case is not the only one involving ex-royals to be heard before the Strasbourg court - Italy's former royal family is seeking to overturn a 54-year-old ban forbidding its male heirs from stepping on to Italian soil.
fields.bodyText: Greece's former king, Constantine, was last night basking in the afterglow of a controversial legal victory in which the European court of human rights ruled that the Greek government had been wrong to confiscate his palaces and estates six years ago and should now pay him compensation. In a landmark decision which is expected to lead to a spate of similar claims from other deposed royals across Europe, the court in Strasbourg agreed that the contested properties belonged to Constantine as an individual and not to the Greek state. It also declared that the socialist government of Andreas Papandreou had violated the former king's right to the "peaceful enjoyment of his possessions". Constantine, 60, who has lived in exile in London since he was deposed by a military junta in 1967, filed the claim along with two other relatives: his sister Princess Irene, who now lives in Madrid, and his aunt, Princess Ekaterini, who lives in Buckinghamshire. The ruling is a severe embarrassment to the current Greek government which has disputed the claim and is loath to give him a single drachma. The margin of his victory is likely to rankle with Athens - the claim was approved by a 15 -2 margin. One of the two dissenting voices was the Greek judge on the panel. At stake is a trio of exquisite palaces and estates which the Greek government claims were obtained by Constan tine's ancestors under dubious circumstances. They include the sprawling estate of Tatoi, just outside Athens, where the royal cemetery is located; Mon Repos, the glorious summer retreat on Corfu where the Duke of Edinburgh was born; and the Polydendri forest estate situated in the foothills of Mount Olympus. The estimated value of the property, thought to total 34,000 acres, is around £300m. Speaking yesterday at his home in Hampstead, Constantine, who is godfather to Prince William, proclaimed himself "extremely grateful" to the court in France. In a statement, he denied the objective was to secure a cash settlement. "We would like to avoid any burden on the taxpayers of Greece," he said. "That would be achieved if the government were to return our home, the graves of our parents and ancestors, and our property. That is our primary aim." The Greek government made it clear yesterday that it was unlikely to hand back any of the disputed property but would reluctantly now start to think about some kind of financial compensation. In a sign that the Greek government may be unwilling to settle amicably with Constantine, she also claimed that the ex-king would now be liable to pay tax on the disputed properties. It remained unclear last night how much this might be. Constantine is believed to be looking for a settlement in the region of £1bn. The Strasbourg court did not name a figure, instead giving the two parties six months to come to an agreement. The Greek monarchy was formally abolished after a 1973 referendum and their land was expropriated. This expropriation was reversed in 1979, but in 1994, the socialist government confiscated Constantine's property to ensure that it could never be used to reestablish his family in Greece. fields.headline: Fibrenet share price tumbles
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Shares in Fibernet, a fibre-optic telecoms operator, yesterday fell nearly 23% after the company asked shareholders to provide £77m, principally to set up a network in France.
fields.body:
Shares in Fibernet, a fibre-optic telecoms operator, yesterday fell nearly 23% after the company asked shareholders to provide £77m, principally to set up a network in France.

The share price dropped 302.5p to 1,025p as Fibernet invited investors to buy four new shares for every 15 they own at a reduced price of 600p each. This is less that half of Wednesday's closing price of 1,328p for its existing stock.

The company said a deeply discounted rights issue was the best way to raise money while protecting the interests of shareholders.

The money will be used to set up a French network and triple its UK capacity.

The announcement came at the same time as the company, reporting preliminary results for the year ended August 31, said it had moved into profitability for the first time.

Pre-tax profit was £3.4m, compared to a loss of £4.6m a year ago. Sales rose from £14.6m to £41.8m.

Charles McGregor, the chief executive, said: "I am pleased with the financial results for the year and the progress we have made in developing and executing our strategy. This, together with the continued growth in our addressable market, provides us with firm foundations on which to build the business going forward."

The fundraising will pay for about 7,000 km of fibre in France.

fields.headline: Indonesian art 'finds' leave critics groaning
fields.trailText: An Indonesian art dealer could make millions of pounds tonight when he holds an auction in Jakarta of 115 long-lost masterpieces that he claims to have discovered in unlikely places across the archipelago.
fields.body:
An Indonesian art dealer could make millions of pounds tonight when he holds an auction in Jakarta of 115 long-lost masterpieces that he claims to have discovered in unlikely places across the archipelago.

J Syahdam acquired one of two Van Goghs from a remote corner of Sumatra, he found a Renoir on a central Java plantation, one of two Picassos came from a flea market, and a Chagall turned up in a Jakarta satellite town.

He bought a Modigliani from a frame seller, a Monet was lurking on an east Java tobacco farm, a Pissaro was gathering dust in the industrial heartland of central Java, he has forgotten where he got hold of the Goya and so the list goes on.

Or that is what he would like the world to believe. The reality, according to almost every other Jakarta-based art dealer, critic, auctioneer and curator, is that the exhibition, titled The Old Painting Pre World War II , on display in a five-star hotel, is nothing more than a collection of modern forgeries.

"This should be renamed the festival of all the fakers in Jakarta," said a respected museum curator, Amir Sidharta, as he wandered round pointing out obvious blemishes in practically every painting. "Or rather just the bad fakers because there are much better copies around."

Mr Sidharta admitted that it was conceivable that one or possibly two paintings by such masters could turn up in Indonesia but not such a haul all at once.

"Who in the world is gullible enough to believe that all these paintings would suddenly appear, in very mysterious circumstances, in remote corners of Indonesia?" he asked. "And if you owned one of these masterpieces you wouldn't sell it here, you'd go to somewhere like London or New York."

Pasteur by Goya is the worst, he says. "This is just a quick reproduction done on top of another picture. It's laughable."

The Corn's Farmer [sic] by Van Gogh - which is listed as being worth between £1.8m and £2.8m - rated little better and Scenery, by Monet, did not even merit comment.

Mr Sidharta said he was offered one of the paintings, The Final Court by Indonesia- based painter L Coroot, earlier this year. "Except then it was by a different artist."

Few of the visitors to the exhibition, who surprisingly numbered only a few dozen for such a supposedly prestigious event, were taken in.

"Some of them, like Ballet Dancers by Degas, are quite good but they just don't seem right," said Boy Luna, a Filipino art teacher. "And I've never seen any of them in an art book."

But Mr Syahdam, who refused to reveal his first name "for security reasons", is sticking to his guns.

"They have all been laboratory tested using 15 separate criteria and the results show that they are the correct age," he said, brandishing a sheaf of dodgy-looking certificates.

But one of his assistants, Adelia Rangkuti, admitted that there had been problems persuading experts to come to authenticate the paintings. "We faxed 30 museums around the world two weeks ago inviting people to come and look at them," she said. "But we never heard back from anyone." Ms Rangkuti also confessed that none of the paintings are insured. She struggled to explain why there had not been more publicity for the exhibition.

"We wanted to make this an event for Indonesian art lovers," she said. "We did not want it to be too big."

One of Mr Syahdam's "experts", local artist Sulebar Soekarman, said that the critics were narrow-minded and looking at the exhibition from the wrong perspective. "The question is not whether they're original or fake but whether they're aesthetically beautiful," he said.

Abdul Rachman, the curator of Jakarta's Fine Art and Ceramic Museum, disagreed. "Indonesia's reputation in the world is already bad and this is just going to make it worse," he said. "It reflects the state of what's going on in the country at large. People reckon they can do what they want and get away with it."

Mr Sidharta hoped the consequences would not be too bad. "This is such a bad joke, hopefully we'll just be laughing about it in six months."

fields.headline: Exiled Sudanese leader goes home
fields.trailText: The Sudanese opposition leader and former prime minister Sadeq al-Mahdi left Cairo for home yesterday after four years of self-imposed exile.
fields.body:
The Sudanese opposition leader and former prime minister Sadeq al-Mahdi left Cairo for home yesterday after four years of self-imposed exile.

Airport sources said Mr Mahdi was travelling on a special Libyan plane, accompanied by many members of his Umma party. "My return was not conditional," Mr Mahdi said yesterday. "But we are willing to exchange dialogue."

The party reopened offices in Sudan this year after Mr Mahdi mended fences with President Omar Hassan al-Bashir, the man who ousted him as prime minister in a military coup in 1989.

After Mr Mahdi's reconciliation with President Bashir, the Umma party broke away from the opposition groups which are fighting Khartoum's Islamist government in an alliance that includes the southern rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA).

Sudan is due to hold presidential and parliamentary elections next month. Some leading politicians, including Mr Mahdi, are boycotting the elections, saying they cannot be free and fair in the current atmosphere.

Mr Mahdi said he would use channels other than parliament to bring about democratic reform and end Sudan's 17-year civil war, launched by the SPLA in 1983 in a bid to secure autonomy for the black south from the Muslim, Arabised north. Up to 2m people have been killed in fighting and war-induced famines.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Up to 70 inmates awaiting trial died on Tuesday in mysterious circumstances in a jail in the northern Mozambican town of Montepuez, a centre of recent anti-government rioting.
fields.body:
Mystery as 70 prisoners die

Up to 70 inmates awaiting trial died on Tuesday in mysterious circumstances in a jail in the northern Mozambican town of Montepuez, a centre of recent anti-government rioting.

The prime minister, Pascoal Mocumbi, was quoted as saying that the prisoners had died "apparently without violence", adding that the deaths might have been caused by suffocation due to overcrowding, food poisoning or lack of water.
Reuters, Maputo

US resident in China spy case

A US resident arrested in China after she helped publicise the government's crackdown on the Falun Gong spiritual movement went on trial amid secrecy yesterday, facing spying charges that could draw a lengthy prison sentence.

Teng Chunyan is charged with passing intelligence to foreign organisations, diplomats said.
AP, Beijing

Attack linked to embassy blasts

One of the two suicide bombers believed to have carried out the attack in Aden last month on USS Cole, in which 17 sailors died, is linked to the 1998 bombings of the US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, a Yemeni source said yesterday.

A composite sketch of the suspected suicide bomber appeared to match that of a man wanted for questioning about the embassy attacks, which killed 224 people.
AP, Sana'a

Church ban for non-Christians

The mayor of the northern Italian town of Rovato has passed an order banning non-Christians from going within 15 metres (50ft) of the local churches, a move that has outraged opposition councillors.

Roberto Manenti, a member of the anti-immigrant Northern League, said the order was a response to similar measures in other countries, where access to certain areas was banned on religious grounds.
Philip Willan, Rome

fields.headline: No: 1768
fields.standfirst: Cindy Crawford
fields.trailText: Cindy Crawford
fields.body:
Aha! Cindy Crawford, the face of erm, er...
The word you're looking for is "Revlon".

Actually, I was going to say "the 80s".
That's effectively the same thing.

I see, I get you, so Cindy's cruising back in on the whole 80s revival is she?
No, she has been given the flick.

Nice, I like it. Good Charlie's Angels throwback. She's on to a winner there.
No, listen to me. Cindy Crawford, supermodel, fitness guru and all-round mole-faced wonder, has been fired as the face of Revlon.

Jeepers! It can't be so! Some things are just made to go together - love and marriage, the horse and carriage, Cindy Crawford and Revlon...
As unbelievable as it may sound, after 11 years together, they are going their separate ways. They get the multi-million-pound cosmetics business, she gets custody of the kids.

But why?
She's too boring.

What? They didn't actually say that did they?
No, they said: "We want a new and exciting image." Apparently, Cindy's beautiful visage has become so familiar that she was now nigh on invisible to the make-up buying public.

Oh right. They mean she's boring.
That's about the gist of it.

Hang on one catwalkin' minute. If my shower is leaking I call a plumber, if I want a light-but- tasty snack I eat a Cracker Barrel. If I want a boring-but-beautiful woman, I summon a supermodel. Surely they do exactly what it says on the can.
No. You see, the new breed of supermodel is a girl who "is quite famous in her own right already". She's a little bit quirky, a little bit je ne sais quoi . She reads books with more words than pictures. She just happens to have legs six inches longer than the average giraffe and cheekbones sharp as razors.

I see. How times have changed. So you're telling me supermodels aren't boring any more.
Well, I wouldn't go that far.

Coming soon:
"Pope is Catholic" shocker.

webTitle: Capitalists revive the age of empire

fields.headline: Capitalists revive the age of empire
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: Fundraisers defy conventional view of conglomerates
fields.trailText: They are the new conglomerates that are buying up some of Britain's best known businesses and yet their names are largely unknown outside financial circles. They have no trouble raising money - often from your pension fund. But their businesses often comprise companies the stock market has shunned. Stranger still, this new breed of mover and shaker has the support of Tony Blair. They are venture capitalists and their influence is growing by the week.
fields.body:
They are the new conglomerates that are buying up some of Britain's best known businesses and yet their names are largely unknown outside financial circles. They have no trouble raising money - often from your pension fund. But their businesses often comprise companies the stock market has shunned. Stranger still, this new breed of mover and shaker has the support of Tony Blair. They are venture capitalists and their influence is growing by the week.

L&G Ventures, a private equity firm, is expected to buy the £700m pub estate put up for sale by Bass and another venture capitalist, Doughty Hanson, is a favourite to take over the £3bn hotel division being put up for sale by Granada-Compass.

The success of this sector was underlined yesterday by interim financial results from 3i Group, the largest UK venture capitalist by number of deals.

It reported a total return on capital of £1bn, producing a 20% payback on shareholder funds. In the six months to September 30 the group sucked in £511m of new funds compared to £327m during the same period of 1999. Not bad for a company that holds stakes in Informa, publisher of Britain's oldest daily newspaper - Lloyd's List - as well as biotech group Cambridge Antibodies and IT hardware specialist Bookham Technology.

Brian Larkham, the chief executive, says: "This result is a huge outperformance of the indices." The performance is specially impressive given the rollercoaster ride stocks such as Bookham have been on.

Perhaps the best known venture capitalist is Nomura, which hunts out unfashionable companies. On the surface Nomura is a Japanese investment bank, yet its London-based Principal Finance Group, run by William Hague's best mate, Guy Hands, has a portfolio that takes in almost 5,000 pubs, making it the country's largest licensed premises landlord.

It also owns a 50% stake in the Thorn radio rental business now known as Box Clever plus 50,000 houses it purchased from the Ministry of Defence, managed under the Annington Homes banner.

Nomura has been tipped as potential purchaser of a variety of other projects, from the ill-fated Millennium dome, which it pulled back from at the last minute, to Welsh Water, which it is still looking at, and Associated British Ports, which it now appears to have given up on.

Nomura bought Angel Trains and bookmaker William Hill but sold both in little over 12 months and is estimated to have made a £500m profit for its efforts.

Doughty Hanson is another of the new power brokers which even shares part of the name of a former old-style conglomerate.

This private equity group has raised $4bn over the past four years and made itself part of Britain's biggest combined miller and baker through its involvement in the acquisition of Rank Hovis McDougal, maker of Hovis bread and Mr Kipling cakes.

Other Doughty Hanson investments include Powderject, which has developed a dry powder, needle-free injection system, and TAG Heuer International, the Swiss watch manufacturer.

All venture capitalists claim to have their particular niche and investment philosophy but most believe they can make money where others have not by more robust management and financial controls, by spinning off poor performers and bringing together similar businesses. After a period of intensive care the venture capitalists hope to make their exit through a trade sale or stock market listing.

Andrew Burrows, director of the Centre for Management Buyout Research, established by Barclays Private Capital and Deloitte & Touche, says there is no doubt some venture capitalists resemble new conglomerates. But the chances of them suffering the same fate as a Williams or the Hansons of old and being broken up is slim. Most are not publicly quoted and are answerable to institutional investors directly rather than private shareholders.

Their influence has certainly grown in providing funds for management buyouts or helping moves from the publicly quoted to the private sector.

Venture capital was at the forefront of new financing when companies as disparate as property group MEPC, United Biscuits and Gala Bingo went private.

Mr Burrows says there has been £7bn worth of such deals this year, double the figure for 1999. The buyout market generally is in its fifth record year with transactions worth £17.6bn to the end of September, compared to £16.9bn for the whole of 1999.

Some of the biggest venture capitalists in the world, Hicks Muse Tate and Furst (which was involved in the United Biscuits deal), Kohlberg Kravis Roberts (currently buying out chemicals group Laporte) and Texas Pacific (which helped buy Hillsdown Holdings last year) have set up big bases in London.

Smaller specialists companies from across the Atlantic such as Providence Equity and Heller Financial have also been building up their UK presence.

There is encouragement from the government, too, which sees this sector as a tool for encouraging entrepreneurship and creating jobs in start-up ventures. The recent pre-Budget statement from Gordon Brown was welcomed by the British Venture Capital Association. Vince O'Brian, chairman of its tax committee, said: "We are glad the government is now listening more acutely to the needs of our industry."

Quintin Barry, a private equity partner at Deloitte & Touche says venture capital is becoming "massively influential" and will be more so as pension funds find an increasing appetite for investing in them.

But in a world where the term conglomerate spells a stock market discount who would boast: "We own 70 businesses, with a combined turnover of €27bn operating in 25 countries and employing nearly 200,000 people." BTR 15 years ago? No, venture capital company CVC's newspaper advertisement yesterday.

Nomura bought Angel Trains and bookmaker William Hill but sold both in little over 12 months and is estimated to have made a £500m profit for its efforts. Doughty Hanson is another of the new power brokers which even shares part of the name of a former old-style conglomerate. This private equity group has raised $4bn over the past four years and made itself part of Britain's biggest combined miller and baker through its involvement in the acquisition of Rank Hovis McDougal, maker of Hovis bread and Mr Kipling cakes. Other Doughty Hanson investments include Powderject, which has developed a dry powder, needle-free injection system, and TAG Heuer International, the Swiss watch manufacturer. All venture capitalists claim to have their particular niche and investment philosophy but most believe they can make money where others have not by more robust management and financial controls, by spinning off poor performers and bringing together similar businesses. After a period of intensive care the venture capitalists hope to make their exit through a trade sale or stock market listing. Andrew Burrows, director of the Centre for Management Buyout Research, established by Barclays Private Capital and Deloitte & Touche, says there is no doubt some venture capitalists resemble new conglomerates. But the chances of them suffering the same fate as a Williams or the Hansons of old and being broken up is slim. Most are not publicly quoted and are answerable to institutional investors directly rather than private shareholders. Their influence has certainly grown in providing funds for management buyouts or helping moves from the publicly quoted to the private sector. Venture capital was at the forefront of new financing when companies as disparate as property group MEPC, United Biscuits and Gala Bingo went private. Mr Burrows says there has been £7bn worth of such deals this year, double the figure for 1999. The buyout market generally is in its fifth record year with transactions worth £17.6bn to the end of September, compared to £16.9bn for the whole of 1999. Some of the biggest venture capitalists in the world, Hicks Muse Tate and Furst (which was involved in the United Biscuits deal), Kohlberg Kravis Roberts (currently buying out chemicals group Laporte) and Texas Pacific (which helped buy Hillsdown Holdings last year) have set up big bases in London. Smaller specialists companies from across the Atlantic such as Providence Equity and Heller Financial have also been building up their UK presence. There is encouragement from the government, too, which sees this sector as a tool for encouraging entrepreneurship and creating jobs in start-up ventures. The recent pre-Budget statement from Gordon Brown was welcomed by the British Venture Capital Association. Vince O'Brian, chairman of its tax committee, said: "We are glad the government is now listening more acutely to the needs of our industry." Quintin Barry, a private equity partner at Deloitte & Touche says venture capital is becoming "massively influential" and will be more so as pension funds find an increasing appetite for investing in them. But in a world where the term conglomerate spells a stock market discount who would boast: "We own 70 businesses, with a combined turnover of €27bn operating in 25 countries and employing nearly 200,000 people." BTR 15 years ago? No, venture capital company CVC's newspaper advertisement yesterday.

webTitle: Comment: Polly Toynbee on the treatment of young offenders

fields.headline: Give them hope
fields.standfirst: Locking young offenders in violent sin bins just turns those already disturbed even madder and badder
fields.trailText: Locking young offenders in violent sin bins just turns those already disturbed even madder and badder
fields.body:
The Children's Society launches a timely blast at the disgraceful treatment of child offenders. Those who visit and inspect young offenders institutions are rendered almost speechless by much of what they see. After the horrors of Feltham, two more - Stoke Heath and Brinsford - will come under savage attack by the chief inspector of prisons shortly. Scores of violent, deeply damaged, angry and hopeless boys fight and bully each other, driving the vulnerable sometimes to suicide, with 994 incidents of self-harm reported last year alone - eating glass, cutting their wrists, banging their heads against walls. It is almost unthinkable that Britain has returned to a regime far worse than the borstals that were closed down 30 years ago.

Britain locks up more teenagers than any other European country. The age of criminal responsibility has been reduced to 10: even Turkey, the next lowest, fixes it at 12. The number of young people in prison custody rose by 11% this year - another 3,000 when crime has been falling for six years.

Most unjust of all are the 653 children and young people remanded in custody before their trials. "You cannot imagine the state they are in," says one inspector. He takes a case he observed: a 15-year-old arrested on a Friday was thrown into police cells for the weekend - no proper meals, no clothes, no contact, completely neglected. The boy was homeless, an escapee from care. On Monday he was handed over to a private escort company which took nine hours to take him to prison. (Most are far from home towns.) It was evening and he was thrown straight into a cell and left. "He was a zombie by then." From the next morning he was bullied and within two days he had his jaw smashed by an out-of-control 17-year-old.

The system cannot cope and many are locked in for 23 hours a day, just to keep order. On remand, most get nothing in the way of treatment, education or care. The average time between arrest and sentencing is 90 days. The gross abuse by the state of these children on remand is the worst scandal. The condition of many of those already sentenced is often scarcely better.

The Home Office response to the Children's Society and to Sir David Ramsbotham, chief inspector of prisons, is utterly inadequate. You have to understand, they say, these children are not little angels. Many are hardened criminals from criminal families who will never escape a life of crime. Many are one-boy crime waves, since 25% of youth crime is committed by just 3% of these teenagers. Norman Warner, chair of the youth justice board, put out a press release accusing the Children's Society of being "unrealistic in suggesting that no young persons under 18 should ever be imprisoned".

But no one is suggesting some of them shouldn't be locked up. The issue is how many, where, and under what regime - in secure units run by local authorities with a duty of care, or by hard-pressed, under-resourced prisons that turn the already disturbed madder and badder. The refusal of the courts to send the Bulger killers from a secure unit into a prison highlighted the sharp difference in regime - one is curative, at least in intent if not always in practice, while the other is containment in violent sin bins.

Behind all this is the government's usual peculiar ambivalence about doing good. In public it talks up prison and punishment, but in private it tries to do the right thing. The result is always the worst of all worlds. Gordon Brown does it too: he makes impassioned speeches about his progressive benefit increases to groups concerned with poverty, but talks prudence and business-friendly policy to the world at large. This double message ends up as no message about how remarkably well the poorest have fared.

S o too, Jack Straw talks tough about juvenile offenders - boasting that ratboys who used to be cautioned and let go are now being seized and dealt with at once. He makes even the good he does sound tough for fear of sounding soft.

The cheap populism of his language has two bad effects. First, the magistrates and judges are always hyper- sensitive to every home secretary's message. Prison populations soared as soon as Michael Howard began his "prison works" ranting. Since Jack Straw's regime began, 9% fewer crimes have been prosecuted, yet prison numbers have swelled because magistrates dished out more and longer sentences in response to the message from his lips. So as prisons fill, the regimes struggle harder to provide anything that might prevent criminals reoffending when they get out.

The second effect is that few who might be interested get to hear about the good the government is doing within the rest of the juvenile crime system. They hear Jack Straw's words and assume his entire programme is a Howard replica. But on the ground, good things are happening that should mean, eventually, that many fewer young people will end up behind bars.

Norman Warner's youth justice board oversees a whole new system that for the first time brings constructive sense to the way the young are treated. From last April, 155 youth offending teams in every area have pooled local budgets and staff so that teachers, doctors, police, probation and social workers concerned with one child or one family draw up a plan together to coordinate education, training, anger-management, cognitive behaviour or drug treat ment courses right from the first offence. For those given a new half- custody, half-community sentence, the same team runs the whole plan seamlessly, inside and out.

Jack Straw sounded punitive at the Labour conference, but he announced one of the most hopeful programmes for keeping the young out of prison. Starting next April, 2,500 of the worst juveniles (four or more offences) will get intensive surveillance and supervision programmes instead of custody. On electronic tags or reporting in from voice-recognition telephones, they will be forced to attend courses for at least 25 hours a week, curfewing often chaotic lives, teaching a better life in the community instead of how to be worse in prison. Currently 90% of young prisoners reoffend on release. If all this works, there is a reasonable chance many fewer will be locked up and fewer will reoffend.

But Labour and Jack Straw will get no credit for any of this while so many of the young are locked away in shameful conditions. Prison for juveniles costs £800 a week - barely enough for containment and far too little for the treatment they need. Better (though variable) local authority secure units cost £3,500. This comes down to money and high-quality staff and both must be found at once. The conditions some of these children are kept in breach the UN convention on the rights of the child, and the Children Act. If they were animals, the RSPCA would sue. It's no use the Home Office telling us how horrible these young criminals are. All that matters is making them better, not worse.

webTitle: End jail for under-18s, says Children's Society

fields.headline: End jail for under-18s, says Children's Society
fields.trailText: A national charity has called for an end to the jailing of under-18s.The Children's Society argues that locking up children is expensive and fails the community. Linda Steele reports.
fields.body:
A national charity has called for an end to the jailing of children in a report published today. The Children's Society argues that locking up children is expensive and fails the community.

In its Tough Justice report, the charity calls for an immediate end to the detention on remand of 15 and 16-year-olds and the phasing out of imprisonment for young people under 18.

The report has the backing of the chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, and the bishop for prisons, the Rev Robert Hardy.

But Lord Warner, chairman of the youth justice board, has dismissed the demand as "unrealistic". The board is a government agency set up earlier this year to reform the youth justice system.

In the past decade, 18 teenagers aged between 15 and 17 have committed suicide in young offender institutions. The charity said there are about 1,000 incidents of self-harm a year by young people in prison.

Sir David said that he had found conditions in young offender institutions so appalling, that if he had been a social services inspector he would have shut them down immediately.

"I strongly support the call for the immediate ending of remanding 15 and 16 year olds in prison custody," he said. "Their present treatment and the conditions in which they are held are not acceptable. If we continue to neglect these young people, if we continue to allow these conditions to prevail, we are setting a very, very dangerous trend for the nation as a whole."

The government was cautious in its response. Home Office minister Charles Clarke said he would be studying it carefully. He added that the government agreed that it was necessary to tackle the underlying problems which cause crime.

The report also calls for the age of criminal responsibility to be raised. Britain has one of the lowest ages in Europe (10 years old). More community alternatives to jail, such as restorative justice projects, should be available. As a last resort, local authority secure accommodation would be preferable to young offender institutions.

The authors estimate that most juvenile crime is caused by around 200 persistent young offenders. But the youth justice board rejected this figure, saying it was at least 10 times higher. The board also criticised claims that more young people were being locked up, saying the figure had remained stable.

Only about 200 15 and 16-year-olds are currently on remand awaiting sentence, according to the board's figures. Lord Warner agreed that more needed to be done to develop better community alternatives for offenders and improve regimes for those who are locked up. But he said: "Calling for something that cannot be achieved could damage the public credibility of the reforms now being implemented."

Mr Hardy said the church and the government had a "difference of focus" over crime and punishment. "The church has to speak for humanity and children, irrespective of the government. That is what I am doing," he said. "Our recommendations are not unrealistic. We need to do all we can on the serious issues of child protection. I am unrepentant about calling for that.

"To condemn 15- and 16-year-olds, give them a criminal record and not to do anything for them in a positive way is a disgrace in a society which still claims, in many respects, to be Christian."

fields.headline: Funding method 'hampers schools'
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ministers are hampering schools by making too much of their funding short term, with strings attached, the government's spending watchdog reports today.
fields.body:
Ministers are hampering schools by making too much of their funding short term, with strings attached, the government's spending watchdog reports today.

The audit commission calls for a halt to extra spending through the standards fund, the main lever used by the education secretary, David Blunkett, to inject cash into priorities such as literacy and numeracy.

The commission urges the government to take stock before ordering councils to delegate more money to schools. Ministers ordered councils to devolve 80% of their education budgets to schools last year and 85% this year, and want most councils to reach 90%.

The commission also criticises some headteachers for failing to link their budgets to their priorities and reports that up to 15% of schools have significant weaknesses in financial management.

Some £1.9bn, or 8%, of school spending will be directed by central government this year in England and Wales and will easily top £2bn next year. But the commission says: "Government should evaluate whether it is the best way to deliver national priorities. In particular, they must ask whether schools will be able to plan ahead effectively if a large proportion of their funding is short term and for specific activities."

Rather than extending the use of standards funds, government should evaluate whether they were the most effective way to deliver national priorities, it says

According to a commission survey, most headteachers welcomed the extra money in the standards fund, but complained of confusion about when it could be spent, a lack of flexibility and problems with planning ahead.

The report also urges a let-up in pressure on councils to release more money to schools - from government on the one hand, and from headteachers' associations on the other.

Many schools "had limited benefit" from the latest round of delegation.

Headteachers and governors in England and Wales now control 82% of money spent on schools - 10 years ago most controlled less than 5%. Ministers have been ratcheting up the requirements on councils to devolve money to schools but the commission reports that three-quarters of headteachers were happy with their local education authority's level of delegation.

It is "unlikely" that much greater gains could be made by pushing delegation further, the commission says. Instead the government should clarify what it expects from LEAs.

The commission rejects calls by headteachers' associations for a national funding formula for schools. Although it notes wide variations in the funding of schools of up to £1,600 in primary schools and £1,500 in secondary schools, about two-thirds of typical schools are funded within £200 of each other. "Funding choices are being made at the most appropriate level and most similar schools are getting comparable funding."

Andrew Foster, controller of the audit commission, said: "The present funding system needs to be made to work better, not replaced."

Estelle Morris, minister for school standards, said: "The audit commission has failed to recognise the key role the standards fund plays in providing ring-fenced support for national priorities." But reforms from next year would give schools more certainty about funding and more freedom on how to use the money.

She added: "We agree there are limits to how far delegation can be pushed ... but we do not accept delegation has gone too fast, or too far."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "I reject the criticism that secondary schools are not able to manage their budgets.

"The job of secondary schools is much harder until the government starts putting more money into core budgets."

fields.headline: Saints, sinners and courtesans
fields.standfirst: Andrew Clements on how to fill the discerning classical music lover's stocking
fields.trailText: Andrew Clements on how to fill the discerning classical music lover's stocking
fields.body:
Handel: Theodora
Gritton/Bickley/Blaze/Agnew/McCreesh
(Archiv, 3 CDs, £29.99)
Handel's penultimate English oratorio was largely overlooked until it was staged at Glyndebourne in 1996 by Peter Sellars when the performances highlighted the beauties in the score. Paul McCreesh's buoyant and sensitive recording has a British cast and does magnificent justice to the melodic invention: Susan Gritton as the martyred virgin and Robin Blaze and Paul Agnew as Didymus and Septimius are all effective, while Susan Bickley proves herself one of the finest mezzo-sopranos of her generation.

Nuits d'Etoiles: Songs by Fauré, Debussy and Poulenc
Gens/Vignoles
(Virgin, £12.99)
French soprano Véronique Gens is one of the finest Mozart singers around, but these 19th-century mélodies show that her range is far greater. She inhabits the varied worlds of these songs with conviction, whether in the delicate phrasing in Fauré's Après un Rêve or the deft dispatch of Poulenc's Banalités. Roger Vignoles accompanies with tact and assertiveness.

Messiaen: Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant-Jésus
Aimard
(Teldec, 2 CDs, £27.99)
As a teenager Pierre-Laurent Aimard studied with Messiaen and his wife Yvonne Loriod. His performance of Messiaen's monumental solo piano piece has a sense of sovereign command, not only of the work's prodigious technical challenges but also of the devotional purpose of the cycle. Aimard brings the work to life in a way that no one has ever managed on record.

Mahler/Cooke: Symphony No 10
Berlin Philharmonic/Rattle (EMI, £13.99)
This consummate version of Mahler's final symphony, in the performing version that the English musicologist Deryck Cooke made from the surviving sketches, demonstrates that the work belongs firmly in the Mahler canon. Rattle recorded it at the start of his career, but this version outstrips its predecessor in the orchestral playing and its grasp of structure and detail, and in the way that Mahler's last emotional journey in music is so heart-wrenchingly charted.

Lindberg: Aura; Engine
BBC Symphony/London Sinfonietta/Knussen
(Deutsche Grammophon, £13.99)
Aura is the most important addition to Magnus Lindberg's discography. Completed in 1994, it marries Lindberg's mastery of the orchestra with superb control of a form that has the ghost of a one-movement symphony behind it. Chamber-like instrumental transparency alternates with textures of awesome power and the musical argument is always lucid. This is a wonderful performance from the BBC Symphony under Oliver Knussen, and the coupling of the dynamic Engine is equally compelling.

Massenet: Thaos
Fleming/Hampson/Bourdeaux Aquitaine National Orchestra/Abel
(Decca, 2 CDs, £29.99)
Thaos has been dismissed as an over-exotic concoction, designed to cash in on the late 19th century's fascination with all things oriental, and carrying a whiff of smuttiness with it. But this sumptuous version, idiomatically conducted by Yves Abel, with Renée Fleming creamily seductive in the title role, demonstrates that it can still be forged into a convincing dramatic unity, with many gorgeous tunes.

Elgar/Payne: Symphony No 3
Bournemouth Symphony/Daniel
(Naxos, £4.99)
Since it appeared in 1998, Anthony Payne's masterly "elaboration" of the sketches for Elgar's Third Symphony has become a repertory piece with bewildering speed. Andrew Davis recorded the work at the time of the premiere, and Paul Daniel has been able to build upon what Davis drew out of the music. In many ways Daniel is more daring than his predecessor - he can give a greater sweep to the first movement, dig deeper into the Adagio and drive the finale home with greater certainty.

Bach: Goldberg Variations
Hewitt (Hyperion, £13.99)
Angela Hewitt's version of the Goldberg Variations is the best of the year's tributes on the 250th anniversary of Bach's death. She makes the best possible case for persisting with Bach's keyboard works on the piano, even in these days of period performance, but it is her sheer concentration and musicianship that distinguish this performance - the best on disc since Glenn Gould, and there can be no higher praise than that.

Tchaikovsky: Piano Trio Op 50
Richter/Kagan/Gutman
(Live Classics, £10.99)
The number of discs that Sviatoslav Richter made in the studio is being outstripped by the recordings of his concerts and recitals that have emerged in a steady stream since his death three years ago. Richter was as great a chamber musician as he was a solo pianist, and this incandescent account of the monumental Tchaikovsky Trio is a thrilling example of his interpretative powers. It is released in a series devoted to the achievement of the violinist Oleg Kagan, and fine though both his playing and that of the cellist Natalia Gutman is, Richter dominates the performance.

Beethoven: Piano Sonatas Opp 57; 101; 109; 110
Solomon (Testament, £10.99)
Every one of the 18 Beethoven sonatas that this great British pianist recorded before a stroke forced him to give up playing in 1956 is now available on CD, and this selection contains arguably the finest performances of all. The purity and naturalness of Solomon's playing makes his account of the Appassionata Sonata Op 57 a wonderfully contained experience, though his command of the A major Op 101 demonstrates that all the technical resources were there when he needed them. But it's the simple poetry he brings to Op 109 and 110 that is so special. Both the beguilingly simple floating of the opening of Op 109 and the unfolding of the fugue in the last movement of Op 110 are the achievement of a supreme artist.
fields.bodyText: Handel: Theodora Gritton/Bickley/Blaze/Agnew/McCreesh (Archiv, 3 CDs, £29.99) Handel's penultimate English oratorio was largely overlooked until it was staged at Glyndebourne in 1996 by Peter Sellars when the performances highlighted the beauties in the score.
