fields.headline: 'Fear of best value inspectors misplaced'
fields.standfirst: Despite criticisms of the best value inspection service, some of the first councils to be visited say the experience can have benefits
fields.trailText: Despite criticisms of the best value inspection service, some of the first councils to be visited tell Simon Parker the experience can have benefits
fields.body:
Few council officers like the idea of having their work rated by a team of government-appointed strangers. So it is not surprising that some people in local government privately confess to hating best value inspectors, and liken the best value inspection service (BVIS) to Chris Woodhead's Ofsted.

Their mood is partly a product of anxiety. The BVIS only started going into authorities over the summer, and has published 18 reports so far. It means that few officers have experienced the new inspection regime in action, and they do not know what to expect.

This anxiety is also a result of real concerns, such as those appearing in a parliamentary select committee report released earlier this year, which attacks what it terms a "developing culture of over-inspection" in local government. The BVIS hopes to publish nearly 700 inspection reports between now and March 2001.

Those councils that have already been assessed, however, say that officers should not get too anxious before the inspector calls. "I don't think it should hold any fear or dread for services that can properly account for what they're doing. It will be more worrying and more challenging the weaker one's service is," says Mike Jordan, development control manager at the London borough of Camden.

The report on Mr Jordan's team was released earlier this week alongside reports on the housing and tourism services at Havant borough council and Richmondshire district council. The three were among the first authorities to be inspected.

Mr Jordan learned that he runs a good service which is likely to improve. That rating was, at least partly, the result of good preparation. The development control team went through the interview process for a Charter Mark award earlier this year. But Mr Jordan notes that "the inspection was in a completely different league to the Charter Mark".

He does, however, echo some of the concerns expressed by the select committee: "It's very difficult to see how they'll resource the whole process if every service in the country is inspected with the same degree of rigour as ours."

Richmondshire best value officer Gayle Sutherland is worried less by the intensity of the inspections, than by the prospect that the BVIS might not be able to keep it up: "They got it about right this time, but my concern is that in future it will be much less rigorous."

The north Yorkshire council received what she describes as a "disappointing" fair rating for its tourism service, and was told it was unlikely to improve.

Richmondshire is critical of the way the BVIS handled the tourism inspection. There were no tourism professionals among the team of inspectors, and Ms Sutherland says they looked more closely at how her council's services matched up to national policy than at how it was adapting those policies to meet local needs.

It is a point of view echoed by Ivan Western, Havant's housing services manager. The authority has no housing of its own, but still has to find homes for those residents that need them. "The inspectors were very good at assessing the services - the things you can measure on the ground. I'm not sure their methodology is worked up to tackle local strategy or the enabling role we play in housing," says Western.

The BVIS admits there were no tourism professionals on the team that inspected Richmondshire, but a spokesman says the inspectors had a combination of skills relevant to the tourism industry, were familiar with the relevant information and shared information with other tourism inspection teams. "Inevitably, inspectors won't have experience in every single service they inspect," he adds. All the teams regularly consult the workers being inspected. "We're committed to a 'no surprises' approach."

Despite his criticisms of the regime, Mr Western says his experience was overwhelmingly positive. Havant won just one star from the inspectors, and was told it was unlikely to improve. "The name of the game is improving the service," he says. "We'd have paid a consultant a lot of money for a report like this." It is hard to imagine many school heads saying the same about Ofsted.

webTitle: Leader: Popularity of the Tate galleries

fields.headline: Tate triumphant
fields.standfirst: In London crowds flock in. Elsewhere...
fields.trailText: Sir Nicholas Serota has every reason to feel very pleased with himself. Some note of triumphalism in his Richard Dimbleby Lecture on Wednesday night was expected, and even forgivable.
fields.body:
Sir Nicholas Serota has every reason to feel very pleased with himself. Some note of triumphalism in his Richard Dimbleby Lecture on Wednesday night was expected, and even forgivable. He has presided over a major new addition to Britain's cultural landscape. The Tate Modern opened to almost universally rapturous reviews and millions have poured through its doors ever since. For many, the visit is an enormous challenge, introducing them to a wide range of contemporary art of which they may have had little previous experience. Serota admits there has been a "sea change in public appreciation of the visual arts". He acknowledged how Antony Gormley's Angel of the North has captured the public imagination and Walsall's new art gallery has transformed the town's aspirations. Not for decades have contemporary art, design and architecture bulked so large on the public agenda; sometimes loved, sometimes ridiculed, they have entered the mainstream in a way previous generations of artists, designers and architects could only dream about.

But Sir Nicholas was in no mood for celebration. Instead he was extraordinarily defensive, as he launched into a passionate and emotional justification of the visual discipline to which he has dedicated his life. Never has such a defence seemed so superfluous. He sounded quixotic when plaintively quoting criticism of modern art in such newspapers as the Sunday Telegraph and Daily Mail. But as he admits, modern art sets out to challenge, often to shock and even to revolt. Its raison d' tre is to subvert convention - of aesthetics, of art and of meaning. That will inevitably antagonise newspapers wallowing in nostalgia.

Instead, Sir Nicholas would have done better to reserve his fire for two key issues which he mentioned only briefly. First, he highlighted concern that government education policy has an "increasingly narrow interpretation of learning" which marginalises the visual arts. Secondly, he pointed out the lamentable degree of centralisation, so that outside London, art galleries in Leeds and Glasgow are languishing for lack of resources. By contrast, he cited the Netherlands, a country of 14m people with six modern art museums of international status. If contemporary art is to be a regular part of millions of people's lives rather than the preserve of a metropolitan elite, then both these points need to be urgently addressed.

webTitle: Is there such a thing as 'The Ideal Christmas Book'?

fields.headline: Present laughter
fields.standfirst: From the sublime to the ridiculous,  Ian Sansom looks at the  books that are made for giving
fields.trailText: From the sublime to the ridiculous, Ian Sansom looks at the books that are made for giving.
fields.body:
It's Christmas morning, and you've got in all the essentials - extra toilet-rolls and tea-bags for the oldies, the Christmas double issue of the Radio Times, a stack of blank video-cassettes, and a range of smorgasbits from M & S. You rush downstairs - let's assume you have a downstairs, and an open fire, and plenty of room for a Christmas tree, and your own full set of crockery and nut-crackers, since let's be honest, Christmas in a small centrally-heated flat with only your commode, a few old photos, a bottle of syrup of figs, the Reader's Digest and a few pre-sliced butter-basted ready-meals for company is no fun, particularly if you're Father Christmas.

You're ready to let rip with the old advocaat and lash into the presents - let's assume you have some presents. And let's assume also, for the sake of argument, that you're a reader of the Guardian. (These assumptions are not mutually exclusive.) Granted all of these comforting notions, there's a good chance that one of those little gift-wrapped goodies nestled among the fallen pine-needles is going to have a name-tag with your name written on it, and it is going to be a book. Why?

Books are, of course, intended as gifts. Most of them are written with the intention of pleasing, even if that pleasure is marked by struggle and pain. Even Kafka, and Jeffrey Archer, set out to entertain, try as they might to avoid it. Writers are making an offering, which is why critics and reviewers are so unpopular: not only does the critic look the writer's gift horse in the mouth, he bashes its teeth in, ties it up by the hooves, sets fire to its tail, flenses, strips and butchers it, and boils up its bones for glue.

Books are not only offered as gratuities, but are traditionally exchanged as gifts. What better way to tell your friends and family what you think of them or to announce how you see yourself than to spell it out clearly in black and white? If you were to gift-wrap Garrison Keillor's We Are Still Married, for example, and give it to your spouse, or were to pop Tim Parks's Adultery and Other Diversions into a jolly red Jiffy for your lover, you'd clearly be wanting to tell them something (and not the same thing as if you were to give your spouse Adultery and Other Diversions and your lover We Are Still Married).

Certain books are of course simply not suitable as gifts. Excellent though they undoubtedly are, the new editions of What to Do When Someone Dies (Which? Books, £9.99 Buy it at BOL) and Smith's General Urology (Appleton and Lange, £29.99 Buy it at BOL) are probably unsuitable as stocking-fillers.

Certain other books, though, are perfectly proper and appropriate. There is such a thing as the Christmas Book. Literally - JM Golby and AW Purdue's The Making of the Modern Christmas (Sutton, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), say, or John Van Der Kiste's Gilbert and Sullivan's Christmas (Sutton, £9.99 Buy it at BOL) - and metaphorically. Publishers think like Scrooge - they believe Christmas is a miserable time, but are nonetheless happy to profit from it by publishing books in November that they expect us poor saps to rush out and buy as presents instead of Body Shop essential oils and HMV 2-for-£22 CDs.

Hence the current glut of "humour" books. Unfortunately, these are not funny, not even, alas, The Little Book of Mornington Crescent (Orion, £6.99 Buy it at BOL), compiled by Tim Brooke-Taylor, Graeme Garden, Barry Cryer and Humphrey Lyttleton, let alone Ha Ha Ha Haa!: Quips, Quotes and Cartoons for Music Lovers (Robson, £6.99 Buy it at BOL). And poor Nick Page may have to find room for Natalie d'Arbeloff's The Joy of Letting Women Down: Secrets of the Worshipped Male (Robson, £8.99) in future editions of his own In Search of the World's Worst Writers (HarperCollins, £6.99 Buy it at BOL). The Literary Review's annual, Poetry 2000 (Robson, £8.99 Buy it at BOL), edited by Clarissa Burden and "explained" by Auberon Waugh, does at least raise a smile, but only Steven Appleby's Encyclopaedia of Personal Problems (Bloomsbury, £10.99) knows its proper place: "Buy this book and rush home to the privacy of your own privy."

Since Christmas is probably the one time of year you can get away with taking drink during the day - unless you're already an alcoholic, or work in publishing - the best Christmas Books are those that are simple enough to read through a haze of Harvey's Bristol Cream, or perhaps a bottle of Kwik-Save Claret (£3.50), as recommended in Malcom Gluck's Superplonk 2001 (Hodder and Stoughton, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), the proverbial Beano of the middle classes.

Best of all, obviously, are books with no words at all - easily accessible to the incapacitated, and fans of Jim Davidson. Thus, presumably, the seasonal reissue of Hoffnung (The Hoffnung Companion to Music, Hoffnung's The Maestro, The Hoffnung Symphony Orchestra, Beer Davies, £6.95 Buy it at BOL) and miscellaneous other soothing eye-pleasers, such as James Haspiel's The Unpublished Marilyn (Mainstream, £20 Buy it at BOL), Terry Matz's Daybook of Saints (Mitchell Beazley, £18.99 Buy it at BOL), and Leonardo Da Vinci: The Complete Paintings (Harry N. Abrams Buy it at BOL), edited by Pietro C. Marani, a gorgeous book which requires its own dedicated coffee table.

The next best thing to picture-books are books which consist of little bits of other books: the pick and mix, as it were, of Christmas Books. John Julius Norwich's Still More Christmas Crackers 1990-1999 (Viking, £16.99 Buy it at BOL) is a classic, but does require updating. Where, one asks, as one is chuckling over all those toothsome selections from Walter Savage Landor and Christopher Smart, is the Christmas commonplace book for Generation X (but then again, would Generation X bother to read it)? Daisy Goodwin's 101 Poems To Get You Through the Day (and Night): A Survival Kit for Modern Life (HarperCollins, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), Michelle Lovric's Women's Wicked Wit (Prion, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), "chock-full of wicked witticisms by women of every kind" and even Milton Shulman's Voltaire, Goldberg & Others (Quartet Books, £7 Buy it at BOL) all fall rather short of the mark.

Not nearly so far or so wide, needless to say, as Gyles Brandreth's Great Party Games (Robson Books, £6.99 Buy it at BOL), or Richard Whiteley's A Treasury of Words and Wordplay (Robson Books, £6.99 Buy it at BOL), which are the publishing equivalent of a stint in panto at the Queen's Theatre, Hornchurch. Other minor celebrities treading the seasonal boards include Helen Yemm, "presenter of the popular BBC series Gardening from Scratch", with her saucy Gardening in your Nightie (Ebury Press, £14.99 Buy it at BOL), and the fragrant Pat Archer - otherwise known as Patricia Gallimore - getting her hands dirty with her Organic Year (BBC Worldwide, £9.99 Buy it at BOL). Boze Hadleigh plays the wicked stepmother in Celebrity Feuds: The Cattiest Rows, Spats and Tiffs Ever Recorded (Robson Books, £8.99 Buy it at BOL).

At that time of year when the mind turns naturally towards thoughts of eternity, we may wish to read the lives of great men and women and to draw deeply upon the lessons contained therein. Hence Benny Hill: King Leer, by Jeremy Norvick (Carlton Books, £14.99 Buy it at BOL), the "fully updated edition" of Noddy Holder's Who's Crazee Now? (Ebury Press, £5.99 Buy it at BOL), John Mortimer's The Summer of a Dormouse: A Year of Growing Old Disgracefully (Viking, £16.99 Buy it at BOL), George Melly's Fishing Memories (Robson Books, £14.95 Buy it at BOL), and Forever Liesl: My Sound of Music Story (Sidgwick & Jackson, £9.99 Buy it at BOL) by Charmian Carr, the one who sang I Am Sixteen, Going On Seventeen in the film, and who seems never to have got over it. Inspirational.

Fed up to the back teeth with all this cold turkey, one might also be inclined to pick up a cookbook. A cookbook is, of course, in and of itself an expression of good intentions, but proferred as a Christmas gift it's more likely to be an act of judgment. All year you may have found yourself subjected to fish fingers, or tuna-pasta bake, so you may feel this is your chance to suggest that maybe next year your mum/dad/partner/flatmate/cooking-Other could make good use of Claudia Roden's Tamarind & Saffron: Favourite Recipes from the Middle East (Penguin, £12.99 Buy it at BOL) or Rowley Leigh's No Place Like Home (Fourth Estate, £25 Buy it at BOL) and rustle up a nice venison stew for a change, with baby onions, chestnuts and chocolate, or some couscous with bits in.

The Christmas Book is not merely a comfort, then, but can also present a challenge. The Ideas in Psychoanalysis series (Icon Books Buy it at BOL) is currently offering Anxiety, Guilt, Phantasy, Perversion and the Unconscious, all at £3.99 in paperback, with Hysteria on its way in Spring 2001. Pocket Essentials has Slasher Movies and David Cronenberg in a similar format and at the same price. Those in serious training for Trivial Pursuit might like to limber up with Toby and Will Musgrave's An Empire of Plants: People and Plants That Changed the World (Cassell, £20 Buy it at BOL) or Georges Ifrah's three-volume The Universal History of Numbers (Harvill, £50 Buy it at BOL).

There are of course books which serve no such discernible purpose - like first novels, these seem to come out of nowhere, belong nowhere, and go nowhere, and exist only for and in the moment: these are the true Christmas Books, gifts in every sense of the word. The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbook (Chronicle Books, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), for example, by Joshua Piven and David Borgenicht, is a kind of Boy's Own book of household hints and handy tips which contains useful advice on how to hot-wire cars, escape killer bees and "Manoeuvre on Top of a Moving Train and Get Inside". Indispensable.

Almost as entertaining and almost equally as useless is John Allen Paulos's I Think Therefore I Laugh: The Flip Side of Philosophy (Penguin, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), a book inspired, apparently, "by Wittgenstein's quip that a book on philosophy might consist entirely of jokes". He was hilarious, Wittgenstein.

Jokes and philosophy do, though, sit comfortably together: they remind us that what appears worthless may in fact hold some value. All royalties from the sale of Richard Curtis and Paul Mayhew-Archer's The Vicar of Dibley: The Great Big Companion to Dibley (Michael Joseph, £14.99 Buy it at BOL), it is worth pointing out, go to charity. This is a good thing, although proceeds from the sale of most Christmas Books eventually go to charity, since like novelty ties, colourful socks, and the marble cheese dome, the Christmas Book exists only to be scooped up and unwrapped once a year, and then thrown aside. They come into the world marked "perishable", and end up in Oxfam. Amidst all the frantic preparations, the Christmas Book is as useful a reminder as the Incarnation itself: we own nothing.

Writers are making an offering, which is why critics and reviewers are so unpopular: not only does the critic look the writer's gift horse in the mouth, he bashes its teeth in, ties it up by the hooves, sets fire to its tail, flenses, strips and butchers it, and boils up its bones for glue. Books are not only offered as gratuities, but are traditionally exchanged as gifts. What better way to tell your friends and family what you think of them or to announce how you see yourself than to spell it out clearly in black and white? If you were to gift-wrap Garrison Keillor's We Are Still Married, for example, and give it to your spouse, or were to pop Tim Parks's Adultery and Other Diversions into a jolly red Jiffy for your lover, you'd clearly be wanting to tell them something (and not the same thing as if you were to give your spouse Adultery and Other Diversions and your lover We Are Still Married). Certain books are of course simply not suitable as gifts. Excellent though they undoubtedly are, the new editions of What to Do When Someone Dies (Which? Books, £9.99 Buy it at BOL) and Smith's General Urology (Appleton and Lange, £29.99 Buy it at BOL) are probably unsuitable as stocking-fillers. Certain other books, though, are perfectly proper and appropriate. There is such a thing as the Christmas Book. Literally - JM Golby and AW Purdue's The Making of the Modern Christmas (Sutton, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), say, or John Van Der Kiste's Gilbert and Sullivan's Christmas (Sutton, £9.99 Buy it at BOL) - and metaphorically. Publishers think like Scrooge - they believe Christmas is a miserable time, but are nonetheless happy to profit from it by publishing books in November that they expect us poor saps to rush out and buy as presents instead of Body Shop essential oils and HMV 2-for-£22 CDs. Hence the current glut of "humour" books. Unfortunately, these are not funny, not even, alas, The Little Book of Mornington Crescent (Orion, £6.99 Buy it at BOL), compiled by Tim Brooke-Taylor, Graeme Garden, Barry Cryer and Humphrey Lyttleton, let alone Ha Ha Ha Haa!: Quips, Quotes and Cartoons for Music Lovers (Robson, £6.99 Buy it at BOL). And poor Nick Page may have to find room for Natalie d'Arbeloff's The Joy of Letting Women Down: Secrets of the Worshipped Male (Robson, £8.99) in future editions of his own In Search of the World's Worst Writers (HarperCollins, £6.99 Buy it at BOL). The Literary Review's annual, Poetry 2000 (Robson, £8.99 Buy it at BOL), edited by Clarissa Burden and "explained" by Auberon Waugh, does at least raise a smile, but only Steven Appleby's Encyclopaedia of Personal Problems (Bloomsbury, £10.99) knows its proper place: "Buy this book and rush home to the privacy of your own privy." Since Christmas is probably the one time of year you can get away with taking drink during the day - unless you're already an alcoholic, or work in publishing - the best Christmas Books are those that are simple enough to read through a haze of Harvey's Bristol Cream, or perhaps a bottle of Kwik-Save Claret (£3.50), as recommended in Malcom Gluck's Superplonk 2001 (Hodder and Stoughton, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), the proverbial Beano of the middle classes. Best of all, obviously, are books with no words at all - easily accessible to the incapacitated, and fans of Jim Davidson. Thus, presumably, the seasonal reissue of Hoffnung (The Hoffnung Companion to Music, Hoffnung's The Maestro, The Hoffnung Symphony Orchestra, Beer Davies, £6.95 Buy it at BOL) and miscellaneous other soothing eye-pleasers, such as James Haspiel's The Unpublished Marilyn (Mainstream, £20 Buy it at BOL), Terry Matz's Daybook of Saints (Mitchell Beazley, £18.99 Buy it at BOL), and Leonardo Da Vinci: The Complete Paintings (Harry N. Abrams Buy it at BOL), edited by Pietro C. Marani, a gorgeous book which requires its own dedicated coffee table. The next best thing to picture-books are books which consist of little bits of other books: the pick and mix, as it were, of Christmas Books. John Julius Norwich's Still More Christmas Crackers 1990-1999 (Viking, £16.99 Buy it at BOL) is a classic, but does require updating. Where, one asks, as one is chuckling over all those toothsome selections from Walter Savage Landor and Christopher Smart, is the Christmas commonplace book for Generation X (but then again, would Generation X bother to read it)? Daisy Goodwin's 101 Poems To Get You Through the Day (and Night): A Survival Kit for Modern Life (HarperCollins, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), Michelle Lovric's Women's Wicked Wit (Prion, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), "chock-full of wicked witticisms by women of every kind" and even Milton Shulman's Voltaire, Goldberg & Others (Quartet Books, £7 Buy it at BOL) all fall rather short of the mark. Not nearly so far or so wide, needless to say, as Gyles Brandreth's Great Party Games (Robson Books, £6.99 Buy it at BOL), or Richard Whiteley's A Treasury of Words and Wordplay (Robson Books, £6.99 Buy it at BOL), which are the publishing equivalent of a stint in panto at the Queen's Theatre, Hornchurch. Other minor celebrities treading the seasonal boards include Helen Yemm, "presenter of the popular BBC series Gardening from Scratch", with her saucy Gardening in your Nightie (Ebury Press, £14.99 Buy it at BOL), and the fragrant Pat Archer - otherwise known as Patricia Gallimore - getting her hands dirty with her Organic Year (BBC Worldwide, £9.99 Buy it at BOL). Boze Hadleigh plays the wicked stepmother in Celebrity Feuds: The Cattiest Rows, Spats and Tiffs Ever Recorded (Robson Books, £8.99 Buy it at BOL). At that time of year when the mind turns naturally towards thoughts of eternity, we may wish to read the lives of great men and women and to draw deeply upon the lessons contained therein. Hence Benny Hill: King Leer, by Jeremy Norvick (Carlton Books, £14.99 Buy it at BOL), the "fully updated edition" of Noddy Holder's Who's Crazee Now? (Ebury Press, £5.99 Buy it at BOL), John Mortimer's The Summer of a Dormouse: A Year of Growing Old Disgracefully (Viking, £16.99 Buy it at BOL), George Melly's Fishing Memories (Robson Books, £14.95 Buy it at BOL), and Forever Liesl: My Sound of Music Story (Sidgwick & Jackson, £9.99 Buy it at BOL) by Charmian Carr, the one who sang I Am Sixteen, Going On Seventeen in the film, and who seems never to have got over it. Inspirational. Fed up to the back teeth with all this cold turkey, one might also be inclined to pick up a cookbook. A cookbook is, of course, in and of itself an expression of good intentions, but proferred as a Christmas gift it's more likely to be an act of judgment. All year you may have found yourself subjected to fish fingers, or tuna-pasta bake, so you may feel this is your chance to suggest that maybe next year your mum/dad/partner/flatmate/cooking-Other could make good use of Claudia Roden's Tamarind & Saffron: Favourite Recipes from the Middle East (Penguin, £12.99 Buy it at BOL) or Rowley Leigh's No Place Like Home (Fourth Estate, £25 Buy it at BOL) and rustle up a nice venison stew for a change, with baby onions, chestnuts and chocolate, or some couscous with bits in. The Christmas Book is not merely a comfort, then, but can also present a challenge. The Ideas in Psychoanalysis series (Icon Books Buy it at BOL) is currently offering Anxiety, Guilt, Phantasy, Perversion and the Unconscious, all at £3.99 in paperback, with Hysteria on its way in Spring 2001. Pocket Essentials has Slasher Movies and David Cronenberg in a similar format and at the same price. Those in serious training for Trivial Pursuit might like to limber up with Toby and Will Musgrave's An Empire of Plants: People and Plants That Changed the World (Cassell, £20 Buy it at BOL) or Georges Ifrah's three-volume The Universal History of Numbers (Harvill, £50 Buy it at BOL). There are of course books which serve no such discernible purpose - like first novels, these seem to come out of nowhere, belong nowhere, and go nowhere, and exist only for and in the moment: these are the true Christmas Books, gifts in every sense of the word. The Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbook (Chronicle Books, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), for example, by Joshua Piven and David Borgenicht, is a kind of Boy's Own book of household hints and handy tips which contains useful advice on how to hot-wire cars, escape killer bees and "Manoeuvre on Top of a Moving Train and Get Inside". Indispensable. Almost as entertaining and almost equally as useless is John Allen Paulos's I Think Therefore I Laugh: The Flip Side of Philosophy (Penguin, £9.99 Buy it at BOL), a book inspired, apparently, "by Wittgenstein's quip that a book on philosophy might consist entirely of jokes". He was hilarious, Wittgenstein. Jokes and philosophy do, though, sit comfortably together: they remind us that what appears worthless may in fact hold some value. All royalties from the sale of Richard Curtis and Paul Mayhew-Archer's The Vicar of Dibley: The Great Big Companion to Dibley (Michael Joseph, £14.99 Buy it at BOL), it is worth pointing out, go to charity. This is a good thing, although proceeds from the sale of most Christmas Books eventually go to charity, since like novelty ties, colourful socks, and the marble cheese dome, the Christmas Book exists only to be scooped up and unwrapped once a year, and then thrown aside. They come into the world marked "perishable", and end up in Oxfam. Amidst all the frantic preparations, the Christmas Book is as useful a reminder as the Incarnation itself: we own nothing.

webTitle: The best of the year's fiction

fields.headline: After the turkey,  the crackers
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark salutes the best of the year's fiction
fields.trailText: Alex Clark salutes the best of the year's fiction.
fields.body:
Christmas presents something of a problem for the publisher or bookshop keen to make an impact on the bestseller lists with a sly novel or two. For a start, not a great deal of fiction is published in the dying months of the year; the push to capture the summer holiday market is long gone, the fizz of the Booker Prize is fading, and attention is already focused on the big releases for January and the next round of lists, awards, magazine profiles and TV interviews.

Even worse, novels make tricky gifts, being neither visually impressive in the manner of a lavishly illustrated work on gardening or interior decoration, nor bearing the obvious intellectual weight of a thumping great tome of history or biography. There's the horribly nuanced matter of gauging another's taste - you wouldn't want to disappoint a Nick Hornby fan with the latest AS Byatt, for example. And there's an absence of immediate gratification with a novel - parading around in a pristine sweater or shoving on a new CD makes for easier overt appreciation, after all.

Those caveats in mind, a hardback novel is still, for many, a luxury, suggesting expense and several hours' absorbed leisure. Given thoughtfully, a good novel can easily outlast the more showy presents. So here's a guide to some of those most likely to be crackers rather than turkeys.

Let's start with the inevitable miseries and neuroses that accompany extended periods of togetherness and festivity. Any harassed parent would be grateful for Helen Simpson's Hey Yeah Right Get A Life (Cape, £14.99 Buy it at BOL) - short stories, in fact, exquisitely written meditations on the end of freedom and frivolity that children betoken. Those anticipating a less than smooth ride on the romantic rollercoaster will also enjoy Julian Barnes's eternal triangulations in Love, etc (Cape, £15.99 Buy it at BOL).

To complete the "bah, humbug" effect, this year's novels come no more misanthropic than Michel Houellebecq's extraordinary Atomised (Heinemann, £12.99 Buy it at BOL), a brilliant work of nihilism that predicts a gloomy end to sexual, social and scientific decadence. It would sit well with JG Ballard's Super-Cannes (Flamingo, £16.99 Buy it at BOL), another dystopian view of the world.

There is, of course, lighter fare. Of the veteran novelists who published this year, Muriel Spark beat all-comers for lightness of touch and deviant wit. Aiding and Abetting (Viking, £12.99 Buy it at BOL), her imagined history of Lord Lucan post-nanny-bashing, is both comic caper and serious meditation on the nature of psychopathy: in Lucan's case, evil turns out to be rather banal and somewhat boring - what you might expect, one supposes, of a man who ate only smoked salmon and lamb chops every day of his adult life. A gentler sort of comedy comes from the woefully overlooked Laurie Graham. The wonderfully titled Dog Days, Glenn Miller Nights (Black Swan, £6.99 Buy it at BOL) marries nostalgia and nervy present-day East End life in the person of Birdie Gibbs, a pensioner with attitude, whose talent for the one-liner makes her more than a match for the teenagers who terrorise the walkways of the Fruit Bowl estate.

Gentler still is Ben Sherwood's debut novel The Man Who Ate the 747 (Picador, £12 Buy it at BOL) - which does exactly what it says on the tin. If this year's Booker Prize shortlist is anything to go by, judges and reading public still like the past. Several novelists looked to history for inspiration most notably, perhaps, in Booker winner and finalist respectively, Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin (Bloomsbury, £16.99 Buy it at BOL) and Kazuo Ishiguro's When We Were Orphans (Faber, £16.99 Buy it at BOL).

The Orange prizewinner was Linda Grant's When I Lived in Modern Times (Granta, £6.99 Buy it at BOL), which launched a young Jewess into the zealotry and political activity of 1940s Palestine. Grant's subject was the ungovernability of passion and the complexity of personal and public identity, but her novel also managed to be delicately witty and a surprisingly light read, in the best sense of the word. Grant rather notably won over the bookies' favourite, Zadie Smith, whose debut novel White Teeth (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99 Buy it at BOL) wrong-footed the critics who expect all precocious talent to squander itself on slim metropolitan docunovels or modishly ironic fairy-tales. Here was a whacking great family saga, replete with comedy and seriousness, linguistically playful and yet thoroughly intent on telling a story. White Teeth has not yet won Smith any gongs, but it has secured her an enviable reputation as the Next Big Thing - a mantle she might have to share for a while with Trezza Azzopardi (The Hiding Place, Picador, £14.99 Buy it at BOL) and Mark Z Danielewski (House of Leaves, Doubleday, £13 Buy it at BOL).

Amazon's reader comments reveal that Smith is a big fan of John Lanchester. In fact, she claims, she wishes she had written his Mr Phillips (Faber, £16.99 Buy it at BOL) herself - quite a tribute for a book that divided critical opinion. Was his deceptively simple tale of a redundant accountant wandering the London streets in a state of amiable alienation a triumph for the miniaturist or a detour up the garden path? A matter of taste, in the end, but Lanchester is certainly one of the most interesting and intelligent of novelists to watch, and re-read.

Honourable mentions are also due to the excellent Julie Myerson, on top form in a Victorian setting in Laura Blundy (Fourth Estate, £15.99 Buy it at BOL); Michel Faber for his startling Under the Skin (Canongate, £10 Buy it at BOL); John Banville for Eclipse (Picador, £15.99 Buy it at BOL); Lawrence Norfolk for In The Shape of a Boar (Weidenfeld and Nicolson, £16.99 Buy it at BOL); and to the posthumous short stories of the much-lamented Penelope Fitzgerald, The Means of Escape (Flamingo, £12.99 Buy it at BOL).

The first year of the millennium saw another decisive retort to the pessimist's claim that the novel is languishing in the doldrums - each and any of these titles will guarantee a prompt thank you note, whoever's stocking they fill.

fields.headline: The stamp of genius
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Glancey savours  a little millennium project  that has the rest licked
fields.trailText: Jonathan Glancey savours a little millennium project that has the rest licked
fields.body:
1000 Years 1000 Words: A Celebration of the Royal Mail Millennium Stamps Project
The Camberwell Press with the Royal Mail
£95

In 1964 Sir Kenneth Clark (the future Lord Clark of Civilisation) resigned as Chairman of the Post Office's stamp advisory committee. What could be less agreeable, he sniffed, than witnessing the Royal Mail produce commemorative stamps for the sake of it: commercial opportunism at its too-ghastly worst. It wasn't. It was an idea encouraged by Tony Benn, postmaster general at the time, not just to make a few extra pennies for the Post Office as was, but to bring art in the form of very affordable miniatures to everyone capable of sending or receiving a letter, just as London Transport had done with its inspired platform posters. Or, of course, the General Post Office film unit of the 1930s which made such brief celluloid wonders as Night Mail. Ever since Clark's departure, the Royal Mail has offered collectors and letter writers a long, perforated streamer of designs varying from reproductions of the Bayeux tapestry to the sniggering visage of Dennis the Menace via the Battle of Britain in a squadron of memorable stamps and every conceivable event and celebration in between. Many of the nation's best artists and designers have been asked to see what they can do within the limits of these tiny frames.

In fact artists, particularly today, rarely get to to work on such a Lilliputian yet populist scale. Miniature art is normally the realm of the Lord's Prayer written on a pinhead by a long-term prisoner, or an exact reproduction of HMS Victory inside the eye of a needle. To celebrate the millennium Barry Robinson, the Royal Mail's head of design, and his team, commissioned 48 special stamps - four each month - during 1999 and a further 48 this year. These have depicted themes drawn across the past 1,000 years of British invention, travel, medicine, science, war, religion and art itself. The range of artists has been as diverse as the subject matter, from the war photographer Don McCullin to eye-teasing Bridget Riley via Royal Mail regular David Gentleman to Anthony Gormley.

The standard of design has been almost uniformly high; the range of styles happily eclectic.The sad thing about these superb miniature artworks, however, is that once they have been licked, stamped and sent through the post, most have been screwed up and dispatched unceremoniously into the wastepaper bin. Some are hoarded by collectors, some go to the poor boys, perhaps, or some Blue Peter good cause (or, at least, they used to), but the rest are pulped.

But, not, happily the Millennium stamps. All 48 - real stamps with a face value of £18 - are included in a volume (in 11 colours rather than the usual four) of "1000 years 1000 words". This collection of the 1999 edition stamps has been designed by Tricket & Webb with a text by Michael Benson. The framing of the stamps and the typesetting are imaginative and finely executed while the texts spin like a top through the book, some funny, some rueful, others bordering on the incomprehensible. It doesn't matter; the effect as a whole speaks volumes. British art, design, wit and whimsy squeezed into a book no bigger than Hymns Ancient and Modern - that such a tiny book should sing a song of British creativity with far greater clarity and delight than the dumb Dome in Greenwich is a testimony to the intelligence that still survives in that slightly battered pillar of public service, the Royal Mail. And to the notion that art can be made accessible to all for as little as 22p today, whatever Lord Clark might think of it.

 Available from Millennium Stamps Book Order, DALI, Camberwell College of Arts, Peckham Road, London SU5 8UF (020 7514 6312)

fields.headline: Sleepy fish and electric elephants
fields.standfirst: Lyn Gardner on children's books from bedtime stories to sophisticated fables
fields.trailText: Lyn Gardner on children's books from bedtime stories to sophisticated fables
fields.body:
Age 0-3

Hushabye
John Burningham
(Jonathan Cape, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

A bedtime tale so snuggly it makes you want to rush off to bed immediately. Books which are the modern equivalent of the lullaby don't come more enchanting than this. Simplicity is the keynote, both in the everyday magic of the text and the drawings. Burningham manages to capture exactly what a fish looks like heavy-eyed with sleep, or how comfy the man in the moon is as he settles down for the night. This book takes the reader from sleepiness to sleep itself.

My Dad
Anthony Browne
(Doubleday, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Here's a chance to introduce the very youngest members of the family to Browne's sideways looks at the world. He always sees the extraordinary in the most ordinary lives; here a dad, who never succeeds in getting out of his dressing gown, manages to see off a wolf, dance the tango, replace one of the three tenors and do long division, all before breakfast. There is a great sense of humour at work, in bold visual jokes that keep children alert and stop parents dropping off during repeated readings.

The Obvious Elephant
Bruce Robinson and Sophie Windham
(Bloomsbury, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

"Imagine a town, in a country, where a simple thing like an elephant had never been seen, or even heard of." That's the tantalising start to this completely enchanting and thought-provoking tale about an elephant that turns up one day. Nobody knows what to do with it. Should they plug it in, using it as a railway engine or vacuum cleaner? Only a little boy called Eric knows what the creature is, and nobody will listen to him.

The Very Small
Joyce Dunbar, illustrated by Debi Gliori
(Doubleday, £10.99)
Buy it at BOL

When Giant Baby Bear is out he finds a Very Small. It looks like a cross between one of Peter Pan's Lost Boys, Thumbelina and an elf. And in Debi Gliori's enchanting illustrations it is irresistible, even to Giant Baby Bear (pretty cute too) who makes Very Small a playground, a bath in a soapdish and dinner (one whole pea). They snuggle down, but it only takes a sneeze from Bear for Very Small to be blown back to his parents. The difference between big and small has never been delivered with such poetry.

Age 4-7

Fairy Tales
Berlie Doherty, illustrated by Jane Ray
(Walker, £14.99)
Buy it at BOL

Is it possible to make Cinderella sound fresh, or Beauty and the Beast seem new-minted? Berlie Doherty can. This wonderful book creates a jewel-like world of enchantment studded with Jane Ray's gold-encrusted, richly coloured drawings that pick up on the style and mood of each story. But it doesn't neglect the words. Doherty's prose is easy and stylish without being tricksy.

Enchantment
Kevin Crossley-Holland, illustrated by Emma Chichester Clark
(Orion, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL
Crossley-Holland retells old folk tales better then anyone else alive, and this selection of fairy tales, ghost stories and tales of wonder from throughout these isles is as good as anything he's done. It is nice to see children being taken seriously as an audience. The foolishness of humans is a recurrent theme where imps, ghosts and boggarts almost always have the last laugh.

How the Whale Became and Other Stories
Ted Hughes, illustrated by Jackie Morris
(Faber and Faber, £17.99)
Buy it at BOL

This book of Ted Hughes's inventive creation fables, first published in 1963, will give pleasure to your children all their lives. Hughes tells us how the tortoise always used to come first in any race, why the hare believes that the moon wants to marry him and why it took a while for the elephant to learn to be itself. Jackie Morris's illustrations display a rich, muted, almost medieval beauty.

Beware of the Storybook Wolves
Lauren Child
(Hodder, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Lauren Child is a writer/illustrator who makes words dance and topography jitterbug and whose sly sense of humour makes both children and adults giggle. This is for anyone who has ever believed there might be a wolf under their bed and who worried that characters in books, particularly the nasty ones, might creep out in the night and get you.

Age 8-11

The Wind Singer
William Nicholson
(Mammoth, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

One of the best and most original books of the year, Nicholson's novel is set in a supposedly perfect society where everyone from the age of two is tested and given a personal rating that they must strive to improve. But Kestral rebels, and together with her twin brother and the smelly outcast Mumpo, sets off on a dangerous journey to find a way to liberate her homeland. This is a page-turning fantasy that clearly has its origins in our own world of Sats tests and league tables. A tough, cheering and inspiring story.

A Handful of Magic
Stephen Elboz
(Oxford University Press, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Elboz writes with real panache. A book to wonder at, but one which also makes you think about the nature of science and progress.

Charmed Life
Diana Wynne Jones
(Collins, £4.99)
Buy it at BOL

Eric Chant, known as Cat, thinks he is just an ordinary boy and that his sister is the gifted witch of the family. But when they are orphaned and whisked off to live in a magician's castle and the magician takes away his troublesome sister's magic, Cat discovers unexpected power. Wynne Jones's Chrestomanci series, of which this is the first, date from the 70s and are becoming hotter than Potter with a new generation of readers.

Ella Enchanted
Gail Carson Levine
(Collins, £3.99)
Buy it at BOL

Magic turns out to be a dangerous thing in this wonderfully witty book. When Ella is born, the fairy Lucinda grants her a gift: obedience. It turns out to be more of a curse, as the unscrupulous discover that they can make Ella do anything they command. Levine's witty, artful fairytale is unputdownable.

Age 12+

Witch Child
Celia Rees
(Bloomsbury, £10.99)
Buy it at BOL

The triumph of Rees's book, which takes the form of a 17th-century journal found sewn into the lining of a quilt 300 years later, is not just that it is a really good and cleverly constructed read. No, she also convincingly charts the psychology and political circumstances that engendered witch-hunts. Mary, a teenager whose adopted grandmother is executed as a witch in a small English village, thinks she is escaping to freedom when she sets sail with others for a fresh life in the New World. But survival is even more in doubt there. Rees writes with grace and urgency through to the convincingly ambiguous ending.

Vicky Angel
Jacqueline Wilson
(Doubleday, £10.99)
Buy it at BOL

Wilson's gift is an instantly accessible prose style that taps into the raw emotions of her young heroines and readers, combined with an ability to write issue-based books that aren't the slightest bit preachy. Her latest deals with death and friendship, as Jade is faced with life without her best friend Vicky, suddenly killed in a road accident. But as teachers, parents and friends worry about Jade having to do everything alone, her real problem is that Vicky is still making them do everything together. She is being haunted.

Heaven Eyes
David Almond
(Hodder, £10)
Buy it at BOL

Erin, January and Mouse run away from a children's home and set sail. They are rescued by Heaven Eyes, a girl with webbed hands and feet who believes they are her lost siblings. Almond's eerie tale is an astonishing piece of writing about the way that the living and the dead find comfort in each other and about daring to go as far as death and having the courage to come back again. A very grown-up, totally compelling book that, like Almond's brilliant Skellig, is about the lost and found, abandonment and redemption, love and faith - particularly faith in yourself and others.

A Long Way From Chicago
Richard Peck
(Hodder Children's Books, £3.99)
Buy it at BOL

It is 1929 and Joey and his sister travel from the Chicago of Bugsy Malone and Al Capone to the hicksville town of their gran on what is to be the first of a yearly summer visit. Here in her parlour they see their first dead body. Peck's brilliant book, a series of interlinked short stories that telescope in time to 1942, has the polecat reek of authentic American fiction. It is full of characters with names such as Shotgun Cheetham, a gran who behaves with the recklessness of a frontier-town outlaw, and a wonderful sense of the way we all turn our lives into myth. Seen entirely through the eyes of the child, this is a great book about the way you grow up slower than you want - and faster than you realise.

webTitle: The best of the weird and the wonderful

fields.headline: Fishing for pearls
fields.standfirst: Claire Armitstead ventures off the beaten track in search of weird and wonderful titles
fields.trailText: Claire Armitstead ventures off the beaten track in search of weird and wonderful titles.
fields.body:
There are so many books in the world that as literary editor I sometimes feel like Coleridge's ancient mariner, muttering through parched lips: "Water, water, every where, Nor any drop to drink." This is particularly true at Christmas, when every mailsack seems to bulge with more trite, unnourishing fare. But every now and then books arrive that demand to be gulped down. Sometimes this is because they are beautifully produced, and that doesn't necessarily mean lavish; sometimes it's because they are so clearly labours of love. Sometimes it is their intelligence that appeals, sometimes their eccentricity.

One of the most astonishing books to cross my desk was Errol Fuller's magnificent self-published The Great Auk, which basically boils down to everything you wanted to know about an extinct bird. Besides all those beautiful 19th-century auk portraits, there are auk anecdotes, auk eggs... I'm not a great fan of bird books, but this irresistible folly captured a buccaneering spirit that sometimes seems as dead as the auk itself. Fuller, an old-fashioned enthusiast whose past publications include - you guessed it - Extinct Birds, put £50,000 into printing 6,000 copies; some are still available at £45 from www.hoppa.demon.co.uk. Extinct Birds will be reissued by OUP in March.

The Great Auk is a good example of the book as a pleasurable object, but such tomes don't have to be big or batty, as the estimable Pushkin Press is forever proving. Earlier this year it produced a series of small silver books under the title The Jewel Quartet. The concept of the quartet - that they all had jewels as a theme - might seem overcute, but the stories genuinely deserve rediscovery. One contains two classic tales, "The Necklace" by Isak Dinesen and "The Pearls" by Guy de Maupassant. But the most cherishable is the least familiar - Madame de by Louise de Vilmorin. De Vilmorin was a noted beauty whose lovers included Antoine de St Exupzry and Orson Welles; her glittering fable of passion and deception centres on a pair of diamond earrings. To make it even more of a gem, Madame de has an afterword by John Julius Norwich, whose father Duff Cooper was its translator. Cooper was one of Vilmorin's lovers while serving as British Ambassador to Paris... So this tiny volume (price £5) offers not just a story, but the story behind the story. In other hands, it might well have been plumped up into a full-blown biography.

There is no shortage of publishers rushing to slake the thirst for well-produced new editions of classics. Penguin this year launched a smart new Modern Classics series, very collectable in their silver jackets, but connoisseurs of the book as object might prefer to go for the Folio Society's superbly produced hardback Books of the Century: 19 titles, in categories ranging from visual arts to the sciences, selected by celebrity poll. If you want a beautiful boxed set of Proust's In Search of Lost Time, introduced by his biographer Jean-Yves Tadie, it is available direct from the Folio Society on 020 7400 4200.

The repackaging of classics is a tried and trusted winner, but Tim Coates has come up with something entirely original: the repackaging of history. His Uncovered Editions collect papers from the archive of the Stationery Office into verbatim narratives, so, for instance, in UFOs in the House of Lords we get a hilarious recreation, directly from Hansard, of a nutty debate that took place in 1979. There are now 23 titles in the series, ranging from the official account of the Rillington Place murders to General Eisenhower's report covering the period between D Day and VE Day. This is inspired publishing, not only archivally valuable but capable of bringing the past back to life without the usual filter of academic or biographer. Uncovered Editions are available from the Stationery Office.

Flair, passion and commitment all play a part in the Very Special Book. And they don't come much more special than Tom Phillips's The Postcard Century (Thames & Hudson, £45 Buy it at BOL). This is the last century seen through both the cards that were sent and the people who sent them. So, in 1939, G&T send a picture of their London ambulance unit to wish Mr Greaves of Warrington a happy birthday. Their message ends: "Nothing exciting here yet." Of such little ironies is great history made.

fields.headline: Connoisseur's choice
fields.standfirst: Vera Rule rounds up some more labours of love
fields.trailText: Vera Rule rounds up some more labours of love.
fields.body:
These are books researched, written, illustrated and produced with exuberant enthusiasm; whole lifetimes of happy obsession have gone into their creation. Some are exquisite hardbacks; some are glum paperbacks with space begrudged between the minuscule lines; all are superlative. Your defence against the holidays.

A Natural History of the Senses by Diane Ackerman (Phoenix Press, £7.99 Buy it at BOL) delights in the sensations of the body; she explains their science with a poet's acuity, redeeming even sunsets and heartbeats from banality through her precision - she could probably make an android understand a kiss.

The Diary of Samuel Pepys, reissued in 11 volumes edited by Robert Latham and William Mathews (Fontana, priced individually Buy it at BOL), allows us to experience history almost in real time, seeing the malicious flames licking London, sniffing bad venison pasties and enduring having the builders in and the roof off during the soused-wet summer months.

Elisabeth Luard's Saffron and Sunshine (Bantam, £20 Buy it at BOL) has an inspired introductory essay on the cooking and hospitality of Mediterranean lands as daily social interaction with the asperities and austerities of real landscapes - a far cry from our restaurant-purchased fantasies of the olived south. The pics are too big and the recipes too few, but it's still fab.

Evan Eisenberg in The Ecology of Eden (Picador, £9.99 Buy it at BOL) synthesises gardens, gods and our permanent nostalgic ache for a paradisal past we never had; he writes with passionate affection about the heroic earthworm and gets our annual award for best footnotes - prolific, wild, tangential and almost better than his chapters.

In Gothic (Fourth Estate, £12.50 Buy it at BOL), Richard Davenport-Hines not only describes in aphorisms constructed to the highest Georgian standards 400 years of artistic and literary excess and ruin, but defines the dark power of the Gothic philosophy of wilful imperfection. He's great on hermits, bikers and the other unsmooth sons of the fallen Lucifer.

Indigo by Jenny Balfour-Paul (British Museum, £19.99 Buy it at BOL) is as saturated with decades of love and knowledge of the plant as a dyer's hands deep-dipped in the azure vat; her text pleads for physical pleasure in our clothes (the nobility of jeans, the burnished shine on a Berber cotton headwrap) and her pictures hit true blue notes all around the world.

Michael Karl Witzel's The American Motel (Motor-books International, £19.99 Buy it at BOL) is Kerouac with a Kodak - Witzel adores the potency of cheap mobility, the daft aspirations of the Art-Deco brochures, the promises of lowlife excitement in the neon-sign heraldry.

David Esterley's Grinling Gibbons and the Art of Carving (V&A, £19.99 Buy it at BOL) makes the baroque wooden masterpieces nearly tangible, displaying what might have been GG's workbench stocked with tools as beautiful as the things they made - we stroked this book as though we could feel the foliage and gamebird plumage.

fields.headline: From Sicily to Stalingrad
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston on audio books
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston on audio books.
fields.body:
It's been another annus mirabilis for audiobooks, at least in the numbers of new titles that have come out. The monthly trickle of just five years ago has now become a gush. Any book looking even a half-likely seller is now issued in audio at the same time.

The Leopard
Giuseppe di Lampedusa
(Cover To Cover, £21.99, 465 min unabridged)
Sicily, 1861 Garibaldi has beaten the Bourbons. The world has two new biscuits and modern Italy is born. Don Fabrizio, Prince of Salina, a compassionate despot, mourns the withering of his class's dominance in feudal Sicily while understanding that change must happen. Corin Redgrave reads it deliciously with spurts of passion for the wonderful descriptions of fading aristocratic grandeur. (Available only by mail order from Cover to Cover; telephone 01672 562255.)

Endurance
Alfred Lansing
(Orion, £12.99, 365 min, abridged)
Endurance was the ship Sir Ernest Shackleton took to the Antarctic in 1914. It was soon trapped, then crushed by ice. The title describes what happens next to the crew on a drifting ice pack in one of the world's least human-friendly regions. Shackleton's 650-mile bid to cross the appalling Weddell Sea in a lifeboat to raise help will never be topped. Tim Pigott-Smith gives it a superb white-knuckle reading.

Stalingrad <BR Antony Beevor
(Isis, £21.99, 17.5 hrs)
The morass of daily advance and retreat at this city that Hitler wanted to grab, and Stalin to hold at any cost, are tricky enough for the non-military enthusiast to retain from the printed page. Audio scores in uttering aloud the many snapshots of courage, degradation and incredible endurance which cram the book. Michael Tudor Barnes uses a dour delivery with a sepulchral sheen.

An Accidental MP
written and read by Martin Bell
(Penguin, £8.99, 165 min abridged)
Bell's account of stumbling into the Commons as the first independent MP in nigh-on 50 years is truly riveting. The first to land a blow on Blair in the Ecclestone affair, Bell concludes that political sleaze has not been killed, just slithered out of reach of its opponents.

The Periodic Kingdom
Peter Atkins
(Orion, £9.99, 180 min)
Oxford's professor of chemistry poetically presents the chart as a series of landscapes. Risk having your dormant interest in chemistry rekindled.

ABC of Relativity
Bertrand Russell
(Orion, £8.99, 180 min)
Risk the same with physics. If only we'd all had Derek Jacobi delivering Russell's sparkling introduction to Einstein first time around when the subject was murdered at school. He makes Russell's guide through the theories of special and general relativity for folk with no mathematical knowledge sound as fresh as it did in 1958.

The Lady in the Van
written and read by Alan Bennett
(BBC Radio, £8.99, 100 min)
Bennett loves eccentrics, and they're obviously drawn to him. For 15 years until her death, a dotty, elderly vagabond, Mary Shepherd, lived in a van in his front yard. It's delivered in his hallmark Eeyore tones.

Selections from The Decameron
Boccaccio
(Naxos, £11.99, 280min)
Naxos continues its noble mission of recording the masterpieces of world literature. Eight performers plus the incomparable Stephen Thorne as linkman narrate these bawdy tales with relish and zest.

The Gielgud Collection
(Hodder Headline, £8.99, 120 min)
An eclectic hotchpotch of the great man's recordings, including The Song of Hiawatha (smile at his "wampum"), This Sceptre'd Isle and, most delicious of all, The Owl and The Pussycat. What a loss!
fields.bodyText: It's been another annus mirabilis for audiobooks, at least in the numbers of new titles that have come out. The monthly trickle of just five years ago has now become a gush. Any book looking even a half-likely seller is now issued in audio at the same time. The Leopard Giuseppe di Lampedusa (Cover To Cover, £21.99, 465 min unabridged) Sicily, 1861 Garibaldi has beaten the Bourbons. The world has two new biscuits and modern Italy is born. Don Fabrizio, Prince of Salina, a compassionate despot, mourns the withering of his class's dominance in feudal Sicily while understanding that change must happen. Corin Redgrave reads it deliciously with spurts of passion for the wonderful descriptions of fading aristocratic grandeur. (Available only by mail order from Cover to Cover; telephone 01672 562255.) Endurance Alfred Lansing (Orion, £12.99, 365 min, abridged) Endurance was the ship Sir Ernest Shackleton took to the Antarctic in 1914. It was soon trapped, then crushed by ice. The title describes what happens next to the crew on a drifting ice pack in one of the world's least human-friendly regions. Shackleton's 650-mile bid to cross the appalling Weddell Sea in a lifeboat to raise help will never be topped. Tim Pigott-Smith gives it a superb white-knuckle reading. Stalingrad

fields.headline: Champions of the written word
fields.standfirst: From cricket's secret hero to boxing's greatest, Stephen Moss surveys the sporting year
fields.trailText: From cricket's secret hero to boxing's greatest, Stephen Moss surveys the sporting year.
fields.body:
What links the eight books I recommend below is that each is a labour of love (or sometimes obsession) on the part of author and publisher. They began with a passion, not a deal. Too many sports books are lazily written and abysmally produced, published on the assumption that myopic fans will buy anything. One reason specialist sports publisher Yellow Jersey has so quickly made an impact since its launch in 1998 is that its titles are carefully chosen and beautifully packaged. It produces good books, not big-name merchandise. Others are less discriminating and seem to think that getting a superstar's name on the contract is the end of the publishing process, not the beginning.

David Beckham's My World (Hodder & Stoughton, £16.99 Buy it at BOL) could have fallen into the merchandising trap - after all, a cornflakes packet with Beckham's chiselled features on the front would probably sell - but elegantly avoids it. With naive text, great pictures and terrific production standards, it is a brilliant artefact, like the player himself. Boring about footie - surely the least interesting thing about Becks - but good on Posh, Brooklyn, cooking, tattoos, cross-dressing and sexuality. "I'm not scared of my feminine side," he says, "and I think a lot of the things I do come from that side of my character." What will Robbie Fowler think?

Football, as Bill Shankly insisted, is more than a game, but he probably didn't foresee that it would become a subject for philosophical kickabouts. David Winner's Brilliant Orange: The Neurotic Genius of Dutch Football (Bloomsbury, £14.99 Buy it at BOL) is a book from the Nick Hornby school: wry, obsessional, digressive, deep. The opening up of Dutch society in the 1960s is paralleled by the rejection of outmoded footballing forms (defenders who just defend, attackers who merely attack) and a new commitment to "total football". This could have been tiresomely self-conscious, like so many Hornby writealikes, but thanks to Winner's lifelong fascination with his subject it isn't. The first chapter is numbered five; chapter one comes sixth; you will have to buy the book to discover the perfectly logical reason why.

John Duncan's In the Red Corner: A Journey Into Cuban Boxing (Yellow Jersey Press, £12 Buy it at BOL) is another obsessive treatment of a distinctive sporting culture and a shaggy dog story recounting Duncan's attempt to set up a fight between Mike Tyson and the Cuban Olympic heavyweight champion Felix Savon. Duncan gets nowhere with his quest, but does spend an enjoyable and illuminating year in Cuba at the expense of boxing promoter Frank Warren. (The author keeps wicket in the cricket team I play for, so you may wish to discount this selection.)

A useful rule of thumb with sports books is that the gems are found in the least likely places. Jack Iverson played five Tests for Australia half a century ago; his first-class career lasted barely three years. Not, on the surface, obvious material for a 376-page biography. But Iverson's career trajectory was like no other cricketer's, and Gideon Haigh has written a superb book about him, Mystery Spinner: The Story of Jack Iverson (Aurum Press, £18.99 Buy it at BOL). Iverson, who developed an unusual way of spinning the ball, didn't play top-flight cricket until he was 31. His rise thereafter was meteoric, but he never quite believed in himself and soon abandoned play. Haigh brilliantly reconstructs this almost forgotten figure without, as he admits, ever understanding why, at the age of 58, he killed himself.

The best sporting stories are human dramas, and one of the greatest is told in Lance Armstrong's It's Not About The Bike (Yellow Jersey Press, £17 Buy it at BOL). In 1996, at the age of 25, American cyclist Armstrong was diagnosed with cancer. He fought it, beat it and, three years later, won the Tour de France. This is a gripping story: from fatherless childhood, through devastating diagnosis and treatment, to triumph in the toughest endurance test in the world. His single-mindedness and his strength of character shine through on every page, and the reader is left with the impression that after winning the battle against cancer riding over the Alps was a doddle.

All sport is about remembered greatness, and there is nothing more affecting than the physical decline of Muhammad Ali, the best boxer and one of the most vivid personalities of all time. Flip Schulke and Matt Schudel's Muhammad Ali: The Birth of a Legend, Miami 1961-1964 (Souvenir Press, £18.99 Buy it at BOL) captures him in his youthful prime, training in Miami in the years between his Olympic gold medal and his assault on Sonny Liston's world title. Schulke's photographs of the exuberant Cassius Clay - he changed his name to Muhammad Ali when he embraced Islam in 1964 - are remarkable, and well supported by Schudel's brisk text.

Too few "proper" historians write about sport, but David Underdown, a specialist in early modern England and a cricket nut, is an exception. Start of Play: Cricket and Culture in Eighteenth-Century England (Penguin, £20 Buy it at BOL) is a readable, insightful, meticulously sourced history that demonstrates the strength and popularity of the professional game a century before the age of Grace. Most chroniclers of cricket are preoccupied with statistics; this book largely ignores scores and relates the game to a rapidly changing society. A cut above the average.

"Horses break the bank, they break your bones, they break your heart," says Times sports writer Simon Barnes in the introduction to On Horseback (HarperCollins, £17.99 Buy it at BOL), a collection of his pieces about the four-legged fiends. But none of the damage has stopped him adoring them, as writer and rider. Barnes is both wise and lyrical on sport, alert to its essence, aware of its banalities, anxious to extol its moments of grace and beauty. Overpriced for an anthology of previously published pieces, but Barnes is a thoroughbred.
