webTitle: The best books of 2000 in brief

fields.headline: Take a whistlestop tour of 2000
fields.standfirst: What to ask for, what to give: these are the gems Guardian critics discovered over the past year
fields.trailText: What to ask for, what to give: these are the gems Guardian critics discovered over the past year.
fields.body:
History

Enlightenment: Britain and the Creation of the Modern World
by Roy Porter
Viking, £25
Buy it at BOL
What does it mean to say that people in periwigs created the modern world more than 200 years ago, before electricity, before emancipation, before revolution? Roy Porter's headlong, heady new book provides thrilling insights into the century of Paine and Pope, of Newton, Locke and Hume, while offering some thought-provoking modern parallels - the daily post with email, Restoration theatre with television, Christian economists with Thatcherism, and so on.

Dark Valley: A Panorama of the 1930s
by Piers Brendon
Cape, £25
Buy it at BOL
Brendon's authoritative and provocative book provides a timely reminder that we're wrong to think of globalisation as a purely modern phenomenon. He presents the 30s as a decade in which each apparently independent part of the world depended on the others. Wall Street crashed and took Tokyo with it.

No Logo
by Naomi Klein
Flamingo, £14.99
Buy it at BOL
Klein's rallying cry against global capitalism is so immediate and timely that it seems almost perverse to classify it as history: but this book will go down as a monument to the dawn of political consciousness in Generation X.

Dr Seuss Goes to War: the World War II Editorial Cartoons of Theodor Seuss Geisel
edited by Richard H Minear
Verso, £17 (January 2001)
Buy it at BOL
Dr Seuss has been such an integral part of childhood for the last two generations that it's almost shocking to find him putting his graphic wit and high-hatted cats to the sly service of the US propaganda machine. The Cat in the Hat may have come back, but fortunately the fasc in the 'tache did not.

Memoirs and letters

Bad Blood
by Lorna Sage
Fourth Estate, £15.99
Buy it at BOL
Lorna Sage's Whitbread-nominated memoir is one of the surprise successes of the autumn: an almost unbearably eloquent account of the unlikely childhood and adolescence that shaped this distinguished academic. Few others have destroyed so successfully the fantasy of the family as a safe place to be or described so well the way in which rage, grief and frustrated desire are passed down the family line like a curse.

Experience
by Martin Amis
Cape, £18
Buy it at BOL
We've all heard the stories about Famous Amis, but here's what they look like from the inside. In what is arguably his best book, he grapples with recent public traumas: the death of his father, Kingsley; the discovery that his cousin, Lucy Partington, who disappeared in 1973, was a victim of Fred West; the realisation that he had a teenage daughter from a distant relationship. But he does so with delicacy and - strangely for such a work of disclosure - a fine sense of private dignity.

Selected Letters of Rebecca West
edited by Bonnie Kime Scott
Yale University Press, £25
Buy it at BOL
Rebecca West is a sadly neglected figure whose masterwork, Black Lamb and Grey Falcon, was one of the great books of the last century. Her letters are irresistible - a mixture of wicked character assassination (of everyone from Virginia Woolf to Jean Rhys to Henry Miller) and shrewd social commentary, as well as a troubling portrait of a brilliant woman whose powers turned so against her that even her only son finally denounced her.

Complete Letters of Oscar Wilde
edited by Merlin Holland and Rupert Hart-Davis
Fourth Estate, £35
Buy it at BOL
It would be hard to have missed the fact that this is Oscar's centenary year. Of all the books and revivals and exhibitions, this is the piece de resistance: meticulously edited by Wilde's grandson Merlin Holland, it is the most comprehensive collection yet of Wilde's correspondence, and charts his development from ambitious young man about town to literary dandy and tortured outcast.

Science

Something New Under the Sun: An Environmental History of the 20th Century
by John McNeill
Allen Lane, £20
Buy it at BOL
McNeill produces some mind-boggling statistics to support his thesis that we may have pushed the earth to the brink of global extinction. For instance, in the last century, humanity moved more rock and soil around the globe than did wind, glaciers, mountain-building processes or volcanoes; so numerous and powerful have we become that we now collectively qualify as a geological process. This may sound frightening, but McNeill is no scaremonger: he provides us with the evidence to make up our own minds.

Trilobite! Eyewitness to Evolution
by Richard Fortey
HarperCollins, £15.99
Buy it at BOL
Trilobites, mysterious little fossilised animals which played a key part in the discovery of time, are Richard Fortey's obsession. The Natural History Museum expert has used their story to tell a number of other narratives: of the revelations of evolution, of how science is done and of the strange people who do it. If there is any justice, Trilobite! will do for palaeontology what Longitude did for navigation.

Seeing And Believing: The Story of the Telescope, or How We Found our Place in the Universe
by Richard Panek
Fourth Estate, £12
Buy it at BOL
Panek's eye-popping book - brief enough to be gobbled at one sitting, rich enough to re-open immediately - is a story of ever-expanding horizons starting with Galileo's perspicillum. Astronomers now penetrate the past by looking across distances so vast that, astronomical having become an abused adjective, there are no words that fit. Panek takes us on a trip from a garden in Padua almost to the edge of time itself - most of it down a little tube with glass at each end.

Just Six Numbers
by Martin Rees
Phoenix, £7.99
Buy it at BOL
This short and admirably lucid introduction to modern cosmology dispenses once and for all with the hope that physics, with all its breathtaking complexities, would somehow go away. In fact, as Rees shows, physics and cosmology are now joined in an arc of knowledge in which theories of the most fundamental particles feed into accounts of the development of the whole universe. At the bottom of it all lies a series of numbers.

Poetry

Marfan
by Peter Reading
Bloodaxe, £6.95
Buy it at BOL
This collection marks a welcome return by this remarkable writer to a poetry of anecdote and reportage, great jokes and dark visions. The poems simmer with humanist political rage and epicurean nihilism, satirising small-town Texas while also strangely celebrating it.

Live from the Hong Kong Nile Club
by August Kleinzahler
Faber, £8.99
Buy it at BOL
This recently published collection is a selection of early poems by a formidably gifted American lyric poet who was recently (and intelligently) compared to Tom Waits.

Selected Poems
by Denise Riley
Reality Street Editions, £7.50
Buy it at BOL
Work by one of the most interesting and admired "avant-garde" poets (for want of a better term), whose critical work as well as her poetry has inspired many other writers. Wide-ranging, sometimes anguished, her poems are fascinating and often beautiful, and certainly more than usually thought-provoking.

Boss Cupid
by Thom Gunn
Faber, £7.99
Buy it at BOL
Gunn's generous poetry, passionate and tactful in equal measure, moves between elegy and celebration with enviable fluency and breadth of technique.

Selected Poems
by Veronica Forrest-Thomson
Invisible Books, £10.95
One for the adventurous: a collection by the late Veronica Forrest-Thomson, whose writing dances on top of Wittgenstein's ideas before flying upwards and onwards. It is intellectually demanding but also charming, camp, vivacious, chirpy and self-doubting, and the volume comes with an essay placing her in a sometimes forgotten tradition of British writing.

Travel

Mexico City - A Cultural And Literary Companion
by Nick Caistor
SignalBooks, £12
Buy it at BOL
In February 1978, electricians burying cables at the back of the cathedral in the central plaza stumbled on the remains of El Templo Mayor, the vast pyramid that the Aztecs had built in the middle of Lake Texcoco to represent the centre of their world. Since then, more and more of the old buildings have been exposed, adding yet another dimension to what many believe is now the largest city in the world. Nick Caistor plots a path through the smog to the very centre of Mexico's psyche.

A Naturalist's Guide To The Tropics
by Marco Lambertini
University of Chicago Press, £17.50
Buy it at BOL
This book is designed for the rucksack rather than the coffee table, making it doubly appealing to the armchair traveller. Like all field guides, it exudes authority. When it tells you that the combined weight of the termites and ants in Malaysia is greater than that of all the hoofed animals, you had better believe it. Colourful as coral (the photographs and charts are a delight), yet dense as what we used to call jungle, this compact volume will have you out of here in no time.

Home Truths
by Bill Murphy
Mainstream, £7.99
Buy it at BOL
Having spent eight months touring ordinary English towns and cities, Murphy concludes that, with the possible exception of Norwich, the country and all who sail in her has gone to the dogs. He went where few travel writers venture - places like Woking, Macclesfield, Huntingdon and Romford - and spent his time in town-centre pubs and cheap Chinese restaurants, the 60s housing estates and 80s shopping malls that are home to most of the English most of the time. Hilarious and depressing by turns.

An Unexpected Light: Travels In Afghanistan
by Jason Elliot
Picador, £16.99
Buy it at BOL
Elliot has little time for the travel writer who "preys shamelessly for as long as the family trust fund will allow on the hospitality of the native people, and returns home to hastily record his or her first impressions in a semi-fictional collection of descriptions that affirm the prejudices of the day". Elliot is made of sterner stuff, and has several awards to prove it. He was 19 when he first got a taste for dodging bullets with somebody else's name on them. The bullets then were Russian, and the name they bore was Mujaheddin. A decade on, and Elliot is back - this time in Taliban territory. And not a trust fund in sight.

In Nevada
by David Thomson
Little Brown, £20
Buy it at BOL
Pronounce Nevada, instructs Thomson, with a short second syllable, so it echoes not "larder" but "sadder". And then he takes you for a long drive out of Lake Tahoe and past the last town with its one-pump gas station, onward and out into the Black Rock Desert - for desert and desertedness, he declares, are the true character of Nevada. And Vegas? "Have no fear," he says. "We do get to Las Vegas eventually."

Hungry For Home
by Cole Moreton
Viking, £14.99
Buy it at BOL
Stand on the edge of Kerry - the most westerly point of the European mainland - and on a clear day you will see the Blasket Islands. Blasket: the very name smells of cold, wet stone. It's half a century since the islanders, grown weary of their hard, medieval lives, begged the authorities to ship them out for good, but the story has lost none of its resonance. And where did they vanish to, those survivors of an ancient race? Moreton found many of them living now in the most modern country in the world.

Abdul's Taxi To Kalighat
by Joe Roberts
Profile Books, £15.99
Buy it at BOL
To Joe, Emma and baby Llewelyn, just arrived from Bath, the Fairlawn hotel in Calcutta seems like a bit of an England that never was, or Fawlty Towers transported to the poorest city on earth. Except that, for all its poverty, Calcutta has a lot more going for it than all those documentaries about Mother Teresa had us believe. It is a living kaleidoscope, says Roberts, and a city buzzing with conversations. It is those conversations, acutely observed, that run through this book like veins of liqueur in some exotic ice cream.

Showbiz

Still Memories: An Autobiography in Photography
by John Mills
Hutchinson, £20
Buy it at BOL
As well as being one of the last survivors of a titanic generation of actors, John Mills is a dab hand with a camera. His photographic odyssey through his own life provides a priceless glimpse of the fun behind the fame, featuring such well-known mischief makers as Laurence Olivier, Peter Sellers and, well, just about everyone actually.

Collected Screenplays 1-3
by Harold Pinter
Faber, £20
Buy it at BOL
Harold Pinter's 70th birthday year has prompted a scattering of theatrical celebrations. Here is a decisive reminder that he is also one of the great British screenwriters, with credits ranging from The Go-Between and The French Lieutenant's Woman to The Comfort of Strangers.

Diaries 1969-1977
by Peter Nichols
Nick Hern Books, £25
Buy it at BOL
In an arena not chiefly known for its self-scrutiny, here is a provocative, truthful and scarringly witty account of the life of a playwright. Nichols (creator of A Day in the Death of Joe Egg and Passion, among other plays) is one of the tribe who have gallingly seen early success slip away, while watching it stick like a limpet to their contemporaries. Nichols is duly galled. Scratchy and self-lacerating, this book places him up there with Simon Gray as one of the great theatre diarists.

The Sopranos: A Family History
Channel 4 Books, £15.99
Buy it at BOL
This purports to be the research notes of a mafia expert, author of such plausible works as Kinship Patterns in Mafia Life. It is so packed with wicked inventions, such as the family cashflow receipts from talent management at the Bada Bing strip joint, that it is clear real author Allen Rucker had a ball compiling it.

A Box of Alan Bennett: The Clothes They Stood Up In; The Lady in the Van, Father! Father! Burning Bright
Profile, £9.99
Buy it at BOL
Alan Bennett has made his life into a performance, in much the same way as Quentin Crisp - though to gentler, more wry effect. Here, prettily boxed, are three pieces originally seen in the London Review of Books. The Lady in the Van is autobiographical, the other two are fiction.

Sci-fi

Perdido Street Station
by China Miville
Macmillan, £16.99
Buy it at BOL
This is no run-of-the-mill fantasy novel. Having accidentally released a flock of rapacious killer butterflies, our hero has to hunt them down with the help of a dimension-jumping spider obsessed with adding new examples to its scissor collection. For once, comparisons with Gormenghast are justified.

Look to Windward
by Iain M Banks
Orbit, £16.99
Buy it at BOL
Ziller, the galactic equivalent of a Soviet dissident, has withdrawn into self-imposed exile on Masaq Orbital in protest at the political barbarism of his own people. Now writing a symphony to mark the moment when light from an exploding star will reach Masaq, he waits for the man he thinks means to kill him. Compassionate, literate and elegantly written, it confirms Banks as the standard by which the rest of SF is judged.

Dracula Cha Cha Cha
by Kim Newman
Simon & Schuster, £16.99
Buy it at BOL
Anybody who is anybody in the vampire world is in Rome for the marriage of Dracula. Few people could write a Dracula novel in which Dracula doesn't actually appear; imagine La Dolce Vita with vampires and you've got some idea.

Crime

Afraid to Death
by Marc Behm
No Exit Press, £6.99
Buy it at BOL
The long-awaited follow-up to the classic Eye of the Beholder plumbs new depths in obsession and brings gothic terror into the quiet of the American countryside.

Motherless Brooklyn
by Jonathan Lethem
Faber, £9.99
Buy it at BOL
A detective suffering from Tourette's Syndrome charts new territory for crime fiction in this deserved winner of the Crime Writers' Association's Gold Dagger.

God Is a Bullet
by Boston Teran
Macmillan, £10
Buy it at BOL
Teran was a surprising winner of the John Creasey Award for best first novel; in this stunning book he takes a despairing look at the dark side of the American dream.

Run
by Douglas Winter
Canongate, £10
Buy it at BOL
Winter out-Tarantinos Tarantino in a novel with the pace of a bullet, which takes you on a nervy ride full of unforgettable villains and gun-runners with treachery on every highway corner.
fields.bodyText: History Enlightenment: Britain and the Creation of the Modern World by Roy Porter Viking, £25 Buy it at BOL What does it mean to say that people in periwigs created the modern world more than 200 years ago, before electricity, before emancipation, before revolution? Roy Porter's headlong, heady new book provides thrilling insights into the century of Paine and Pope, of Newton, Locke and Hume, while offering some thought-provoking modern parallels - the daily post with email, Restoration theatre with television, Christian economists with Thatcherism, and so on. Dark Valley: A Panorama of the 1930s by Piers Brendon Cape, £25 Buy it at BOL Brendon's authoritative and provocative book provides a timely reminder that we're wrong to think of globalisation as a purely modern phenomenon. He presents the 30s as a decade in which each apparently independent part of the world depended on the others. Wall Street crashed and took Tokyo with it. No Logo by Naomi Klein Flamingo, £14.99 Buy it at BOL Klein's rallying cry against global capitalism is so immediate and timely that it seems almost perverse to classify it as history: but this book will go down as a monument to the dawn of political consciousness in Generation X. Dr Seuss Goes to War: the World War II Editorial Cartoons of Theodor Seuss Geisel edited by Richard H Minear Verso, £17 (January 2001) Buy it at BOL Dr Seuss has been such an integral part of childhood for the last two generations that it's almost shocking to find him putting his graphic wit and high-hatted cats to the sly service of the US propaganda machine. The Cat in the Hat may have come back, but fortunately the fasc in the 'tache did not. Memoirs and letters Bad Blood by Lorna Sage Fourth Estate, £15.99 Buy it at BOL Lorna Sage's Whitbread-nominated memoir is one of the surprise successes of the autumn: an almost unbearably eloquent account of the unlikely childhood and adolescence that shaped this distinguished academic. Few others have destroyed so successfully the fantasy of the family as a safe place to be or described so well the way in which rage, grief and frustrated desire are passed down the family line like a curse. Experience by Martin Amis Cape, £18 Buy it at BOL We've all heard the stories about Famous Amis, but here's what they look like from the inside. In what is arguably his best book, he grapples with recent public traumas: the death of his father, Kingsley; the discovery that his cousin, Lucy Partington, who disappeared in 1973, was a victim of Fred West; the realisation that he had a teenage daughter from a distant relationship. But he does so with delicacy and - strangely for such a work of disclosure - a fine sense of private dignity. Selected Letters of Rebecca West edited by Bonnie Kime Scott Yale University Press, £25 Buy it at BOL Rebecca West is a sadly neglected figure whose masterwork, Black Lamb and Grey Falcon, was one of the great books of the last century. Her letters are irresistible - a mixture of wicked character assassination (of everyone from Virginia Woolf to Jean Rhys to Henry Miller) and shrewd social commentary, as well as a troubling portrait of a brilliant woman whose powers turned so against her that even her only son finally denounced her. Complete Letters of Oscar Wilde edited by Merlin Holland and Rupert Hart-Davis Fourth Estate, £35 Buy it at BOL It would be hard to have missed the fact that this is Oscar's centenary year. Of all the books and revivals and exhibitions, this is the piece de resistance: meticulously edited by Wilde's grandson Merlin Holland, it is the most comprehensive collection yet of Wilde's correspondence, and charts his development from ambitious young man about town to literary dandy and tortured outcast. Science Something New Under the Sun: An Environmental History of the 20th Century by John McNeill Allen Lane, £20 Buy it at BOL McNeill produces some mind-boggling statistics to support his thesis that we may have pushed the earth to the brink of global extinction. For instance, in the last century, humanity moved more rock and soil around the globe than did wind, glaciers, mountain-building processes or volcanoes; so numerous and powerful have we become that we now collectively qualify as a geological process. This may sound frightening, but McNeill is no scaremonger: he provides us with the evidence to make up our own minds. Trilobite! Eyewitness to Evolution by Richard Fortey HarperCollins, £15.99 Buy it at BOL Trilobites, mysterious little fossilised animals which played a key part in the discovery of time, are Richard Fortey's obsession. The Natural History Museum expert has used their story to tell a number of other narratives: of the revelations of evolution, of how science is done and of the strange people who do it. If there is any justice, Trilobite! will do for palaeontology what Longitude did for navigation. Seeing And Believing: The Story of the Telescope, or How We Found our Place in the Universe by Richard Panek Fourth Estate, £12 Buy it at BOL Panek's eye-popping book - brief enough to be gobbled at one sitting, rich enough to re-open immediately - is a story of ever-expanding horizons starting with Galileo's perspicillum. Astronomers now penetrate the past by looking across distances so vast that, astronomical having become an abused adjective, there are no words that fit. Panek takes us on a trip from a garden in Padua almost to the edge of time itself - most of it down a little tube with glass at each end. Just Six Numbers by Martin Rees Phoenix, £7.99 Buy it at BOL This short and admirably lucid introduction to modern cosmology dispenses once and for all with the hope that physics, with all its breathtaking complexities, would somehow go away. In fact, as Rees shows, physics and cosmology are now joined in an arc of knowledge in which theories of the most fundamental particles feed into accounts of the development of the whole universe. At the bottom of it all lies a series of numbers. Poetry Marfan by Peter Reading Bloodaxe, £6.95 Buy it at BOL This collection marks a welcome return by this remarkable writer to a poetry of anecdote and reportage, great jokes and dark visions. The poems simmer with humanist political rage and epicurean nihilism, satirising small-town Texas while also strangely celebrating it. Live from the Hong Kong Nile Club by August Kleinzahler Faber, £8.99 Buy it at BOL This recently published collection is a selection of early poems by a formidably gifted American lyric poet who was recently (and intelligently) compared to Tom Waits. Selected Poems by Denise Riley Reality Street Editions, £7.50 Buy it at BOL Work by one of the most interesting and admired "avant-garde" poets (for want of a better term), whose critical work as well as her poetry has inspired many other writers. Wide-ranging, sometimes anguished, her poems are fascinating and often beautiful, and certainly more than usually thought-provoking. Boss Cupid by Thom Gunn Faber, £7.99 Buy it at BOL Gunn's generous poetry, passionate and tactful in equal measure, moves between elegy and celebration with enviable fluency and breadth of technique. Selected Poems by Veronica Forrest-Thomson Invisible Books, £10.95 One for the adventurous: a collection by the late Veronica Forrest-Thomson, whose writing dances on top of Wittgenstein's ideas before flying upwards and onwards. It is intellectually demanding but also charming, camp, vivacious, chirpy and self-doubting, and the volume comes with an essay placing her in a sometimes forgotten tradition of British writing. Travel Mexico City - A Cultural And Literary Companion by Nick Caistor SignalBooks, £12 Buy it at BOL In February 1978, electricians burying cables at the back of the cathedral in the central plaza stumbled on the remains of El Templo Mayor, the vast pyramid that the Aztecs had built in the middle of Lake Texcoco to represent the centre of their world. Since then, more and more of the old buildings have been exposed, adding yet another dimension to what many believe is now the largest city in the world. Nick Caistor plots a path through the smog to the very centre of Mexico's psyche. A Naturalist's Guide To The Tropics by Marco Lambertini University of Chicago Press, £17.50 Buy it at BOL This book is designed for the rucksack rather than the coffee table, making it doubly appealing to the armchair traveller. Like all field guides, it exudes authority. When it tells you that the combined weight of the termites and ants in Malaysia is greater than that of all the hoofed animals, you had better believe it. Colourful as coral (the photographs and charts are a delight), yet dense as what we used to call jungle, this compact volume will have you out of here in no time. Home Truths by Bill Murphy Mainstream, £7.99 Buy it at BOL Having spent eight months touring ordinary English towns and cities, Murphy concludes that, with the possible exception of Norwich, the country and all who sail in her has gone to the dogs. He went where few travel writers venture - places like Woking, Macclesfield, Huntingdon and Romford - and spent his time in town-centre pubs and cheap Chinese restaurants, the 60s housing estates and 80s shopping malls that are home to most of the English most of the time. Hilarious and depressing by turns. An Unexpected Light: Travels In Afghanistan by Jason Elliot Picador, £16.99 Buy it at BOL Elliot has little time for the travel writer who "preys shamelessly for as long as the family trust fund will allow on the hospitality of the native people, and returns home to hastily record his or her first impressions in a semi-fictional collection of descriptions that affirm the prejudices of the day". Elliot is made of sterner stuff, and has several awards to prove it. He was 19 when he first got a taste for dodging bullets with somebody else's name on them. The bullets then were Russian, and the name they bore was Mujaheddin. A decade on, and Elliot is back - this time in Taliban territory. And not a trust fund in sight. In Nevada by David Thomson Little Brown, £20 Buy it at BOL Pronounce Nevada, instructs Thomson, with a short second syllable, so it echoes not "larder" but "sadder". And then he takes you for a long drive out of Lake Tahoe and past the last town with its one-pump gas station, onward and out into the Black Rock Desert - for desert and desertedness, he declares, are the true character of Nevada. And Vegas? "Have no fear," he says. "We do get to Las Vegas eventually." Hungry For Home by Cole Moreton Viking, £14.99 Buy it at BOL Stand on the edge of Kerry - the most westerly point of the European mainland - and on a clear day you will see the Blasket Islands. Blasket: the very name smells of cold, wet stone. It's half a century since the islanders, grown weary of their hard, medieval lives, begged the authorities to ship them out for good, but the story has lost none of its resonance. And where did they vanish to, those survivors of an ancient race? Moreton found many of them living now in the most modern country in the world. Abdul's Taxi To Kalighat by Joe Roberts Profile Books, £15.99 Buy it at BOL To Joe, Emma and baby Llewelyn, just arrived from Bath, the Fairlawn hotel in Calcutta seems like a bit of an England that never was, or Fawlty Towers transported to the poorest city on earth. Except that, for all its poverty, Calcutta has a lot more going for it than all those documentaries about Mother Teresa had us believe. It is a living kaleidoscope, says Roberts, and a city buzzing with conversations. It is those conversations, acutely observed, that run through this book like veins of liqueur in some exotic ice cream. Showbiz Still Memories: An Autobiography in Photography by John Mills Hutchinson, £20 Buy it at BOL As well as being one of the last survivors of a titanic generation of actors, John Mills is a dab hand with a camera. His photographic odyssey through his own life provides a priceless glimpse of the fun behind the fame, featuring such well-known mischief makers as Laurence Olivier, Peter Sellers and, well, just about everyone actually. Collected Screenplays 1-3 by Harold Pinter Faber, £20 Buy it at BOL Harold Pinter's 70th birthday year has prompted a scattering of theatrical celebrations. Here is a decisive reminder that he is also one of the great British screenwriters, with credits ranging from The Go-Between and The French Lieutenant's Woman to The Comfort of Strangers. Diaries 1969-1977 by Peter Nichols Nick Hern Books, £25 Buy it at BOL In an arena not chiefly known for its self-scrutiny, here is a provocative, truthful and scarringly witty account of the life of a playwright. Nichols (creator of A Day in the Death of Joe Egg and Passion, among other plays) is one of the tribe who have gallingly seen early success slip away, while watching it stick like a limpet to their contemporaries. Nichols is duly galled. Scratchy and self-lacerating, this book places him up there with Simon Gray as one of the great theatre diarists. The Sopranos: A Family History Channel 4 Books, £15.99 Buy it at BOL This purports to be the research notes of a mafia expert, author of such plausible works as Kinship Patterns in Mafia Life. It is so packed with wicked inventions, such as the family cashflow receipts from talent management at the Bada Bing strip joint, that it is clear real author Allen Rucker had a ball compiling it. A Box of Alan Bennett: The Clothes They Stood Up In; The Lady in the Van, Father! Father! Burning Bright Profile, £9.99 Buy it at BOL Alan Bennett has made his life into a performance, in much the same way as Quentin Crisp - though to gentler, more wry effect. Here, prettily boxed, are three pieces originally seen in the London Review of Books. The Lady in the Van is autobiographical, the other two are fiction. Sci-fi Perdido Street Station by China Miville Macmillan, £16.99 Buy it at BOL This is no run-of-the-mill fantasy novel. Having accidentally released a flock of rapacious killer butterflies, our hero has to hunt them down with the help of a dimension-jumping spider obsessed with adding new examples to its scissor collection. For once, comparisons with Gormenghast are justified. Look to Windward by Iain M Banks Orbit, £16.99 Buy it at BOL Ziller, the galactic equivalent of a Soviet dissident, has withdrawn into self-imposed exile on Masaq Orbital in protest at the political barbarism of his own people. Now writing a symphony to mark the moment when light from an exploding star will reach Masaq, he waits for the man he thinks means to kill him. Compassionate, literate and elegantly written, it confirms Banks as the standard by which the rest of SF is judged. Dracula Cha Cha Cha by Kim Newman Simon & Schuster, £16.99 Buy it at BOL Anybody who is anybody in the vampire world is in Rome for the marriage of Dracula. Few people could write a Dracula novel in which Dracula doesn't actually appear; imagine La Dolce Vita with vampires and you've got some idea. Crime Afraid to Death by Marc Behm No Exit Press, £6.99 Buy it at BOL The long-awaited follow-up to the classic Eye of the Beholder plumbs new depths in obsession and brings gothic terror into the quiet of the American countryside. Motherless Brooklyn by Jonathan Lethem Faber, £9.99 Buy it at BOL A detective suffering from Tourette's Syndrome charts new territory for crime fiction in this deserved winner of the Crime Writers' Association's Gold Dagger. God Is a Bullet by Boston Teran Macmillan, £10 Buy it at BOL Teran was a surprising winner of the John Creasey Award for best first novel; in this stunning book he takes a despairing look at the dark side of the American dream. Run by Douglas Winter Canongate, £10 Buy it at BOL Winter out-Tarantinos Tarantino in a novel with the pace of a bullet, which takes you on a nervy ride full of unforgettable villains and gun-runners with treachery on every highway corner.

webTitle: The Journals of Woodrow Wyatt: From Major to Blair, 1992-97

fields.headline: The Journals of Woodrow Wyatt: From Major to Blair, 1992-97
fields.standfirst:
Macmillan, £25
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: The Voice of Reason make his third bid for stardom
fields.body:
Everyone has been congratulating me on being the only person to predict the outcome of the election. Except Rupert, who was a little short with me on the phone. I hope I am not on the way out from the Times or the News of the World.

Have been reading the proofs of William Shawcross's biography of Rupert. I sent William a stiff letter saying how badly he had misjudged Rupert and that he wasn't an enemy of the people. I also faxed Rupert a copy of this letter without telling William. Rupert telephoned to thank me and praised me for my insight.

Have written to all the new ministers to tell them how delighted I am by their appointments. My dear friend Norman is thrilled to have been given the grace-and-favour home Dorneywood, as it signifies he is not just a short-term chancellor.

At a party at the Channon's, Bianca Jagger remembered meeting me in the House of Lords. She is very pretty and must be like an octopus to go to bed with. Apparently, it wasn't Bianca after all; still, she's posh and foreign so it was an easy mistake to make.

Andrew Morton's biography of Princess Diana has just been published, and it's full of ridiculous suggestions that Prince Charles has been having an affair with Camilla Parker-Bowles. The Queen Mother, looking as gracious as ever, thanked me for what I wrote as we sat in the Royal Box at Ascot.

Poor Margaret. Major is being so beastly not making her a Life Countess. I invited her to dinner to commiserate. "At least Mark will be all right," she said. What a marvellously stoical woman.

Petronella wrote an article in the Sunday Telegraph about Margaret which said she might have got something wrong once. I must have a word with her about being snide. If she doesn't crawl no one will speak to her.

Poor Norman had to take all the flak for the ERM debacle, when he had been advising John to bail out days ago. Must put the record straight in my column.

Poor John having to deal with so many shits. England will commit an act of collective lunacy if it votes in Blair.

My throat is horribly constricted; I wonder if it is related to my chest infection.

And if you really are busy - the digested read, digested: The Voice of Reason make his third bid for stardom

fields.headline: Big spenders dig deeper
fields.standfirst:
Rio Ferdinand's proposed move heralds a new boom-or-bust philosophy
Rangers break the bank for Flo
fields.trailText: Rio Ferdinand's proposed move heralds a new boom-or-bust philosophy in the Premiership, write Daniel Taylor and Vivek Chaudhary.
fields.body:
After a two-month self-imposed moratorium, the British transfer market has burst into life once again with two deals the like of which have never been seen.

While Tore Andre Flo's £12m move from Chelsea to Rangers yesterday constituted a Scottish transfer record, Leeds United were putting the final touches to the £18m deal - an English record - that would also make Rio Ferdinand the world's most expensive defender.

The Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale flew down to London yesterday and talks involving the England defender and his agent were progressing last night, though the West Yorkshire club were hopeful of completing a deal in time for Sunday's visit of Arsenal.

It is likely to prove the most extravagant 24 hours in the British game's history though it is not so much the level of the fees but the timing which has shocked the game.

For the past few months clubs have adopted widespread caution in the market, hardly daring to dip toes in the water for fear of spending heavily on a player who could walk out for nothing as soon as the EC delivers next month's directive on transfer regulations.

The reaction of George Graham was typical. "I was very surprised when I heard about the Ferdinand deal," said the Tottenham manager yesterday. "From what I am hearing, clubs are not prepared to go in for big transfers until they get a bit more information from the EC about the future of the transfer system."

His information, however, may be as out of date as his tactics. Privately many senior clubs are confident that despite changes to the transfer system, a compensation package will remain if players have the right to break contracts.

It is still not clear what the compensation will be based on, whether it will depend on the remainder of a player's contract or his worth to a club.

The players' union, whose members stand to gain most from lower fees and higher wages, is divided over the proposed changes.

The French and the Scandinavian players' unions are keen to ensure total freedom so that they will be able to break contracts given a period of notice. However Spanish, Italian and German unions are adamant that total freedom will be disastrous and that some kind of contractual stability must remain.

The willingness of most parties to see a continuation of some kind of recompense system has certainly been enough to encourage a loosening of the purse-strings. In September, straight after the EC cast doubt on the transfer system continuing, spending by Premiership clubs slumped to £4.475m. In June it had been £47.1m, rising to £84.5m in July and totalling £57m for August.

The market gained some confidence in October, with the £8m that Chelsea paid Ajax for Jesper Gronkjaer being the only really big deal among a host of smaller ones.

It is this month, though, that confidence has really returned. If the Ferdinand deal is completed Premiership clubs will have shelled out £22.25m this month, a figure that does not include the cash which Chelsea will receive for Flo.

For Ridsdale, however, the issue is more about how much money Leeds can make by having a successful side than about how much they might lose by a player walking away under any changed system.

"There are people not spending money who are having a pop at us, partly out of envy as much as anything else," he said. "I believe they are looking at the matter in a short-term and narrow-minded view.

"We generate our revenue from qualifying for Europe, the income of playing in the Champions League, the gate receipts, the sponsorship, everything that success brings. That type of money far outweighs anything we might lose in the transfer market.

"We exist to have the best possible team and if we are winning trophies and qualifying for the Champions League there should be no reason why our players would want to leave anyway.

"Our annual income has gone up from £20m to £57m and this year it should be more than £70m. That's not because of transfer dealings, it's because of our success on the pitch and the finance that attracts."

The difference between Ridsdale's attitude and Graham's highlights a gulf in thinking between the big clubs and the rest, who cannot afford to take a chance.

Brendon Batson of the Professional Footballers' Association believes there are "huge risks involved" for clubs willing to pay bloated transfer fees. "Peter Ridsdale has said it's an investment for the long-term future of Leeds but it's a risky move. As we stand, the whole matter regarding future transfers is far from resolved."

 EC heads of state are due to discuss a declaration for sport in Nice next month. There is growing political will for sport to be exempt from European competition laws under the Treaty of Rome.

June 47.1m

July 84.5m

August 57m

September 4.475m

October 23.26m

November 22.25m *

*Includes £18m Ferdinand (West Ham - Leeds). Doesn't include £12m Flo (Chelsea - Rangers)

webTitle: Rangers break bank as Flo prepares for baptism of fire

fields.headline: Rangers break bank as Flo prepares for baptism of fire
fields.trailText: Tore Ander Flo has finally become a Rangers player for £12m. His first duty will be to help secure a result against Celtic on Sunday.
fields.body:
Ibrox has witnessed a few exorbitant imports arriving in times of crisis but none of them has matched the unveiling by Rangers yesterday of Tore Andre Flo, their new £12m striker.

Dick Advocaat, the Rangers manager, blithely described the fee for the perennial Chelsea substitute as "far too much to pay for any footballer" but insisted the market had dictated that Rangers pay such a sum for the Norwegian international. The transfer represents a staggering increase in Flo's value given that Chelsea bought him for £300,000 three years ago.

The move marked the end of Flo's miserable bench-warming duties at Stamford Bridge, with the striker almost certain to experience the fiercest baptism in British football on Sunday when Rangers play Celtic at Ibrox. It also completes Advocaat's year-long quest for a striker, and for the club, currently in a state of high anxiety 15 points behind Celtic in the Premier League, his arrival could not be more timely. "He is a player I have been chasing for years," said Advocaat, whose first sighting of Flo was in the 1995-96 Cup-Winners' Cup when the Norwegian, then playing for Brann Bergen, single-handedly knocked Advocaat's PSV Eindhoven out of the competition.

"He destroyed us and I would have liked him then had we not already got Ronaldo and Luc Nilis at PSV. Flo is an excellent player with lots of skill, but more than that, he's coming at an excellent moment for Rangers."

This was a reference to the rockiest six weeks Advocaat has experienced as a manager. Rangers' disintegration on the home front and expulsion from the Champions League - both provoked to a large extent by a shocking toll of injuries - means the derby game and the upcoming Uefa Cup tie against Kaiserslautern could hardly look more ominous for Advocaat. The Dutchman has now spent £74m on transfers in 30 months at Rangers.

Flo yesterday explained away any wrenches he felt at having to leave the Premiership. "I really liked life at Chelsea but quickly realised when I wasn't playing that I had to do something," he said. "When Rangers came for me I spoke with guys like Jim Duffy and Ray Wilkins [both on Chelsea's coaching staff], both of whom said that this was a great club. I'm delighted with the chance Rangers have offered me and I want to win things here."

webTitle: Just like home for happy Hoggard

fields.headline: Just like home for happy Hoggard
fields.standfirst:
England quick bowler makes the most of the conditions to take four for 13
Pakistan Cricket Board XI 117
England 76-2
fields.trailText: Matthew Hoggard must wonder whether he has read his cricket books quite right. Pakistan, is it not, is a land of dust and heat, of flat and emasculating pitches, high scores ground out - Naved Latif's 394 for Sarghoda, a 13-hour epic compiled only last week, being merely the latest - and interminable draws? Unless they have mastered the mysteries of reverse swing, fast bowlers have tended not to come here by choice and they generally depart sore of foot with a throbbing bowling average.
fields.body:
Matthew Hoggard must wonder whether he has read his cricket books quite right. Pakistan, is it not, is a land of dust and heat, of flat and emasculating pitches, high scores ground out - Naved Latif's 394 for Sarghoda, a 13-hour epic compiled only last week, being merely the latest - and interminable draws? Unless they have mastered the mysteries of reverse swing, fast bowlers have tended not to come here by choice and they generally depart sore of foot with a throbbing bowling average.

But this young fellow thinks he is in paradise. Wherever he turns up to play, the grass grows miraculously and the air fills with moisture. They should send him to end the Afghan drought.

Yesterday, if he had ignored the honking traffic in the distance and the haze of smog that pervaded the atmosphere all day, he might have imagined he was at Chesterfield after an insertion on a damp pitch. He bowled like it too, taking four for 13 as England dismissed the Pakistan Cricket Board XI for 117 in just under 43 overs.

With the nine for 102 that he took in Rawalpindi in his only other match of the tour, he has now taken 13 wickets at fewer than nine runs apiece and that, whatever the conditions, is exceptional.

Maybe the atmosphere has something to do with it. The Bagh-e-Jinnah, known in another era as Lawrence Gardens and scene of three Tests in the 50s, is a wonderfully scenic parkland counterpoint to the usual concrete bowls.

Rohan Kanhai made a ravishing double hundred here and shared a stand of 162 with Gary Sobers and Wes Hall took a hat-trick. But that was then and this was now. The pitch yesterday was clammy all day (and may well remain so) and, perhaps influenced by the surroundings of high trees, the ball swung dizzily at times.

Hoggard did his damage in two spells, removing the one-time Test batsman Mohammad Ramzan with the new ball for a duck and then returning to mop up with a 21-ball spell of three for three.

It was an aggressive performance but then he cuts a figure to match with a No1 crop that suggests he has "love" and "hate" tattooed on his knuckles, even if his walk back to his mark resembles Gabriel Oak on the way home after a hard day in the fields.

Most eye-catching is the tight line he bowls, which rarely deviates from just outside off stump and is the product of an uncomplicated repeating action. He may not get a Test on this tour but he is within touching distance and will be keeping the other seamers on their toes. Competition in that department at least is healthy.

For batsmen looking to gain or maintain form for the Tests, this pitch is far from ideal. The movement afforded the seamers is unlikely to be repeated in Faisalabad or Karachi, and good work can be undone. Nonetheless Marcus Trescothick played with enviable technique and patience for almost two hours in making 28 not out of England's 76 for two against some testing and at times ferocious pace bowling from another former Test player, Fazal-e-Akbar, and the definitely un-Pakistani-sounding Stephen John before the smoggy light became too diffuse to allow them to continue.

Nasser Hussain opened the batting, played several resounding pulls and actually looked in fairly good order in making 23 before he edged the sort of delivery that will dismiss anyone. Perhaps it is a good sign that he got bat on it.

At the other end, John accounted for Graeme Hick, who had a torrid, almost embarrassing half-hour at the crease, during which his bat was beaten several times. He was unquestionably lbw to Fazal, dropped at mid-on from a mishook next ball, scored a boundary off the inside edge past his stumps and then edged tentatively to the wicketkeeper. Innings on pitches such as these need to be kept in perspective, but it did not look too clever.

 The former India captain Mohammad Azharuddin, who according a Central Bureau of Investigation report had admitted fixing matches, has denied the charge. "This is all wrong. I have done nothing of this kind," Azharuddin said in an interview published on the internet site Rediff.com. During the interview he was asked if he had admitted fixing matches. "They [the CBI] asked and they answered," he replied.

fields.headline: With love, and new life, from Hungary
fields.standfirst:
Amadinda Percussion Group
St Paul's Hall, Huddersfield
***
fields.trailText:
Amadinda Percussion Group
St Paul's Hall, Huddersfield
***
fields.body:
When music written 60 years ago by John Cage seems to take control of a concert in the Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival, you have to wonder if there was any other time in the history of the world in any art form where this could be possible. But it may just be that the Amadinda Percussion Group from Hungary succeed in breathing new life into those old works.

Led by Zoltan Racz, who can produce the most unbelievably beautiful sounds from a row of beer-cans, this quartet presented Cage's music with such astonishing control and range of expression that it upstaged most of the UK premieres they had to offer.

Laszlo Sary's three settings of Japanese poems translated into Hungarian were lovely and evocative, but at the same time a touch fey. Lukas Ligeti's Pattern Transformations, based on the music of the Buganda people, were extremely pretty and glowed with charm but hardly offered any great message for today.

The long Reconstruction Before John by Zoltan Vaczi, an Amadinda player, could almost be seen as a parody of modern music over the last 30 years, with every possible sound included: carpet-beating (with two different qualities of carpet), thwacking a besom, more beer-cans, alongside a vast range of more traditional percussion instruments. It rose gradually to an ear-splitting climax, which is probably the easiest of all formal devices.

And it came with an enormous programme note of impenetrable philosophy and numerology which also explained that it is in seven sections. Nobody could possibly have identified the sections, but that too may be part of the parody.

Another work by Vaczi and his colleague Aurel Hollo was shorter and a lot more fun, with bicycle wheels and frying-pans brought into the act.

But then came the song-cycle With Pipes, Drums, Fiddles by the grand old man of new music, Gyorgy Ligeti, now in his late 70s. First performed only a few weeks ago in Metz, this group of seven songs shows that Ligeti still bursts with new ideas and is an absolute master of his materials.

The range of instruments used for a mere 12 minutes of music must have needed an articulated lorry to transport, but he used them with a delicacy, variety, wit and sense of timing that evoke constant wonder. Although the sounds were familiar, there was not a note that seemed derivative or unoriginal.

The marvellous Katalin Karolyi sang the exceptionally wide-ranging lines with such clarity of expression that nobody need translations of the Hungarian texts.

 The Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival continues tomorrow and Sunday. Box office: 01484 430528.

fields.headline: The Fall fail to rise again
fields.standfirst:
The Fall
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Fall
Dingwalls, London
***
fields.body:
The last time I saw the Fall at Dingwalls, they were strictly a subsistence-level act, Mark E Smith and Julia Nagle struggling on with a fill-in drummer after the group proper combusted during an American tour. Since then, the duo have built up a new band or perhaps that should be two bands. There is the studio Fall, still making punchy, complex and inventive albums like last year's The Marshall Suite and their latest, The Unutterable. And there's the live Fall, which doesn't quite measure up, either to the band's brilliance on record or to the virtuosity of previous live line-ups.

The spirit isn't lacking: cocky young recruits Adam Helal and Neville Wilding do their stuff with aplomb, pushing the thumping bass and vindictive surf guitar respectively. But the sound rarely transcends standard garage-band dynamics; it's only when Nagle switches from guitar to keyboards that more interesting textures creep in.

Smith himself looks more battle-scarred and lemon-faced than ever. He grudgingly sidles on to the stage in his leather jacket looking like a sullen copper facing another day interrogating shoplifters. As a singer, Smith has almost entirely dispensed with consonants, and mostly sounds like a half-hearted W C Fields impersonator trying to dislodge a fishbone from his throat. Perhaps he's just had enough of the stage routine - you can only imagine what it must be like playing Fall gigs for 23 years of your life. He only really seemed to enjoy himself on the spirited rock 'n' roll revamp Foldin' Money.

A rather desultory set did the business on the more straightforward numbers - Touch Sensitive, The Joke, Wilding's sub-Stranglers number Hands Up Billy. The final encore was an unexpected revival of the 1985-vintage Paintwork - a spirited crowd-pleaser but a reminder that too much of the time, this line-up resembles a competent Fall tribute band (except that they don't play that many old Fall covers).

And yet there were a couple of moments I wouldn't have missed. One was a version of Dr Buck's Letter from the new record - its electronic creak entirely transformed into a moody semi-funk groove, as close as the Fall get to the Meters. And there was a delicate synthesiser interlude, over which MES intoned dryly and more or less intelligibly. One phrase rang clear as crystal: "What a pain in the arse this bloody group is" Who says he doesn't speak for his frustrated following?

 The Fall tour continues at the Lomax, Liverpool (0151-707 9977), tonight and the Liquid Room, Edinburgh (0131-225 2564), tomorrow.

fields.headline: RNCM Wind Orchestra
fields.standfirst:
Sema Group Concert Hall,
Manchester
***
fields.trailText:
Sema Group Concert Hall,
Manchester
***
fields.body:
Fresh, innovative works for wind bands are to be treasured, and the RNCM has not been backward in commissioning them. Its American Reflections concert featured two recent examples: Judith Bingham's 1997 Three American Icons and the world premiere of Philip Grange's Clarinet Concerto.

Written for Alan Hacker and more fully entitled Concerto Sheng Sheng Bu Shi for Solo Clarinet Radical and Symphonic Wind Band, the concerto's basic idea of individual-versus-crowd opposition was not new, but Grange's source of dramatic inspiration - the Tiananmen Square tragedy- is undeniably hard-hitting. Hacker was a compelling soloist but the work's toughness - only at the end relenting in the clarinet's wan, fragmented lament - was ultimately rather unforgiving.

Bingham's icons are Lee Harvey Oswald, Marilyn Monroe and J F Kennedy, and her work is whimsically set in the form of a French suite. Drawing on a range of idioms from jazz to Steve Reich, she elaborated on her subjects with panache. Oswald's dark portrait contrasted vividly with that of his victim, his portentous quasi-minimalism hovering threateningly over Kennedy's maniacal big band swing. Bingham's portrayals may be one-dimensional - her Marilyn obligingly oscillated between chaotic fragility and a fixed, artificial lyricism - but they are engagingly and colourfully drawn.

Copland's 1964 Emblems started the symbolic theme with evocations of "musical states of being" rather than images. With Richard Rodney Bennett's The Four Seasons and John Corigliano's 1970 Gazebo Dances, these were works in a more familiar mode, less inclined to explore new textures and irresistibly drawn to a full-blooded wind sound. Corigliano's lighthearted tribute to American rural band music was an unashamedly brash conclusion.

The RNCM band rose to the considerable challenges of a demanding programme with the indefatigable Timothy Reynish and the young Russian conductor Andrei Danilov.

 The American Reflections festival continues until December 15. Box office: 0161-273 6283.

webTitle: Gas and electricity bills may rise 25% in the new year

fields.headline: Gas and electricity bills may rise 25% in the new year
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Domestic gas and electricity bills are set to rise by as much as 25% in the new year because of soaring prices for oil and gas on world markets and growing imports, senior industry sources said yesterday.
fields.body:
Domestic gas and electricity bills are set to rise by as much as 25% in the new year because of soaring prices for oil and gas on world markets and growing imports, senior industry sources said yesterday.

The expected increases could begin to undo the steep reductions in bills brought about by price controls and competition among suppliers which, according to Callum McCarthy, the energy regulator, amount to £2.3bn a year.

Anna Walker, the director general for energy at the DTI, told an Institute of Economic Affairs conference in London that the UK faced a 100% rise in wholesale gas prices, primarily because of links to Europe.

Britain imports gas via the interconnector to Europe, where prices are index-linked to those for oil, and EU directives to open up energy markets are being flouted - especially in France.

Jeremy Nicholson, a policy adviser to the energy intensive users' group, said gas prices had doubled in the past year and had already cost heavy industry £500m in extra costs. "There is likely to be an impact on domestic bills next year," he said.

Experts said the initial impact would be felt on gas bills and would then fall on electricity bills, with one forecasting that consumers may have to pay up to a quarter more - particularly after Ofgem, the regulator, lifts price controls on gas in April.

Ann Robinson, the chairman of Energywatch, the new consumer watchdog, said the rises would begin to hit consumers from January or February.

"I suspect any increase in gas prices will work in favour of the dominant supplier, British Gas, which will be in a strong position because of its huge customer base and low infrastructure costs to absorb them more easily than smaller competitors," she said.

Ms Robinson said competition was not working because BG, part of Centrica, retained a 70% market share and only 17% of electricity consumers had switched supplier. "This is in my view way, way too low." She said the 6m UK households suffering fuel poverty had benefited least from competition.

webTitle: Britain's trade deficit soars to record

fields.headline: Britain's trade deficit soars to record
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's quarterly trade deficit with the rest of the world jumped to the highest level ever recorded in the three months to September according to official figures yesterday, writes Charlotte Denny .
fields.body:
Britain's quarterly trade deficit with the rest of the world jumped to the highest level ever recorded in the three months to September according to official figures yesterday, writes Charlotte Denny .

The gap between exports and imports stood at £7.7bn over the last quarter, according to the office for national statistics. But while exporters have blamed the high level of the pound against the euro for their difficulties, the ONS data showed that it is trade with countries outside the European Union which is collapsing.

The deficit with non-EU countries stood at a record £7.5bn over the last quarter, while the deficit with countries within the European Union was £178m, the lowest shortfall for nearly 10 years.

"Trade with the EU remains buoyant, in direct contrast to that with the rest of the world where the trend continues to show a growing deficit," said Ross Walker from Royal Bank of Scotland.

Britain's trade deficit with the rest of the world in September stood at £2.5bn, £300m higher than the previous month, the ONS said. Stripping out oil, where rising crude prices pushed the surplus to a 15-year high, the monthly deficit stood at a record £3.2bn.

The gap between exports and imports stood at £7.7bn over the last quarter, according to the office for national statistics. But while exporters have blamed the high level of the pound against the euro for their difficulties, the ONS data showed that it is trade with countries outside the European Union which is collapsing. The deficit with non-EU countries stood at a record £7.5bn over the last quarter, while the deficit with countries within the European Union was £178m, the lowest shortfall for nearly 10 years. "Trade with the EU remains buoyant, in direct contrast to that with the rest of the world where the trend continues to show a growing deficit," said Ross Walker from Royal Bank of Scotland. Britain's trade deficit with the rest of the world in September stood at £2.5bn, £300m higher than the previous month, the ONS said. Stripping out oil, where rising crude prices pushed the surplus to a 15-year high, the monthly deficit stood at a record £3.2bn.

webTitle: The growth of online share dealing

fields.headline: Net growth
fields.trailText: Internet share dealers may have got stung when technology stocks crashed earlier this year, but their enthusiasm for online facilities remained strong, prompting continued growth in the market and the launch of yet more services this week.
fields.body:
Internet share dealers may have got stung when technology stocks crashed earlier this year, but their enthusiasm for online facilities remained strong, prompting continued growth in the market and the launch of yet more services this week.

Fidelity Investments hit the market with ShareNetwork, a service that lets its customers buy from over 2,000 stocks and shares at £14.50 per deal. Citibank is thinking along the same lines. It will give customers access to over 2,300 companies, with trades costing between £20 and £50, depending on their size.

Meanwhile, existing internet share dealer E*Trade is transforming itself into a 'clicks and mortar' operation with plans to put dealing centres in shops and retail outlets. And companies aimed at helping the novice share dealer are springing up. Trade Basics, an online education tool for would-be internet dealers or those who want to supplement their knowledge, also went live this week.

Fidelity was moved to launch its service after 41% of its customers cited share-dealing facilities as the most requested service on the internet. This is backed up by findings from ComPeer and the Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers (APCIMS). They say the number of online share dealing accounts opened by individual investors rose to 303,000 in the three months to September 30, up from 257,000 in the three months to June 30.

APCIMS figures for the number of execution-only deals - deals done exclusively over the phone or through the web - also point to a significant increase in the popularity of internet dealing. In third quarter 1999 one in 100 execution-only deals where done over the internet. By third quarter 2000 this had leaped to one in every four deals.

There are 16 million individual share owners in the UK, holding stocks worth £330bn at the end of last year.

webTitle: Want to make your own Star Wars movie? We did

fields.headline: Want to make your own Star Wars movie? We did
fields.standfirst: Howard Wen  on the fan films proliferating on the net - with or without their inspirations' blessing
fields.trailText: Howard Wen on the fan films proliferating on the net - with or without their inspirations' blessing
fields.body:
Have you seen The Dark Redemption, the Star Wars prequel film set days before the events of the original Star Wars? What about Bounty Trail, which features the further adventures of Star Wars intergalactic bounty hunter Boba Fett? Or how about that episode of The X-Files in which Mulder and Scully investigate the death of Elvis Presley? If Star Trek: Voyager isn't doing it for you, then take a look at the other Trek series, Hidden Frontier.

If the above sound like fanciful ideas dreamed up by fans, that's because they are. And the odd thing is, they also actually exist for you to watch and enjoy.

These are products of the 'fan film' scene - an offshoot culture of independent digital film-making. Fan films feature the characters, settings or premise of popular genre properties in stories that audiences will probably never get to see on the movie screen or television. Most fan film-makers go through the same hard work involved in making a typical independent short film - scriptwriting, casting, on-set production and post-production. The difference is that they work with a property that belongs to somebody else, in most cases without the consent of the original creator or copyright holder.

"I think with many of these properties the creators have crafted such fully realised universes that someone can come in and create their own story alongside the 'big boys,'" says Justin Young, a 21-year-old college student and fan film-maker who has produced his own films based on the "Highlander" movie and TV series.

But creating your own sequel or prequel to these "fully realized universes" has only recently become feasible for the average fan. Once upon a time, fans had to be content with penning a fan-fiction story (or writing the script for a "virtual season" for a TV show, for instance); these days, they can create and distribute actual films that, in their special effects at least, are not so far behind what's being releasing in cinemas.

Armed with inexpensive digital camcorders and broadband Net connections, fans now have the means to create and distribute their own audiovisual productions.

For a small group of devotees, fandom is becoming a matter of participation rather than just spectacle. In the process, fan film-makers may be helping to change the way we experience the movies.

Fan film-makers generally give credit for the current interest in fan films to Troops, the well-received parody film that crossed Star Wars with reality TV show Cops. Produced two years ago, Troops was distributed as large video files downloaded from web sites, the same way most fan films are released today.

What's striking about Troops is the effects. Here's a film, produced on a home PC, that does a not-half-bad job of mimicking the kinds of million-dollar bells and whistles George Lucas brought to the screen in Star Wars.

The technological success of Troops inspired fans to broaden their approach: Why make only parodies when you can do 'serious' short films set in the Star Wars universe?

Several Star Wars fan films are available online or in production. "For some reason we thought we were the only doofuses with this idea, that we'd be alone in kick-starting this new minigenre," says Devon Read, a 20-year-old graphic designer who's finishing up production on his Star Wars fan film.

While Star Wars remains the most popular subject by far, the world of fan films has grown to include unofficial films based on other properties like Star Trek, The X-Files, Highlander, Batman, Spiderman, The X-Men and more.

One obvious question from all of this: Why bother making a film based on somebody else's property, rather than something of your own creation?

"Hey, it's Star Wars!" explains Jeff Vitkuske, a high school student from Ontario, Canada, who is busy producing fan films based on Star Wars and The X-Men.

"It's great to make up something yourself," he says, "but let me tell you - there's nothing like watching yourself wielding a light saber!"

In fact, there's nothing new about fans co-opting their favourite media sensations. According to Henry Jenkins, director of comparative media studies at MIT, humans have always reinterpreted the stories they hear. "Throughout most of human history, people operated according to a folk culture model - that is, they saw themselves as entitled to add to or retell the core myths and stories of their culture."

Jenkins points out that more than 200 appropriations of Alice's Adventures in Wonderland were published in the 20 years after the novel first appeared and many of them circulated commercially. If anything, what's recent is the inflexibility of media corporations in responding to fans' creations.

"Contemporary mass culture assumes that the average citizen consumes but does not participate," says Jenkins, "whereas fandom holds onto the ideal of a culture where everyone is free and able to participate."

Not that many fan film-makers would turn down an offer to join the big studios. Both Troops and Bounty Trail helped their creators move on to work in the film industry. Bounty Trail caught the attention of Lucas, who subsequently hired the fan-film director to work on the production of the second Star Wars prequel.

While technology enables fan film-makers to achieve near Hollywood effects, it has not delivered the key to good film-making. The acting and screenwriting in most fan films are not exactly of Oscar-winning quality, and other production values tend to betray the films' amateur origins. In the Star Trek knockoff Hidden Frontier, you can't help speculating on the little things - like if those among the cast who actually look good in their Starfleet uniforms are the aspiring actors, while those who do not are the regulars at Trek conventions.

"My opinion on fan films (and I've only really seen the Star Wars ones) is that on the whole they're mediocre," says Scott Middlebrook, who has reviewed more than 60 fan-made films for Force Flicks, a Star Wars multimedia fan site.

"A lot of the more popular films are fairly average - nothing more than light saber duels with little or no story. Parodies seem to come up better than the serious films. I guess if the film's not taking itself too seriously, it's easier for the audience to do the same. Plus, 'Star Wars' fans can get a tad anal and nit-picking (myself included) about the more serious stuff."

But, again, the effects aren't half-bad. That's partly due to the immense amount of sharing on the internet among fan film-makers when it comes to special effects and other production techniques. Many designers who have made their own 3-D models of Star Wars vehicles and droids are willing to share their work for credit on a fan film.

A plethora of tutorials - essentially constituting a Star Wars Film-making for Dummies - show film-makers everything from how to create light saber and laser blast effects to making authentic-looking costumes and props. Says Justin Young: "We will always be a step or two behind ILM [Lucas' Industrial Light and Magic], but I think how close we have come would shock most people."

As for the legal issues, fan films appear to fall within a gray area between fan fiction and parody, both of which are legally protected under US law. Within the fan-film scene, de facto rules keep most fan film-makers from selling their work.

Still, at least one fan film has landed its producer in trouble with the law. Marc Kimball, a 40-year-old animator for a video production company, took an old 8mm movie that he had shot in 1980 of himself starring as Superman, updated the film's effects with modern computer graphics and distributed the revised film for free on the internet.

Lawyers representing DC Comics, the company that owns Superman, sent Kimball a cease-and-desist letter a week later. It stated that Kimball's work was unauthorised and accused Kimball of using a DC Comics property without the express written permission of DC Comics. Kimball promptly took down the site he had set up for distributing his film, without contesting the company's claims.

"I thought I had done everything right. The movie had original music and legal music-library stuff, an original story, original special effects," says Kimball. Furthermore, there were no ad banners on his web site, and he did not sell or make videotape copies of his film. He insists, "I treated Superman with respect. The only thing was I used the Superman logo, name and costume, and they shut me down." (When asked for its official stance on fan films based on its properties and for comment on the Kimball matter, DC Comics' publicity manager responded to Salon: "DC Comics has a long history of energetically protecting its copyrights and trademarks. Therefore, we stand by our cease-and-desist letter in this particular case.")

While DC Comics takes the hard line, other media giants may be opting for a more enlightened approach - drawing their fans into the fold. Lucasfilm, the production company behind the Star Wars series, has an informal agreement with Star Wars fans: "We love our fans, and we love it when they express their creativity and enthusiasm for Star Wars," emphasises Lynne Hale, Lucas' publicist. "When it does cross the line, or when we do have a problem, is when they use Star Wars copyrighted materials for commercial use." Otherwise, Star Wars fan film-makers have the blessing of Lucas himself.

On November 6, the official web site for the Star Wars movies and AtomFilms announced that they will partner to launch the Star Wars Fan Film Network later this year, which will feature fan-made movies. Lucasfilm is going so far as to make sound effects - from Darth Vader's breathing to the equally recognisable light saber hum - available from its library for fan film-makers to use. The Star Wars Fan Film Network even plans to pay fan film-makers through royalties generated from advertising and sponsorship related to the site.

"Soon, [copyright holders] are going to need those active fans more than ever before," says MIT's Jenkins. "In a world with multiple media options, video on demand and micropayments, fans may become the new gatekeepers who help direct consumers toward interesting and engaging media content. The smart media executive should figure out which direction the media-consuming public is moving, run around in front and shout, 'Follow me.'"

What motivates most fan film-makers is the desire to see other stories based on their favourite movie, TV series or superhero. Young says fan films can also help to supply a missing piece of the story that, without their creative efforts, might never have been pursued by the original creators.

Young points out that there are no new episodes or shows based on Highlander, the inspiration for his own creation. And after the critical and box-office drubbing of the last movie, Highlander: Endgame, the future of this franchise's film series is in doubt.

Similarly, Lucas has stated that he will not make a sequel trilogy to his Star Wars saga. "I see the Star Wars fan-film community only growing more once [Episode III is released]," says Young. He feels that fan film-making has grown to such a point that "if the creators won't give you more, now you can simply create more yourself."

Considering the extent to which digital film-making and broadband internet technology have already advanced and converged, some of the more extreme possibilities of the fan-film scene may not sound so far-fetched: will there come a time when fans "take over" TV shows, movies or other media properties? Will fan film-makers create the next Star Wars trilogy in Lucas' place?

"In a few years, there could be 50 [fan-made] Star Trek series online," says Young. "That is very exciting. It also forces the professionals to work harder and really pay attention to what fans want. Hey, we're making what we want to see. If that's not what they're producing, then they should catch a hint."

Useful links

 For Troops, go to theforce.net/troops; for Dark Redemption go to theforce.net/theater/shortfilms/darkredemption/index.shtml; for The X Files parody go to www.fountainheadpictures.com

The Star Wars Fan Film Network will launch later this year, at www.starwars.atomfilms.com

fields.headline: LPO/Elder
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall,
London
***
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall,
London
***
fields.body:
How many concerts does it take to make a festival? Just four, according to the London Philharmonic, whose latest package, Sleeping Beauties, was launched by Mark Elder and the orchestra on Wednesday. Devised by the cellist Steven Isserlis and the LPO's artistic director Serge Dorny, the aim of the series is to highlight infrequently performed works by great composers and to contrast them with better known masterpieces. The results aren't particularly adventurous - until relatively recently orchestral pro grammes like these were the rule rather than the exception on the South Bank - but they are fresh and ingenious.

So Dvorak's Cello Concerto in one programme is contrasted with his Piano Concerto in another, and Brahms's First Serenade is set against his Second Symphony; while the three works in the opening concert all have their counterparts later.

The Piano Concerto of Schumann, whose Violin Concerto will be played in the last concert of the series, was framed between Sibelius's The Oceanides (Finlandia is to come) and Tchaikovsky's Second Symphony, the "Little Russian" (to be followed later by the Romeo and Juliet Overture). The Sibelius certainly does not crop up that frequently, though to suggest, as the programme note did, that none of his tone poems with the exception of Finlandia is heard as often as they deserve is stretching the point a bit. In many ways The Oceanides is atypical of its kind - it is based on Greek mythology rather than the Finnish Kalevala, and rather than following a narrative, Sibelius's shimmering score evokes the marine world with what is almost his own brand of impressionism.

Elder adeptly caught its dappled colouring, recognis ing that this is a seascape of cold Nordic colours, of glinting metallic textures and sharply profiled details, rather than a hazy Mediterranean one, and the LPO conveyed that vivdly.

The lean, edgy sound of the strings also seemed thoroughly appropriate in Tchaikovsky's Second, which was laid out in crisp, bold statements, the woodwind tightly marshalled; the folk tunes that pervade the symphony movements had a suitably bucolic feel, with a deliciously smoochy horn solo at the end of the first movement, pinpoint clarinet duetting to launch the march, and a rumbustious climax to the finale.

The soloist in the Schumann piano concerto was Elisabeth Leonskaja. Her steely, rather inflexible playing had a take-it-or-leave-it directness, leaving very little space for flights of fancy or seductive charm. Sometimes she was prosaically literal when the music begged for something more impulsive; Elder and the orchestra followed attentively, and did what they could in the Intermezzo to bring a warmer, human dimension to the performance.

 Further concerts in the festival on November 29, December 9 and 15. Box office: 0207-960 4242.

The soloist in the Schumann piano concerto was Elisabeth Leonskaja. Her steely, rather inflexible playing had a take-it-or-leave-it directness, leaving very little space for flights of fancy or seductive charm. Sometimes she was prosaically literal when the music begged for something more impulsive; Elder and the orchestra followed attentively, and did what they could in the Intermezzo to bring a warmer, human dimension to the performance.  Further concerts in the festival on November 29, December 9 and 15.
