webTitle: Serps compensation plan damned by MPs

fields.headline: Serps compensation plan damned by MPs
fields.standfirst:
Redress plan for £13bn pension fiasco damned

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government was last night caught up in the worst case of maladministration since the second world war after a cross-party committee of MPs said its plan to compensate victims of misinformation over state pensions in the last 15 years was a "cheat's charter" with all the makings of disaster.
fields.body:
The government was last night caught up in the worst case of maladministration since the second world war after a cross-party committee of MPs said its plan to compensate victims of misinformation over state pensions in the last 15 years was a "cheat's charter" with all the makings of disaster.

The bill to redress years of official incompetence and misjudgment following Margaret Thatcher's plans to slash the cost of Serps, the state earnings-related pension scheme, could reach £13bn.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, hinted that he was ready to make further concessions to protect the millions of potential victims who received false information after legislation passed in 1986 - and due for implementation this year - halved the amount of Serps that widows or widowers could receive after the death of their spouse.

The Commons public administration select committee blamed human error for the failure to warn up to 20m prospective pensioners of the changes .

False information was included in official literature up until 1996. After investigating how ministers and officials persistently failed to address the mistake, the MPs said: "This represents a political and administrative failure that will cost the public purse many billions of pounds. It also represents a story of injustice to individuals."

The present government's proposal to defer the changes to Serps until 2002 and compensate individuals claiming personal exposure to the misinformation was fraught with administrative difficulty, they said. Officials would have to decide whether individuals were genuinely misled and suffered financially as a result, or whether they were making up a story to gain a higher pension.

"What is proposed might well seem to be an invitation to fraud. We hope the proposed redress scheme is not a cheat's charter. It is certainly a hostage to fortune.

"Our fear is that the original maladministration in this case may well now be compounded by a redress scheme that has all the makings of an administrative disaster."

Simpler approaches should be examined. "It is important that one administrative failure, of astonishing proportions, should not be compounded by another," the committee insisted.

Mr Darling said the former Tory government should take responsibility for "inexcusable blunders" that would cost millions to sort out. "They must take the blame for this mess that will cost millions to sort out. I will take responsibility for sorting it out.

"I have no intention of introducing a scheme that isn't fair and workable," he told BBC Radio 4's World at One. "I think when people see my final proposals they will realise the government is clearing up the colossal mess it inherited from the Conservatives."

The implication was that Mr Darling would change the compensation scheme before the final version is presented to parliament before Christmas. But he added: "The policy of aligning Serps inheritance rules with all other pension rules is absolutely right."

So the plan to halve the Serps pension of widows and widowers will go ahead.

Some MPs were estimating the eventual cost of clearing up the mess to be £13.4bn between now and 2050, as retirees who were supposed to have been told to make other arrangements after 1985 are paid the full value of the Serps pensions that Mrs Thatcher tried to curtail in her heyday.

The Liberal Democrats urged Mr Darling to head off a system of complex questionnaires for claimants and the possibility of fraud by paying full Serps pensions to all widows who have retired without any further investigation.

Steve Webb, a social security expert who now sits as Liberal Democrat MP for Kingston, predicted: "It's clear this is going to be a shambles. The information sent out to people is confusing and contradictory. Asking people to "show that they were given the wrong information" makes no sense.

"The only decent thing to do would be for the government to cancel the cut to widows pensions for those who've already reached pension age," Professor Webb said.

David Willetts, the Conservative social security spokesman, said: "We very much regret the failures which occurred during our years in office. The need now is for a swift and generous scheme of compensation for those who have been affected."

Age Concern, the charity which is taking the government to the European court of human rights over the Serps policy, said: "We have said all along that the compensation scheme will be thwarted by its very complexity. It would be far more straightforward to scrap the change altogether.

"The committee is right to point out that the failure to inform contributors is not tolerated in the private sector and we do not believe it should be tolerated in the public sector."

fields.headline: Bryn Terfel, lieder of the pack in Birmingham
fields.standfirst:
Bryn Terfel
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
*****
fields.trailText:
Bryn Terfel
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
*****
fields.body:
At best, a lieder recital is one of the most powerful, concentrated and subtle artistic experiences available to humanity. At worst it can be remote, suffocatingly constrained or downright cringe-making. It was no surprise to find that Bryn Terfel had packed the Symphony Hall to the rafters for his mostly German programme on Wednesday. The question was whether or not he could make this intimate medium work in a large concert hall, and for an audience that presumably was largely attracted by the prospect of hearing Terfel's splendid voice rather than by any special reverence for German romantic lieder.

He did - and exceptionally well. Starting with Schumann's salon-storming ballad Die Beiden Grenadiere (The Two Grenadiers) was an inspiration in itself, but somehow Terfel managed both to camp it up and to make the ending deeply moving. We all thundered our approval - a faux pas in terms of Lieder recital etiquette, for unwritten rules dictate that you clap only at the end of each group of songs. Gently, with all his natural, unforced friendliness, Terfel put us right.

That was another major achievement. It showed that to break through the traditional icy formality of a Lieder evening, you don't need populist gimmicks, just a fine artist with a human touch. After that, we were Play-doh in his hands.

The rarefied beauty of Schumann's Widmung (Dedication) and the eerie riddle of Mein Wagen Rollet Langsam (My Carriage Lumbers Slowly) stood open to all. Attention remained fixed through Brahms's dark, agnostic meditations on death in Four Serious Songs.

The voice itself is hypnotic enough. But there's so much more: beautiful phrasing, and a feeling for the sense of each word that can make translation unnecessary - the deeper psychological meaning comes straight across, even if you can't speak a word of German.

After this, and three very accessible Shakespeare settings by Schubert, John Ireland was a bit of an anticlimax. Granted, The Bells of San Marie and the Joyce setting Tutto E Sciolto are haunting, artful songs - but after Schubert, Brahms and Schumann? However George Butterworth, killed in action in the first world war at 31, emerged as a songwriter of real stature in his six Housman settings, particularly Is My Team ploughing? And here, as throughout this evening, it was hard not to notice the skill and subtlety of Terfel's pianist. If there's such a thing as an accompanist of genius, it is Malcolm Martineau. He can vanish discreetly into the background when required, or turn the final solo bars of a song like Is My Team ploughing? into a poignant summing up. In the hands of musicians like these two, the future of the song recital should be assured.

fields.headline: Heavyweights bounce back
fields.standfirst:
Market forces

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Something approaching calm returned to the London market yesterday after the relentless sell-off of technology stocks that dealers and investors have had to weather over the past fortnight.
fields.body:
Something approaching calm returned to the London market yesterday after the relentless sell-off of technology stocks that dealers and investors have had to weather over the past fortnight.

In fact, the FTSE 100 ended the session in quite strong shape, up 65.9 points on the day at 6,287.3.

A lot of this could be put down to the holiday in the US, which meant that, with markets closed across the Atlantic, there were no fresh falls on the Nasdaq for London traders to catch up with. That said, the Footsie only managed to claw back a third of the loss suffered on Wednesday, which marked the biggest one-day sell-off since May.

Also, with Wall Street closed, trading volume was relatively subdued, with 1.3bn shares changing hands.

Dealers noted that a two-way debate is under way among analysts, with the prospect of falling interest rates (as economies on both sides of the Atlantic slow) balanced against the prospect of falling earnings.

That said, those sectors which have suffered particularly hard over recent sessions were the first to bounce back yesterday. Among the heavyweight telecom issues, for example, Vodafone recouped 8.5p to 250p and BT gained 21p to 641p, while big index movers such as Glaxo Wellcome (up 44p to £20.84) were moving higher.

Among the pure tech stocks, Bookham Technology managed a near 10% bounce, closing 112p higher at £12.71 and CMG added 76p to £10.46. But the overall sector performance was patchy. Affinity Internet, for example, shed 50p to 587.5p.

There were also a few particularly painful situations, such as mobile phone network specialist Filtronic , which issued a trading update late on Wednesday afternoon. While this was probably positive, it contained a few worrying hints, such as one reference to "significant fluctuations in short-term performance" in one division.

The update had been issued in line with the new "best practice" advice from regulators, where companies doing presentations to institutional investors and analysts are expected to share their thoughts with the rest of the market. But yesterday a string of broker downgrades hit the market, lead by Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, which slapped a "reduce" tag on the stock.

The investment bank has slashed its 2001 profits forecast on the firm from £18m to just £7.5m, citing its expectation that the growth in cellular handsets will be closer to 10% year-on-year against its earlier expectations of 45%.

The shares responded with a 155p slump to 455p. Earlier this year, the price was sitting above £23.

Another stressful market was that in BTG , the drug patent group, which dropped 257.5p to £13.50. The fall followed its interim results statement, which included news that US drug regulators have delayed the start of phase three tests on BTG's Varisolve procedure for treating varicose veins.

Dresdner Kleinwort Benson - clearly an investment bank in a bearish mood at the moment - cut its rating on the stock from "buy" to "hold" saying it did not believe that the risks associated with Varisolve are being fully reflected in the share price.

In the property sector, Frogmore Estates reconfirmed the trend towards taking companies private with news that a management buyout is being discussed with an offer on the table at 612p a share in cash. The company's share price jumped 54p to 578p on the news.

Elsewhere, Gearhouse compounded a 40% surge on Wednesday with a further 8.5p jump to 30.5p yesterday. The move followed Tuesday's news that John Hemming, the Birmingham-based technology entrepreneur, has increased his stake to 13.5%.

There have been reports that Mr Hemming plans to push for a seat on the board.

fields.headline: FSA slams retirement review delay
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Howard Davies, the chairman of the financial services authority, yesterday criticised the government over a delayed review of the rules regarding pension options at retirement.
fields.body:
Howard Davies, the chairman of the financial services authority, yesterday criticised the government over a delayed review of the rules regarding pension options at retirement.

The review of inland revenue regulations was supposed to have been completed by March.

But Mr Davies, who was speaking primarily as chairman of the Employers' Forum on Age, said that "absolutely nothing" had been heard from ministers. The existing rules forbid people from taking part of their pension and then carrying on working part-time for the same employer.

The delay was "holding things back" in terms of introducing a more flexible approach to retirement, he said.

His comments could prove embarrassing for the government because the issue is one close to Tony Blair's heart.

A report produced by the prime minister's performance and innovation unit said there was a need to encourage opportunities for flexible retirement. It called on the inland revenue and the department of social security to "urgently review" the rules on taking a pension while staying with the same employer.

The unit's report said there was evidence that many people wanted to reduce their hours or responsibilities towards the end of their working lives.

The Employers' Forum on Age, a body lobbying for a mixed-age workforce, has been calling for changes so employers are able to continue benefiting from the experience offered by older workers.

"We were thrilled last year to hear a review of the rules was scheduled for completion by March 2000. So far we have heard absolutely nothing from the government on the review," said Mr Davies, speaking at the National Association of Pension Funds' (NAPF) annual conference.

"We are in a slightly odd position where the government's performance and innovation unit shares that view [that a more flexible approach to retirement is needed] in a foreword signed by the prime minister, yet nothing has happened." Mr Davies said continued pressure on ministers had failed to produce a response, or a new timetable.

"I'm disappointed the issues seem to have become snarled up in Whitehall," he added.

The revenue said talks with the DSS and the NAPF were continuing, and there were plans to issue a consultation paper by early next year. "The March deadline was only a suggested deadline. Obviously it is quite a complex issue and we want to make sure it is done properly," added an official.
